Sweet chocolate nose. Smooth drinking. Well balanced sweet/dry/bitter, listed in order of prominence. Mostly chocolate taste with a strong hint of fruit and hops, almost want to call it grape. Deep brown pour with dark brown head, nice color but weak foam. Agitation brings out bitterness, better in the bottle. Nutty aftertaste.
Really delicous stout. Has a real dark chocolate taste. Looks perfect once poured with a nice head and good nose.

Das Bier ist schwarz und hat eine sehr schöne große bräunliche Schaumkrone. Der Geruch ist süß röstmalzig, Vanille, etwas Kaffee. Der Geschmack ist wunderbar röstmalzig, viel Vanille, Schokolade und Espresso, sehr lecker, nicht zu stark, aber sehr aromatisch.
Bottle. Pours black with tan head. Aroma is slightly toasty, chocolate. Taste is full bodied, dry, a bit burnt, rich. Overall, okay.

12oz bottle. 2/26/15 package date (5mths old). Appearance: Black, opaque, thick, creamy brown head. 
Aroma: Roasty malt, dark cocoa, hint of vanilla
Taste: Starts with sweet rich maltiness, rich roast and coffee, and some dark cocoa. Moderately strong bitterness. Very smooth flavor considering the heavy roast. 
Mouthfeel: Medium body and moderate carbonation. 
Finish: Lingering bitterness and roast. Very dry. 
Overall: Good American style stout. Roasted malt flavor is dominant, but smooth instead of harsh. Complimented by some sweet base malt and chocolate. Drinkable considering the richness and alcohol.

12 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Poured black, certainly heavy, tan head and a bit of lacing on the glass. Aroma of coffee and roasted malts and some hints of chocolate. Taste is also coffee and some roasted malts and chocolate finish. Very good stout, quite enjoyable.

From a bottle. Pours very dark black/brown with a fizzy light tan head. Tastes like dark coffee, dark chocolate, toasted malt, light tobacco and light ash. Medium body and low carbonation. Smells like dark chocolate, ash, dark coffee, and roasted malt.

330mL bottle from Beer Cartel. PKGD 2/27/15
Opaque black body, holds a small but firm dense tan head.
Nose not overly pungent, but certainly plenty to enjoy about it; dark chocolate, roast nut, burnt meatiness, licorice, rich caramels with earthy hop spice.
Lovely and smooth on the palate, low carbonation, tremendous sense of balance and length.
Excellent flavour - lots of roast/burnt nutty malt, deep toffee, bitter chocolate, touch of mid-roast coffee, with earthy hops lending an assertive but well tempered bitterness to the whole thing.
Class act overall!

I like this - nothing too exciting to look at and doesnt give too much away on the nose. Taste is super balanced and just a really enjoyable beer. Roasted malts, coffee, vanilla, earthy bitterness. I dig.

Smells like a stout I guess. Mild hints of chocolate. Medium sharp carbonation. Extremely smooth. Not foamy or syrupy at all. Just the right silky smooth consistency. Pretty much the perfect example of a straight-up stout. It has those coffee, dark chocolate, and roasted nut tastes that you would expect without any of them being over-pronounced. Aftertaste is medium to long length and the same.

Opaque black as promised, with small mocha head. Very roasty aromas - charcoal, coffee beans and well toasted bread. The taste is masterfully balanced between sweet and roasty. Treacle, caramel, toast, then charred meat comes in which builds slowly to a dry ashy finish. Medium bodied and prickly acidity on the tongue. Very good stout.

Pours jet black with brown lasting head. Aroma of burnt sugar, molasses, and milk chocolate. Taste is chocolate, maple syrup and molasses. Thick mouthfeel. Great stout. Competes with imperial stouts at 6%. Very impressive!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

La bière se présente comme une véritable huile noire et très opaque, surmontée dune mousse beige crémeuse. Pain grillé, café et sucre brun sont les arômes dominants au nez. La texture en bouche est agréablement onctueuse, les saveurs de chocolat et de café tapissant le palais à chaque gorgée. Des notes de tabac et danis font surface plus la bière tempère. Quel stout délicieusement décadent, mais facile à boire!

Opaque dark black., little head. Faint aroma, with a hint of anise seed. Thick, dark with notes of roasted coffee moving through to a hoppy, watery stage which then leaves the mouth clean and dry. Very well balanced.

Pours opaque black, small tan head. The brewers licorice really comes through in the aroma---its a bit spicy and anise-y---along with deep toasted notes. Medium body, very smooth. Dry, ashy finish. The carbonation on this is exactly spot-on. It provides a little pricklyiness, but not too much to overwhelm the flavors.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2015 APPEARANCE - NOSE - Delicious coffee scents right away. Sets me up for the wonderful first sip. FLAVOR - perfect coffee heavy stout flavor. Roasty, slightly bitter (which is the flavor that remains on my tongue). NOTES - I can see why it?s scored 100. And it confirms my theory that Bell?s can make nearly any style beer spot on!

355ml bottle enjoyed @ my vacation apartment. Pours pitch black. Aroma is lots of roasted malt, espresso, dark chocolate and some smoke. Flavour is roasted and medium bitter. Medium bodied, smooth texture, soft carbonation. Finish is ashy and roasted.

On tap at Barcade St Marks. Pours black, huge frothy oatmeal-style head. Aroma is very rich. Chocolate and robust roasted malts, coffee, oatmeal flakes. Flavor is fantastic rich chocolate, coffee bitterness, light licorice or fruit notes in there. Pretty creamy but still full bodied mouthfeel. Actually extremely full bodied for 6% abv.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2015 Bottle. Clear dark reddish brown with a foamy tan head that lasts and laces some. Aromas of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, and caramel. Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, light caramel, and molasses. Medium bodied, smooth and creamy with a roasty, slightly dry end.
So far the only "regular" stout I have tried. I enjoyed it immensely, it is one of the best beers I have had. It added to my respect for Bells, and left me eager to try more stouts.

Aroma coffee, roasty, 
Appearance black, frothy, tan foam, brown foam, 
Taste coffee, lightly bitter, 
Palate full body, creamy, thick feel, 
Overall great stout that I would 100% suggest to a friend or any stout lover

Bottle into stout glass. Lots of head black beer. Not much aroma. Malt roast a touch sweet. Can't taste the licorice. Bitter aftertaste but Smooth. Decent stout but not one of the greats. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle from Beer Frog cons 2015-05-11 Spring Hill, Fl
AR: milk chocolate bar, wee salmiak 
AP: black, frothy cream dark brown fluffy head
F: roasted malt, salt liqurice, dry but wee sweet, rich carbonation, wee bourbon vanilla,

Faint Chocolate and roasted malted aroma, also slightly smoky. All that fades over time. Lightly carbonated, almost no head. Roasted and chocolate malt flavors. Slight bitter finish which dissipates quickly. Black in color.
coffee, nuts, toast, black, very bitter, full body, A really good tasting heavy stout

Aromas of roasted coffee, with just a bit of a burnt flavor to it.

Quite dark, nearly black.

Taste is mostly bitter with just a touch of sweetness.

Full bodied, slightly oily texture, average carbonation and a long slightly burnt, bitter coffee finish.

Overall a pretty good stout. I like the just mildly burnt coffee aromas; the complexity of flavors falls short of the great stouts though.
Bottle, black pour, tan head, nose is chocolate, taste is chocolate, coffee, rich
One of the best-looking beers you will find. Aroma is espresso. Flavor is more bitter than expected, but pretty good.

Bottle share at ThePeters leaving drinks. Aroma is big earthy coffee, amaretto biscuit, smoke, malt extract,praline. Dark mahogany brown coloured pour with a halo of loose sark tan head. Flavour is milky, toasted coconut, coffee bean, earth, . palate is semi sweet, little dry and earthy, little chalk. Big flavoursome stout.

Bottle split at Pedro leaving drinks, CBC Clerko, 24/04/15 big thanks to Manny G.
Pitch black with a big old dirty tan head that retains well. 
Nose is rich roast, chocolate, charr, light spice, toffee fudge, toasted brown sugars. 
Taste comprises roast malt, cocoa powder, dark fruit rinds, toffee, molasses.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, semi drying close. 
Decent well rounded stout but way short of the 4 score this ones riding at.
Most definitely a leader back in the day but theres plenty of better offerings out there now !
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Bottle many thanks to Manny G! It pours jet black with a decent tan head. The nose is rich roast, dark chocolate, sticky, liquorice, gateaux and earth. The taste is smooth, bitter-sweet, rich roast, dark chocolate, coffee grounds, toasty, mild acidity, cocoa, ash and liquorice with a dry, roasty finish. Medium, moderate carbonation and foamy carbonation. Smooth and easy-going. Not a top 3 stout, but rather drinkable.

Tap at Imperial Bottle Shop, post CBC

A: Pitch black with a light cappuccino head, lacing.

N: Licorice, cocoa, biscuit, light char, hint of wood, some earth and pine, rounding out with molasses.

T: Sweet for the most part; light bitterness and char underneath.

M: Rich, creamy body, soft carbonation, no alcohol.

O: Roasty stout. The flavors here are properly meshed together, and it astounds me that a beer this good can come from the same place that put out Eccentric Ale and Batch 9000.

Bottle to snifter. 
Aroma is coffee, toasted barley, 
Appearance: dark black, small off white head.
Taste: chicory, toasted barley. A little too bitter in the after taste. 
Palate. Low carbonation. Smooth enough.

Good beer, though I am a little disappointed.
Eager to try Bells other higher touted stouts, though this probably tempered my expectation of those.
Opaque black pour with tan two finger head. Milk chocolate aroma. Coffee roast flavors with a very slight licorice finish. A classic stout.
Sweet, roasty, dark ...flavor sticks around like a decadent dessert. Bottle to Glass...
Smells great. Thick mouth feel with sweety coffee flavor. Not bad. Solid stout. Always forget about it
Molasses and dark chocolate on the nose. Bitter dark chocolate up front. Not much sweetness to balance...dry. Muted bitterness intensifies on the finish.

Opaque, black, thin tan head with great retention and viscous lacing. Aromas of smoke, wood, dark fruit and licorice. Dark fruit sweetness accompanies the bittersweet bakers chocolate, with notes of licorice, roasted coffee and molasses. Full body, minimal carbonation, silky smooth mouthfeel, and a lingering smokiness in the finish.

Bottle to pint glass
Toasted malt, light coffee, molasses, and mace. Silky black with a 1/2 cm creamy tan head. Taste is chocolate, toasted malt, a touch of coffee, vanilla.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2015 Old rating. Bottle from Old Town. Jet black with a small dark tan head. Aromas of cacao nib, roasted coffee, prune, wood and fennel. Slightly bittersweet on the the palate but muted, not harsh at all. Medium body. Nice long dry finish that rides off into the sunset. Excellent stout.

Shared at a tasting. More underwhelming than I remembered. Soft carbonation. Smooth, easy drinking, but pretty average stout. Only a little fennel this time and some coffee.

July 31st, 2013 - The Kalamazoo Stout had long been a myth in California. Spotted here in there between trees, flitting between hands and persons, but never easy to catch, grasp or drink. But Bells distribution line sagged out to include our corner of the country, bringing with it all the delicious Bells Brewery drinks, and for myself, this particular treasure. My friend and I held this beer in high enough esteem that it was included alongside aged Winter Warlocks and New Belgium Folies. The stout pours thick and oily, as expected, and effuses a lovely coffee aroma, mostly roasted, but not sweet like a mocha. Its more bitter, leading with espresso and a dryer, more continental flavor. The flavor is what really hooked itself into my memory though. I first notice a supremely foamy palate, which quickly and efficiently drapes the taste of finely roasted beans across the tongue. Lots of intensely dark chocolate here, like the essence of cacao nibs, and a deep dive of an aftertaste bringing velvety, luxurious dark chocolate. And I note here: "Gawwdamn!" The only drawback seems to be that this stout seems a little mild compared to the 2007 Winter Warlock, but thats comparing an old churlish boxer with a fresh faced pugilist. Different styles, same sport, and each should be appreciated in their respective corners. Each is a champion, and the Kalamazoo comes that way out of the bottle.

12oz bottle, dated 05/06/13. Pours just about black with a beige head. Aroma is raisin, molasses, soy, licorice. Flavor is dark chocolate, raisin, molasses. Licorice bitterness in the finish. So much flavor at 6%. A great stout.

Black, head, lace. Rich coffee chocolate roast aroma.Dark fruit. Same in taste, smooth rich, balanced. Poundable for a stout. Flawless great stout. In the middle of a  (light) sweet /robust stout. Very nice.

Light aromas dark malts, slight roast, slight coffee, toffee, coffee bean oils and chocolate. Appears black with a thin foam rim. Taste brings dark roast, dry earth, chocolate cocoa and coffee oils. Overall, for a stout, not too bad. Decent body.

Pours a solid black with a short brown head. The aroma is rich, with dark malt, toast, coffee, and dark chocolate. The flavor is rich malt and chocolate up front with a slight coffee middle and bitter, toasty finish over a heavy body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a bottle showing big black and opaque with a long lasting finger of fluffy coffee colored foam. 

The nose shows a lot of chocolate with notes of sweet licorice here and there. 

The palate is mostly dry but with a very perceivable lactose/licorice sweetness that takes out a lot of the bitterness also. The licorice doesnt seem to appear until at the very end and even so, very subtly. Dark licorice also appears throughout the background. Lacks the weight of most stouts and drinks closer to a porter but an extremely easy to drink stout. Great for spring or fall drinking.
Bottle from JSA. Black with a thin tan head. Aroma is coffee malt. Bitter roasted malt tempered by sweet golden syrup. Tangy dry roast finish. Easy drinking

Bottle at home while visiting Jacksonville. Pours dark brown/black. Lovely coffee choc aroma with light grass. Medium body, light carbonation. Dry bitter coffee and choc, a hint of milk choc sweetness, woody dryness... I like the dry bitterness. Tasty enough. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Smooth and creamy with a load of deep flavors including chocolate, coffee, and a beautiful roasted malt backbone
Earthy, strong roast, dark chocolate, ash, nutty. Extremely dry and light bodied for abv.

12oz bottle from Wegmans, West Seneca, NY.  An inky black pour with a tawny gleam, and an almost non-existent tan head; rich earthy aroma with traces of coffee grounds and licorice; a milky texture with a soft and bitter taste with lots of burnt malts and molasses; and a dry, satisfying finish with some lingering biscuit. A very moreish stout.

Pours a deep black with khaki colored head. Coffee, roasted malt, chocolate, and some nice molasses notes on the nose; follows onto the palate. Finishes with some sweetness, more molasses and chocolate.

Brilliantly black with coffee colored head. Aroma of deeply toasted malts bringing out the aroma of oatmeal and coffee with a hint of brown sugar and noticeable but not powerful hops. Rich with a brilliant toasted oat character and slight bitterness flushed by slightly above average effervescence.

A great showing and definitely a pleasant stout that doesn't stick too closely to the formulaic type by throwing us a bit of bitterness 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12oz bottle pours a black color with a bit of head. Nice molasses and chocolate.
Very good, and now I am really looking forward to the expedition stout. This was nice not being too alcoholic. Roasted, creamy, caramel and malts.

Bottle dated September 2014. Deep brown with a thin ring of a head. Chocolate malt nose with fainter roast, slightly inky with stewed plum and grape jelly fruitiness. Medium body and effervescent, slightly sweet approach turning more carbonic to a watery, moderately-hopped astringent roast finish. Nicely minerally and chocolaty and the flavor balance and acidity is pleasant but the malt seems simple.

I really enjoyed Bells Expedition Stout and thought that this would also be good. I was disappointed. It looks and pours like a nice stout but not much aroma. The first thing I noticed was it hit my taste buds on the tip of my tongue then seemed to disappear. I didnt really notice any licorice flavor or much of any flavor for that matter. I let it warm up a bit and took a good sip to savor the flavor but had the same reaction. Not what I expected from this type of beer. My daughter didnt even want to finish her glass.

Slightly subdued aroma, but lots of roasted malt, cocoa and coffee in the nose. Looks great, completely black with a thick long lasting coffee-colored head. Tastes delicious, a mix of coffee and caramel. Upfront roasty malts, finishes with a caramel sweetness, leafy bitter notes and licorice like qualities. Bitterness lingers on the tongue. Quite intense flavors in this one for such a low ABV -- delicious. Creamy, medium bodied stout with average carbonation.
Tap at Mr Beerys. Opaque black pour with tan head that dissipates. Dark roast grains and molasses aroma. Medium body very dark roast borderline burnt with some charcoal notes.

Pours black with a small light tan head. Aroma is heavy roasted malts with coffee tones and molasses. Taste is all of the above in abundance starting with the chocolatey malts and coffee followed by a heavy bitter finish.

(bottle) clear deep brown colour with a creamy brown head. aroma of vanilla, tobacco and caramel, slightly earthy and perfumed, with some notes of strawberries and espresso. flavour is mostly vanilla, toffee and liquorice, with a light caramel sweetness, some brown sugar and a medium-bitter finish. medium-bodied with soft carbonation.

355ml bottle @ Southwest Porch at Bryant Park, New York 

Pours pitch black with a smooth brown head. Aroma of roasty malts, licorice, coffee and dark chocolate. Taste is smooth, roasty and sweetish with loads of dark chocolate, coffee and licorice. Finish is smooth and roasty with some licorice and coffee. Quite nicely balanced and tasty.

Smooth with a creamy chocolate taste with a hint of carmel. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
bottle scura schiuma media buona secchezza liquirizia discreto amaro caffe buon corpo complessa ma non eccessiva

Pitch Black Color, Huge Mocha Head. Long lasting Leaving Lots of Lacing. Roasted Barley and Chocolate Aroma. Roasted Barly, Chocolate Sweet, Coffee Bitter. Nicely Balanced. Not Too Sweet, Lasting Bitter Aftertaste. Nice. Recommended.

2014/11/24 - Pours a jet black colour with a frothy, tan head that slowly reduces. Aroma is toasted coffee, dark chocolate, lactose, smokey notes and a touch of vanilla. Taste is similar to nose; bitter cocoa, milk chocolate, caramel, mild vanilla, smokey notes and roasted coffee. Mouthfeel is medium and slick with smooth carbonation and a bitter/sweet finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle poured into a tulip glass. Black color with a small white head. Nose is smoky, roasted chocolates. Taste is similar, thin mouthfeel but still creamy and satisfying. This is a very well done stout, I can see why its so highly rated.

Bottle from Chris in a trade. Thanks! Poured a black oil with a thick mocha head in my tulip at home. Head lasted and some nice lacing. The aroma was dark chocolate, cocoa nibs, vanilla, caramel, roasted malts, nuts. The taste is similar with the dark chocolate and caramel...then the vanilla, lactose, and roasted goodness on the backend. The texture is velvet and full bodied. Some oil. Very smooth and delicious.
UPDATED: JUN 26, 2015 Faint roasted smell... above average stout appearance. Roasted malt, faint chocolate on taste. Seems like a milk stout. Slightly bitter on aftertaste. Overrated, but still good.

dense beige head leaves lacing and foamhead. coffee colour. aroma of leather, milk chocolate. taste caramel, leather, milk chocolate aftertaste moderate bitter from the roasted malts. quite dense mouthfeel, medium carbonation. very tasty given the low abv. bottle 12 fl oz / bd sep-2013

Quite tasty roasty. Don't get a ton of licorice, but a nice chocolate flavor from the malt. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Opaque dark brown/black with thin brown head. Mil roasty cocoa aroma. Flavors of molasses, licorice, effervescent, raised malt. Not ultra complex, loads of flavor. Light licorice molasses finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I passed on this for awhile because of brewers licorice. This imparts a very subtle flavor to the beer that does not equate with licorice. This is a well balanced stout with mostly chocolate and coffee nuances as with many other stouts. While I like roastiness in a stout this one seems to rely less on this quality but still is in stout territory as opposed to a porter.
Fantastic beer. Thick, black, could use a tad more licorice if it is claimed as licorice beer.

Super roasty yet smooth. I think that is what is the big standout of this beer for me. That and the sweet start that moves quickly to a bitter dark roasted flavor like a french roasted coffee. I actually bumped the aroma a point after giving a little time to warm up. I would suggest doing the same for both flavor and aroma purposes. This beer drinks better after it has had a couple minutes in the glass in my opinion. This is definitely one youll want to try if your a craft beer lover - it is a necessity if you are a stout drinker.

Pours black. Deep tan head with good retention. Smells of chocolate and mollasses. Taste of rich chocolate and coffee with a mollasses sweetness. Very nice beer! Thick on the palate very nice mouth feel. Lacing on the glass is lasting.
Roasty flavored and can taste a bit like chocolate. Very dark looking. Brewed with licorice and has a real smoothness to it.
Out of the bottle from the local liquor store...chocolaty and sweet, but smooth. Nice

Bottle from City Swiggers, New York, NY. A dark brown/black coloured pour with a healthy beige head on top. Rich, chocolate, malty, roasty aroma. Tastes incredibly smooth and rich, chocolate, malty, hint of coffee, slight sweetness. A gorgeous stout from Bells.

BOD 2/22/14. Pitch black pour with a very good head. Lacing and retention are also very good. Surprisingly light nose of chocolate and roast over a mineral note. Rich heavy medium body with a nice creamy texture. Below average carbonation with almost no effervescence on the finish. The flavor profile is balanced, but lacks the complexity found in world class stouts. It begins with chocolate, fades to roast and flows into a mild sweetness with a licorice note. Hops and roast create a slightly bitter middle with just a hint of coffee and NO dark fruit. The finish is slightly astringent.

Pours black with approx two fingers wide tan head. A bit more carbonation than expected. A bit oily feeling that lingers n the mouth. Has a bit of a burnt roast finish. Not getting a lot of chocolate out of it. 

Pretty decent stout. Nothing stands out as unique, but overall very solid.

"made with brewers licorice, and while no one flavoe dominates the others, that is the preeminant one. good roasted aroma with a hint of the licorice. full bodied, and actually comes across a lot stronger than 6% would have you beleive. id buy this if it were here, but for as highly ranked as it is, my expectations were sky high, so it was ever so slightly disapointing. a very good, but not quite great, stout. keep in mind Im judging off one 12 oz sample, though. Ill have to try again sometime. courtesy of a trade w/ bluesandbarbq."

12 oz. bottle from Cash Wise in Williston. Appearance: finger dark brown-red color, dark brown color, light oily lacing. Aroma: roast, chocolate, heavy licorice, coffee, very hidden and faint floral. Palate: full body, soft creamy carbonation, creamy texture into oily finishing texture, super smooth, medium bitter finish. Taste: sweet chocolate and licorice, into more malty sweetness, almost molasses, and then into a coffee bitterness, with light touches of floral hoppiness. Overall, very complex, but so smooth you hardly notice even! The balance is phenomenal, the taste is great, the beer is great.
chesnut brown. foamy dark head. Aroma of hay grain licorice. Tastes dark choco, licorice. creamy yet dry palate.
Big roast aroma. Nice head and tight carbonation. The smooth caramel and milk cocoa makes this brew an A++++ Such a good balance of flavors all around

12oz bottle. Black with a frothy tan head. Flavors are dark/milk chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, caramel, licorice and brown sugar with ashy and resinous notes. Medium to full body, soft carbonation, oily and sticky texture.

Poured from 12 oz. bottle. 

Opaque,black-brown with a 2-finger tan head and very good lacing. 

Aroma of licorice, chocolate, dark toast, coffee, berries and roasted malt. 

Taste of chocolate, molasses, licorice, toast, toasted malt, black raspberry and coffee. 

Medium body and high/medium carbonization. Nice mouthfeel without a heavy body. 

A very nice stout with a great combination of fruity, roasty and malty flavors. 



---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle from BOTW. Big nose: licorice, chocolate, soy, coffee, some berries. Lovely black with a huge, bubbly tan head. Rich malt flavor, chocolate, umami, big roast. Good stout.

Really nice stout. Khaki head in deep brown black pour. Meaty roasty nose give way to smoky and dark chocolate taste. Black licorice is there too but subtle. Touch of coffee in the finish. Nice medium to full body. Excellent.

Transfer from BA review on 2-11-13-
 Poured from bottle into a pint glass

 Appearance Poured a deep brown nearly black color with a two finger thick and creamy tan colored head. The head slowly fades leaving a fantastic level of lacing on the sides of the glass.

 Smell  The aroma is heaviest of cocoa mixed with a burnt brown sugar sweetness. Other aromas of roasted malt and coffee combined with these aromas well creating an overall rather dark and sweet roasty aroma.

 Taste  The flavors start out with sweeter chocolate and some vanilla and brown sugar. The flavor dries some more toward the middle as flavors of coffee and a light licorice come to the tongue. The flavors take the taste to its end where they are joined by a light earthy hop taste. When all combined the flavors leave a nice cocoa and roasted semi sweet flavor on the tongue with just the right amount of bitter from the coffee and the hop to balance it all out.

 Mouthfeel  The body of the beer is on the slightly thicker side in terms of creaminess with a carbonation level that is medium. The thicker body is nice for the darker flavors of the brew while the moderate carbonation suits the abv. and the more bitter flavors well, keeping the brew very drinkable.

 Overall  A tasty stout with a great drinkability and wonderful feel/flavor. A great roasty, but rather balanced stout.

Btl 2013 pours extremely dark brown almost black color.Thick creamy tan head that lingers leaving sheets of lace on glass. Aromas of roasted grain,toast, smoke,wood,resin,molasses and black licorice. Tastes of sweet toffee, bakers chocolate,ash,latte and licorice. Full body,velvety mouthfeel, average carbonation and a dry toasty bitter finish. Smooth yet bold flavors combined with a perfect mouthfeel make this stout stand out as one of the best!
This is a delicious full bodied stout. Incredible smooth with robust flavors of molasses and chocolate.
Bottle, thanks Shawn. Black with tan head. Meaty aroma, roasty with molasses. Roasty taste with molasses. A bit thin and bitter. I was expecting better

pours unclear extremely dark brown with a very nice light beige head, some retention and lacing. roasted coffee beans - maybe overly roasted, obvious licorice and resin, bitter chocolate, ashes, dry molasses, some boiled roasted veggies though. low carbonation, medium to full body - oily and thick, dry, bittering harsh piney-ashy finish. a let-down for me.
Bottle. Large tan head, about as black as they come. Toasted malts and bread. thick, creamy, chocolate and nutty bittersweet. Excellent stout.

Bottle. Pours a deep black with brown head. Aroma is dark roasted malts, chocolate, caramel, vanilla and licorice. Taste has sweet chocolate with roaste bitterness. Light bodied for such an intense regular stout. Could be more cohesive, good stuff.

Bottle pour. The nose is toffee and cocoa with a sniff of drip coffee. Perfectly carbonated with a smooth mouthfeel. The liquorice back end dances with your tastebuds and gives this an extra element that elevates the beer to another level. Fantastic.

Pours black with a thin tan head that leaves some fair lacing in the glass. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, and toffee. Taste is full of dark chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt. It has a bitter sweetness on the back end. Once again, Bells does not disappoint.
Black colour. Medium body, roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, this is a great stout.
Bottle from whole foods, mount pleasant. Black body with a small offwhite head. Chocolate, coffee, roasted malt. Smooth and easy drinkable.
Bottle. Thanks to Hallinghansen. Pours black with a creamy head. Roast, chocolate, bread and milk. Smooth and lovely!
Pours jet black with slight mocha head. Chocolate, cocoa, toffee, roasted coffee beans, hints of licorice. Slightly bitter, slightly sweet, very good.

This is soooo good. Like too good for words. Chocolate and toffee like crazy as soon as you pop the top. Just awesome smelling stuff. The taste is so rich and velvety. Tons of chocolate, toffee, nice maltiness. Just an exceptional stout. I think this one is probably the best I have had in a long time. I have never had a bad Bells beer. I will be adding this to my normal rotation. Cheers.

Pours black into a shaker. Creamy mocha head with excellent retention recedes leaving scant sheets. Molasses and chocolate aromas. Medium bodied with chocolate and caramel upfront turning dry in the lasting espresso finish.

Served on-tap at Hunger N Thirst.


A - Pours pitch black with a dense one and a half finger tall tan head, slowly dissipating down to a thin film, leaving thick sheets of lace on the sides of the glass.


S - Smells of coffee grounds, chocolate malt, toffee, vanilla and some smokey malt.


T - Starts off with a mix of coffee and dark roasted chocolate malt quickly being joined by the vanilla, light smoke, vanilla and a touch of bitter earthy hops. Finish is roasty with a touch of sweetness, lingering long after the finish.


M - Heavy body with moderate carbonation. Smooth, roasty feel usually wears on the palate but this one isnt as bad.


O - A very nice stout. I love that it is only six percent, allowing you to really enjoy the beer without fear of it messing you up too bad.

The color is that of black coffee deep tan head that is dense.
Smells sweet and a rich roasted malt aroma. I didnt really pick-up any coffee or chocolate that is common in some brands.
A nice roasted malt taste, maybe some hops for balance. it does have a drier finish.
Porter like.
Smooth and balance with some heaviness to it.
Good flavor for this style.
Drink well my friends

12 oz bottle. Tasted on 7/14/14. Beer from Total Wine Tampa, Fl. The beer pours to a deep black color with a medium tan head. The beer has a rich complex flavor with notes of chocolate, coffee & done slight sweetness. The finish is dry & smooth. Overall a great stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours black with thick tan head. Smells of sweet sugar, chocolate, malt and coffee. Taste is sweet chocolate, coffee and smoked malts. Light body medium carbonation.
Bottle pour opaque black. Nose roast, toast, coffee. Taste mild bitter up front followed by strong roast. All the roast flavors, coffee,bakers chocolate, slight nutty. Roasty bitter finish.

Black. Sweet molasses and roasted malt. Light and semi-rich overall on the palate. Cocoa as well. Very good

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottled from BevMo. Black in color on the pour. Nose is mostly bitter, dry roasted coffee/malts. Rich and roasty up front. Lots of coffee bitterness. Smooth and easy drinking. Good quality stout.

Bottle. Wow, This is a hefty stout. Black pour with a creamy mocha head. Absolutely tons of roasty malt, nicely balanced liquorice, lots of smooth chocolate and coffee, and a touch of smoke at the end.
Pours black with a finger of frothy brown head. Aroma is dark smoked chocolate malt with some fig tartness. The flavor is very smoky with hints of bitter dark chocolate and slight must.
Very rough taste, a little palettey, but very rich tasting. It might be good with a hardy meal.

Excellent Stout by far! The intense chocolate and coffee flavor thrills your mouth yet smooth down the throat. Try it with spicy seafood.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle shared at a tasting at Dancing Camel Florentin. Pours black with a brown head, aroma of chocolate, wood, smoke and acidity, flavor of chocolate, sausage, wood, vanilla, medium bodied. Nice

THX to Kraddel! 35 ml. bottle split by 2 @ Barely Legal Tasting Room. Pours black with a big creamy tanned head. Grainy roasted malt and coffee grounds in the nose with some light milk sourness, touch lactose. Bitter tastes of coffee grounds, very grainy, charcoal, roasted malts, hurbned herbs, quite bitter with some light spoiled milk sourness in the back. Grainy body. I dont get it, I had troubles getting through my tasting glass. I wouldnt buy this if this was cheap and local. This is like someone tried making Stouterik and totally messed-up. Yet the score is this high.

Thnx to geoffrey ! 
Pours black , good grey head 
Smell is sweet , roasted malts , 
Rather high carbo . 
Bitter , coffee taste , pretty thin mouthfeel , little amount of sharp sourness almost , in the end . 
Very flat tasting beer . Nothing special ,
Bottle. Pours black with creamy tan head. Good lacing. Nose is chocolate and roast. Taste is cocoa with some coffee. Dry finish. Good stout.
Brass tap on tap. Hey black with a copper top. Aroma oatmeal, cocoa nibs, chocolate, caramel and toffee. Smokey at first, well rounded stout.
Deep dark pour. Nice tan head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate with some licorice. Similar flavor ....this is a really good beer.

[Bottle] Inky black pour with very little head on top. Nose is of bitter chocolate, wood ash, coffee and lighter anise notes. Taste is of bitter malts, mocha, charred tobacco, molasses and moderate hop bitterness. Oily palate and a sticky, coating mouthfeel. A nice beer. Tasting notes from 2/2012.

12 oz. bottle to shaker. Pours BLACK. Light does not shine though it. Two finger brown head, no a lot of lacing, surprisingly. Aroma of dark malts, dark chocolate, coffee and anise. Taste is super-complex. Bitter up front, bittersweet in the middle and it finishes bitter from the malts not the hops. Amazing. Notes of coffee and complex dark malts. Body is borderline medium to heavy, carbonation is perfect, but unseen. This stout is World Class.
Bottle, pours dark black, aroma is roasty, taste is lots of roast and it is really nice and smooth, really solid beer

Bottle. Roasted malt and chocolate aroma with light notes of coffee. Pours deep black colored with a thin, light brown head and not much lacing. Roasted malt flavors with just a hint of coffee to start. Rich chocolate rounds out the finish with the flavors lingering on the palate on the smooth, rich, flavorful finish.

On tap at Urge. Pours a pitch black with a one finger tan head with excellent lacing. Aroma is of coffee, roasted malts, chocolate, molasses, smoke, and caramel. Taste is pretty similar to the aroma with a lot of nice coffee, chocolate, and roasted malt notes. Has a medium-full body with a semi bitter,medium-long finish. Overall, a very nice stout that is very complex, while still being pretty drinkable.

Bouteille: Literally black, small tanned head; rich and dry roasty nose including a tinge of vanilla, dried fruits and traces of wood plus a chocolatey touch; moderate to solid bitter flavour, nearly full bodied and pretty soft; lingering dry finish of cacao and roasted malt with illusions of tobacc. Rich and impressive drop
Deep dark black. Licorice, vanilla and coffee in aroma. Taste is bitter, no toastiness like many stouts but more dark roast. Not extremely full, so quite drinkable. Super beer!
Just a amazingly well put together beer! Notes of chocolate roast malts vanilla I could drink this everyday! A+

Delicious....interesting all around. Can't quite place the nose, but I want to say sweet roasted peanuts. More of that on the palate, smooth dry finish. Love it

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Deep brown with medium khaki head. Toasty, Malty, berry aroma. Taste chocolate roast malt flavor. Nice full body.

I caught notes of blueberry in the aroma 
Thick dark color without much head
Light sweetness in the front, then the bitter hits in the medium and it ends on a medium sour. 

Medium body with a smooth and a bit oily feel with a kick of carbonation near the finish which is bitter and long. 

In all a balanced stout, easy to drink

Oh dear god. Like smitten golden rye, its interesting, and I love bells, but this is a failed experiment to my taste buds.

Not NEARLY as bad as mad scientist though.

Bottled Jan 2014. Poured into snifter. Black, a cm of dense foamy brown head. Aroma is very yeasty, chocolate, slight berry. Body is medium, low carbonation, pretty foamy in the mouth. Taste is light coffee, caramel, smoke, soft bitterness, slightly sour yeasty character. Subdued flavours, all balancing each other out. Very nice - shows that a stout doesnt have to blow your head off to be good.
This beer is a medium stout that is dark brown with has strong flavors of coffee. It is very tasty, but Im not typcially a big fan of coffee flavored beers.

12oz bottle shared by Ed. Poured a deeper black body with a big bubbly head of deep beige. Aroma is chocolate and vanilla, well done toast, seems like a light touch of caramel. Flavor is nice and roasty, darker chocolate, vanilla, dark toast. Solid beer.

12oz bottle thanks to Pizz5116. Pours pitch black with a small tan head of foam. Aroma of roasted malt and chocolate, and not much else. Taste of black roasted malts, licorice, dark chocolate, and caramel. Pretty solid.
It pours out very dark. The initial taste is subtle chocolate and has a dry aftertaste.
UPDATED: JUL 12, 2014 Draft. Pours black. Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate. Taste follows the nose with a sweet beginning and a nice dry aftertaste.
Bottle at home. Huge creamy head. Aroma of charred wood, roasted cashews, coffee. Tastes smoky, rubber, licorice. Dry finish. Nice.
Lots of burnt malt, leather and earth in the smell. Medium body, with notes of milk and coffee in the taste. Great stout!
Pours dark with little carbonation. Smells neutral smoky/nutty. Tastrs light of the same. Smoky finish. Its ok. unimpressed from the ratings i read.
The bottle says licorice. I can't taste any licorice. Bit of a let down. Otherwise it's a pretty meh stout. I was expecting more.

On tap at Taco Mac. Pours near black with a creamy mocha head. Good splotchy lacing. Aroma is roast, cocoa and a bit of licorice. Taste is moderately sweet followed by a fairly dry and mildly bitter finish. Roasted malts and smoky flavors dominate. Creamy mouthfeel with some nice bubbles. Excellent stout.

Botella. Sigo con mi ruta de cervezas americana, esta vez en el champs de Troy. En este caso toca una stout de Michigan. Negra opaca, espuma marron, aroma a caramelo, chocolate, cafe.. servida un poco fria para mi gusto.
A black beer with nice aroma and strong bitterness. Is very creamy but to bitter for my liking.

Pours a dark black with light brown head. Has a strong coffee, chocolate, and oaky aroma. The beer is smooth and creamy with a strong coffee, chocolate, dark malt, and liquorish taste. An amazing stout!
The licorice adds a nice depth. One of the most gorgeous pours as far as color. One of my favorite stouts

One of the worlds best stouts.

Aroma is woody - distinct from many other stouts. The flavor retains the woody/grainy theme. Toasty, roasty, totes ma-goats.

Reminds me of a Romeo y Julieta cigar. This might be the stout to have with a Romeo and Juliet on a warm summer night after the sun goes down.

Pours deep brown/black with a tan head. Aroma is full of licorice, cherries, chocolate, roasted malt. Taste is sweet light malt, chocolate, cream, some licorice. Medium body, but actually pretty light for a stout.. Carbonation is just right. Bitter on the tongue. Really nice

Dark black pour with a thin, dark tan head that receded quickly. Strong chocolate notes with a hint of licorice. Slightly oily texture. Light bitterness in the middle and somewhat stronger at the finish. Overall, very enjoyable.

12 oz bottle from Hy-Vee Muscatine. Black appearance with a brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, bitter chocolate, coffee and ash tray. Similar flavor, roasty, malty, bittersweet, cocoa, espresso notes. Pretty full body, good overall, but too much ash for me. FUCK.

Reviewed from notes. Rcvd in trade.
The appearance was a dark black body with a light brown one finger head that concaves to a lumpy film and leaving some thick foamy lacing clinging to the sides of the glass.
The smell had a dry roasty coffee, slight licorice, perhaps a bit of bourbon and chocolate.
The taste was slightly sweet and somewhat bitter - balanced very well between the previously mentioned flavors, dry sweet aftertaste and finish.
The palate was about a medium, sessionable, adequately carbonated.
Overall, I would say very good for the style and am really liking the licorice that comes out.

Black pour with no head.
Almost no nose.
Thin/watery body.
Fruity notes with cocoa. molasses
Semidry finish

Drought. Inky black with chocolate colored creamy head, coffee aroma, coffee-alcohol taste. Medium carbonation, longish bitter finish with strong alcohol aftetaste. It is in fact strange with not such a high alcohol content to taste so much alcohol. I liked the brew but it really did not meet my expectations.

Bottle from Village Wine and Spirits. Deep dark chocolate, licorice, mocha aromas. Black, creamy tan head, with great lacing. Chocolate, tar, tobacco juice, deep hopping (a bit rough on the tongue in mid and finish). Smooth and so creamy (any oats in this?). A great little stout, one that punches well above its weight.

Does the label change? The guy on my bottle is a different one from this picture. This is one of those perfect beers. Looks like a good quart of freshly-brewed coffee. Aromas of chocolates and plums. Flavours are chocolate, roasted malts, figs (the green ones, in brine). Very creamy, velvety on the palate. Terribly subtle and well-balanced. I could drink more of this.

12 oz bottle poured into snifter..Opaque pour with thin tan head..aroma of caramel, licorice, roasted malts..taste matches aroma, but not as sweet as I thought, with the licorice..and little more carbonated than I expected..but very good overall..would definitely buy again.

Black with light tan foam. Nice aroma - malt and molasses. Taste is the same but surprising light. Sweet finish which lingers. Very mild roast. As it warms sweetness gains a nice richness. Good beer but continues to demonstrate my limited love for straight up stouts and porters.

P: Pitch black abyss that shows no signs of light. Capped with a bubbly dark chocolate milk froth. Thick sticky lacing. 

S: Chocolate syrup, biscotti, praline, brown sugar, prunes, melted chocolate ice cream, cinnamon and roasted dark grains. 

T/M: Bitter dark chocolate, with hints of black licorice swimming around. Ground spices, tree bark, earthiness that reminds me of moss, cracked black pepper, spicy sting of what seems like chilies hits the tongue toward the end of the swallow. Finishes with an effervescent tingle and lasting medicinal notes. Alcohol is very subtle and is heard to seek out. 

O: A smooth easy drinking stout that has sweetness and lots of earthy bitter notes to round out the taste. I was worried at first because Im not a fan of licorice forward beers but it works well with this beer and compliments nicely. A great stout to stock up on.

Serving type: bottle

12oz bottle from The Beer Store Wilson. Dark black pour, zero visibility with one finger thick frothy khaki head. Excellent lacing. Dark roasted malt, coffee, chocolate malt as warms. Wasnt as excited with the aroma as I was hoping to be. Roasted coffee and some dark chocolate up front with a long malt and coffee finish. Fizzy carbonation, medium body, dry texture, chalky feel on the palate.

Found this at my bodega in Brooklyn. So glad to see this in my hood. Beautiful in so many ways. Tastes like a toasted marshmallow dipped in coffee served on a black Twizzler. Warm for the winter, exciting enough for spring.
A chocolate and coffee aroma. A dark pour with a thick mocha head. Tastes of coffee and dark, bitter chocolate. A nice beer.

2/26/14. Bottle. Pours with a light mocha one finger head that stays around for a while. Nice lacing. Dark and thick without being boozy. Malty without being sweet. Hops sit pretty far back on this one. Nice everyday stout. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12oz bottle. Pours black with a small tan head. Chocolate malt aromas. Chocolate malt flavors with light hopping. The malt bitterness carries the full body of the beer to not be sweet but instead is very well balanced. Excellent beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Poured from the tap. Dark black with tan head. Strong coffee aroma with some roast malt and mild creamy chocolate. Same flavour. Full body. Excellent.
A smooth and creamy stout that keeps its edge with underlying notes of licorice, cocoa, leather, and a roasted meatiness. Everything blends seamlessly together, making a standout beer.
Pours black...minimal head...aroma is chocolate and licorice...tons of flavor,roasted malt,molasses and black licorice...very very good stout...i really enjoy.
Lots of roast and coffee flavor up front, a little licorice in the back, but not enough to be overpowering. Good beer.

I love this beer. The licorice and the stout blend botanical extract and ale art and science perfectly. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Draft at Clinton hall NYC. Pours a deep black color with a head that fades. Veryifh but flavorful. ECM stout that's very drinkable 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours dark brown to black with brown head from 12oz. bottle into pint glass. Heavy dark roasted malt aroma, you can smell the bitter licorice coming through as well. Deep bitter roast flavor with a lot of coffee and cocoa. Has an almost smoky burnt after taste resembling the char on grilled red meat. Delicious.

Mouth-watering aromas of chocolate, sorghum and roast malts. Its a gorgeous nearly-black opaque color with a mocha head thats frothy and firm. An absolute explosion of flavor! This is a stout-drinkers stout, with roasted malt, espresso, and a sharp hop ending that is absolutely perfect. The mouthfeel is creamy like a milkshake, with a lingering roasted malt and hop flavor that lasts long enough to demand another sip.

Pours a dark black color. Loads of coffee and black licorice taste here. Oddly very juicy and wet as well. Some dark chocolate here as well. Almost a BBQ meaty sort of thing going on here. Bright as well. Sharp tasting but still silky on the palate.

Bottle. Pours deep brown with a brown head. Aroma is licorice, roasted malts, milky and some coffee. Taste is moderate bitter and moderate sweet. Very smooth and silky. Medium bodied with a dry finish.
12 oz bottle. Pours jet black, with a small tan head which quickly dissipates. Some lacing. Nose is chocolate and malt. Taste is dark malt with a hint of chocolate. Delicious.

Bottle to glass. Pours an opaque black with quick dissipating head. Not much aroma, some slight chocolate malts come thru. Taste is chocolate malts with roasted coffee beans and toast. Palate is thin, decently carbonated. Some lingering bitterness. Good, but overrated in my opinion. Plenty of other options available that blow this away, even from Bells.
12oz bottle. Pours a deep black with small brown head. Subtle roasted chocolate malt aroma. Full bodied with strong roasty malt flavor. Lingering roasty finish. Pretty good.

Trying to remember everything about this from last night,,, what stood out to me is that it was wholly more enjoyable than the Green Flash Double Stout I drank before it.
The Kalamazoo was very affordable also.

Very good dry coffee stout !
Well balanced.
Was once my favorite.
Till I found stronger tasting dry Imperial Stouts.
Like (1) Thirsty Dogs Siberian Night, (2) Founders Imperial Stout, (3) Troegs Java Head Stout & (4) Thirsty Dogs Old Leghumper Porter.

12oz bottle into a pint glass.

Pours pitch black with a very dark tan one finger head. Great head retention and lacing. 

The smell, apart from a slight metallic note, is awesome. Tons of toast and roasted malt with a good shot of coffee. There is some fruitiness going on too.

The flavor is a lot more bold than the aroma. Dark roast coffee and dark fruit along with some burnt caramel. Dark chocolate accompanies a high bitterness with a bit of cream to finish is off. Moderate mouthfeel with a fairly dry finish.

Overall, a really good, if not excellent, stout. While the aroma is lacking a bit it is full of flavor and stops short of being over the top remaining quite drinkable. Very nice.

Oh yeah. Pours jet black with an initial tan head that fades and no lacing. Nose is roasted malt and some molasses. Notes of espresso, licorice, molasses, bitter chocolate and some fruityness in the background. Taste are med/heavy sweet and med/heavy bitter. Full, oily and somewhat sticky body with a long lasting bitter finish. Very drinkable.
Chocolate caramel scent and taste along with a smooth yet somewhat bitter finish make this stout a must drink go bells
Very good stout, smooth with chocolate notes and a good malty flavor. Recommended.

A glass of inky blackness. Faintly smoky in the aroma. A delectable tongue coating oatiness, that is well supported by considerable roast character as well as supple chocolate. Extremely good and deserving of all its fame.

12oz bottle. Definitely get a smell of coffee on the first whiff. Just a light smell of chocolate. This a pitch black beer with minimal head. A slightly sweet beer with a hint of saltiness. Creamy in texture and a medium body. A bitter aftertaste that doesnt linger very long. I would easily buy a 6er of this beer.

Bottle received from 2013 summer secret santa. Thank you jsquire! Pours very dark brown, almost black, with a rather small dark brownish beige head that leaves a small trace on the glass while dissipating. Smell is sweet and malty with roasted malts, molasses, sweet liquorice candy, soy sauce, caramel, hay, minerals, vanilla fudge and coffe hard candy. Taste is sweet, bitter and malty with roasted malts, high quality dark chocolate, coffee, moist soil, caramel, brown sugar, hay, banana bread, vanilla fudge, minerals, chocolate chip cookies, caramelized almonds, toffee and hints of soot. Mouthfeel is round, soft, tiny velvety and medium bodied. Finish is tiny sweet and bitter with roasted malts, caramel, toffee, dark chocolate, hay, minerals, coffee, sweet liquorice candy, golden syrup and bread. Nicely drinkable...
Hey big suprise... it pours dark and tastes like a stout. Not a huge fan of the style, but this is a good stout. Goes very well with a steak.
Bottle from Bells. Poured black with wisps of creamy tan head. Decent aroma of rich choc, coffee, sweet molasses. Light carb med thick body. Bitter sweet choc taste that lingers.
Pour is a typical stout, dark with a lite tan head. Lite smells of chocolate and malt. Some smokey, slight char taste and a smooth bitterness that makes this a great stout.

very dark brown with coffee colored i finger head. roasted malt, dark chocolate and coffee nose, slightly burned malt. soft mouthfeel, do not really notice licorice/anise. solid, but IMHO not a 100 beer

Dark brown with chestnut highlights. A small tan head with decent lacing. Aroma of chocolate with some caramel, hint of roast and umami. Taste some bakers chocolate with licorice and a little caramel. Roastiness mid taste with some bitterness and light charred flavors. Finishes semi dry with mild lingering roasted bitterness. Mouthfeel is soft and clean with a medium body and carbonation. Easy to drink for a stout. Has good roasted flavor.

Black oily pour with a quarter inch of oatmeal head. Nose is creamy, chocolate, rich smooth coffee and black licorice. Average to low carbonation, creamy mouthfeel, finish is dry on the teeth too. Good smooth taste, creamy chocolate and coffee and roasted malts, a bit bitter and acidic, more so than double cream stout. Really great stout with robust flavors. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle to glass. I don't usually drink stouts, but I like this one. A balanced and not overpowering coffee and chocolate flavor.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
THis is one great stout! Not too sweet/sugary, nice level bitterness. Lovely.

Great delicious toasty stout. From Albany shop. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from bottle: pours black with a thick tan head. aroma of caramel, roasted malt, little breast. Taste is nice and roasted with a little hop bite. Almost tastes like a black IPA. Medium body, a little sticky. Excellent beer.

Une belle bière noire à la mousse café crème où une écume reste à la parois du verre et une dentelle glisse lentement. De belles odeurs de gousse de vanille fraîche nous charme le nez, suivi de près par des effluves danis, effacées presque aussitôt par des arômes de café noir. Un goût de torréfaction soccupe de la bouche, limprègne dune amertume douce et persistante, alors quun aspect rôti se traîne la patte pour apporter une variante appréciable. Embouteillée le 31 octobre 2013 (931-211213)

Great appearance, dry frontal but settles out after a few sips. Definite tastes of molasses, licorice and chocolate. Has a fantastic aroma and definitive dark pour. A great and traditional northern stout. I'm a native Nashvillian and we cannot get Bells in TN, had to find it in AZ, and boy am I happy!! Fantastic brew...

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pour from a 12oz bottle. Nice black pour with a dark black head. Quite nice to look at. Looked thicker than it tasted in terms of mouthfeel. Dry. A bit smoky and some astringency. No real malt presence.

Batch 10175 (Jan 7, 2011)

A: pours a black ale with little/no translucency except in the final ounce. Two fingers toasted cocoa falls slowly to a thick sheet of the same. Cobweb lacing. 

S: cocoa, coffee, wood, grain, molasses, dark chocolate. the nose is what gets me every time on this beer. Beautiful smell.

T: Dark chocolate, espresso. Graham. Dates, lightly. Bitterness that plays around at the base. The malts on this are slightly spicy at the rear of the palate as well. Hints of cream at the back-end. This beer resonates for-ev-errr.

M: Thick and silky. Low to medium carb. Both dries and slicks the palate.

O: So far, my second favorite stout. Excellently crafted. Obsidian still holds the top for me, but this would be a great substitute.

Serving type: bottle

05-09-2011

Pours an opaque very dark brown with a smooth, short, mocha-taupe head. Smoke, chocolate, and coffee nose. Not thick, but not thin. Some mild astringency combined with a fine scrubbing. Strong flavors of smoky coffee, but lacks some much needed malt sweetness IMO.
what can i say that probably hasnt already been said? a little dry, lots of coffee bitterness, a bit oily, somewhat of burnt walnuts and dark cocoa. another great Bells product.
UPDATED: DEC 25, 2013 Had a six pack from Holmes with Erik. This is a good stout. Not as good as their double cream stout. Had a sweet smell and food course type aroma.

12 oz bottle from Holmes with Wayne. Sweet fruity aroma. Taste was the same. Finish was a bit harsh. Not a bad stout overall.

An alright stout. It seems a little watery and lacking in taste to me, but its still solid.

Dark brown ale with a slight tan head. Has a roasty aroma and a slight roasty flavor with a hint of coffee in the finish. The beer is smooth and has a nice full body feel. Nicely balanced. This is a beer that is a joy to drink without it having to try too hard.

From a bottle dated 2/18/13. Pours dark with thin tan head. Roasted coffee and caramel on the nose. Chocolate and licorice with boozy finish... Excellent stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Poured from a bottle. Pours a black opaque hue with decent amount of light brown head. Aromas of oak, chocolate, dark malt. Taste is complex but not overpowering. Taste of chocolate, dark malts, dates, some hop spice. Well balanced finish. One of the best single stouts I've ever had.

Near perfect. First smell is strong oak. Flavor is robust and powerful mat first overwhelming but the palate eventually tames it. Dark Roasted malts with hops in the background. Beautiful lacing throughout. Smooth and crisp finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle- Pour is dark black with a nice tan head..Nose is nice roast, caramel, dark chocolate...Taste is nice roast, spice, dark chocolate, faint nutty, coffee bean, dry..

12 oz. bottle in a pint glass. Pours a jet black with a moderate mocha head. Typical stout look. Aroma is roasted malts, espresso, light coffee, toffee, and caramel. I doubt really care for coffee scents (or tastes), but this is a complex and balanced aroma. Taste pretty follows the nose, but it is very smooth and doesnt have the normal coffee astringency which I dislike. There are also some dark fruit tastes such as raisins, and some licorice. I actually surprised at how complex the taste is. I think that this my favorite stout so far.

A black body with a nice tan head that had great retention and decent lace. Aroma had a heavy roasted malt profile. Notes of coffee and chocolate. Some bitter hops. Flavor had good roasted malts. Chocolate was slightly bitter and there was hint of molasses in the after taste. A very dry finish. Nice mouth feel.

Near perfect. First smell is strong oak. Flavor is robust and powerful mat first overwhelming but the palate eventually tames it. Dark Roasted malts with hops in the background. Beautiful lacing throughout. Smooth and crisp finish.

Dark pour with a dark khaki head, aroma of licorice, coffee, dark fruit, and dark chocolate malts. Great taste, both robust and smooth with the taste closely matching the aroma. Awesome stout, damn near perfect.

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2014 12 oz bottled served in a snifter. Bottled date of May 2012.

This is a black and opaque beer with only the tiniest dark brown at the very edges. The head is a thick tan color, and starts ample (about 2 fingers) but quickly settles to a top coat and ring. It leaves moderate lacing on the glass.

Aroma is moderately strong and consists mainly of dark roasted malts, dried dark fruits, and some alcohol phenols.

Flavor: dominated, as it should be, by dark roasted malts; lasting and rich finish featuring dark roasted malts with a hint of hop spiciness, black licorice and dark chocolate.

Feel: Full body with medium-low carbonation. 

O - I sampled this Bells immediately after a Green Flash Double Stout. Overall, I found the GF slightly superior, but was surprised at the similarity, particularly in the aroma. The GF has a slightly stronger flavor. 
Improves considerably with warming. 

Revisited in March 2014 when it was paired with a Weyerbachher Heresy, losing on all counts in this rather unfair comparison.

Aroma is of roasted barley, coffee, and chocolate. Taste is very smooth. Roasted barley and a slight coffee aftertaste. Bit of a bitter finish. The flavors all go very well together and is balanced. The coffee flavors come through more as I drink it. Not sweet. Depth of flavors more in line with imperial stout. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Hints of chocolate and roast on the nose. Light tan head with nice lacing. The overall impression I get from this stout is a wonderful balance of complex malt flavors - chocolate, roast, residual sweetness and maybe a hint a licorice. The beer is smooth and creamy as the description states which is helped by the light carbonation.

Quality stout. Wonderful roasted notes, with a smooth finish and hints if licorice. Not as sweet as I would like for a stout, but a well balanced stout nonetheless.

leTs hop a flight to KAZO bro. pours deep dark brown, quick tan head with a spotty lacing coat. nose of black coffee and licorice. taste follows with light astringency and mild nuttiness. body is light, slightly creamy.

Beautiful black pour with tan head. Aroma of chocolate and heavy malt, same on the palate with a nice long slightly bitter finish. Super drinkable stout.

Bottle. Poured a black color with a beautiful khaki head and amazing lacing. Taste of roasted and toasted malts, dark cocoa, coffee, smoky finish. Creamy yet watery mouthfeel, medium carbonation. Top shelf brew right here.

Roasty coffee and bakers chocolate on the nose. Dark brown body and khaki head. Bitter coffee and chocolates aggravated by a disagreeable astringent taste. In desperate need of a sweet flavor to balance it and add AGREEABLE complexity.

Beautiful. smooth stout with perfect balance of roastiness and sweetness. Strong vanilla notes present in both the flavor and aroma. the head is a foamy tan, which dissipated rather quickly, but leaves a film and attractive lacing on the glass. Great big mouthfeel and no lingering slickness keep this a very drinkable stout.
Nice dark pour. Hint of molases in aroma. Powerful aroma of slight chocolate and licorice malts. Very good.

Dark black pour with small tan head. Aroma of malts, chocolate and faint licorice. Taste of roasted malts, slight chocolate and coffee, hint of licorice and faint woodiness. Full bodied, medium carbonation, nothing really jumps out of this one, just a straight forward damn good stout all around.

Black pour with small mocha head. Aroma of roasted malt, smoke, and leather. Aggressive, nearly overpowering roastiness on the tongue. Bitter coffee, tobacco, licorice. Full bodied, slick. An intense stout for sure, just didnt agree with me.
Pours black out of bottle with slight tan head that fades quickly. Aromas of chocolate, malt, tobacco. Taste of smokey malt, light chocolate. A little light on the palate soft carbonation.
Bottle. Black with small tan head. Aroma of chocolate, roasted malts, and a hint of licorice. Medium body with notes of roasted malts, some malt sweetness, and light licorice finish.

Pours a motor oil black with tan head leaving moderate lacing. Aroma of malt and coffee. Notes of licorice and roasted malts, little coffee aftertaste. Very good stout, this should be the base that all stouts measure against.

Bam! Pitch black pour with amazing beige head. Smell is roasty and strong coffee. Taste. ....oooh Yeah. ....bitter chocolate, strong coffee, mildly sweet with a beautiful bitter aftertaste that keeps on lasting. Mouthfeel couldnt be lovelier, full thick sticky body and perfect carbonation. I could drink this by the gallon! Awesome Stout. From a trade with Jimsal27. Thanks Jimmy!

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2014 On tap at Bells Eccentric Cafe. Pour is very black, completely opaque. Tan head, moderate lacing. Excellent carbonation. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee. Flavor is roasted and smoky and a little bitter. Long hoppy finish.

Pours black with a creamy tan head. Well balanced with nice molasses and chocolate. Hint of coffee at the end. Another great one from Bells!

Bottled from deciccos. Dark pour. Tan head takes a bit to settle. Roasty roasty malts and light bitter finish. Good.

12oz bottle. Aroma is dry, dark malt. Appearance is black with a tan head. Taste is a dark malt bomb. It starts semi-sweet then goes dry. Finishes burnt malt. Palate is dry. Overall, a great stout. Well done.

Bottle. Near black pour with a dark, tan head. Sting malt, toasty and chocolate aromas. Sweet with a bitter, coffee finish.
Another great beer from Bells. Very smooth drinkable stout. Bottle says its brewed with licorice , didnt get that at all probably added to the overall flavor profile which was pleasant.

12oz bottle shared. Pours pretty much solid motor oil black with large frothy mocha colored head. Aroma is packed full of deep dark malts and chocolate. The flavor is incredibly smooth. The roasted malts and chocolate malts are very balanced, incredibly smooth. Lots of lacing. Tons of flavor and my newest best friend.

Bottled June 3, 2013 (4.5 months old).
Appearance: The body is pitch black, even through the edges, with a short brown head that sticks around for a moment before settling into a sparse coating with a dense ring.
Aroma: Sweet caramel is prominent, slight burnt edge to it, sweet cocoa is behind it with a mild smokey presence. The aroma is sweet with the caramel and cocoa being the most prominent. I wish the aroma were a bit stronger though.
Taste: The intro is mild, with bittersweet chocolate creeping in. The flavor is rather mild until the finish which is a touch astringent. The finish hints at burnt malts with a touch of caramel. This is balanced between the specialty malts, but nothing jumps out. The finish is semi-sweet.
Palate: Medium bodied, Id like a little more body, with moderate carbonation.
Overall: I enjoy Kalamazoo Stout, but I do not understand why this is rated so highly. Nothing jumps out at me flavor wise, and while this is balanced nicely, I dont love it. This may be a batch variation, or perhaps it doesnt hold up to age, but I dont get the high ratings.
UPDATED: JAN 12, 2014 A really dark great looking stout. I expect nothing less really coming from Bells for a stout. Really solid stout.

Another fantastic beer and stout from bells. Super chocolately and nicely bitter. Not their best stout, but a close second. Smells chocagely and pours a dark brown almost black in color. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Aroma is malty goodness and caramel, hint of chocolate. Black as night pour, mininal head. Taste is malts, bitter chocolate, caramel and molasses. Very smooth. Coffee aftertaste. Well done stout. Must try.

Thanks Aaron! Bottle poured into a teku, jet black with a mocha head that lasts for a second. Smell is cocoa and slight licorice. Taste is fantastic... Cocoa, slight char, lil coffee, roasted malts, and just the right amount of hops to balance everything out. Great beer. Bells crushes with their stouts.
Pours plenty dark. Lots of roasted malt aroma, some anise. Taste is bitter malt, some hops. Very low residual sweetness. Pretty thick mouthfeel. Finishes bitter and dry. Pretty great.

Pours opaque black with a creamy mouse-like tan head. Espresso roasted malt nose with notes of charcoal. First sip yields a rich roasted malt flavor with notes of licorice, charred wood and rich espresso. The mouthfeel is smooth and silky. At its core, this is a very simple American Stout that rises to extraordinary proportions. Very drinkable and flavorful. A must find.
From bottle. Pours a deep red with tan head. Roasted nutty malt and vanilla. Taste was all roasted malt and caramel. Some coffee aftertaste.
coffee notes and a smooth roastiness. opaque, with no apparent head. not too bitter. clean finish.

Bottle, courtesy of Kermis. Pours a black beer with a medium sized, beige creamy head on top. Aroma of coffee, vanilla and chocolate. Flavour is moderately sweet with cacao and coffee building the palate. Very full bodied and well balanced. Medium long finish, sweet. Coffee is strong in this one. Nice brew for sure.

Bottle in Denver courtesy of Kermis. Poured a deep mahogany colour with an oily consistency and a thin tan head. The aroma is rich roasted malt with some milky cream. The flavour is strong bitter with a big liqourice roasted malt weak chocolate coffee palate and I swear there was a momentary hint of coconut too.

Bottle shared at post GABF tasting. Pours near black with a ring beige head. Aroma of roast, coffee, chocolate, a little dark fruit, licorice and soy. Flavour is moderate sweet and over moderate bitter. Medium bodied with light carbonation.

Tap sampler, Bells Eccentric Café, 31/viii/13. Pours a near-unctuous deep chestnut. Aroma of charred nuts. Taste is confidently unidimensional and geared towards liquorice, roast and dark chocolate. Nice quality stout.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2014 Bottle: Intense, dark-brown, nearly black with some deep ruby tints. Leathery, light-tan head, cloudy and fluffy - long lasting without leaving any lacing. Aroma is huge, bigger than expected. Dark fruits, boozy raisins and dates, dark chocolate fudge, mild black licorice, and heavy, finishing roasted malts. Flavor is full steam with some sweet black licorice, booze-soaked dates and raisins, superbly roasted malts, and an unsung, unsweetened, oily & roasty coffee bean finish. Hops? Eh, not many to speak of. Very good beer, here, so much presence for only 6% ABV. Like a mini Expedition.
Bottle poured with little head. Dark black color with maybe a little red or brown color too. Smells, roasty chocolate. Nice full flavor.

Draught at the Bells Eccentric Café, Kalamazoo, MI.
Black colour with a reddish hue and a foamy light tan head. 
Roasted malt, mild coffee and creamy vanilla in the aroma.
Roasted malt, caramel sweetness and coffee in the flavour. Too much coffee for me. After the Expedition Stout this wasnt that great.

I guess this is the one I tried since it was specified it was one of the best acording to Rate Beer, but no firther information was given. It was nice and very exquisit. Very aromatic and drinkable all around.

Bottle dated March. Opaque brown/black, no foam. Roasty, chocolate aroma. Flavor is same but with a milkiness that softens the profile. Perhaps that is the licorice noted on the bottle. Slightly bitter after taste. All in all, a quality stout. Robust and flavorful yet fairly low ABV.

Really nice solid stout. Starts creamy and smooth, moves seamlessly to espresso, bitter roast malts, anise and burnt sugary prunes. A little lacking in aroma and I can see how others might not like the astringent finish. But I love it.

Poured from bottle into pint glass. Dark pour with a thin tan head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, nuts, toast, roasty, alcohol, soy sauce, smoke, vanilla, raisin. Full creamy thick body. Carbonation is pretty lively, more than I expected for a stout but nice. Heavy malt flavor, coffee, walnut, molasses, with a long bitter finish. Another great brew from Bells.

Pours a rich black umber color with a tight khaki finger or two of foam. Nose is full of sweet molasses, dark cocoa and a touch of roasted peanut. The palate follows with a heavy carbonation, good roasted malt backbone some sweet cocoa and vanilla notes mingle turn a bit bittersweet on the lingering finish.
On draft at bell ec, Great aroma of coffee and chocolate, chocolate coffe taste with maybe a little dark fruit! Really good

12 oz bottle poured into stout glassware. Beautiful opaque color with a small brownish head that lingers. Aroma of licorice, chocolate, and chicory. Nice aroma but wish it was a bit stronger. Aroma- Toasty malt, chocolate and raisin.
Taste- Coffee, chocolate, figs and malt.

Overall- Very solid stout. Once again, Bells does not disappoint.
Bottle. Pours pitch black with one finger tan head. Good looking beer. Great taste, chocolate and roasted coffee.

Black with a large brown head that dissipates to a small wispy topping and ring around glass that lasts throughout. Aroma is sweet and roasty, caramel, chocolate, coffee - pretty luscious. Flavor follows. Medium body, not nearly as full as I was expecting nor the mouthfeel. Sweet and roasty, just enough bitterness. Nice smooth coffee finish. Very tasty and very well balanced. A lot of malt, chocolate, a little dark fruit, a little roasty. Tastes similar. Remarkably smooth. Malt, chocolate, molasses. Creamy. A little roasty at the end, but not too much.

12 oz bottle. Pours a nice light black with a thin beige head, leaving nice lace on the glass. The aroma is heavy on licorice with a decent amount of roasted malt and a hint of chocolate. 12 oz bottle purchased at The Craft Beer Outlet in Philly on June 20, 2013. Black, thin head. Aroma of dry licorice and fruity herbs. Juicy taste of licorice, cocoa bitter, bitter dry to the bones. This is a kick ass stout!

Pours ruby red brown and lands black and opaque with a rich tan head that settles down to about half a finger. Aroma is a very nice mix of roasted malt, cocoa and cinammon or licorice. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle dated 12/10/12. Poured into a shaker pint. Consumed at about cellar temperature.

Appearance: Pours with about a finger of a brown head that doesnt last long. Very dark with a bit of ruby on the edges. Your typical stout, really.

Smell: A bit sweeter than the taste, and even some dark fruits. Plenty of chocolate and coffee, and any other sort of word thats used to describe most stouts -- its here in Kalamazoo Stout.

Taste/feel: Throw out the dark fruits and some of the sweetness, the taste is much more of roasty malts, with traces of coffee and chocolate as well. A stout thats not powerfully flavorful, so its really quite easy drinking. The feel is about middle of the road -- its pretty lightly carbonated, and the beers not thick or thin.

Kalamazoo Stout is a solid Bells beer. Im not a big fan of stouts, but this ones fine and good. Its not super big, roasty, and thick like some other stouts out there (or Imperial Stouts, of course), but thats not a bad thing. Not extremely memorable, but still a good one. Definitely overrated, though, in my opinion.
Bottle. Pours opaque dark brown with slight toffee head with nice lacing. Aroma of roasted malts and coffee. Taste of dark chocolates and coffee. Very nice.

Rich dark brown/black color; Medium to heavy creamy body; Aroma of toasted/smoky malt, dark chocolate, coffee, & light licorice; Flavor of roasted/burnt malt, hops, bittersweet chocolate, coffee, and some licorice; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; Very good stout.
July 2012. From bottle. Pours black with a beige head. Rich aromas of licorice, chocolate, malt and coffee. Sweet and smooth at first, then bitter on the finish. Awesome stout.

Jet black with mild dark tan head. Aroma is dark chocolate, licorice, berry. Taste is wonderful dark roast coffee and maybe fig with a chocolate flavor as well. Fizzles on the tongue so you cannot drink too fast but is smooth and had a slick smooth body.

Bottle at home in Salisbury, CT - picked up at Grassroots in Jacksonville, FL. Pours deep brown with a huge, cascading beige foam head. The aroma holds some milky chocolate, dried berries and soft roasted malts. Medium sweet flavor with moderate ashy roast, some lightly burnt bread, mild bitter earth, some cocoa. Light to medium bodied with fine, massaging carbonation. Sweet finish, some lightly sticky chocolate, subtle roasted malts, hints of burnt wood, baking cocoa. Very nice.
The aroma smelled of coffee and a little chocolate hint as well. The taste was very good. Would definitely have this beer again. Bells knows what it is doing with this stout.

I cant believe its taken me this long to review such a classic, perfect stout. Thick and solid black in color, this beer is the definition of opaque. A dense, foamy light brown head sits atop it thickly. The aroma is rich with roasted malts, with a slight sweetness to soften the harsh edges. Its slightly sweet, but still packed with straight-up roasted malts in the mouth, delivered softly, like butter on the tongue. It has that classic, dry, intense roasted malt flavor but with just enough sweetness to make it incredibly delicious. Simple, full, and wickedly palatable.

I poured a 12oz bottle into a nonic pint glass. The bottle was dated 11/26/12 making it just over four months old.

Appearance: Dark black color, completely opaque. Forms a huge, brown, frothy head which is slow to dissolve and leaves plenty of lacing on the glass.

Smell: Mild nose of milk chocolate and black licorice. 

Taste: Im so used to reviewing flavored and/or imperial stouts I forget how good a "regular" or stout can be. Bells Kalamazoo Stout is definitely one of the better examples of such a brew: plenty of flavor and a perfect balance of sweetness and bitterness. Theres a slight licorice taste to make it a tad unique, which is all the more appreciable. 

Theres a smooth sweetness at the start. Mild milk chocolate, roasted malt and some dairy flavors are all prominent at first. Theres a strong surge of bitterness at the apex of the swig. Dry, slightly salty, coffee and nutty-like flavors and bitterness appear, though they themselves quickly recede as a lightly sweet taste of black licorice and the faintest hint of sour red grape appear on the finish. This is a delectable tasting brew for sure, but not so robust or amazing as to be among the upper echelon beers.

Drinkability: What really makes Bells Kalamazoo Stout a cut above the rest is its drinkability. Theres a lot of flavor here, but the actually deliver is remarkably drinker-friendly. The mouthfeel is smooth and soft and goes down easily. Though theres a slightly bitter aftertaste its nowhere near cloying and is actually rather pleasant. At 6% ABV its tempting to drink in large quantities since it doesnt feel like a heavy beer at all. The versatility makes it ideal to pair with food, as a stand-alone beverage, or a dessert in a glass. You decide.

12 Fl Oz bottle.  Pours like old engine oil with a large but short-lived mocha coloured head.  Sweet roasty malt, some hay, molasses, and a little caramel.  Taste is bakers chocolate, coffee, and burnt toast.  Light bodied relative to appearance, a little sticky and creamy, short finish.  I suspect that this beer may have mellowed out considerably as it is 3-4 year old stock.  Would like to compare to a freshly brewed sample.

Creamy, licorice, and star anise aroma. Bakers chocolate, burnt coffee, and licorice taste. Finishes exceptionally smooth.
