 Overall:  A stout for the imperial stout lover looking to drink the common mans stout.  Impressive.

I give it A+, best stout ever.  Its an American stout not a classic stout, but the american hops and the dark malts do great together.  Good body, right carbonation.  Nice complexity, I detect molasses for sure and probably anise.

Black in color and small tan head. Aroma is rich,full body and sweet. At first taste your mouth is over taken with a ton of flavors bitter coffee,dark chocolate,alcohol,licorice and malts. Over all great beer.

The aroma of this beer is strongly of chocolate, caramel and roasted malts; the appearance is black with a prominent tan head that disappears quickly. The beer is mildly umami, mildly sweet, and slightly bitter, but the palate is much heavier, combining a full body, creamy texture, flat carbonation, and long finish.

The beer is a deep, dark brown with a half inch of beige head. The aroma offers molasses, dark roast, black coffee. Malty with dark roasted coffee. Rich and slightly sweet, finishing bitter. Molasses with a touch of dark chocolate. Medium bodied with moderately low carbonation. Another solid offering from Bells.

Tap at American Ice in a mason jar plus many bottles over time. Dark pour, a large tan foamy head. Aroma is roasty chocolate with some other stuff Im sure. Taste is a bit boozy, well it made me feel drunk. Really thick mouthfeel without being sticky like a roasty chocolate milkshake. Dense, bitter, no sugar though. Balanced palate with background hoppiness. One of the best lower abv beers since I almost only like Imperial Stouts. Has the richness of an Imperial stout without the abv. I dont like that weak @$$ $h!t in my stouts so thank you for Kzoo.
UPDATED: MAR 11, 2013 Super solid stout. A bit hoppy. 12oz pour from bottle, deep opaque black with deep charcoal foam. Thick foam.

Pours a dark--almost black--brown with a coffee colored head that lingers for a while. Scent is roasted malts, coffee, a bit of licorice and chocolate. Flavor is divine. Wonderful roasty malts and coffee giving way to an almost milk chocolate like sweetness that further gives way to a well balanced bitterness at the end. Beautifully balanced and wonderfully drinkable. Creamy in the mouth and goes down like silk. An excellent beer.

Pours black with a fading tan head. Aroma is of molasses, toast, roasted malt, and brown sugar. Taste is of roasted malt and dark chocolate, fairly clean, with a lingering roasty finish and a very light touch of herbal hops. Medium body and carbonation. Solid stout.

Poured from a bottle to a tulip. Thick brown velvety head that combines to a brown Swiss cheese like head with large bubbles. Slow to dissipate. Black brown color in the glass. No light escapes the glass. Smell chocolate figgy notes. Slight bitterness to go with the powerful malts. This is a smooth drinking stout. Not very syrupy like some others. High quality stout.

12oz Bottle A - Pours black with a small mocha head. Good lacing. S - Cocoa dominated. T - Cocoa, roasted coffee, & dark fruit. M - Medium bodied. Smooth but thin mouthfeel. Nice carbonation. Roasted coffee finish. O - Solid stout with a sessionable quality.

I really liked pouring this one. I wasnt paying attention and it hurled itself out of the bottle and quickly filled the glass with inky blackness, then suddenly there was foam everywhere. The head has a weird delay when you pour it. At first, reasonable - then your glass has disappeared under creamy suds along with your coaster beneath.

This is one of those stouts that hides nothing. Everything you smell, youre going to taste, and all of it is good. Lots of roasted coffee and charred wood, without the bitterness Id expected. Some cocoa. Finishes well but isnt super complex - went awesome with the roast beef sandwich I had. Feels thinner than most other stouts.

Overall, a nice stout that definitely pairs well with food and doesnt overwhelm the palate. I will definitely come back to this one when I want to just enjoy a stout without subconsciously starting to critique it.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2012 Bells Kalamazoo Stout - Darkest beer I have ever seen.  Tiny head, but lacing is terrific.  Smells of licorice, coffee roast, dark chocolate, and booze - definitely grabs your attention!  Taste - hoo boy.  Definitely notice the roasted coffee notes right off the bat.  Quite bitter and potent.  Impressive, but also kind of overwhelming - have to sip it quite slowly.  More acid than Id like as well.  I would not say its syrupy per se, but it is so in-your-face that its hard to believe its not an impy.  I can see why a lot of folks might love this, but it doesnt compare to my very favorite stouts.  I actually think I prefer their Java - theres just...slightly too much going on in this one.  NOVEMBER 6 RE-RATE: Compared next to Java.  This admittedly had the appearance advantage - heads were about even, but Kalamazoo lasted slightly longer than I expected, and its lacing was better (not that Javas was bad).  Aroma - slight advantage to Java, though not reflected in the score.  Kalamazoo is arguably more complex - licorice, roast, and chocolate - but I am biased toward coffee aromas, so Java wins there.  Taste and palate - definitely prefer Java.  I can hardly believe Java has the higher ABV - I taste more booze in Kalamazoo.  Also, Java is less heavy-bodied while being just as flavorful.  Kalamazoo seems to favor the chocolate-preferring crowd.  I like my stouts more coffee-ish and less heavy-bodied, so again, I have to say I prefer Java here.  Kalamazoo is still a fine stout, dont get me wrong, but I am just more of a coffee gal.

Bottle from the brewery. Pours a dark black with red/brown at the fringes and head forms with a good swirl. Smell is slightly sweet and quite roasty, a bit of chocolate as well. Palate is thick bodied with a small amount of  carbonation. Taste is roasty and ever so slightly sweet, and gets slightly bitter later on. Aftertaste is all roasty, very nice.
Pours jet black with brown head.  Aroma is light...malts, coffee, chocolate.  Taste is the same, but much bolder.  An ideal stout.
Bottle->SA glass.  Black, tan head.  Nice version of standard chocolate/coffee/malt aroma and taste.  A very decent stout, but nothing really special (particularly when compared to Expedition).

Bottle from Oxford meijer. Dark brown black color and thick foam head. Sweet malt nose and coffee malt taste. Medium thick body and sweet undertones. Licorice like coffee aftertaste. A mans stout. Bells does it again.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle shared at home.  Pours black with a tan head. Strong coffee aroma.  Cereal notes along with the coffee. Sharp bitter finish. Nice stout.

Aroma is roasted malts, a little coffee, smoke, dark chocolate - very complex and leaves you wanting more. Well, Ive come to appreciate stouts since my last rating.  However, I dont think this one is my favorite, even though it is quite good as far as stouts go. A - Pours a dark black color with just a hint of brown around the edges and a finger of frothy chocolate colored head. The head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some light lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of roasted chocolate and dark malts. There is just a touch of dark fruit, coffee, and smoke as well.

T - Starts off with a mix of roasted chocolate and dark malts with a touch of plum and other dark fruits. Through the middle, a bit of lactose sweetness comes through alongside some light smoke and a bit of coffee. The finish is a mix of lightly burnt chocolate, a bit of bitterness, vanilla, and a hint of coffee.

M - Medium-plus bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a dry and lightly sweet finish.

D - Very drinkable. Excellent example of an American Stout. Balance is spot on.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2012 Pours black with a small tan head. Smells roasted with some bitterness. Taste is roasty and bitter. Full-bodied with a slick, smooth texture and mild mouth-carbonation, Bell?s Kalamazoo Stout finishes with a touch of bitterness.

Poured from a bottle: brownish/black with a tan head. The aroma is a roasted coffee smell, maybe espresso. Taste is not too thick, slightly bitter, but very smooth. Creamy texture with lively carbonation. Overall a good stout.

Bottle.  Pours a black color with a tan head.  Roasted, chocolate aromas.  Dark, burnt, roasted, and licorice flavors.  I like a lot of Bells beers, but this one just doesnt do it for me.  Maybe its the licorice flavor that Im not feeling.
Faints of chocolate, licorice, coffee aroma. Slightly sweet, slightly carbonated, slightly hoppy taste. Not cloying, hot, or dry.  Great drinking stout!

Bottle. Pours black, pitch black. Medium tan creamy head that laces well. Aroma is medium sweet espresso and chocolate. Flavor is medium sweet, coffee, chocolate, molasses, slightly bitter finish. Rich and creamy in the mouth.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2015 Tasted from a 12oz bottle into shaker. It appeared opaque black with a sudsy tan head, long-lasting with sheets of lace. Aromas of coffee, bakers cocoa, berries, roasted barley, burnt toast, fruity ale yeast esters. VERY smooth and creamy flavor while somehow simultaneously crisp and tart (although less so than Guinness) with a measured earthy, citrusy English-style hops bitterness. Hints of brown bread, fruitcake, toffee, caramelized brown sugar, peach cobbler, roasted marshmallows, chocolate milk. Overall impression is of a chocolate frosted long John donut. Medium body and carbonation, full-bodied bready mouthfeel, mild fruity tartness, complex aftertaste which eventually finished dry. Definitely leaves you wanting more. Delicious.

19th December 2009Opaque black stout, light brown head. Airy palate, a little dry. Dark malt, bitter chocolate. Lots of minerals. Finishes soft and semi dry with a trace of espresso. A light stout thats easy to drink but doesnt inspire.
It has a chocolate, roasted malt smell and tastes like bitter chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, licorice pretty good. Its a good traditional and stout thats a little sweeter than most.
Pours black. Thin brown head...aroma of sweet coffe beans....taste is excellent....sweet black licorice some nuts with a light spice zing finish...very smooth....
Smooth, nutty taste. Little spice in the middle. Pours as dark as any stout. Medium head

Pours dark black with a thick mocha head. Aroma of dark chocolate, light licorice and bitter hops. Taste follows with licorice subdued. A little light on the mouthfeel but pretty taste. I hate licorice but I like this beer. All the flavors meld together to form a pretty good beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2015 35,5 cl bottle @ home. Rated on 12.03.2011
Aroma has cocoa, some coffee and roasted malt. Flavour is slightly sweet with floury cocoa powder, some licorice and hints of coffee. Brilliant stuff for this ABV. 8+4+8+4+16=4.0. Re-rate: strong licorice notes, some soy sauce and coffee. Feels like a foreign stout. 8+4+8+3+15=3.8

Bottle from Breeze Thru. Pours a thick cola brownish-black with a nice tan head and great lacing. Aroma has chocolate and coffee, with some meat smoke and a bit of dark fruit. Taste has bittersweet bakers chocolate, roasted-to-burnt malts, lactose, molasses, meat juice. Some definite bitter strength throughout (coffee grounds?). It finishes bitter with some underlying sweetness, and with some length. Solid strong stout, nothing flashy. I do not remember why I missed this one when making my way through all the stouts on the right side of the chalkboard at the Eccentric Cafe in October, but glad to have it now.
Smooth and mild.  Chocolate and caramel notes, not overpowering.  A subtle stout, but not unpleasant in any way.  Not sure I can agree with a 100% rating, but certainly a very good offering.

Pours black with a small, brief head. Aroma is light, sweet roasted malt. Taste is subtle with slightly sweet and roast grain. No licorice flavor detected, but there is a cetain quality that might come from that ingredient. Has a surprising, lasting bitter finish but by no means overwhelming. Its a good stout, but not particularly stand out.

The pour is a very dark brown with a creamy brown head and substantial lacing.  The scent is chocolate and a sweet roasted note.  The taste is complex, with the roast and chocolate up front, a hint of licorice, in the middle, and a bitter finish at the end.  An excellent stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Pours a deep jet-black with decent head retention. Decent body, lots of medium-dry roasty goodness and a lingering bitterness (burnt?) to finish. Supposedly has licorice, but I couldnt detect any. Tasted really good with chocolate cake.
Subtle aromas.  Pours thin and black with a nice big head.  Complex flavors of chocolate and roastiness.  Nice bitter after taste in the mouth.  Smooth and creamy and very yummy.  Great stout.

Originally reviewed: 1/18/09. Thanks to Kiefdog for this extra brew in a recent trade! 

Pours a deep oil-like black with a large foamy tan head on top. Retention is perfect, leaving with it beautiful lacing rings. Smells average for a stout. Some chocolate, roasted malts, slight coffee scent to it. 

This tastes pretty good for a sweet stout. Again, the tastes mirror the scents pretty well as Im tasting dark chocolate, coffee, nuts, and some wine-like flavor. Mouthfeel is a little weak. Slightly watery. It looks thick, but goes down a little thin. All in all, not bad. Give it a try.
Smells great, nice roasted malts with hints of licorice and molasses. Dark and creamy and utterly delicious. One of the best stouts on the market.

Dark, dark pour and small medium tan head.  This is one smooth stout.  Not sweet, overtones of chocolate, caramel, licorice.  Roasty and smooth, with a complex, delightful finish.  Not too much alcohol, I could drink this one a lot.

Had in puerto Rico in my hotel a nice change of pace from all the medalla lights I had been pounding.  Pours deep dark brown with nice toasty nose.  Tastes of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and caramel.  Smooth creamy and quite drinkable.

Bottle. Looking gorgeous this one, black in color and with a dense, finger-thick tan head. Coffee, some chocolate and roasted malts, as well as beef stock on the nose. The flavor goes down the same path, roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Maybe a bit one tracked, but sure pleasant. Full body, creamy and dry on the palate, some metallic notes in the else roasted finish. Sure a very nice one, dangerously easy drinking too, at only 6% ABV. 110930

A: Pours a very dark brown color one expects from a stout. Its not impregnable to the light, but it works well. The head is a one finger dark cream color with good lacing, but lacking retention.

S: Very strong roast, espresso, and chocolate notes, with the licorice appearing as a secondary characteristic to the main scent. Amazingly in your face aroma.

T: The flavors are quite good, if not on the same level as the smell. Theres an opening of wood and vanilla, followed by a sudden, welcome upsurge of roasted malt and chocolate. Finally, theres a combination of a vegetal component and some subtle licorice on the finish. The flavors progress smoothly and create a good balance, being neither overly sweet nor bitter, and tastes bigger than its 6% might suggest.

M: Good thickness overall, with a smooth, semi-creamy body and little dryness on the back end. Carbonation is low.

O: Definitely a great stout. Its not perfect, but it genuinely makes me wish I didnt have to drive to Virginia to get it (then again, its worth going a state over to pick it up...)

A rich and creamy stout...pours a very dark brown with a tannish head.  A chocolatey flavor  with perhaps a little toffee flavor.  Overall very tasty, much better than the first time I had it as well.  Cheers!

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with James and Tony, Pours a deep, opaque brown, bordering on black, with a tan lacing. Aroma of chocolate, toffee, caramel, roasted malts, molasses, and crazy hints of marshmallow. Full bodied with a thick, rich, almost sticky palate. Finishes with a roasty spiciness. Great stout from Bells.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2015 355 ml bottle.
Rated on 20110312.
Pours black color with small head. Aroma of oat, chocolate, roasted malts and caramel. Flavor of chocolate, oat, roasted malts and mild ripe fruits. Excellent.
5337

Aromatics start and end with coffee, in between you get chocolate, & malt. great use of the ingredients to make aromatics. Pours jet black with off white had and heavy lacing. Taste is straight cocoa, coffee and malt. Fantastic palate and overall a great beer a great stout!

Jet black color with a fairly tan head. Very sweet tasting stout with licorice, burnt malts, cocoa, coffee, and burnt barley, accompanied by a bittersweet flavor. The body is both heavy and thick; the carbonation is rather strong but it goes well with the flavor once it warms up. This is one of the best stouts Ive ever had and its worth checking out!
12oz bottle -pours black with khaki head and nice lacing.  Nose is roasted malts and chocolate/coffee.  Flavor is roasted malts.  Taste is bitter.  dry finish.  identical to cold espresso with booze.

[Thanks to MatSciGuy]. 12fl. bottle. Black colour with a nice and good formation of a creamy and tan head with a perfect duration and nice lasting on the glass. Aroma has notes of licorice, toasted malts and coffee. Flavor has moderate notes of dark coffee and licorice, slightly spicy sensation on the tongue, dense on palate. The final is moderate bittery, maintaining the black chocolate notes. Carbonation is soft. Body is medium to high. Texture is oily.

Probably the darkest black pour I have ever seen. Quickly dissipating head. Aroma is very roasty with notes of licorice, coffee, and tobacco. The scent is reminiscent of Mikkeller Beer Geek Brunch Weasel, which is high praise. The flavor is wonderfully roasty without being burnt. Notes of bitter chocolate and espresso with a touch of sweetness. The lower ABV is nice compared to other stouts that have this much flavor. Nice beefy mouthfeel and lower carb.

Nice chocolate and roasted coffee aroma.  Sweet and gummy, with a wisp of booze finishing the aroma.  Beautiful black with a hint of brown at the edges when held to light.  Head is massive and brown.  Head lasts forever and then leaves scant cover across the top.  Full flavored with roast, chocolate stick, caramelized brown sugar and chocolate mousse.  Tannic on the finish, in a good way.  Taste lingers forever.

Standard Market,  draft.  Black with a creamy tan head. Vanilla bean and coconut aroma.  Coffee and sweet espresso right away, roasty malt backbone gives a nice balance.  Complex, flavorful, well balanced.

Pours an opaque dark black, perhaps the darkest stout I have tried. Nice mocha head with a nose of chocolate, espresso and malt. Taste is chocolate with some bitterness to even the taste. Finish is dry and somewhat lasting. Nice DARK stout from a premier brewery. Cheers ! Quaff Score ( drinkable with hearty enjoyment ) 9 / 10

Pours a dark black with a tan head and aroma of roasted malt and chocolate. Taste is sweet and toasty, of roasted malt, dark chocolate, and coffee with slight bitterness as well. Flavors come together really nicely making this a drinkable and enjoyable stout.

Bottle- Pours a virtual black color with a good creamy head that fades slowly to ample lacing. Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and bit of caramel sweetness. Initial taste of burnt coffee, roasted malt and bittersweet chocolate. Has a lingering finish and a clean finish. Full body, thick, smooth and creamy. Easy drinker and an excellent stout. Well worth a try.

12oz bottle. Pours a jet black color with a tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, coffee. Creamy on the palate with smooth carbonation. Flavor is sweet, roasty, some bitter coffee, a little smokey, with a little, bitter finish. An excellent, easy drinking stout.

This stout pours as black as night with a lite tan head. Aroma is full of roasted coffee notes and malt. Taste follows the aroma closely, lots of coffee, toffee and roasted goodness. Mouth feel is initially syrupy but clears up towards the end resulting in a very drinkable brew.

Date: March 16, 2012 Mode: Bottle Source: Heritage Description: Opaque dark brown/black pour with large amount of off-white head and some lacing. Aroma was roasted malt, chocolate and roasted coffee. Taste was consistent with aroma . Light to medium bodied, pretty smooth and creamy with some carbonation though.

Mold aroma and a deep black appearance leads into a satisfying taste of mocha and incredible mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

I am not sure how to rate this at all. It has a nice flavor but it's almost too balanced! Not a single thing wrong.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle. Black colour with a tan head. Aroma is caramel, coffee, roasted malt. Flavour is coffee, roasted malt, hop, chocolate. Balanced easy drinkable beer.

From notes.  First reviewed 10/228/2011.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a pint glass. Batch 9984.

With a quick pour, my glass fills with a dark brown ebony liquid with a viscous look and a creamy tan head. Eventually it fades to a collar and leaves just a bit of lace. 

Roasted malt, a bit of smoke, roast coffee, and a bit of unsweetened dark chocolate dominate the nose.

The taste has a little sweetness sneak through along with the mostly unsweetened dark chocolate and roasted malt. The malt has some light burnt character to it, and there is some milk creaminess to it. The finish has a bit of licorice and a bitter coffee flavor.

The creaminess to the mouthfeel is nice. Too often stouts on the lighter part of the ABV spectrum just seem watery to me, but this has some character to it. The carbonation has a mostly creamy nature, but there are a few stray bubbles that are noticeably fizzy. The body is medium to full, and there is a soft stickiness to go along with the chocolate in the flavor.

This is definitely one of the more enjoyable stouts I have had in this ABV range. I would definitely have a few of these while I sat at a pub.

Bottle.  This is a good stout.  Black in appearance with a dark tan head.  Light aroma of chocolate and coffee.  The taste is much more apparent.  It is heavily favored towards coffee, with a hint of chocolate, and has a smoky aftertaste.  Not my favorite Bells, but very good.

Location/Date:Bottle split with Bryan on 3/09/2012.
Appearance: Pours perfect black opaque head.
Aroma: Aroma is roasty of malt and chocolate.
Taste: Really toasty, hint of bitterness, some chocolate.
Palate:Smooth body, lingering aftertaste.
Summary: A really nice stout that is tasty yet not super boozy.

On tap @ the Beer Seller.
Black brew with a creamy tan head.  Nose of oats, Hersheys syrup, and some roast.  Smooth and creamy - chocolate and coffee with bits of smoke.
Pours a deep dark brown with a very thin head.  A very smooth taste of coffee and a hint of chocolate is followed by a quick aftertaste of smoked malt which has a touch of bitterness.  Well built.

12 ounce bottle purchased almost a year and a half ago at Sun Devil Liquors in Phoenix.  Pours a true pitch black, possibly the first non-imperial stout that I have seen pour so dark.  The two full fingers of creamy dark brown head have good retention.  Aroma of tar, smoke, musty dark roasted grains, and a hint of milk chocolate.  Flavor of ashy soy sauce, hard roasted malts, leather, and some bitter coffee.  Strange astringent finish.  This bottle certainly appears to be INFECTED as everything seems off and I am finding almost nothing that other reviewers are finding.  That is unfortunate as I was really looking forward to this world-class stout...will have to try and find another bottle and re-rate.  (1693, 668)

Pours a strong black coffee color with a medium tan cap with orange hues. A one finger cap quickly dissipates to lacings on top. Aroma is chocoloate, coffee, orange, and fusal hops. Flavor is maltose malt, toffee, chocolate, coffee, orange, and roasted barley. Mild citrus and fusal hops in background. Very good beer with lots of toasty roasted barley.
Pours near black with a medium tan head. Big roasty aroma of coffee and chocolate. Taste is similar with more licorice and bitterness.
Bottle from Bells.  Black, thin head.  Pleasant roasty aroma.  Smooth taste up front, followed by a roasty bitter finish.  I liked this, but not as much as I thought I would, given the high ratings.

12oz bottle.  Pours black with a medium tan head.  Slightly sweet aroma with roasted malts, chocolate, coffee and caramel.  Nice roasty flavor with dark chocolate, coffee, caramel and a hint of smoke.  Smooth and slightly sweet finish.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Black body, large medium-brown head, good retention, and decent lacing.

S: Large roasted malt component, coffee, chocolate, and a bit of licorice.

T: Roasted coffee is the most prominent note, with general roasted notes, chocolate, licorice and caramel following.

M: Medium bodied, nice dry, slightly bitter finish.

O: A hell of a lot of flavor is packed into this 6% ABV stout.  More complex than many imperial stouts.

Appearance: blackish with brown around edges, medium tan head. Aroma: milk chocolate, roasted malts. Taste: milk chocolate up front moving into a more bitter cocoa flavor in the end, leaves that almost hoppy bitter aftertaste (in a pleasant way). Mouthfeel: medium body, mild-med. carbonation. Overall: really quite delicious. I like the complexity and bitterness. Solid stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 A - pours dark opaque chocolate brown with nice dark brown high head. S - aromas of burned malts and licorice up front. Hints of milk chocolate, molasses and hazelnut. M - creamy mf, medium bodied. Lingering chocolate malty ending. Slightly sweet throughout. Nice hint of bitter on the palate. T - burned malts and chocolate on the nose. Strong complex palate. Dark caramel, nuttiness, oakiness, chocolate, cream. Nice bitterness on the palate. Lingering malty ending with hints of leather, vegetal notes and nice dark chocolate. O - great plain ol stout. Creamy chocolatey goodness. Great beer 8-

Aroma of dark malt.  Pours a nice thick head.  Tastes of coffee, molasses.  A little bit of a metallic finish on the palate.  Great stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark chocolate color with thin mocha head. Very nice lacing. Black licorice and roasted malts on the nose. More anise along with espresso on the palate. A hint of dirt or mud on as well. Nice roasted malt finish.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2012 This is a nice stout... not sour (as ive had from several lately...) it there is liqourous here... you cant taste it.  nice stout good aroma chocolate coffee.  Sweet stout, very well balanced... tiny bit bitter but it comes and goes... a real winner! 

Updated... I upgraded palate taste and overall by one.  Taste really is spot on, dont know why I was hard on this one in the past.
Cask at Rich Os. Opaque black with a thick dark tan head. Sweet roasty aroma. Soft cask mouth feel, firm bitterness, coffee, chocolate.
Alittle malty for my taste but overall a nicely roasted stout.Mocha head prevails.

Thanks to the generosity of Savvy1982, I finally get to try this landmark stout! As a tribute to Savvy, Ill even comment on the glass from which I sipped it. Poured a jet black into my hefty chalice from La Naufrageur, and raised a firm brown head. Bonus points for leaving a cool island of foam shaped like a rising phoenix near the end. Aroma is mouthwatering sweet milk chocolate, hazelnuts, coffee, and molasses. Dense flavourul palate, rich with chocolate, cream, dark caramel, and nuts. Velvety texture. Roasty dry bitter finish. Certainly worthy of the accolades!
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: 12 ounce bottle into signature pint glass, bottled 9/14/2011.  Pours pitch black color, with a nice 2 finger fairly dense tan head with great retention that reduces to a nice cap that lingers.  Some decent lacing clinging to the glass.  Aromas of big milk chocolate, caramel, coffee, roasted malt, light herbal hops, and a hint of licorice.  Nice well balanced aromas with good strength.  Taste of big milk chocolate, coffee, caramel, roasted malt, pine, herbal hops, and a bit of spiciness.  Good amount of bitterness on the finish with lingering notes of milk chocolate, caramel, pine, and herbal spiciness for a bit.  Very robust flavors for 6%, with great balance.  Medium carbonation and body; with a nice creamy mouthfeel.  Hardly any alcohol presence except for a slight warming after the finish.  Overall this is an excellent and highly robust stout.  Very drinkable with great flavor balance.

Poured almost black with a nice light brown head and some lacing. Aroma of roasted malts and dried fruit. Thick malt flavors with a creaminess, a lot going on, smooth and with a slight bitter finish. Great beer.
Poured black, with thin, tan, foamy head.  Slight coffee aroma.  Taste is mild chocolate and coffee, with only a small hop bite.  Creamy palate.  A great stout.

Poured into a snifter.

4.0 A: Black color. Two fingers of dense frothy, light brown head. Retention is average and a good sized ring of lacing is left.

4.5 S: Great nose on this. This has the coffee with creme thing going. Plenty of coffee with a vanilla like milkiness. Also lots of chocolate to accompany a moderate, though supple roastiness. Licorice adds yet another layer of complexity. Really pleasant.

4.5 T: Taste is much like the nose. Plenty of coffee, chocolate, vanilla creme, and licorice, which is a bit stronger in the taste. The roastiness if more aggressive, but still in a good range. Really tasty. 

4.0 M: Lighter medium body. Good moderate carbonation. Creamy for the body, but I would prefer a bit more body and creaminess.

4.5 D: Really great beer. This one surprised me. I wasnt expecting it to be this stellar.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 11-19-2011 18:37:42

Bottle. Licorice sweet veggie scent with a frothy head, slow to disolve, with a dark black body. The palates medium body was complimented by a crisp texture Im not used to with a stout, but I found it quickly pleasing to the tongue. The biting coffee taste gave way to a malty, hay aftertaste. 

So whos the weird guy on the bottle? Im not sure, but the beer inside is impeccable.
Interesting little stout. Easy to drink, not too heavy, but still nice and flavorful. I was able to down a couple back to back without any problem.
Bottle. Black with small beige head. Aroma is roasted malts, chocolate and coffee, Flavour is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, little liquorice, medium sweet, hops and medium bitter,

Trade by Beerbill, thanks. Almost black with a beige. Aroma is sweet, roasted malt, coffee and dark chocolate. Flavor is quite sweet and rather bitter. Dry and roasted rather bitter finish. Smooth. 271211
Bottle. Huge creamy head with excellent duration. Color is black. Aroma and taste are nice and creamy roast malt, licorice, chocolate, coffee and hops.

Bottle. Black with fleeting head and thick sugar beading.   Aroma is a lovely soft roasted malt and a little [green] raisin.  Taste is medium to heavy to sweet, slightly lactic, and ends pleasantly smoky chocolate bitter. Body is fairly light and smooth with fair carbonation.  If there was a tradition of a German stout I would think this would compare with the best in terms of nose and palate.

Bottle. Pours black with a small off-white head. The nose is smoky, some charred coffee, dark malts, some coffee. The taste is moderately sweet, but dry, floral hops are very well represented. Smooth, slightly acidic. The palate is medium, balanced well. Overall, a good stout. This didnt blow my socks off, though. Re-rate?

Had this multiple times not sure where the rating is!  Basically expedition stouts little brother in terms of alcohol, but not flavor.  Dark, roasty, very smooth, very drinkable.  Its got good hops, some chocolate, and a very smooth somewhat dry finish.

Great dark chocolate start, delicious coffee finish. Didnt get much of a taste for the supposed licorice, but that is probably just me. One of the best stouts I have ever had, Ill be enjoying this every winter. Time to find out how it ages!

Pour from a 12 oz bottle. Inky dark brew with one finger of brown head that settles down to a small, persistent head. Ample lacing. Aroma of roasted grains, coffee. Taste is sweet malts at the very start quickly overpowered by roated grains, burnt malts, coffee all blending together in a subtly complex manner. Creamy rich and satisfying palate. Most excellent.

12 oz bottle.  Pours opaque black with a tan head.  Smells strongly of chocolate with a bit of coffee (what else is new?).  More of a coffee smell, I think, very roasty.  Creamy enough mouthfeel, though its not under-carbonated.

Purchased as a 12 oz. bottle from Barunis Bar and Hotel in Baden, PA. Pours dark brown to black with medium carbonation and about an eighth of an inch of foam.  A bit of an updraft on the taste through the nose is my only criticism, otherwise, this is a perfect example of a stout well done.  Perfectly fine and humbly crafted, without any excess or pretentiousness.

12oz bottle from Picks poured into an English Pint. Batch 10455 Pours black with about a finger of dark tan head. Aroma of coffee, chocolate and a bit of caramel. Taste is medium bitter. Strongly coffee with some resin notes. Medium bodied with a creamy texture. Lively carbonation and a long bitter coffee finish. Overall, very good. I will be drinking this one again.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2014 roasty coffee and dark chocolate  aroma.  taste is wood, chocolate, coffee, roasted malt and a slight vegetable quality.  the finish is very dry.  I don?t taste the licorice but a nice beer nonetheless.

Pours black with a thick chocolate head. Aroma is chocolate, spicy, some coffee, brown sugar, a little dry and grassy with a hint of smoke. Flavor is sharp but smooth, bittersweet chocolate, creamy, mild spice; subtle smoky and licorice notes.

Sampled down at the beach. Damn is this good. Awesome black pour with good dark tan head and some lacing. Pretty much a spot on perfect example of the style.  Big bold and roasty. Marshmellow, hints of molasses, leather, and dark chocolate.  Creamy mouthfeel. Semi bitter chocolate finish. Great beer.

Beautiful dark, espresso colored pour with a creamy head. Picturesque in the glass. Hearty stout flavor with a hint of chocolate and even a coffee undertone. Given to me by cousin Chris while celebrating Thanksgiving in Ann Arbor.
A great example of the style.  Creamy, black coloration, thick head.  Chocolate and perhaps licorice (molasses?) Tried from a bottle offered by Nick Cunigan during the Dutch Republic readings group.

Mycket diskret och mjölkig doft.
Ingen komplex smak, men stora toner av stark kaffe. Lång eftersmak med mycket kaffe, men tyvärr är det bara eftersmaken som är värd att skriva om

Bottle from River City Cellars, Richmond. Almost black, with a tight, off-white head. Intense, black coffee and liquorice aroma with a touch of rich sweetness. Flavours of dense chocolate, charred malts and brown sugar, with a touch of warming alcohol in the finish. Excellent.

Bottle provided by FullObs....THX..... it pours pitch black with a small light brown head.....the aroma is coffee, roasted malt, caramel and some chocolate..... the flavor is roasted malt, coffee and light smoke.... nice creamy texture..... full body....  lovely stout.....

next up on my quest to appreciate a good stout.. this beauty poured out a deep.. deep brown (appeared black) with a generous tan head. aroma of roasted malts, caramel, coffee and chocolate overflowing from the glass. great mouth feel! creamy and full bodied. great, but not overpowering today flavor up front. smooth chocolate going down with some hints of molasses and coffee on the finish. good stuff!

Considering this is just a normal stout and not an imperial it has a surprisingly bold flavor.  Not much aroma to this one.  The appearance is jet black with a thin tan head.  Taste of roasty chocolate and a hint of coffee at the end.  Overall a very nice stout, not near the caliber of Expedition Stout but an acceptable substitute if it isnt available.

Black pour with a thin tan head. Burnt coffee aroma with a very small touch of malt sweetness. Excellent palate, creamy and full. This is my first Bells stout and Im very impressed.Toasted malt flavors with chocolate/coffee at the front and a little bitterness bringing up the rear. Excellent beer.

Bottle from Binnys Beverage Depot - Downtown, Chicago, October 2011. Rating number 1500. 

Black, thick liquid but not like an Imperial Stout. Creamy and tan head. Aroma and taste of ash, wood, licorice, chocolate and toffee. Nice body on this one. Good mouth feel, I liked this beer, descent stuff indeed.
jet black thought it was kinda light tasting for a stout not alot of the roastyness some have. crisp with no lingering flavor

A black beer with a medium tan head.  The aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee.  The flavor is roasted coffee with an almost burnt taste and a bitter finish.  There are definite highlights here, but nothing too outstanding.
Tap.  Dark black pour, creamy lasting head and a slightly chocolatey aroma.  Flavor is a good meld of dark chocolate, vanilla, light coffee and finished with some lactose & sweetness.  Very good!

Just glorious, and makes me consider whether Bells has ever made a bad stout. A bit of chocolate and darkly roasted coffee hits your nose moments after removing the bottle cap. Dark, dark body and a fluffy head prevent close inspection. The full-bodied sweetness is followed by a hint of bitterness, which makes the stout not as heavy as might be expected. A true classic, and one more reason for me to adore my sons for purchasing a six pack of this for my birthday.

Bottle/12oz - Pours a dark black/brown in color with a small tan head that faded to a thin tan head over the beer.  Aroma is strong of dark roasted malts and chocolate with just a hint of the alcohol.  Flavor is a mix of roasted malts, chocolate, a small amount of chocolate and, again, just a hint of the alcohol.  Finish is slightly bitter with plenty of roasted maltiness... excellent!

Nice aroma of roast, dark chocolate, brown sugar.  the appearance is deep black, light tan head.  The flavor is milk chocolate, roast, molasses, some wood.  Not as sweet as I might have expected.  Medium to medium/thick in body. The finish is roast, pine hops.  A little dry.  Quite good.

Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma is roasty, coffee, earthy and dark chocolate.  Taste is light bitter.  Medium mouthfeel with a creamy texture.   Overall this is a great stout, it has all the elements that work well together.

Bouteille 12oz, courtoisie de SlovakSniper. De couleur noire et opaque. Nez de chocolat au lait et de crème brûlée (moyennement lactique), de malt rôti, moyen de café avec des notes de réglisse noire ainsi que des traces de vanille, de fruits (cerises noires) et de mélasse sucrée. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen ainsi quune texture riche et moyennement crémeuse. Goût de chocolat au lait (léger-moyen lactique) avec des notes de crème et de réglisse noire ainsi que des traces fruitées (cerises noires) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût de malt rôti (faibles notes brûlées et terreuses) avec des traces de mélasse sucrée et de chocolat noir puis un léger-moyen goût de café sinstalle progressivement jusquen finale, où lon y retrouve également des notes de houblon herbeux ainsi que de faibles traces boisées (fumée de bois). Post-goût long, moyen-léger amer de rôti avec un goût de chocolat au lait ainsi que des notes de café et danis.

Quality stout pour from bottle into Maudite glass. Attractive 1.5" light brown head on oil-black beer. Aroma is chocolate, balanced with strong malt and alcohol. Great depth of flavor: roast malt, burnt toast, chocolate, some coffee, and the licorice just showing enough (but not too much--Im not a licorice fan anyway). Really covers the whole spectrum of traditional stout flavors with poise. Finish rounds it out with that fantastic earthiness that I enjoy. This is a fantastic example of the style.

12 oz bottle. What a great stout!
A: chocolate, roasted malts, malty
T: bitter chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, licorice, slightly malty

Pours opaque dark brown with small tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, licorice, molasses, and dark roasted malts.  Taste is bitter black malt with just a hint of caramel and a dry finish.  Its good but not great...too one-dimensional for my liking.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma of caramel, roasted malt, coffee, hay and malt. Flavor is sweet and malty with some roasted and burnt notes also some chocolate. Medium body, average carboantion. Nice stout.

12 oz. Bottle.  Pours dark with nice head, very nice appearance.  Aroma is coffee, choc. & faint liquorice.  I dont like liquorice, but this didnt offend the senses.  Taste was woody, toasty, with hints of coffe, choc. & liqourice like the nose.  I enjoyed this stout very much but I actually longed for a stronger punch...no complaints though. A great brew that I would easily recommend to any stout lovers.

Dark brown pour.  Dark tan head lingered a bit.  Earthy aroma with a hint of cherry.  Opens up to a milk chocolate as it warms.  Smooth malty flavor, easy to drink.  Lingers on the tongue for a while.  I really like this one.

Bottle. Great pour. Roasted malt, coffee, chocolate, peat. Wonderful mouthfeel, so substantial and bitterness flows over your tongue toward the edges like spreading warmth. Massive amounts of flavor. For me, this could be a little sweeter. Still, it all adds up. This is a well-rounded, hard-to-fault beer.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2011 Poured from a bottle into a pint glass at Dema (Westin) in Detroit, Mich. Color was coffee caramel. More than an inch of head. Healthy amount of lacing. Lots of film on the sides.

Smelled mostly of roasted coffee malts.

Coffee heavy on the taste. Malty, smoky finish.

Full body. Creamy texture. Lively carbonation. Almost felt kind of fake. Flattened out at the end.

I couldnt get behind this as much as the other three Bells I had (Pale Ale, Two Hearted, Amber Ale), but that wont stop me from trying more Bells.

deep dark brown, respectable tan head, bubbly and rocky, but quickly dissipating.  quite a bit of sticky tan lace.  nose of roasty malt, fruity notes, chocolate malt.  flavor has a bitter coffee note and a more mild fruity note.  full bodied, thick mouth feel, coffee bitter (as opposed to hop bitter) finish.  the flavor is much more interesting than the nose suggests.  a fairly complex brew with roasty, fruity, chocolate and winey notes with a rather sharp sharp feeling on the tongue.  rather enjoyable.

This stout pours almost black with an average brown head that disipates, but not completely.  There are notes of chocolate, roasted coffee, resin, something earthy, and licorice.  I am not fond of black licorice, and the notice of the use brewers licorice was a source of trepidation.  However, the licorice complements the other aromas and flavors.  It feels soft in the mouth, a real pleasure to drink.

Quite delicious.  Pours pitch black with a light head.  Roasty on the nose, but even more roast on the tongue.  Big coffee flavor, little sweetness but I didnt get the licorice as advertised (and thank goodness).  Love the mouthfeel, sticks with ya.  Enjoyed everything about this beer.

Taste of roasted malt and some licorice in there. Late kick from the hops, too.

Smooth, yet still big and chewy, its a mouthful. Very complex with bitter chocolate, hints of charred wood, and those anise notes. Maybe even some grape in there, too. It all leads to a dry, chalky, woody, lingering finish.

Pours a midnight black with a thick mane of light brown foam. Nose is coffee and molasses. Very rich and creamy on the palate, its flavor is of coffee, dark roasted nuts and malt, with hints of semi-sweet chocolate and caramalized molasses. A big bold stout that can stand up a straw. Well done Bells! A meal unto itself although it can be paired with pretzels and nuts or with game meat such as venison or bear.

(bottle)  Cant believe I never rated this beer before, as Ive had it multiple times.  Anyway, pours jet black with a medium sized dark tan head that leaves a bit of lacing and retains fairly well.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate ganache, sumatra coffee, peanut butter. licorice, and faint vanilla.  Flavor has plenty of roasted peaunts, sumatra coffee, chocolate, roasted malt, and molasses.  Flavor finishes roasty, almost veering towards astringency, but reigns it in to maintain an even roasted finish.  Mouthfeel is full with light carbonation.  This is definitely a classic.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2011 A brilliant stout! Probably the best Ive had below 9% abv. Pours black with a very small tan head. Nose is roasted malt, coffee, brown sugar. Taste is again coffee, and a very balanced malty sweetness with a subtle bitter hoppy coffee finish. This rivals many much more powerful imperial stouts! An overall great beer, and thanks to the (relatively) low abc, this is one you dont have to worry too much about consuming on a weekday night!

Bottle, poured into a snifter.  Dark brown.  Creamy coffee head.  Opaque.  Wonderful aroma: light, powdery cocoa, freshly burnt wood, licorice, blueberry, traces of smoke.  Full bodied; creamy texture.  Flavour of peanut brittle, slightly burnt.  More licorice with coffee grounds and hot chocolate mix.  Some smoke in there too.  Long, toasty finish with bitter coffee and burnt wood.
real nice roasty aroma. lotsa roast chocolate coffee and caramel malts. drinkable. a little light, but a very nice beer.

tap. pours black with a light tan creamy head. aroma is roasted malt, coffee, and black licorice. flavor is the same as aroma but a bit stronger and has some bitter hops at the end. has some descent lacing and perfect body for the style.

Aroma of coffee, vanilla, toffee, and maybe molasses.  Pours thick but not like an Imperial Stout.  Taste resembles the aromas, with maybe semi-sweet chocolate.  Its a bit sweet.  One of the very best stouts I have had.  I have had this one  many times, so its not a one-hit rating.  I will buy it again!

Poured from a bottle. Appearance is a dark brown with a light tan head. Aroma is dark toasty malt with accents of chocolate, cream, marshmallow,  and coffee. Taste is roasted marshmallow with hints of coffee and chocolate. Smooth and velvety mouthfeel. Nice beer...

Bottle @ Akkurat, Stockholm. Pours opaque black with a large, beige and long lasting head, thats leaving some excellent lacings.Nose of coffee, bitter chocolateand dark fruits.Flavour of coffee, bitter chocolate and again dark fruit notes. Full bodie, creamy to oily texture and soft carbonation. Its an outstandin stout
Bottle pours dark brown with huge thick brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts and black licorice.  Flavors of dark, roasted malts with hints of licorice, dark chocolate, and molasses.
Bottle. Very nice stout. Dark, not much carbonation. Creamy and bitter. Very nice.

Pours absolutely black with a small and quickly dissipating tan head. Aroma is roasted coffee and chocolate with the faintest hint of the advertised licorice. Taste is more bitter than sweet, but a healthy dose of both. Palate is rich and impressive as it gets your whole mouth involved in the experience. Any stout enthusiast should have this in their everyday rotation for sure. Likewise, fans of other styles looking for a change of pace need look no further.

I am always a little worried about a new stout as I have tasted some really bad ones in the past. There beer however, did not let me down. I overall taste of this stout was delicious. I would gladly drink this beer anytime any day.

Bottle. dark with a large off white head from the pour. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, malt, dark chocolate and some cocoa. Taste is similar. lots of cocoa,chocolate, coffee and burnt wood. All well balanced. nice bitterness that lingers.

Quite a well-crafted brew! According to the label it is made with brewers licorice, but you would hardly know it because there are so many other flavors to enjoy. Its just a nice, roasty stout with notes of chocolate, licorice, wood, vanilla, etc. None of the flavors is overpowering, they compliment each other perfectly.

A- Pours a ½ finger mocha head dissipates quickly to thin ring around the glass, dark black color, opaque, splotchy lacing.
S- Unappealing Metallic smell, slight coffee aroma, slight roastiness as well.
T- Some bitterness, roasted malts, coffee, slight chocolate, taste very similar to the aroma not the best tasting beer. 
M- Medium mouth feel, moderate carbonation, crisp finish.
O- This is an interesting beer, not the best from bells, definitely would not buy again.
12oz bottle. Absolutely pitch black, thin brown head leaving lacing. Great, creamy texture, and roasty aroma. Coffee bean and light chocolate aroma. Mild bitterness. Very flavorful and interesting.

This is one hell of a stout. Pours black with a two finger head that laces the whole way through. Aroma of chocolate and smoke. Taste is very smooth almost milk stout texture but a bite at the end to bring it back around.

Pours near-black with a minimal amount of quickly dissipating, dark tan head.  Aroma is more subtle than I expected with smoke, coffee, and vanilla dominating.  This is a little thinner than some of the other great stouts, but what it lacks in body, it makes up in flavor--slight dry sweetness with the perfect amout of bitterness complimenting the smoky, earthy, roasty, cocoa powder-like notes.  Excellent brew.

Bottle...  Poured black with a khaki head. A wonderful, definitive stout with loads of roast, malts, dark chocolate, licorice, and coffee tones.  Molasses, charred grain flavors, and lots of roast in the finish.

Pours thick and a rich black with light tan head.  Aroma is chocolate caramel and light hops.  Taste is balanced sweetness, chocolate, roastyness, anise, and light piney hops.  Great stout.  2nd best of the category.

12oz bottle pours inky black with brownish edges and a thick one finger beige head.  Aroma is chocolate, smoke, coffee with cream, and earthy hops.  Taste is extra smooth bittersweet chocolate, smoke, earth, and a lingering coffee finish.  Body is medium-heavy with soft carbonation and a dry bitter finish.  Overall, this is a great stout, perfectly balanced between roastiness and chocolatey sweetness.
Not as smoky as their Porter. A bit more hops and slightly sweeter. Not much head. Has good flowery aroma.

OH MY GOD THANK YOU JEFF!!! What a wonderful treat we have here.  Dark chocolate brown with a good cap. Smell is phenomenal and very simple what was unexpected. Coconut I love that aroma in a stout, Ill have to agree with my friend here and say a cross between red and black liquorish, lots of sweet toasted malts. YUM YUM smooth. Taste also simple but yummy. Toasted sweet malts, sweet thickness, hints of some sour, trace milk chocolate, slight bitter. Near perfect beer. P.S. what the hell is with the scary looking burn victim on the label, looks like the dad from That 70s show tried to put out a camp fire with his face.

Quality product.  Excellent stout.  Pours beautiful black with brown head, that disappeared quicker than I normally would like.  Good balance, roasty malt flavor, not real bitter, caramel, chocolate and licorice flavor.  Not heavy, a drinkable stout, even for a non stout drinker.

Bought during RBSG 2010. Dumped out an obvious black brew with a medium to dark brown head that is somewhat foamy and leaves a ring with tiny speckly lacing. The aroma is awesome. It is, however, not complex which is fine by me. There is a great cross between red and black licorice, roasted coconut, nuts and almonds. Excellent. Simplistic. Maybe I held on to this bottle a bit late but whatever. Soft roast taste, oatmeal, mild licorice, plenty of malts, bit of sour tanginess that I might put on the age of the bottle. Fairly smooth. Tasty stuff.

Poured a nice opaque black, with a thick tan head. Scent of honey dew, chocolate, caramel and hops arouse the palate. Thats right. The taste was creamy and smooth, with notes of dark chocolate and lightly roasted malts with a splash of caramel. The finish was dry and bitter, like a cold black coffee. Overall a great stout, and not anywhere as aggressive as it looks.

Tulip pour. This one poured a nice dark black with a thin head (not a very vigorous pour) and had some creamy and sweet lacing around the edges. The aroma was hypnotic, producing sweet roast and smokey aromas with some chocolate and coffee. Smoked bacon, chocolate, roasted hops, and solid dry bitters made this one a nice overall stout. Not as sweet as the nose would lead on.

The nose is all about the bittersweet chocolate (with just a hint of burnt coffee). Based on this alone, I expected this stout to be a bit on the sweet side. I was quite wrong. It is surprisingly dry given the smell. Despite that, it tastes of a nice rich maltiness, chocolate, coffee, and a bit of a dark almost "woody" flavor. The pour is black with a dark tan head; the mouthfeel is unsurprisingly smooth with a nice thick body to it. Overall, its a very good stout and worth buying again.

Nice, easygoing stout with an awful lot of stuff going on.  Roasty with a Raisinette flavor backing it up, and all the while licorice is slipping into the seams.  The finish is well-roasted yet hoppy enough to provide a coffee-like bitterness.  Good but the licorice-soaked chocolate raisin thing gets to be a bit much.  (10/08)

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2015 Aroma of roasted malts and chocolate. Simple, yet powerfully effective. Rich taste of 75% chocolate and coffee, with a dry finish that I just wish were a little longer. Great, no-nonsense stout.
Bottle. Coffee, dark roasted malt, molasses, chocolate aroma. Black with a moderate tan head and fairly decent lacing. Roasted malt, coffee, molasses, nice dry bitter finish. Medium bodied.

12oz bottle from Plaza liquors in Tucson 
Appearance: Pours dark brown, almost black, with a medium sized beige head and some lacing 
Aroma: Roasted coffee, chocolate and molasses 
Taste: Roasted malts, coffee, ashy, chocolate and grainy 
Nice, lots of roasted coffee.

12 oz bottle from Horrocks Farm Market in Lansing, batch #9984. Served in an English pint with Bells Special Double Cream Stout side-by-side. Pours clear reddish black with a tall light brown head. The head fades slowly to a bare cover and leaves a small amount of fine lace. The nose has big notes of roasted malts, caramel and chocolate, along with touches of molasses and licorice. The flavour is mostly dry with plenty of roast malts and just a touch of caramel sweetness. Hops provide adequate balance, but are not emphasized. The licorice comes through in the middle and carries through to the finish, which is long and mostly roasty. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, milky texture and soft carbonation. Overall, a very nice stout with a nice licorice accent. More subtle and interesting than the Special Double Cream Stout. 2011-05-17

Pours a very dark brown body with a lacing, fuzzy tan head.  Aromas of very roasted dark Malta and dark sugar.  Flavor is much the same.  Finish is slightly dry but the licorice lasts well after the swallow.

Bottle.  Pours a deep dark black with a bubbly tan head the recedes fairly quick.  Aroma is of toasted malt and little hints of chocolate.  Tastes thick with the roasted malt and chocolate flavor.  Catching bits of coffee and sweet caramel as well.   Overall a really nice stout, and just slightly nicer than its  Bells brother, the Double Cream Stout.  Very nice enjoyment before hitting the beach today.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a brown head. Aromas of roasted malt, licorice, caramel, molasses. Taste is very smooth with more roast and a hint of vanilla. Finishes dry with bitter coffee. Very nice.

12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  It pours midnight black with a small tan head with average lacing.  The aromas are of roasted malt and slightly sweet coffee.  Flavors that dominate are roasted malts, slightly bitter, with notes of coffee on the long dry finish.  This has a creamy mouthfeel and is not nearly as sweet as expected, actually not really sweet at all.  Overall, a nice stout, that has resemblance to Bells Cream Stout, but is much drier and less sweet.  Good job on this one.

Finally getting around to rating this!  Consumption of this product has happened many times (fresh and aged), yet the most recent was a 4 year old bottle, fridge cellared.  Pours a dark black, with brown tones on the head.  Epic dark malts and roasty milk chocolate flavors scream off the nose.  Flavors bring coffee, dark and milk chocolate, roasty bitterness, and plenty of subsiding hop notes to the palate, all the while being extremely creamy in the mouth.  I love this brew!!

Pours a midnight black with a light brown head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, licorice and molasses. Very roasty taste, with a bit of coffee and dark chocolate. Smooth and creamy body with decent lacing. Very good stout, one of the best available year-round.

12 oz Bottle.  Appearance is black with half a finger of beige head.  Aroma is chocolate, licorice, and some vanilla.  Taste is roasted malts with the hints of chocolate, licorice and molasses.  Theres also a slight resin hops flavor present. Palate is wonderfully rich, full-bodied, and creamy.  Nice stout.

Apr 23, tap @ Excentric Café. Pours black as night with a small brown head leaving some lacing. Stouty malty aroma. Fullbodied malty mouthfeel. Fruity, acidy, meaty, peaty, tart and dark fruits flavor. Acidy tart palate. Finishes longlived dry tart.

12 oz bottle gifted by eBeerSnob  
Aroma more coffee than hops. Heavy mouthfeel was comfortable not the motor oil of Bourbon Bounty Stout. Dry finish more pleasing to me than Bells Ebpedition Stout 
A superb stout not available in my state this was a treat
UPDATED: FEB 19, 2012 This is a very good stout. Prototypical, but done well. Quite roasty and not getting a lot of that licorice, which is a good thing. Top of the line stout.

12oz bottle thanks to JulienHuxley. Batch 9588. About a year old probably.
Appearance : Black with medium brown creamy head.

Aroma : Great chocolate and coffee with nice hops. Light resinous notes. Very rich for such a low abv.

Taste : Roasted malt with light hops. Finish is hoppy with roasted malt and chocolate. Lengthy notes of resinous hops and chocolate. 

Overall : Very tasty and rich for such a light beer. Very impressive. Awesome finish. Nice hop presence.

Another one of those beers I am sure I have had before, but Ive also already drank everything else in the bar, so I pick it just because its a Stout, only to realize when I get home that I had never tried it before! Wonderful discovery! Wonderful beer!

Dark and opaque with a big creamy brown head that lasts all the way down to the bottom. In the nose is roasted malt, chocolate malt, caramel malt, some molasses and brewers licorice. The palate is full-bodied, smooth and creamy with a lasting finish. The flavor is wonderfully balanced between rich chocolate and caramel malt and a dry and lingering roasted and bitter finish. Absolutely delightful.

Draft. Served on cask at Town Hall Tap. Poured into a nice nonic glass a dark brown color with a mocha tan head. Cask causes it to cascade like a nitro beer. Heavy roasted nose along with dark chocolate and slight leather. The head is intense and sticks around for quite a while. Medium mouthfeel, a tad light than expected. Very smooth flavors. Dark roast coffee notes upfront with some vanilla and chocolate flavors as well. Slight bitterness in the end.

A: The beer is almost black in color and pours with about a finger of dark tan head.

S: Plenty of roasted malt and coffee notes to the nose followed up by dark chocolate and licorice.  Actually, a lot of licorice.  Molasses is present as well is a touch of soap.

T: The flavor is very similar to the nose, with a nice roasted character, though not overwhelming or charred in nature.  Toffee and molasses flavors provide the bulk of the sweetness along with a bit of licorice.

M: Medium in body with a medium level of carbonation.

O: Really nice easy drinking stout.  You could definitely have a couple of these.

Aroma coffee, roast, licorice, molasses, maltiness. Pour black with a small hint of brown around edges beige head with ridiculous lacing. Taste very roasty, burnt espresso, heavy bitterness, bakers chocolate. MF lingering bitterness, full body mild carb. Solid brew a little harsh.

Bottle from Phaleslu, big thanks. Pours solid black with a medium sized oily brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, nut, molasses, some coffee bitterness. Taste is oh so good, smooth roasty malts, nice sweetness, mild bitter finish. This is a great breakfast beer.
Pours totally black with a tan head, incredible lacing, leaves amazing concentric rings as you drink it.  So roasty, but a ton of chocolate as well, while still being quite drinkable.

The beer pours a dark black with a light tan head rising about a finger. The head falls pretty quickly leaving not much but a little ring around the glass. The lacing is decent.

The aroma is light sweet malts, a little cherry with light coffee at the end. 

The taste is light sweet to start but then has a pretty strong and bitter coffee finish.

The feel is medium bodied with a smooth and slightly dry finish.

Overall, pretty good, nothing crazy or overpowering, really reminds me of a sessional porter
Deep black pour with small brown head. Aroma is intense coffee. Flavor is even more intense, espresso-like. One of the most coffee-centric beers Ive tried. Very nice.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2011 Thin head quickly dissolves with little lacing.  Compare to Old Rasputin without ORs excellent aroma, though BKS has notes of roasted coffee.  Taste is bitter with a licorice aroma in the finish which is a little slick.

12 oz. bottle, sent by FuckSociety (thanks Sebastian), pours a silky black with a small tan head. Aroma sweet dark chocolate, some roastiness and light espresso. Flavour is essentially a mix of the same - rich, lightly sweetened dark chocolate, roasted malt, espresso and a little caramel. Roasty, lightly bitter finish. Most wonderful.

Pours out pitch black with a red shine out of the bottle. A light brown head, ok sized, holds pretty decent. The smell is roastiness, coffee and chocolate. Taste is also very roasted malts, some caramel, with at the end the chocolate that holds a very long time. The mouthfeel is not complete what I hoped for, a bit watery. Expected more from this one, a bit plain...  but not a bad beer.

Bottle. Cant believe I have not rated this yet.  Pour is black with a thin brown head.  Aroma is crisp roasted malt, light chocolate, light cocoa, and faintly hoppy.  Flavor is crisp chocolate malt with hints of roasted malt, milk shake, and a faint hoppy crispness in the finish.  Really tasty. Bells brews so many good stouts.

12oz bottle from PA. Pours deep black in color with a rich tan head. Beautiful roasted aroma is accentuated with light chocolate notes in the nose. Great silky medium body that finishes with a very slight chalky dry mouth feel. Nice roasty notes upfront that make way to bitter chocolate and slight licorice and caramel. This beer is extremely drinkable and a perfectly balanced very enjoyable all around stout. Overall: (A-)

12 oz bottle purchased form Bells General store.

Pours into my snifter a dark blackish brown with hints of brownish ruby on the edges. The head is thick and tan. As it recedes it leaves quite a bit of nice lacing.

THe smell is sweet and sugary, I dont know if I really smell the licorice but there are some good cocoa notes and a hint of coffee.

The licorice reveals itself massively in the flavor. Along with the massive licorice prescence there is some coffee and sweetness. The mouthfeel is a bit thinner than I expected or what have wanted, so it is docked a little bit.

Overall a solid stout, but not one of my favorites.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-12-2010 01:17:05
UPDATED: JUN 8, 2011 This one is a favorite. Lost in a blind tasting to founders breakfast stout and mikellers geek stout. The body is thick and black with molasses sweetness. Highly recommended

Dark brown beer with a frothy, tan head. Faint coffee smells. Tastes a bit plain, like a burnt Guinness. Chalky stout with trace tastes of dark chocolate, and black coffee. Definitely a quality beer, but a bit too chalky, and dry for me.

12 oz. bottle from Johns Grocery Iowa City
Poured in snifter at 55F

Ar:  Big roasty aroma.  There is a port-like quality in the aroma, with a bit of woodiness and some spice.
Ap:  Pours a deep coffee black with a 1" dark cinnamon head that leaves good lace.  Beautiful beer here.
T:  Flavor profile isnt out of the ordinary, but it is excellent.  A bit of malt sweetness, but not a ton.  Bitter chocolate and a bit of coffee.  The licorice comes through on the finish, along with a nice bitterness that cuts through the richness of this beer.
P:  Rich, creamy body with softish carbonation.

O:  World class stout.  This satisfies like a big burly Imperial, yet at the same time its pretty darn easy to down a bottle.

This stout carries on the tradition of what stouts were supposed to be - the fullest-bodied, strongest version of a porter.  If Bells Porter is too sweet for you, or if you dont like the stickiness of chocolaty flavor of it, try this stout.

Firs off, this beer pours an impressive hear even at fridge temperature.  This heal ends up being non-uniform and can last for over 15 minutes with just one bottle, normal pour.  The beer, of course, is the blackest brown and in a glass mug, you could confuse it for the darkest-brewed coffee.  Kalamazoo stout is advertised on the bottle as having brewers licorice, and you can smell and taste the bite in the beer.

The beers taste is just as youd expect, thick, creamy and delicious.  The taste or roasted barley is unmistakable and pairs with the licorice flavor perfectly.

If youre drinking this with a meal, youd better have some good food planned to keep up - Id recommend steak.  This beer is a little bit more bitter than Bells porter.  Have this with a nice steak and potato plate, and have a porter with/for dessert.

Aroma - Not very noticeable
Appearance - A nice dark deep, creamy stout, great head
Taste - A solid stout, good malty flavor but not too strong
Palate - Full bodied, creamy
OVerall - A very solid stout; not boring but not extraordinary either

Bottle from a trade probably over a year ago.  Pours a deep dark black with a huge deep mocha tan head.  Smooth chocolate and roast, light sweetness.  No big tell tale signs of age, this smells lovely, cocoa and vanilla.  Medium bodied, lightly sweet chocolate and toast. Pairs up nicely with ice cream.  Smooth, delicious and full of soft cocoa and roast.  Finishes with a slow lingering roast bitterness. Great stuff.
Bottle.  Dark brown to black, thick, dark tan foamy head.  Rich aroma - molasses and malt.   Thick, creamy, soft carbonation.  Finish lingers.   Excellent stout.
Smoky through and through. Chocolate, raisins. Really great stout. You drink this and then you imagine how great the expedition  tastes. Solid beer.

Bottle, courtesy of HopBurp.  Pours thick, dark brown and black in my glass, with a 2-finger foamy brown head that recedes to leave some blebby brown lacing.  Aromas of coffee, berry, bakers chocolate, and honey rise out of the glass.  The flavor is mild oats and honey, caramel, and slightly bitter cocoa with a mocha finish.  This is smooth and nearly creamy, with low carbonation and a dry finish.  A very good, smooth, rich stout.  Thanks HopBurp!
I was surprised with the taste of this stout, mainly because it wasnt very thick and had the bitter aftertaste of a hoppy ale. I do not dislike this beer by any means, just surprised.
A smooth stout that tastes very good with a slight licorice flavor on top of the rich caramel malt flavor. Not a fan of the aroma though.

Black with red highlights.  Smells of coffee, malted chocolate, bitter chocolate, soy sauce, raisins, prunes, firewood.  Tastes gently and expertly balanced: quite sweet and quite bitter from deep roasting, and a touch salty.  Very creamy, slightly woody. Dry slightly smoky finish.
12 oz bottle, pours a dark black color with a nice tan head.  Aromas of coffee, chocolate, malt, smells great.  A medium bodied beer with tons of roasted malt flavor.
One of the strongest roasted malt flavors Ive ever tasted tasted in a beer.  Still has the traditional chocolate/coffee flavors normally in a stout, but just moreso.  Just a great, everyday stout.
Pitch black pour and a 2 finger head. Coffee, molasses and chocolate tones.  A lighter but superb version of the Expedition.    Bells usually is spot on and this is no exception.

12 oz. bottle. Pours pitch black with a thin brown head. The aroma is caramel, molasses, roasted malts, chocolate and coffee. The flavor is bitter chocolate and malty sweet. The palate is thick and sticky. Overall, a very strong and flavorful stout.

Review from notes, sampled 1/2/2008
Received in a trade with Jay23 thanks for the chance to try this.

Pours a solid black with a tan head that dissipates quickly and leaves minimal lacing around the glass. Smells of roasted malts some dried fruit and a sweet milk stout smell. Taste is sweet lactose some more of the dried fruit and a touch of hops in the background. Has a creamy mouthfeel, but is a little thin. Great sweet stout, not over the top with sweetness like so many of this style tend to be.

I poured a 12 oz bottle into a snifter, where it sat inky black beneath a thin khaki cap that quickly became a ring and left a little lacing. This is pretty much the definition of an up-the-middle line drive of a stout: solid contact, outstanding execution, but not as exciting as a swing from the heels. You get tons of roast and a hint of caramel sweetness (especially as it warms) in the nose, and then even more roast in the flavor. The body is surprisingly light for a beer that is so flavorful, and the finish is clean with a hint of hops turning the roast caramel-and-chocolate notes into high-acidity Columbian coffee.

Bottle. Poured almost black with a huge light brown rocky head that lasted throughout and had excellent lacing. The aroma was of burnt cereal malts, a leathery yeast with notes of molasses, chocolate and coffee. It tasted mildly bitter and acidic in the beginning and finished with a sweet/bitter coffee flavor that stayed with you for an average length of time. Mouthfeel was full in body and creamy in texture with a flat carbonation. Overall a pretty basic stout.

Pour is pitch black with a decent tan head. Nose is mostly of coffee with some chocolate notes as well and some roasty undertones. Taste is very nice and mellow,and encompasses everything in the smell and flows well between flavors.

A=Pitch black with thin head that fizzles away rather fast,leaving only faint,moderate lacing.

S&T=Roasted barley,toffee,cocoa, some natural dark flavors. Comes through fairly thick. Very impressive.

M=Medium to heavy body, ditto with the carbonation. Could use less carbonation,IMO.

Really good example of stout. Thick,creamy and bursting with rich dark stout flavors, highly recommended.

Pours black with a chocolate-looking medium head. Nose is typical stout, with coffee roastiness and a touch of hops and dark chocolate. Flavor is also quite typical for a stout. Given the very high esteem this one is held in, will re-try a bottle in case this one is old/ bad.

Bottle. Just about entirely black with a darker tan head that really doesnt last or develop all that much.  Roasty dark maltiness and a slight bit of smoke in the aroma and a hint of minerals.  Very roasted flavor profile, and catch coffee and bitter chocolate as well.  Lots of vibrant bubbly carbonation, mediumish body and dry.  Cant believe that this clocks in at only 6% as the flavor is huge.  Good brew, and drinkable as hell.

Poured from a 120z bottle from Manny57.  Pours black as night with loads of tan head.  Smells of dark chocolate and some coffee.  Tastes of roasted malts and bittersweet chocolate.  A sweet stout.  Nicely done.

A pitch black beer with a tan fast-disappearing head. Aroma is strong coffee and bitter chocolate. The flavor is sweet and strong notes of coffee and heavy chocolate notes combined with hints of smoke.  Finish is chocolate and slightly bitter.  Sweetness is retained from start to finish.
Bottle: Not the most complex by any stretch but this medium body stout is solid...  Smooth with a toasted malt & licorice balance.

Pours a dense dark cola with dark brown head that dissipates quickly.  Huge smooth mouthfull of chocolate malt.  Bittering in the finish with just enough carbonation to balance.  Best for dessert or sipping in front of a cool weather fire.
12oz bottle.  Aroma of chocolate and coffee.  Flavor of chocolate, roasted malts, and and some slight hoppiness.  A nice texture for a stout.  A great beer.

Pours black with a large creamy tan head. Very nice looking beer with good lacing and close knit carbonation bubbles. Aroma is not overly complicated and includes notes of milk chocolate, roasted barley, coffee and a tad of hops. Flavor is extremely smooth and well balanced, sweet and flavorful first with a bitter hoppy finish.

THOUGHTS: Very good. Just like a stout should be. Not overly complicated, but complex enough to make it quite interesting.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a very dark brown that was nearly opaque black in the glass with a large, tan to light brown head that kept a nice sheet. The aroma had moderate to heavy roasted malt, caramel and coffee; maple syrup, licorice and a hint of cola. The initial flavor was light to moderately sweet, light to moderately bitter and slightly sour; while the finish was sweet, rather bitter and slightly sour with a long duration. There was chocolate, roasted malt, caramel, maple syrup, bitter chocolate, coffee, slight licorice, burnt malt, cream, molasses, chocolate syrup and more underlying licorice. The medium to full body was silky and then a little dry with somewhat soft, yet slightly tingly carbonation and a slightly astringent, dry and ever so slightly chalky finish.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2010 Bottle.

A - Dark black color with a large, creamy, thick, frothy, full, meringue-like, dark tan head. Amazing retention finally resulting in a nice layer of lace. Very nice looking beer.

S - Sweet milk chocolate and dark chocolate, coffee, anise all are quire strong. Some roasted malt and some nuttiness. Sweet cream/mocha flavors. Sweet and roasted mix well.

T - Similar to the nose with a great amount of sweet milk chocolate and more bitter dark/bakers chocolate. Good amount of coffee as well with some creamy sweetness. Mid sip a slight roasted malt and earthy/nutty flavors comes out. Undertones of anise. Great balance of sweetness and roasted bitterness in the beer.

M - Medium body with average carbonation. Quite smooth and goes down easy.

D - So easy to drink. Great flavors and really balanced especially between the sweet and bitter flavors that can come with a stout.

Notes: Batch 9984. Really enjoyed this. A great stout, and just what I was hoping for. Definitely worth picking up. Really balanced and a joy to drink.

Bottle; bought from Cracked Kettle, drunk at home.

Nice mocha lacing, rather thick which simmers down quite quickly leaving lacing only around the edge of the brew, opaque jet black colour. 

Aroma is grains, burnt toast. peppers. quite hoppy and creamy. 

Taste is dark chocolate, rich roasted malts, some leather, dried prunes and roasted malts. Interesting and complex but not as challenging as I had hoped. Quality effort either way.

Pours deep brown with a two finger thick tan frothy head. Excellent nose of malted milk balls, chocolate, coffee and some roasted malt. The flavor is a bit dryer and light bitterness in the mid to finish that lingers. Medium mourhfeel. Lots of lacing left on the glass as I sip it down.

Pours black as night - no light gets thru; malty / licorice nose;  rapidity dissipating tan head with only minor lacing;  smooth going down; hints of chocolate and express; improves as it warms (note to self...keep it on the shelf)....full bodied; not too much alcoholic taste at all...damn, this is good...full bodied with a long finish...overall, it makes Guinness seem like Miller light....lingers at the back of your tongue; wonderful...

Pours a pitch black color with a little burnt brown colored head.  Aroma is sweeter with roasted malts, chocolate, booze, barney, and possibly a little port wine.  Flavor is very malty.  A slight soy sauce flavor comes up front along with a little roastyness.  Bringing up the back end is coffee, chocolate, and perhaps a little resin.  Leaves a roasty coffee finish.  Thank you Justin for the hook up.

G: Poured into a pint glass.

A: Very dark with a pretty good head.

S: Some lactose sweetness along with some dark malts, fruit, and maybe a tad bit of caramel.

T: Much like the smell, with some hops and a wee bit of coffee.

M: Fairly thick, but not overly so. 

D: Fairly drinkable. A less-intense stout experience.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-23-2009

Black as night with a bulbous cream colored head that hung around for ages.  Looks like the top of a chocolate milk shake.  Left a generous amount of lacing.  I cant wait to try this!!!  Only the most minute red hue at the bottom of the glass.  Almost Perfect.  Roasted malt in the nose that had coffee mixed with a sweet milk chocolate that was most enchanting.  Both aromas were very robust and inviting.  Both were balanced exactly and made for easy detection.  Didnt get the licorice as mentioned on the label, but that was fine by me.  The taste revealed burnt coffee and toastiness.  Bittersweet chocolate along with what I found to be a hint of caramel in the taste.  Again, balanced exceptionally well.  Didnt have the overall cream flavor that Oatmeal Stouts have, but thats OK.  Just different styles.  Leaves me wanting another sip quickly.  Medium/Full mouthfeel with decisive dryness.  Smooth with lots left on the palate after each sip.  As mentioned, not quite as creamy as some others, but still head and shoulders above average.  This beer could get me in trouble.  Truly an outstanding beer.  Well balanced and easy drinking.  Could make a night or two out of this all too easy.  I can see myself sitting by the fireplace with this all night long.

Near black with a deep caramel colored head. Smells sweet and of dark chocolate. The beer started with a sweet brown sugar flavor that fades to a bitter finish. Medium towards full body. Rating would have been even higher if not for the bitter finish that took away from the sweetness to quickly.
