Bottle to chilled glass.  Pours a thick dark brown, pretty much black.  Almost no head, but whats there is a caramel yellow color.  Not much lacing.  Honesty, I cant really taste much of anything in this beer.  Its got a thick mouthfeel.

Appearance:  black, with a nice creamy mocha head; hint of residual lacing.  Aroma:  dark roasted malts, and definite notes of black licorice, but not the mass-produced commercial kind, its more like a farmers market type.  Taste:  creamy coffee, unsweetened black licorice, dark toasty malts, some dried oatmeal, and an outdoorsy combination of earth and oak bark. Finish:  lingering, smoothly bitter and extremely dry; this is where I got a hint of bittersweet dark chocolate.  Notes:  Palate is very creamy, drinkable and smooth.  Pretty straightforward stout with a nice bit of brewers licorice.  Good for breakfast.  I would have liked a bit more sweetness, but I guess thats what Bells Double Cream Stout is for.

Aroma is chocolate. Pours a deep black with a solid light tan foam. Taste is a nice upfront roasted malt and chocolate matched with the sweetness of licorice but finishes with a balancing bitterness. Another solid stout from Bells.

From a bottle, pours black with very little head. Aroma is mostly toasted malts with the licorice being more subtle. Taste is bitter chocolate with very little sweetness. Medium body, more on the thin side for this style. Overall this is a very good stout.

Bottle. Pours black with nice foamy tan head. Extremely roasty with some licorice, a bit of chocolate, and some dark fruit. Id need to try this again for a definitive rating. My initial impression is that its a bit thinner on the palate than the Bells Expedition and other stouts, but this was still good. I think the roasted flavor may have overpowered less noticeable notes. Good beer that I need to try again, preferably sober.

This is an interesting one.  Im a big Bells fan, and Ive enjoyed all their stouts Ive tried so far, but this one kind of misses the mark.  Its good, with the licorice being pretty obvious in the aroma.  Pours the usual stout black with tan head.  Roasted malt flavor with an interesting bitterness in the background that kind of throws you for a loop....Ill stick with Expedition or Java Stout instead of this one for ones to have on the regulars list.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2012 Bottle @ Grannys house in Exira, Iowa. Deep black appearance with a dark brown head. Dark milk chocolate, roasty, slightly burnt dark malty, espresso aroma. Roasty, dark chocolate, black coffee, slightly burnt flavor. Roasty, chocolate aftertaste. Yum!

I cant decide if I like this beer or not.  Has a nice robust stout/porter feel - easy drinking, but I dont like the finish.  Tastes like tart apples (in the aroma as well).  I think this leaves the beer a bit unbalanced.
UPDATED: OCT 18, 2015 Yumm. the taste of liquorice is present, but not overwhelming. Really nice beer. Had it from a bottle a friend brought over from the US. He can bring more of these next time.

Pours black with a nice brown head.  The darkness of the head immediately makes me think that this beer will taste like soy sauce- there is a bit, but fortunately its only underneath more pleasant flavors.  Aroma is of chocolate, malty sweetness, brewing coffee, slight pine.  Flavor is chocolate and bitterness, little to no hop flavor.  Big, thick, syrupy body.  Roast and coffee are now coming through in the flavor as the aftertaste has settled in for a bit.  Overall, very nice.  I would not have put this at 6%; it tastes like it would be much higher.

Ohhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh goodness.  Well, theres nothing to say except that I dont like licorice.  I wouldnt have bought it had I read the label.  That being said, its a really good stout.  Not heavy, kinda crisp and dry.  Really well balanced.  Unfortunately, the licorice is overpowering.  If you like licorice, youll really like this one.

Pour is pretty thick with a fairly standard head. Color is dark brown but not quite black. Nose is roasty and full of coffee. Some roasted nuts as well. Taste is very balanced. Plenty of malt with some fading hoppy bitterness. Not much hops though. Bitter pleasant black coffee. Tart fruit. Apricot, dates. This is some pretty good stuff. Watching Dallas Cowboys and Min Vikings play some football. About to cook some stir fry with the wife. Not a bad beer for the occasion.

a perfectly balanced stout, as bells is known to make.  aroma- dark malt, licorice, smoke, coffee.  pours black with little brown head.  taste is bitter black licorice, coffee, dark malt, some woodiness.  palate is clean and smooth, medium bodied.

12oz bottle, batch 9801, bottled June 4, 2010.  Served at around 50F.  Pours very dark brown/black with a massive foamy four-finger light brown head that slowly recedes and leaves plenty of foamy lacing behind.  Aroma features roasted malts, chocolate, licorice, coffee, some yeast and a touch of mustiness.  Moderate to good strength.  Rich and robust flavor of milk and dark chocolates, licorice, some dark fruit, coffee, caramel, toffee, very malty with just a touch of hops on the finish.  Delicious.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied and quite creamy and velvety smooth, low to medium carbonation.  One of the most flavorful regular stout Ive ever had...cant believe I hadnt reviewed it yet as Ive gone through a number of sixers through the years and will continue to do so.  Fantastic stuff!

poured from a 12-ounce bottle into a pint glass.  This has been sitting in my refrigerator for a few months and I figured its about time I tackle this monster.  Ive developed an affinity for stouts as of late and appreciate this beer on many levels.  It is smoky, with hints of chocolate and malt, but lacks body. Either way, I would certainly drink again.

Poured from 12oz bottle, pours a very dark color with a thin tan head, has aroma full of chocolate and coffee, aroma is very creamy with hints of chocolate and a hint of coffee in the finish, this is a great stout.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2011 Chocolate, whipped cream, caramel and a little yeast. Looks like an espresso, tastes like dry and rich beer. Creamy texture. A good stout but definitely not my style. 
Re-indexed: much more used to this kind of bitter stouts although I still believe its too dry.

Batch no. 8555 bottle courtesy of fiulijn (huge thanks Alex!)
Poured an extremely dark brown body with almost no head. Oily malty nose, dry, raisins, chocolate. Nice balanced 

creamy maltiness, som roast, slightly yoghurty, some raisins, maybe some chocolate as well and licorice. Ashy 

bitterness in the end. A very nice stout indeed.
Pours black with brown head and foamy lacing.  Notes of chocolate, molasses.  Balanced taste with a slight bitter finish.  Smooth and creamy.

Bouteille de 16oz. (gracieuseté de slovak, merci beaucoup) Seconde expérience avec se fabuleux stout. Bière noire opaque avec une belle mousse brune, durable. Nez opulent de torréfaction, de chocolat, très agréable. La bouche est soyeuse, de fortes notes chocolatées et de café moka. Très beau stout. merci

Le liquide est noir opaque.  Une mousse épaisse et tenace repose sur le liquide.  Une dentelle est observée.  Le nez est complexe avec des grains rôtis, du chocolat mi-amer, de la réglisse, de la mélasse, du toffee et du café fort.  Au goût, lattaque est tout aussi pleine avec des notes torréfiées de chocolat et de café.  Présence très sentie de la réglisse avec une touche de fumée en fin de parcours.  En bouche, belle rondeur avec une texture crémeuse malgré une effervescence qui me semble légèrement nerveuse.  La finale est bonne, très bonne, avec la présence derrière la langue de notes amères de grains rôtis qui restent longuement accrochées.  En résumé, a marvelous stout from Michigan. (merci à B.P.)

As good as this is in the bottle, it becomes a top beer on draft, probably only beaten in the Stout category by some of Cigar Citys offerings. I wish it had a little more weight behind it, but the taste is amazing. Lots of mocha and coffee, with the slightest hint of pure smoke.

Pours jet black with a thin tan head and little to no lacing. Aromas are licorice, chocolate, and coffee. The taste is smooth chocolate with a nice bitter burnt coffee bean finish. Its about as smooth as Ive ever tasted for a stout. As the beer warmed up the licorice taste got pretty strong which I didnt really enjoy. Overall a very good beer but I prefer it cold since Im not a huge fan of black licorice.
Deep dark color with a roasty aroma. A very roasty malt flavor mixed with a creamy, chocolate, coffee, caramel taste. Very full bodied with a smooth finish. A very worthy stout.
Bottle from the foodery in Philly.  Roasty stout with vanilla.. Some cocoa and smoke.  Chalky mouthfeel. A lot of power for a regular stout, clearly borders on an imperial.
A very solid, roasty and nicely bitter stout.  I want a fresher bottle than the one I got from the store to really gauge the taste but I really like this one as is.

Pours a deep, dark brown with a thin tan head that quickly dissipates. The aroma provides a hint of coffee, and the flavor is reminiscent of black coffee with a bit of fruity malt sweetness to balance. Heavily roasted malts are one thing, but the flavor of this one makes me think they went one step further and burnt some of the malt. Again, however, the malt sweetness brings some balance to this dark bitterness. This combination provides a nice crisp mouthfeel without giving up the distinctive flavor profile that makes this stout as easy-drinking as many of the year-round offerings from Bells.

Delicious. Truly great stout. Thick, firm head, very roasty, malty, slightly hoppy aroma. Highly roasted flavor, malty, yet has definite hop flavor. Awesome balance of roasted, malty/caramel, hop flavors with hints of coffee, molasses and alcohol. This one is better than good.

12oz bottle pours black with nice tan head. Aroma is chocolate, molasses and roasted malts. Taste is bitter with roasted malts, chocolate, molasses, slights caramel. Texture is rich, creamy, and smooth. Very nice stout.

Bottle. Black with a thin tan head, lots of lacing. Aroma is chocolate, light roast, lots of toast, the licorice is hiding in there too. Flavor is chocolate, toast, not much roast, a little hop bitter moving around there, and just a tiny big of licorice (which is nice). Great thick velvety mouth feel. I wish I had more of this around.

Black pour with tan creamy head. If I wasnt so fat I might actually be able to walk on the head.  Nose is chocolate, coffee, roasted malt, burnt sugar, toffee, and some fruity type esters.  Taste is full of roast, malts, cara malts, fruits and coffee.  Bitterness blends right in with the roast.  Full bodied, rich and creamy.  Taste really lingers for some time after the swallow.  What a wonderful stout.  Nice.

Pours dark black with a cola colored head.  Aroma consists of a fresh roasted coffee thats basically off-the-hook.  Very easy on the palate, no harsh bubbles.  Almost a creamy mouthfeel to it from the delectably smooth dark chocolate & roasted coffee flavors.   Overall, this is an extreme pleasure to drink.  I only have three words: Off. The. Hook.

Bottle: Pours a Dark Brown/Black into my guinness glass, with a nice fluffy tan head with decent retention and lacing. Aroma was at first a little musky, and a little roasted malt. Taste is a little bitter, body was at first very light, with a creamy feel, but the carbonation neutralizes it, with a bit of bitterness at the end. Flavors are roasted malt, chocolate, caramel, just a fine stout.

120z bottle.  Pours jet black with a small brown head. Aroma mainly of roasted malt with some nice bitter espresso overtones.  Smooth, creamy, slightly viscous mouthfeel with soft carbonation contribute to chocolate, a little licorice, perfectly roasted malt, and some coffee on the palate.  Nice and balanced across the board.  Could be a little more body, but Im still happy with what Im imbibing.

From a 12oz bottle.  Pour is dark brown to black in color with a small tan head.  Aroma is chocolate, some roasted coffee, and some anise.  Flavor is chocolate, roasted coffee, anise again, and slightly smokey.  Smooth and silky on the tongue.  This is what a stout should be.

Tried along side Old Rasputin. 
Aroma: Medium chocolate, coffee malt
Appearance: Black, Medium Head dwindles down to and  leaves a thin froth
Taste: coffee malt, medium hops
Palate: Light, thin, avg carbonation, short finish
Overall: Okay, this time but Im suspecting that this beer may be old... Ill have to buy another one.

12 oz bottle. Pours a very deep brown nearly black with a big creamy tan head. Aroma is very roasty and chocolately as expected. Theres a sharp woody and slight tobacco note as well. Lots of sweet caramels and cocoa powder. The roastiness is so strong it has a sharpness on the nose. Flavor starts rich and creamy, lots of cocoa and black malts. The roast is at the front from start to finish, with a lot of sweetness to back up that bitter sharpness also coming from the herbal hops. Medium to full body and a soft carbonation. Excellent stout!
UPDATED: AUG 15, 2010 Nice dark, smooth beer. Pretty good nose. Nice bitter taste of chocolate, not sweet at all. Great aftertaste. This beer is a choice buy.

Roasty, chocolate aroma is very enticing. Whispy, creamy, mocha-colored head tops a dark brown velvety stout. Flavors of roast, chocolate, and caramel malts round out with a dry, slightly-bitter finish.

Pours a dark black color with an off-white soapy head.  Has an aroma of roasty malt, chocolate, and caramel.  Has a sweet, roasty taste.  Charcoal, chocolate notes on the finish.  Very creamy.  The roastiness makes this a top brew.  I would say the roasty notes in this brew are comparable to another excellent dark beer, Duck Rabbit Baltic Porter.  At 6% this is a perfect session beer for the late fall, winter months.  An unlike other sub 7% brews, this one fills you nicely.  Cannot wait to get my hands on a few more.

Pours pitch black wth a full thick creamy head and wonderful lacing.  Smells of roast coffee, a bit chocolate, maybe a touch of smoke.  Oily mouthfeel, rich deep roasted malts give flavors of coffee chocolate and licorice.  The finish is rather long and tastes of bitter roast coffee.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2017 I cant say this isnt good. It is good. But I just wasnt in love with this beer. Maybe I am just not a fan of brewers licorice as I dont like the non-brewers kind?  Serving: Bottle
<<<<<<<<<<<<&l REMOVED DUE TO PROFANITY>>>>>>>>>>&

Poured into pint glass ink black, solid black. Tan head - very little head. Mild lacing. 

Brown Sugar, Dark Truffle, Milk Chocolate

For a milk stout, this beer is exceptional. Bells has covered all the bases with this one. Dark Cherry, French roast, Vanilla bean, Dark Chocolate, Earthy, Malty, nut. 

Dry, tannic, warm. 

I turn to milk stouts as a snack, something to enjoy after dinner and could get around to two or three in a row if Im in the mood. This beer is pleasant, great drinkability, sipper and savor or session if you can. I would recommend this for the man looking to get his woman a stout or a man looking to enjoy a few on a cool night. Love this beer.

bottle from Eulogy in Philly. 
slightly cloying aroma of boiling wort, chocolate malt, vanilla, licorice, soggy wood, lactic acid, toasted (and maybe burnt) nuts, and light alcohol.
pours slightly darker and much thicker than coke, with smallish tan frothy/rocky head.
flavor is surprisingly mild, with a dry sweetness and a light bittersweet chocolate to balance, with a hint of sourness.
medium bodied, very dry, slightly overcarbonated and rough, with a long bittersweet chocolate finish.
as it warms there is much more licorice plus sourness from roasted malts. this is a great stout, subtle and deep.

Pours a deep, dark brown--practically black.  The best thing here is the frothy, billowy head, which is medium brown in color.  Head lasts quite a while, to be replaced by some nice, heavy lacing.  The aroma is a bit too restrained for a stout, but there are chocolate malts and more than a hint of licorice.  Mouthfeel is surprisingly thin, almost watery, but it does not detract from the overall experience.  Moderate carbonation.  Taste is complex--licorice predominates, with chocolate malts following, and only a hint of alcohol.  Roasted, but not burnt--unmistakably a stout, but much in common with a fine porter.  In all, an exemplary stout.

Pours a dark black with a nice dark tan 2-finger head.  Leaves a nice sticky lacing with each drink. Aroma is chocolate and toffee notes up front with roasted, almost burnt smelling malts and black liquorish behind it. Not an overwhelming smell, but nice.Taste is that of black liquorish and toffee with a biscuity taste up front, then sweet dark chocolate as it warms. Palate is low carbonation with a nice, full body and creamy texture. Overall, very easy to drink and tasty!

12oz bottle. Wow. Pours dark black with no light shining through. Creamy head. Good lacing. Aroma of chocolate and coffee. Tastes of vanilla and licorice. Nice bitterness throughout. This is a well made stout.

Batch 8432. Packaged on April 11, 2008.

Pours a thick brown/tan head. This beer is pretty much as black as the night sky (but really just a extremely dark brown). I was in awe when I first saw this beer come out of the bottle. The head stayed up almost the entire time, while the lacing was dominate. Thats right dominate.

The smell is of roasted/chocolate malts, while the beer is amazingly balance between the hops and the malts. The presence of both were well represented. I could again taste the same roasted/chocolate malts and the hop flavor was grassy.

This is such an amazing beer and I would recommend this to anybody! I am so impressed with Bells on this one!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-14-2008 00:51:10

Pours black with a tan head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, and roasted malt. Tastes like a mix of cocoa, coffee, roasted malts, beautifully integrated.  To me, this is exactly what a stout should taste like.
UPDATED: SEP 24, 2012 Nice stout. pours very black and smooth. My favorite Bells beer that Ive tried. I enjoy the hell out of it.

Bottle from de Gekraakte Ketel, Amsterdam. Black with a good beige head. Roasted aroma with lots of milky oats as well as chocolate. Thick chocolate and milky flavours, roast is more subdued in the mouth. Some licorice as expected. Very good.
Batch 9668.  Huge coffee, dark malt and slight smoke aroma.  Nice dryness at the beginning and a rich creamy body.  Vanilla and chocolate in the body.  Quite smooth.  Nice beer.

Bottle from Cracked Kettle. Dark, dark brown with puffy oak head. Nose of cocoa and lots of malts. Taste is very wheaty, malty, rough. Then turns sweet and chocolatey. Quite bitter too, especially in the end. Very good.

bottle.. Jet black pour , thin beige head , good lace .  Aroma is chocolate and malty sweetness . Roasted coffee bean flavor , notes of caramel and licorice . Light to medium bodied , creamy , soft carbonation . Finish is coffee bitterness and dry . A little thin I thought , but still very good .

12 oz bottle from warehouse wines. aroma has cocoa, roasty nut, with a bit of molasses to it. pours a dark brown with a medium brown head. taste like a lighter version of the expedition. coffee, cocoa, with a molasses aftertaste. palate has a light mouthfeel with no mouth warming. a bit sticky.

Found this one bottled at Lundeens in Sycamore, Illinois.  One truly outstanding and interesting stout.  Opaque dark brown pour with a thick, tan head.  Nose of licorice, bitter chocolate, sweet coffee, and malts.   Similar flavors.  Balanced finish.  I am very impressed with Bells and this one is no different.
Like almost all of Bells offerings, this beer is exceptionally good and very well balanced.  A really, really good stout.

Black pour tan head ... dark roasted malt and chocolate aroma ... taste is loaded with bitter roasted malts, caramel, chocolate and licorice is evident  ..... creamy but mostly a bitter dark roasted mouthfeel and not very heavy ..... a very good stout

Murky dark brown with red corners. A nice mocha crown that shows a bit of retention and some lacing. Nice dose of coffee and dark roasted malt. Creamy and milky up front opening to a strong coffee flavor and smooth finish.  A touch thin but Ive had this bottle for about a year now and have never tried it fresh so cant say if its always like this or not. Fairly easy to drink.

Another pint that looks like it was scooped out of the gulf, post rig explosion of coarse.  This bad boy poured a real nice head and bubbles with roast and chocolate effervescence.  Its the mildest stout to date with a well balanced dose of roasted malt that gives way to chocolate, carmel, and toffee.  A real treat from Bells...

(12 oz bottle).  Pours black with a unique head!  The head is about 2" and tan.  Its starts off chunky with a little bit of cascading, but it has a small layer of pillowy head.  Aroma of coffee, nuts, coffee ice cream?  Wow!  Fabulous!  Burnt flavors wresting with sweetness, a little sour and some hops.  Flavors go back and forth.  I think I just found my new favorite stout.  It is so rich and creamy; the sweetness is decadent, but not overpowering.  Superb!!

I love Bells Brewing. I unabashedly state that they are the best brewers of stout in the country. So I am thrilled to finally get ahold of some Kalamazoo Stout, one of the few Bells stout varieties I have not tried.

This beer is pitch black in the glass with a dense tan head that could support small coins. Smells sweet and chocolatey with light hints of mocha. Very nice.

There is much more coffee in the flavor than in the nose. More bitter than I was expecting but with a sweetness that offsets it. The bitter and the sweet lead to flavors reminiscient of dark chocolate.

A nice thick body that is just heavenly in the mouth. Drinks smooth as silk with some light smokiness in the aftertaste acconpanied by hints of coffee and a creamy sweetness. 

Its money. I might drink nothing but stout if Bells distributed to Atlanta...

Bottle. Black with tan head that sticks whole beer. Aroma is coffee, dark chocolates, creamy berry fruits, roasted character that grows as beer warms. Taste is smooth sweet chocolate going bitter roasted in finish. Light booze tinge but smooth and drinkable. Measurables of of imperial, smoothness of normal stout. Excellent.
Yep, its that good. A great version of what an American Stout can be. Toasted malts, cocoa, coffee, burnt caramel, big hop presence. Surprisingly easy to drink.

Bottle courtesy tarheels86.  Very fine stout.  Starts with a thick, brown head.  Black in the glass.  Chewy, fresh malt with noticeable licorice in the aroma.  Big, well-rounded chocolate/malt and seemingly near molasses (?) or sugary tree sap flavor.  Clean caramel notes on the finish.  So finely blended the taste takes on a smoke character.  I am impressed.
Pours black with a tan head. Nose is licorice, vanilla and roasted coffee beans. Taste is roasted malts, red licorice, coffee beans and vanilla. Very smooth drinking.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a shaker.  Pours opaque black as my soul with decent brown head.  Decent lacing and a little creamy.  Taste is roasted malt, with some chocolate and coffee, with a hint of molasses.

12oz bottle of batch 9095, bottled on April 16, 2009, rated May 23rd, 2010.  Pours pitch black with a big tan head.  Aroma is roasty, with a touch of sweet raisin and a tiny bit of lactose.  Taste has lots of roasted coffee, a bit of mildly sweet caramel, some chocolate bitterness, and a touch of sweet fruit.  Mouthfeel is surprisingly light for something with so much flavor.  Finsh is roasty and pleasantly bitter.

Appearance: Murky dark brown with red corners. A nice 1 finger mocha crown that shows a bit of retention and some lacing. Attractive.

Smell: Nice dose of coffee and dark roasted malt.

Taste: Creamy and milky up front opening to a strong coffee flavor and smooth finish.

Mouthfeel: A touch thin but Ive had this bottle for about a year now and have never tried it fresh so cant say if its always like this or not.

Drinkability: Fairly easy to drink.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-22-2009
Roasty, malty, coffee aroma. Frothy tan head, opaque black, gorgeous lacing. Roasty, malty, and sweet. A very nice stout. A little thin.

Pours black with a light brown head. Instantly you can smell the subtle coffee flavors mixed with roasted malts and caramel. Tastes like chocolate coffee and roasted malts and hops. Great finish for a stout(the few I have tried). Not usually a favorite style of mine but was much better than expected.

Bottle split with pat and james. Pours a pitch black body with tan lacing. The aroma displays notes of molasses, chocolate, and roast. The mouth feel is medium to full dominated by flavors of chocolate, caramel and molasses. Delicious stout.
Poured very dark with a pretty good white/tan head.  Had a solid chocolatety malt backbone with a hint of smoke and caramel.  I thought it was an overall above average stout.
12 oz. dark pour from bottle.  Cherries, chocolate and burnt wood on the nose.  Taste is roasted coffee, chocolate, malt and nuts.  Warm finish.  Another excellent beer from Bells.

Bottle. 12 oz. Split with James and Tony. Pours a deep, opaque brown, bordering on black, with a tan lacing. Aroma of chocolate, toffee, caramel, roasted malts, molasses, and crazy hints of marshmallow. Full bodied with a thick, rich, almost sticky palate. Finishes with a roasty spiciness. Excellent stout from Bells.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2010 Bottle split with pat and Tony. Pours a pitch black body with tan lacing. The aroma displays notes of molasses, chocolate, and roast. The mouhfeel is medium to full dominated by flavors of chocolate, caramel  and molasses. Delicious stout.
Bottles, Earthy aroma with a slightly bitter flavor.  Weak burnt marshmellow palate.  Overall a very good stout!

Cocoa powder (dry), mocha chocolate. Sweet, pungent dates. Malt is very dry. Balanced, awesome.

Appearance is pitch black. Puffy light brown head.

Sweet malts, mild Belgian chocolate and some nice raisins & dates. Very sweet and chocolatey, but with a dry, burnt cookie background.

Feels smooth, not quite silky but a little oily. A sweetish stout. Really nice and very easy-drinking.

12 oz bottle from Erie PA. Almost a motor oil consistency pour bearing a thick head that almost seems to never die. Complex aromas of cocoa, slight licorice, chocolate, brown sugar, caramel, oak, light coffee, slight vanilla undertones oh and roasted malt to be a little unspecific. The flavors are almost just as complex. You get the roasted malts (chocolate, slight coffee, oak, caramel) with a slight vanilla/wood finish. Burnt/roasted aftertaste, bitter, lightly creamy, lightly sweet, complex(wow), great. This is now the best "stout" I have ever had, and will buy more in the future for sure.....

2007 Bottle via trade with Charles-Darwin.  "Find out for yourself" on the bottle....true that.  Pours black and nearly flat.  Rim of glass and lily pad film of head. Equal dark sweet malts and licorice translate from nose to body.  Medium body continues to be slick and encompasses whole mouth and tongue.  Normal in duration.  Long gently decreasing crisp / dry finish. Some settled slime mold like trub at bottom of glass.  A slick pint in all definitions.
More bitter than I expected from a stout. Slightly sprucy aroma. Roasted, with a hoppy kick.

I was able to drink a bottle of Kalamazoo immediately after a bottle of Bells Expedition and found them to be totally different.   Where the Expedition is full-bodied and has an almost oily consistency that sticks to your teeth, the Kalamazoo is rather thin.   As for taste, I would describe the Kalamazoo as far drier, with a roasted, almost smokiness to it.  It is far less sweet tasting than the Expedition but thats not necessarily a bad thing...just different.   

The bottle I poured had a tall, thick head that took at least 3 minutes to settle.  Color is inky black and almost opaque.   

For me, this is a great stout to pair with a sweet heavy food.   Its not the concentrated slap in the face you get from Expedition, but its still a smoky, chocolaty, dry stout that is absolutely worth finding.

Bottle.Pours a dark black with a thin brown head.Nose is licorice,chocolate and toast.Taste is dark roasted malt and sweet hops with coffee and chocolate.Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy.This is a great beer and maybe the best "everyday" stout.

Bottle. Very rich looking pour, dark black with tall brown head. Aroma is loaded with cocoa, licorice and roasted malts. Taste is quite sweet, some roast bitterness, quite good. Palate is a bit too oily and slick, like the Expedition Stout but I like this one more.

Kalamazoo Brewing Company--Bells Beer--Bells Kalamazoo Stout--2004	12 oz. Bottle.  6.50% ABV.  55 IBUs?  (4.25 / 5.0)  Thin lacy tan head.  Light sediment.  Opaque black red color.  Roasted rich hop malt front.  Dry sweet burnt chocolate biscuit mild espresso body.  Tart dry sweet spicy mild hop end.  Healing oral smooth.  Sampled 12/19/2004 & $/6/2005.

Bottle pours almost black  with medium brown head, nice lacing.  Aroma very nice, sweet and chocolate.  Taste is a bit underwhelming, coffee, chocolate, malt, roast and a little vanilla.  Medium somewhat creamy body, very smooth with a mildly bitter finish.  Nice warming sensation.

This is nice but somewhat overrated.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2012 Delicious, I want to suck it dry.  No.  Backspace Backspace Backspace.  HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA.  What do you really think?  High voice.  Its delicious.  Yaaaaaaaaaaaa.   Yaaaaaaaaaa.   Do it.

These are all things that my fiancee was saying while I was preparing to review this great stout.  Its pretty good, aroma is roasty and calming.  In the taste Im getting coffee and roasted malts.  One of my favorites.  Now my fiancee is biting me and chasing our cat.  Shes special, but not that special.

Pours pitch black with a foamy brown head.  Burnt malt and chocolate aroma with some earthy notes.  Nice roasted malt and bittersweet chocolate flavor and a bitter, creamy finish.  Doesnt try to do too much; just a really good stout.
AJs in phx; while on vacation; notes from this a little vague - had near same time as deschutes obsidian stout - notes state they are very similiar with Bellse being slightly more drinkable...

12 oz bottle from Brickskellers in DC... Oh my! Ive been looking for Bells stuff for almost three years. My friend told me about Brickskellers and I was in town, so I stopped in and checked out the beer list-  ~800 beers! I went straight for the Bells and asked what the bartender suggested: Kalamazoo. Pours black, with a nice chocolaty head-- amazing lacing. Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate. Flavor is like any other porter: chocolate, coffee- but oh so much nicer! Goes down very easily at 6% (so much so that I had one to begin the afternoon, and one to end the evening). This may be my new favorite porter, and I look forward to tasting the rest of Bells stuff in the coming weeks.

355ml Bottle, brought to Amsterdam by GodOfThunder, thanks Jay! Pitch black colour, beige-brown head. Aroma of firm roasted malts, chocolate, bit of moccha, some yeast. Flavour is soft, very nice roasted malts, hint of coffee, moccha, chocolate, nice light hoppy and roasted bitter finish. Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel. Good, reminded me of Praght Extra Stout.

Draft at Maduro.  Pitch black with a rusty beige-brown head.  Very soft on the palate, an easy drinker.  Mild roasted malt and chocolate notes.  All around pleasant and drinkable, mellow mossy tones.  Fairly middle of the road, a little overrated for sure.  Well done nonetheless.

Bottle tasting at home.  I bought a mix-and-match six pack, this is the fourth of six.  A darn decent stout, better than I was expecting. Not that Bells doesnt make great beer, the name just... gave me lowered expectations.  A big no-no, I know.
  This bad boy has a big roasted profile with lots of dark chocolate and coffee. Nice malts character - caramel, coffee, chocolate, and all toasted to a wonderful finish. Full body with a smooth, creamy finish that has a nice finish of both bitterness and alchohol that played off each other and never became overwhelming.  A nice stout to drink if the days were a little colder and the nights a little longer.

Poured black with a large chocolate head with tons of lasting power.  Just stuck around coated the glass.  Aroma is of roasted malt.  Roastyness, some licorice and chocolate.  Bitterness in the finish for balance.
Pours jet black with no foam. The aroma notes has coffee,chocolate, and a little bit of vanilla in there. Its incredibly smooth and sits very well on the tongue.

Dark, almost opaque color with a thin tawny head. Aromas of burnt coffee and faint hints of chocolate. Some fruity and hoppy notes as well in the nose. Medium bodied and smooth. The taste is consistent with the aromas. Nice coffee bitterness. Chocolate and caramel and toffee even a little vanilla bean. Very easy drinking stout. Not at all heavy. Makes you want more than one. A very, very competent offering by a premier brewery.

Pours as a stout should, black with a mocha colored head.  Head dissipates but hangs around for the long haul.  Aroma is roasty with some coffee and burnt toast.  Taste is smooth with some lingering bitterness.  Top notch stout.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2010 Drank my last bottle a couple days ago, so going from memory, a fond memory.    Poured an attractive deep black/brown with thick head.  Smooth tasting with hint of roasted malt and tinge of hops on the finish.  Not as complex as some of the stouts Ive had, but very drinkable.
This is my favorite beer. Very nice aroma. Perfectly blended roast and dark malt flavor. Chocolate taste with hint of coffee. Very good creamy finish. very good beer.

Got a 6-pack of bottles from Binnys Beverage Depot. Not a whole lot of aroma here. (Must admit - I work at a chemical plant so I cant judge beer by aroma.) Slight smells of coffee and chocolate. Looks great. Nice brown head, dark as motor oil. Definitely no shortage of taste - the chocolate and coffee come through perfectly and are not overdone. Good on the tongue with a pleasant aftertaste. Would definitely buy this again.

Purchased at World Market, Winston-Salem, NC

Beautiful pour; extremely inviting scent.  Tastes terrificly smooth without being too heavy.

12 oz. Bottle 
Pours a thick, dark brown head.
Nice medium aroma.
Rich and flavorful 
You can taste a hint of chocolate, coffee, molasses and licorice.
Deep black with a creamy head.  Rich and flavorful with chocolate, coffee, molasses and a hint of licorice.  A very solid stout.

12 oz bottle, stout glass. 
Opaque. Two finger dark brown head that shows excellent retention and thick sticky lace. 
Roasted malt aroma, with notes of chocolate, liquorice and molasses. Occasional hint of sour milk, not offputting however. 
Flavor is coffee, roasty malts with just a slight hint of liquorice. 
Long roasted coffee finish. Tasty and easy drinking.

This was the first beer I had after finding out my first duty assignment. I decided to come to my favorite bar and have one beer, even though I had PT the next day. I considered long and hard and eventually decided upon a beer that honored my mother who opposed my decision to join the US Army- a Kalamazoo Stout. Kalamazoo Stout because Kalamazoo is where she went to university.

Pours black with a rather thick head for a stout, medium brown head. Aroma is of chocolate, molasses, and alcohol. Body is thin with some nice carbonation. Pleasant and smooth on the tongue, it really dances on the back corners. Taste is fruit then coffee on the back end with alcohol.

Bottle #8364  Bottle poured to glass.  Dark brown/black beer with a brown head.  Aroma is roasty, slight toffee and caramel.  Smooth mouth-feel, sweet on side of the tongue.  Soft carbonation but yet light and tingly on the palate.  Fermented fairly dry, nice Belgian lacing on the side of the glass.  Head dissipated  in a few minutes but soft carbonation remained.  This is another Excellent beer from Bell Brewery.  Keep up the good work

Thanks to barzigkin for sharing this bottle.

Pours black with a tan head. The aroma is awesome, with coffee, roasted malts and some cream. The flavor is bitter coffee, roasted malts, cream and some chocolate. The aftertaste is cream. Thick mouthfeel and low carbonation.

Batch 9210. Drank on 3/1/10. A black beer with a very nice brown head-looks great. The aroma was roasty, & chocolate. The taste was roasty, chocolate, like baked chocolate  bread with a nice roasted crust. Very nice stout.
Bottle thanks to barzigkin. Dark brown red. Aroma is coffee, vanilla, earth, slightly bitter with a roasty finish.
12 ounce bottle A deep dark pour brown head A big coffe and licorice presence.A real nice stout

Bottle from BarZigKin.  Dark pour with a thick tan head.  Aroma is lightly roasted coffee, and a little chocolate.  More milk chocolate taste, caramel, roasted malts.  I can definitely taste the licorice, which has to be one of my least favorite candies, though it isnt present enough to ruin the beer for me.

12oz bottle.  Pours a near-opaque body with a creamy tan head that fades to a lightly sticky ring.  Aroma is roasty, very fresh coffee, milk chocolate and cream.  Taste is a blend of fresh coffee, bittersweet chocolate, roastiness and light sweetness.  Full, creamy mouthfeel and body.  Looooooong coffee bitter finish thats very smooth.  I want to drink the whole six-pack!!

Bottle.  Pours dark as night with a small tan head.  Aroma and flavor is of coffee, a bit of chocolate, licorice, molasses, semisweet roasted malt.  Thick, somewhat chalky mouth feel; a bit astringent.  Very tasty, semisweet stout.

Pours a dark coffee color with a dark beige head, typical for a stout.  Aroma was a mix of roasted malts, coffee, and dark chocolate.  Taste was similar to the aroma, but with a little more emphasis on the roast and coffee rather than cocoa.  Pretty good weight, one of the better stouts Ive had.

12 oz. bottle(#9515) to favorite  snifter. Aroma earthy malt little coffee and very faint licorice. Appearance has solid pour with tight off white head that dissapears to a lasting film on top. Surprised that it wasnt as thick as I thought it might be. Taste is creamy malt with licorice and coffee after tastes that finishes dry. Palate is thin-medium body chaulky feel and dry finish.I really like this one Bells continues to succeed!

MrChopin is my hero!  Can you guess he sent me this?  Yummy yummy yummy.  Great dark ass brew.  Nose has a hint of cat piss, in a really good way.  Malt and HINTS of sweetness hidden among the bitter.  Nice finish with pungent afters.  Malt and hoppiness and good.  Some cocoa, and some malt-ball.  Nice brew.
cola black with a beige head and heavy lacing. strong roasted coffee nose, mouthfeel slightly more viscous than most stouts, but not syrupy. somewhat bitter. awesome.

Deep black with coffee head. Nice lasting lacing. Aroma is somewhat lacking although I am a bit stuffy. Flavor is cocoa and roasted malt. A bit subdued as well. Not much on the finish. Decent but not getting what is in the description.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2010 12 oz bottle poured into English pint glass.  Pours to an opaque dark brown with a creamy tan head.  Nose is caramel, roasted grains, and coffee.  There is a bitter bite from the roasted grains, but it met with a slightly sweet creamyness.  The crystal and roasted malts meet each other half way, making a fairly smooth beer.  Thee coffee profile is fabulous. They must have been conservative with their hop usage while brewing this one, as there isnt any detectible flavor.  This is an excellent American stout.

Great subtle aroma of coffee in sweet malts. Rich and heady, roasted, just a bit of alcohol in the end. Very dark, not much head or lacing. Smooth dark malt with coffee on the tounge, after a few sips there is a bitterness at the end that has just a hint of licorice, but otherwise its unpronounced. I thought it was just hops until I read the label. A very nice and smooth stout, but just a touch thinnish.

Pours Black with a thick foamy head. Deep brown in colour. Very rich malty aroma, coffee, and roasted barley. and a hint of chocolate. NIce flavour chocolate and coffee, with a bold and bitter mid palate. then roasted malt and a long lingering bitter almost sour flavour constantly changing until I take  another drink. this is a nice stout.

Draft at redlight redlight.  Pours black (opaque).  Strong roasted notes on the nose, but a great complexity beyond just that.  Hints of Belgian chocolate, toffee, mocha, and vanilla make for a enticing aroma.  Semi-sweet very delicious flavor.  Creamy and smooth, an excellent stout.
pours pitch black with tan head. aroma is burnt malts, bitter chocolate, old coffee. drinks semisweet with burnt malts all over this one as well as hints of bitter chocolate and molasses.

(sample)  Pours a black color with tan head.  Has a huge roasted coffee aroma,  which is also backed up with a chocolate nose.  Tastes of chocolate, coffee, nuts and roasted malt.  Also has notes of vanilla and smoke.  Creamy texture, flat carbonation and full bodied.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2013 12oz bottle.  Re-rating.  Pours black with an orange-tinged tan head.  The nose is very molasses forward, dried fruit, earthy notes, light vanilla, plum, and coffee.  Taste has big coffee notes up front, followed by dry molasses, some light acidity, dried fruits, light cocoa, a light hint of methol,  and a dry bitter finish that has some ash, and citrus.

12 oz. bottle poured into a snifter. Pours a deep, dark, opaque black with a thick frothy tan head that dissipates quickly but resurrects nicely with a slight swirl of the glass. Good lacing. The aroma is roasted malt, cocoa, and very subtle caramel. Flavor is roasted malt with a coffee bitterness, almost like espresso. Nicely balanced by a molasses sweetness. Dry finish. Full bodied. Very smooth and creamy. Medium carbonation. Really nice stout.

12 oz Bottle -- Pours black with a small tan head.  Flavors and aromas of fennel, dark and milk chocolate, roasted malts, and hay.  Sweet throughout and a very long finish that is slightly sour and bitter.

Bottle pours deep, dark brown with a turbulent khaki colored head.  Aroma is heavy in licorice, cocoa, vanilla, and roasted malt with a touch of coconut.  Flavor shows the same, with additional notes of graham cracker, coffee, caramel, and trace amount of molasses.  The overall body is moderate-full with a decent amount of carbonation.  Starts sweet and finishes with a beautiful earthy hop presence. Ive been waiting for this one to hit AZ for some time.  Even though typically im partial to drier stouts, this balances almost perfectly, making it one of the most sessionable stouts on the market.

Pours dark brown with nice tan head. Nice sweet malt, chocolate, slight caramel. Flavor is roasted malt, chocolate and slight dried fruit and traces of bitter. Medium to light body. Nice lingering toasted malts.

Bottle from Chevy Chase Wine & Liquors in DC.  This is a blackun.  Pretty damn dark with a two-finger tan head and decent lacing.  Aroma is roast, anise, chocolate, and caramel.  Flavor is caramel malt and roasted malt, bitter coffee, chocolate, molasses, and licorice.  Fairly complex.  A touch of rubbing alcohol at first, but this goes away as the beer warms so I dont consider it a flaw.  Smooth on the palate with medium-full body and some great lasting roast/bitterness.  Overall this is a very good stout.
Pours out dark black with a huge tan head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is a bit roasty with some chocolate and coffee notes, and the taste is the same.  solid brew

Ill be damned.  This is one of the better beers Ive ever tasted.  Im not even normally a stout person.

Beautiful color, almost black with a decent off-white head.
Wonderful roast flavor well balanced with molasses. 
Finishes really smooth.
Excellent.  Highly recommend.ed

Thanks to Savvy1982 for the share! Pours black with a nice tan head. The aroma is bursting with chocolate, vanilla, crackers and red fruit. The flavor has even more punch than the nose. Dark chocolate, coffee, graham crackers, vanilla, milk chocolate, and a nutty finish. Like the other world class stouts Ive tried, it alternates from bitter to sweet. Wow!

Pours a conservative head with a light opaque body. No heaviness in the taste, balanced and very roasty. Very well put together flavors of chocolate, brown sugar, and small hints of hops to provide a subtle bitterness in the finish.

Bottle shared by awiseman.  Aroma is sweet and syrupy, with some dark fruit.  Pours almost black with a thin soapy looking tan head.  Taste of cream and molasses, with some coffee notes later on.  Initially sharp on the tongue, with some bitterness.  Thick and creamy mouthfeel.  Very enjoyable.

Bottle from Red Barrel in Mooresville shared with Brother Nathan. Pours dark black with slight brown edge and minimal beige head. Nose is roasted malt, brown sugar and molasses. Flavor is slightly sour/bitter, dark roasted malt, minimal hops and again molasses. A very decent stout.
Pours out dark black with a small tan head that dissipates quickly. Aroma is a bit roasty with some chocolate and coffee notes, and the taste is the same. Another solid brew from the folks at Bells.
Draft at Mothers Pub, Gainesville, FL. Pours motor oil black with a foamy brown head. Loads of roasted malts, caramel, brown sugar, goes down easy.
UPDATED: MAR 14, 2010 Pours black with a beautiful dark beige head... almost brown. The aroma and taste is roasted malts and dark chocolate. By far the best Bells I have had.  Overall very good.

Dark brown to black hue with a modest layer of that head that persists and leaves thick lacing on the glass. Nose is dominated by roastiness as well as cocoa and coffee. Flavor is sweet chocolate malts balanced by bitter coffee and roast, hints of anise, molasses, and caramel in the background, drying finish. Full body, moderate-high carbonation leaves a touch of prickliness, smooth texture. A full bodied, easy-drinking, smooth American stout that embodies the style in all ways, delicious!

obsidian pour with a tall tan head.  aromas of chocolate, molasses, cream, cocoa butter.  Rich flavors of roasted malt, tabacco, chocolate, cream, coffee bean.  Delicious and straightforward.  A delightfully creamy stout. An impressively big stout, with a creamy mouth.

Super dark black pour with a vivacious tan head. Aroma is loaded with coffee, molasses, roast, chocolate, and cream. Huge pronounced aromatics. Flavor is utterly delicious. A massive roast note combines with huge coffee and humongous bitter chocolate with the perfect hop balance. Palate is amazingly full and rich, with a velvety smooth mouthfeel and a chalky roasty dry finish.

aroma is bakers chocolate devoid of java. appearance is jet black with little lingering head but film. flavor is big cocoa and well developed hops that provide good background bitterness; which lingers and does well to mesh with the chocolate savory note rather then offset it. palate is thickened even when stored (temporarily) in a chicago winter to preclude fridge space limitations the day before christmas dinner.

One of the darkest richest pours i have ever seen. lots of tan head. subtle sweet toast notes on the nose. delicious mixture of sweet, just a hint of bitter, and wonderful toast notes all of which linger on the palate beautifully.

Batch #8338 Bottled 2/22/08. I left work for the last time today as I joined the realm of the retired and this was the first post-work beer I had. Poured black with a good brown creamy head. The head left nice lacing throughout the glass. The aroma was sweet chocolate, coffee and a hint of anise/licorice. The initial flavor was on a lightly sweet side with chocolate, coffee and then rolled to a mild bitterness with more of the coffee and anise flavors coming through. Thhe finish remained slightly on the bitter side, but was very smooth and flavorful. At 6% ABV this is a good session beer and very enjoyable

Bottle, with thanks to bitbucket. Bob you are the man! Pours a deep black, with ultra-fine carbonation. Nose is graham crackers, coconut, sweet roasty/toasty malt, marshmallow, chocolate, oh man this smells like the best smores ever. Brazil nuts and hazelnuts also present. Flavours of roast barley, light smoke, milk chocolate, dry nuttiness, like a Ferraro Rocher without the sugar. Fantastic!

UPDATED: JUN 17, 2012 (br-btl cm-lbl, Bells Brewery in Comstock MI, "Brewed with brewers licorice", 6%)

opq-bk, thin-tan-head, syrupy-full-body, ^co2.

aroma: roasted-malt §lcrc §bready-alchl §fresh-hop.

roast-malt §lcrc T1 §sweet-bread fruity alchl-warm T2 §herbal-hop chrcl T3.
too top-of-the-tongue, needs to be creamier, no good malt or hop flavors. mostly burnt and yeast phenols.
Pours a dark with lite white/brown head.  Chocolate overwellming taste and aroma.  Wonderfull overall stout. Great brew.
Licorice aroma with a strong coffee taste. A bitter aftertaste that hits hard.

This is one beastly stout!  Gorgeous black color in the glass with dark brown head that almost overflowed my glass.  Head retention is good with nice lace.  Nose has some pleasant freshly ground coffee aromas and a trace of fruit in the distant background.  Big dessert flavors are noted on the palate, perhaps like one of those double chocolate chip cookies.  Hops balance out nicely, and finish is long with a lot of roasty flavors.
another great brew from bells. these guys know whats up. great black color with dirty brown head that lasts till the end. if u like stouts this is a no brainer.

Pours jet black in color with a boisterous brown head that leaves a decent lacing behind.  Aroma consists of bubblegum, licorice, with hints of toffee, coffee, and roasted malt.  Taste is bitterness of roasted malt and coffee up front, with sweetness of black licorice in the finish.  A bit watery finish as well though.

Bottle. Black, with a foamy medium tan head that soon dissipates to about half a fingers width but leaves some nice lacing. Chocolate and a little licorice in the aroma. Flavor is rather rich up front, with clean roasted and caramel malts leading into a chocolate coffee finish and a lightly bitter aftertaste. This has a malt profile that would make a great imperial stout, if it were about one and a half times as big. Smooth palate. A nice stout. I could easily see this as a great everyday drinking stout, if it didnt come from a thousand miles away...

A: Deep black in color with a nice espresso head that fades to a nice ring atop the glass. 

S: Nice malty brew. There are definite Coffee, Chocolate, and Caramel aromas here. 

T: I like this one, not the best of the Bells bunch but good nonetheless. Has a nice smokiness to it. I can taste hazelnuts, chocolate, dark roasted coffee, and charcoal. 

M: Its an easy drinker. Medium in body, but goes down ever so smooth.
This beer pours a really dark black with a medium tan head. Smell of roasted coffee and chocolate. Taste is the same as the smell; roasted coffee and chocolate. Great beer and on a winter day.
12-oz bottle. Licorice and soy sauce in the aroma. Roasty malt and licorice up front. Coffee in the finish. Medium body. Clean finish. High drinkability. Another winner by Bells.
deep black, licorice and choc dominate in the nose but also seep into the flavorsome coffee nice well done stout

Dark brown-black with a beige-brownish lasting and ceamy head. Aromas of rosted nuts and chocolate. Full body with masses of flavors, crisp CO2 attack than chocolate, roasted malt, licorice and a long roasty finish. I sampled this one too cold, but I suspect it is amazing as it warms up. Very nice stout.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2010 Solid, dark pour topped by an ample creamy head.  Aroma is roasted caramel and chocolate malts with hints of spice.  Flavor is the same, and brings forth hints of dark fruit  along with notes of allspice.  Mouthfeel is fantastically creamy and smooth.  Almost (but not quite) too big for its britches to be in the standard stout category.  This is amazing, and seems to be my favorite regular stout so far.  Cant seem to go wrong with a Bells stout.
Nice black pour with a creamy head.  The roasted malts give off a rich smooth chocolate coffee flavor.  The hops are present in the background but does not steal the show.

This stout poured a deep black colour with a nice big, dark brown head. Nice lacing too. To the nose there are scents of roasted coffee, caramel, cocoa and molassass. First sip was rich and smooth with a velvet mouthfeel. Flavours of coffee with a little chocolate and hopps. Finish is creamy and very roasted with a little hopp flavour. Palate has a nice mild coffee flavour that lasts and lasts....One of the best stouts Ive ever had.
Poured thick black with tan head, smelled of dark coffee and smoky undertones.  A very woody, roasted stout with coffee and sweet malt after.  Excellent beer!

Batch 9016.  Pours a rich dark black with just a dusting of light brown sugar head that very quickly dissipates.  Aroma is fully of coffee, dark chocolate and anise.  Wow, the first taste is a carnival of caramel, coffee, anise, dark fruits, and more.  This type of flavor is normally reserved for the imperial stouts, but this little guy makes up for in flavor what he lacks in booze.  The dryness is just right, and well balanced by the creamy, full mouthfeel.  A supreme treat.  I miss K-zoo.

Bottle. Poured black with a particularly thin dark brown/chocolate head. Aroma has sweet coffee notes with a bit of caramel underneath. Flavor has strong coffee notes, but chocolate and caramel undertones balance it out nicely. Quite thick on the tongue.

11/2009
Batch 9210

Pours very dark brown with a bubbly tan head.  Smells like  a mix of fresh roasted coffee and molasses.  Has a silky cream flavor immediately balanced by coffee, dark chocolate, and molasses.

Apparently I forgot this one, so this is actually from a couple weeks ago. Pours pitch black with a thick, chocolaty head. Aroma of sweet caramel, coffee, and very earthy tones. Wonder taste of dark chocolate, strong coffee with caramel, and has a thick mouthfeel. Finishes sweet with a hint of bitterness. Guinness lovers eat (drink?) your heart out.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2009 Very complex stout, full of flavor that few can get.  Surprised it is not considered an imperial, but non the less very tasty.  The pour was black, the black licorice stood out in flavor, Very balance.

Poured from bottle into Nonic Imperial Pint.

Black, completely opaque, thin head that dissipates. Would have scored higher if better head retention.

Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and licorice.

More bitter than I would expect from a Sweet Stout, and only slightly sweet. Bitterness seems to come from both hops and heavily roasted malts. Coffee, chocolate and licorice flavors.

Full-bodied, exceedingly smooth, relatively low carbonation.

Between the smoothness and fantastic taste, this is one of the most drinkable stouts.

Not sure if this is an English Sweet Stout or an American Stout. Doesnt matter, as either way, this is the best non-Imperial Stout I have ever had.

Incredibly complex for a stout, with waves of sensational variations of palate - rich, creamy, chocolatey, caramel, etc. Absolutely delicious and top-notch. Wow. The sheer opaqueness of this dark brew is not the kind youd be OK spilling on your white carpet. Really amazing and one of the best stouts Ive had.
Tried a sample at Brewfest Tallahassee, and it was probably the best beer outside of the VIP section.  A great example of a standard stout with coffee, chocolate, roast, and more.

I am a big stout fan and was heavily anticipating the entrance of Bell into my home state, Alabama, and I was honestly disappointed by this Bell creation.  On the bright side, it had a nice texture, thick and creamy.  However, it also did not taste very good.  The coffee flavor was obvious and maybe a bit overdone; moreover, there was another flavor that I cannot identify and really did not enjoy.  I dont think I would drink this beer again.
Drank it with my wife, while eating a delicious Vosges Red Fire Chocolate Bar.  Pours pitch black, medium bodied, nice roasted mouth feel, not sweet, rather dry with chocolate undertones.

Pours pitch black wth a big, frothy, light brown head. Aroma holds roasted malt, coffee, bitter chocolate, some cream, and a bit of sweetness, perhaps caramel, as well. Flavor is excellent: dry, roasty malt abound, along with coffee, caramel, and dark chocolate. A nice dry bitterness holds at the finish, but the majority of the palate prior to that is rich and delicious. Really an excellent specimen of a lower alcohol stout, deservedly in the top 5 for the style. Another excellent brew from Bells.

Pours black. Big smells of roasted malts. Flavor is very well balanced with the malts and bitterness. Gets better as it warms up in the glass with some hints of chocolate and roasted malts tasting somewhat sweet with wisps of coffee. Good stout for any occasion.

Bottle, awesome awesome stout.  Big roasty nose that seems overwhelming and heavy, but a smooth silky body that stays nice and light as it warms.  Im so amazed at the coffee and rich creamy chocolate notes.  The body is pretty standard black with no visibility and a light brown loose frothy head that receeded as quickly as it grew.  Lots of lacing on the glass however.  This beer is just so balanced.  There is no waste.  Hats off to Bells on this one.

pours dark brown, beihe head.
Aroma of roasted malts, light bitetrness.
Flavor, malty with hints of spices and roast. Some hints of chocolate giving a light bitter mouthfeel.
Medium body, wonderful and easy to drink. Might seem to be more than 6%

12oz bottle.  Pours dark brown with nice looking tan head. Decent aroma.  Very smooth for a stout at first but goes down like a bigger stout.  Great aftertaste.  Hints of chocolate and almost a coffee taste going down.  Delicious.   Ive had better stouts but this one worth buying again.

12 oz bottle. Dark brown with a thick tan head that leaves some lacing. Aroma of chocolate, roasty grains, caramel and even some hop aroma buried in there. The flavor is rich and sweet with lots of chocolate and coffee, there is also a roasted bitterness. Full body with average carbonation and a soft creamy mouth feel. Long roasty finish. Very well done Stout, tastes a lot bigger than it really is.

Pours black with no head. Aroma is metallic, fish-like and not terribly pleasant. In fact, I cant stand inhaling while I sip this. Taste is heavy on bitter, roasted malts - at least on the back end. Up front, it is missing something . . . like flavor. Abrupt finish too. The mouth feel is good though - creamy and full-bodied. 
Drinkable, but there are better stouts out there.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2010 Nice aroma and flavor from this one.  Sometimes I need to remind myself not every stout I drink is an imperial and need to adjust my expectations accordingly.  Overall, a great offering from Bells, but you already knew that.

Bottle at Monks Café Wallingatan, Stockholm.

Rosted malt, licorice and coffe beans.

Well balanced despite lots of flavours but low in alcohol
Bottle. Very big beer for a 6%ABV. Lots of roasted tones, coffee, dark chocolate. Small saltiness.

12 oz bottle. Pours pitch black with a dark tan head, minimal lacing. Delicious. Substantial roasted malt flavor, but still smooth. Very Delicious. Excellent finish that leaves you wanting more. Oh, and did i say it was delicious? Because it is.
Bottle at Hopleaf. This black ale poured with a two-finger tan head and a strong chocolate nose. There is a rich coffee and treacle flavor with a very dry finish and lots of carbonation.
Bottle. Dark pour with tan head. Dark malt, slight caramel and licorice flavoring. Although these flavors usually are heavy flavor is light on the senses and has a smooth mouthfeel.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2013 Pours pitch black with a great tan head that clings to the glass. Obvious roated, light nose. A solid stout with a nice "burnt" finish.  Light on the tongue but smooth.

Notes: still great 4 yrs later

Pours dark brown/black with a dark brown head. The aroma is dark fruit, licorice, and a touch of chocolate. The flavor is smooth and chocolaty. Nice roasted feel with low carbonation. You taste the licorice on the palate as it goes down. Medium bodied and Kalua like. Feels way bigger than a 6%. Tastiest stout Ive had!

Bottle at Monks Café, Stockholm. 
Pours pitch black with a brown head. 
Aroma is roasted malt, coffee and dark chocolate with hints of prunes. 
Flavour is dark chocolate, liquorice and coffee. 
Quite smooth on the palate.

Pours just a hint off jet-black with off-tan thin head.  Aroma is sweet, chocolate, hint of roast and some plums/raisins.  Oh this is good.  Very smooth, creamy, with a roasty and dry aftertaste that lingers.   Chocolate, coffee and and a hint of fruit flavor very faint and fades as the roastiness steps up.  Well balanced, nice flavor, nothing too extreme.  If anything the palate is a bit light.

Pure black, small dark brown head. Chocolate aroma. Wonderful velvety mouthfeel with a beautiful and undeniably silky finish with plenty of flavours rolling across your tongue. Full bodied. Nice bitterness in the finish. Complex chocolate flavours develop in the finish. With a richer aroma, it would be nearly perfect. Breathtaking.

Bottle at Monks Cafe, Stockholm. Pitch black body with a medium brown head. ARoma has lots of coffee, roasted malt, caramel and chocolate. Flavour is coffee, roasted malt, coffee and light tobacco. Creamy texture. Lovely brew.
Great Stout! Smooth, dark, dry, roasted flavors. Thus pours dark brown/black with little head. Classic stout flavor without much more. It doesnt need more, this is done perfectly.
A strong aroma and a very opaque appearance. The mix of flavors includes a creamy caramel, coffee, licorice, grapes and cherries. Hearty, but very smooth for a stout.

3 bottles consumed, acquired via trade. Pours black as pitch with a very minimal tan head and solid lacing. Aroma is licorice, chocolate, toasted malt, a hint of earthy hop. Flavor is big on the toasted malt with less licorice than I expected and a solid chocolate backing that keeps it all in line. Another excellent beer from Bells, I really wish they distributed out here, I bet theyd find a huge market!

12oz bottle. dark black pour. small lasting dark tan head. the aroma fills the air with the pour. dark chocolate, roast. the taste is smooth and creamy, thick on the tongue. heavy chocolate and toasted malts. touch of bitter balance at the finish. wish i could get this in my neck of NY. delicious

(Bottle, Monks Café, Wallingatan, Stockholm) Black colour with frothy, beige head. Roasted, malty nose with dark chocolate, cocoa, coffee and a hint of liquorice. Malty, roasted taste with notes of dark chocolate, coffee, some liquorice and a dry, smotth, creamy finish with some coffee bitterness. Great balance. More or less what stout is all about. Lovely beer!

Bottle, poured into pint glass. I was stoked to see this at my local bottle shop; first time Ive seen Bells anywhere in GA. Poured inky black, with a one-inch light brown head that held till the beer was about two-thirds gone. Beautiful nose of roasted malts, slightly burnt chocolate, and caramel. Taste is VERY roasted and smoky, with a bit of espresso and molasses coming through. My new favorite stout not preceded by the word "imperial."

Bottle (Batch 9095) thanks to FlssmrBrewAlum.. Pours black with a thin ring head..Aroma is slightly sweet with some roasted malts...Lots of dark chocolate with lingering bitterness, some coffee and roasted malts as well.. Lots of carbonation

Appearance is a beauty. Thick, creamy head that dissapears after a few minutes leaving a thick lace. The beer pours very dark and gives the impression of thickness. 

Smell is typical for this style, cream/milk with hints of caramel and other sweet scents. 

Taste is damn good, delivering what I want in a sweet stout with major blasts of cream.

Mouthfeel is good with a medium to thick body that coats the mouth as it goes down. 

Drinkability is a high point, this goes down easy and Would make a good session stout. Would have again.

12 oz. bottle at Fries Cafe in Cincinnati.  Pours almost black with lumpy brown head that thins quickly.  Aroma is roast, coffee, a bit of chocolate, syrup, molasses.  Flavor is very smoky, with roast coffee, syrup, sugar, malt.  Complex but slightly overwhelmed by the smokiness.  Medium body and smooth on the palate, both sweet and a little bitter.  Sweet coffee aftertaste.  Very unique stout.

Bottled. Aroma has roast, rye, coffee, some dried fruits. Excellent! Black coloured with a beige head. The taste is slightly bitter, has some sweetness, coffee, roast, rye, dried fruits and some black currant. Medium bodied. Fine beer.

Bottled. Dark color, medium brownish head. Aroma of roasted malt, bit of rye, plums, dried fruit, slight hint of vanilla, chocolat. Taste of rye and roasted malts, and is not as complex as the aroma. Very good beer, a bit overrated perhaps, but for the style it deserves its rating.

Extremely complex nose but the flavor does not quite live up. Nevertheless an excellent flavor. Missing the licorice but the rest of the chocolate and coffee flavors carries it through. Body not completely full as you would expect. Hoppiness quite pronounced for style and not out of place at all. The only thing keeping this from being truly excellent is the palate. Dont get me wrong though, this beer is still highly recommended.

(12oz bottle) Pours black with tan bubbles carbonating the top 1". Great lacing. Nose is extremely complex, oats, sweet syrup. Taste is beet sugar, coffee, dark chocolate and also quite complex. Nicely carbonated, smoky dry finish with some lingering coffee as well. Quite good.
Heavy Oreo cookie malty, light hop light yeast.  Sweet yet mild 6% ABV. No metalic aftertaste, only sweet root beer.  No head strong lacing and 99% opaque.  Great great drinking stout.

from crackedkettle.com - almost opaque black colour with a firm persistent dark beige foam; nice lace leaved on the side of the glass; the aroma is charming and robust showing notes of licorice along with roasted malts and dark chocolate; fair hop presence too; respectable malt body, creamy mouthfeel and with a fair and subtle carbonation; solidly bitter, quite dry and with a long hoppy finish with more roasted chocolate and licorice - absolutely wonderful beer

Bottle on 08/08/09.  Pours a deep opaque black with a small tannish head which quickly dissipated.  Aroma is caramel and chocolate with a sort of milk stout-ish sweetness.  Flavors are what I think a great pint of Guinness should taste like.  Deeply roasted and dry without being too heavy.  The finish is distinctly bitter, with probable contribution by the strongly roasted/burnt malts.  A nice solid offering that Ive been wanting to try for a good while.

Bottle on 8/8/09.  Pours jet black, bubbly mocha head that doesnt stay long.  Coffee in aroma that is dominated by sweet chocolate and caramel.  Extremely well balanced stout.  Nice sweetness, then a slow bitterness, then an amazing bitter coffee finish that lingers.

Deep rich black, huge foamy brown head. Aroma roasted coffee, chocolate, soy sauce, caramel. Flavor slightly smoky, roast (almost burnt) chocolate, coffee, caramel, and a lingering tang of soy sauce. Decent stout.

This was an overall good Stout. Poured dark with a small brown head that was short lasting. Not quite as strong as some Stouts but was refreshingly tasty. The aroma was pleasant with undertones of coffee and roasted grains. A must try. Not the best Stout around but still delicious.

batch #6007 bottle thanks to brentfeesh.  i think this bottle was at least 5 years old because it was not popping up on website.  poured black with a tan head that laced the glass.  aroma of coffee, chocolate, and dark fruits.  flavor was coffee, chocolate, dark fruit, and burnt roast.

12 ounce bottle enjoyed on a rainy summer day. Absolutely picture perfect pour. It came out a dark black color with a very nice 1.5 finger width tan head. The aroma is fairly bland for a stout. It consisted of roasted malt, faint coffee, and possibly some very subtle dark fruit notes. The taste also consisted of roasted malt and some coffee. It left a bit of a strange metallic aftertaste though. Finished with a nice bitter taste. Overall, a very good stout, but definitely not as good as Bells Expedition...
Tried this at a tasting at Wine World in NA. Bought some, went home and consumed more. Is it great? Yes. Best? No. But its a wonderful beer!

Bottle courtesy of ericandersnavy.  Batch 6007. Solid black pour with a tangible head. Beautiful notes of coffee and chocolate. Some smoked notes as well like soft bacon. Meat remains on the flavor. Interesting taste. Finish retains a smoky feeling. Some amounts of bitter coffee. A good stout that aged for several years before we enjoyed it.
Pours dark brown with tan head. Roasted malt chocolate sweet licorice. Taste roasted malt burnt bread herbs licorice dry sweet smooth. Exellent stout.

Syrupy black pourgreat head with lacing.  Nose is coffee and a little fruit with ever-so-slight hops.  Chewy mouthfeel.  Taste is strong coffee with consistent smooth malts.  Caramel finish with some hops.  Very complex, powerful brew.  Awesome, but I prefer Expedition.
Pours dark with a light tan head.  Aroma similar to taste with some dry toastiness and a little bitterness.  A good beer.

Batch 8927 - Thanks shawnm213! - Pours a thin dk brown with a small tan head...aroma is burnt toast, cocoa, lt malt...flavour is similar, dry roast, coffee, lingering charred grain bitterness...nice and dry, and well balanced...

Lovely fat aroma for a 6% brew, loads of "brown" smells of molasses, chocolate, light caramell, smooth roasted flavours and some coffe. Very big for the ABV, very drinkable and perfectly balanced but the aroma is a just a bit fater and more inviting then the taste actually delivers.

Pours nearly black with a thin beige head and nice lacing. Coffee aroma and a little roasted malt. The flavor is complex with some coffee, malt, chocolate and a mildly smoky finish. Medium-heavy mouth feel is satisfying. Not too sweet nor bitter, good balance. Overall quite good and will probably be a regular for me.

bottle, pours black with a medium tan head.  Really nice yeasty and roasted malt aroma.  Some oats in there as well.  Flavors are fairly sweet with roasted malt being the primary flavor, accented by some molasses and maple syrup.  Ends dry with a coffee tone. Mouth is medium bodied with light carbonation.  Very drinkable!!!
This amazing beer starts out with a complex aroma. Rich aroma.  The tastes come in as a malty sweetness.  the beer finishes with no bitterness whatever.
(bottle) black with small, quickly disappearing brown head; aroma of coffee, smoked longan; flavours of roasted malts, smokiness, quite dry
Nice dark brown color with creamy head. Liquorish, caramel , roasted malt, chocolate flavors are abundant I loved this beer I cant wait to drive to VA again so I can get more.

Very neat looking chocolate milkshake coloured head alround good retention.Aroma chocolate,coffee mocca like liccorice,maltiness,vanilla note,flavour coffee roasted mellow though,liccorice sweetness prominent,chocolate,seems oily in texture,tasted many better than this it seems dull or flat tasting,finish bitter smooth,roasted flavours but have tasted better.

Pours a near black brown with thin tan head.  Aroma strong of roasted malt, coffee, slight chocolate, and a decent bit of smoke.  Flavor matches well and has a very nice combination of flavors going on.  Quite different, in a good way, than most other stouts.  Finishes creamy and smooth.

Pours a deep black with a thin, brown head. Aroma is roasty with hints of chocolate. Texture is thick, creamy, and quite smooth. Flavor is very roasty with apparent notes of chocolate and coffee and hints of smoke, molasses. Medium bitterness with a sweet finish. Good stout overall.

On tap at Bells Eccentric Café. Opaque black with a medium off-white head. Great roast aroma with chocolate and molasses. Flavor is dominated by roasted malts with bitter dark chocolate, a bit of smoke, and subtle coffee. A touch of toffee sweetness balances it out. Mouthfeel is medium-bodied and creamy. A ton of flavor, and very drinkable. A quintessential stout.

Black with a medium beige head. Sweet aroma with roasted malt, chocolate and caramel notes. Flavour had dark bitter chocolate, burned malt, coffee and toffee notes. Finished sweet. Perfect balance and a nice mouthfeel.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown-black, with a small tan head.  Faint licorice, semisweet chocolate and coffee on the nose.  Flavor is wonderfully roasty and smoky, all dark and wonderful.  The roastiness is kept in check by some residual sugar and salt (sort of club soda-esque), perhaps if prompted I might claim to taste licorice as well.  Finishing palate is quite dry.  Overall this is an excellent standard stout; doesnt try to do too much.
Nice, sweet, slight smoky flavor, smooth like an oatmeal stout, like an imperial sweet stout. This great, especially for the price. Bottle at Total Wine Ft. Lauderdale.

Pitch black beer, light brown head. The aroma has coffee, chocolate and malt, really powerful smell for such a small abv beer. I am seriously impressed. Sweet taste, a bit tarry, bitter and roasted. The mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. A top notch beer and my favorite from Bells easily so far, if every stout around this abv would pack this much flavour I would be one happy camper.

12 oz bottle.  Poured almost pitch black with a small brown head.  Could pick up an aroma of milk chocolate and not much else.  Taste is similar; rich in chocolate and dark coffee flavors, but there isnt much going on here.  Its nice and creamy, but I would prefer for more to be going on here.
Pours a dark brown with creamy beige, full head.  A beautiful pour.  Mouth feel is slightly smoky with hint of sweetness. Coffee and chocolate present.  Very, very enjoyable.
Pours black with a beige head. Smells of chocolate and molasses.  This is a very drinkable and smooth stout.

Bottle. A black beer with a creamy, persistent, brown head. The aroma is fantastic, powerful rich and malty, with notes of roasted malts, black chocolate, coffee and molasses. Very light hops in the nose. The flavour has a medium sweetness and a light acidity. The roasted malts are present, but quite gently. Creamy and smooth mouthfeel, medium body, lively carbonation, long finish with medium bitterness. Overall fantastic aroma and appearence, very good flavour and palate and very drinkable since the ABV. A perfect session stout.

Comes out of the bottle a deep, opaque sable with a thick beige head. Aroma is strong and oily, mainly of burnt coffee. Mouth-filling flavor is strongly smoky with a coffee undertone and hints of molasses. There is just a hint of sweetness and just a hint of hop bitterness. Texture is thick and smooth with a tingly edge, and it leaves a coffee-ish aftertaste.

The bottle I had poured a nice dark brown color, not as dark as some of the stouts I have tried recently.  It had a nice caramel light brown colored head that left nice lacing in the glass.  It had a great aroma, not too much of coffee, but a heavy scent of chocolate and molasses.  When I tasted it, I noticed right off the bat that this stout was not quite as strong as others - didnt quite have the bitter coffee flavor.  It was balanced very well.  I like this beer and will be having this again.

This is a batch 8606 bottle.
Appearance  Pours a dark brown, almost black with light brown edges when held up to the light. A nice dense mocha colored head forms about 1 finger in size. The head retention is wonderful, sticks around for a while. After a little while it subsides to a thin layering of large bubbles.

Smell  This smells slightly astringent. Lots of hops, burnt chocolate, coffee, and the tiniest bit of figs. 

Taste  This has a chalky bitter bakers chocolate feel and taste to it. Like a mocha made with 72% cacao chocolate. Bits of coffee and hops.

Mouthfeel  Like in the taste, this feels chalky. Also it feels a lot thicker than I expected, but not too thick. The higher carbonation makes it a prickly stout.

Drinkability  This isnt the best of stouts, but it certainly is a good one. One will do just fine.
Dark pour with off white head. Creamy, sweet, smooth and rich. Aroma is slightly roasty with nice malt presence. Taste is sweet and semi roasty. Really solid.

Pours dark black but has ruby hints in the light, a very dense brown head that fades to a low patchy film. Aroma is of prune, molasses, dark chocolate, coffee and some sweet caramel notes.  Flavor starts off with some chocolate, fruity prune which fade to the background for a light caramel and finishes with a nice molasses and bitter coffee ending.  Beer has a very nice density and an odd combo of an oily and creamy mouth feel.  Overall a great stout that is just a good,  basic form (non-imperial) of this style.
Pours a dark brown with a light brown head. Great aroma of roasted malts, caramel, coffee, and chocolate. Very roasty tasting stout with great balance. Definitely worth trying...it is what it is...
Aroma of coffee. Flavors of coffee, chocolate, molasses, and booze. Thick and kind of chewy.

Tap @ Eccentric Cafe. Pitch black colour, firm beige head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Flavour of roasted malts, coffee cream and a decent amount of hops. Bitter and dry. Epic stout.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2011 Another gem from whats becoming my favorite brewery (if its not already). Pours to a small, dark tan head. Creamy, moderately thick body. Wonderful blend of nuts, coffee, and caramel. Absolutely delicious!

Requisite black appearance with a large, dense, deep tan head and very good lacing.  Roasted malt aroma with nuances of coffee and bitter chocolate.  Earthy taste with a little smoke  and a subdued sweetness beneath the bitter roasted flavors.  Dry, lingering finish follows the rich, full bodied, moderately carbonate mouthfeel.
Pours black. Roasty malts, coffee, burnt coffee and cocoa nose. Flavor is a bitter cocoa, and roast, some hop bitterness. Smooth mouthfeel, slightly oily. Excellent stout.

Pours an opaque black with a good bit of light brown-tan head and an aroma of matled chocolate.

Flavor starts as dark-roasted coffee and finishes chocolatey with a hint of the licorice mentioned on the label.

Mouthfeel is smooth, not slick at all.  Alcohol content is low and well-hidden. It may be blasphemy, but I think this is a better beer than Expedition Stout!

12 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet (Batch 8927, bottled January 8, 2009).  Black pour with a creamy tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, coffee, and dark chocolate.  Wonderful flavor of bittersweet chocolate and dark roasted coffee.  Very sessionable at only 6% alcohol.
