This has a lot of flavor for a non-imperial stout; hard to imagine finding a stout that is much better.

Another Bells brew, courtesy of my Philly kinfolk.  This label has a drawing of an old guy on it, and he has me wondering if this could be up to the level of their supreme Expedition Stout.  Dark pour and noisy tan head.  Aroma of coffee grounds and yeast.  This is a dry, hoppy stout that is medium bodied and flavorful.  A fine brew that may not be worthy of an expedition, but is well worth drinking if you see it.

bottle poured a dark chestnut brown in color with a dark tan head that took some vigor to produce. aroma of coffee, chocolate, and light roast. mouth feel is creamy with a nice coating and low carbonation. flavor has a nice malted chocolate, coffee, and licorice. comes of rich but the flavors are not overdone and the sweetness is right.

12oz bottle.  Black pour with a big light brown head.  Malty chocolate aroma with coffee and licorice.  Chocolate flavor with a licorice and molasses influence and a bitter coffee finish.  World class.
A very rich, creamy stout with hints of coffee and very dark roasted malts. Very heavy on the tongue leaving you with the impression you are drinking a cream just like a good strong stout should be.

very good beer that has a rich aroma and it great to the taste.  A bit strong for people who are used to lower alc content such as bud or miller. but if you enjoy your beer with a rich malt flavor, this is your beer. Get it in Kalamazoo MI.
Lots of dark fruit in this one, specifically raisins, in addition to the lovely roasty notes that you usually get from a stout.  Man, I wish I lived somewhere that Bells distributed...
pours dark brown almost black little tan head aroma very fain tasted of coffee, chocolate, and malt sweet after taste
12oz bottle. Pours dark brown. Little head. Aroma of roasted. Very subtle. Taste of light coffee and nuts, at least thats what your mom said. Slight bitter aftertaste.

had a couple of times, best tasting was with stumac+mel, in the parking lot of Sherlocks on my 25th birthday. . .. man, this was the bees knees... big licorice aromas ..  very roasty .. tar and burnt sugar .. . big and bold, yet fun and balanced .. . great abv hideout .. . great stuff .. .

Pours black with a medium tan head if poured roughly. Aroma is a heavy roast, sweet chocolate, and coffee.  Flavor roasted malt, sweet chocolate, coffee, and bit of caramel especially in the aftertaste. Nice balanced sweet stout. Could drink this all day.

bottle, sampled 3/14/07.
Pours a thick, dark, flat brown with an inch+ of dark tan head.  Aroma shows plenty of toasted malts, a healthy dose of booze, and some dark bittersweet notes.  Flavor follows, with plenty of smooth, dark semi-sweet roasted grains and some light bitterness.  Licorice notes show up in the flavor, though not overpowering or dominant.  Light booze notes round out the flavor.  Flavor on this on lacks some depth, but without detriment- a nice, simple-ish well brewed stout.  Palate is very smooth and clean with an even finish.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours almost black with small red highlights.  A monster of a tan head!  The first aroma I get is an odd licorice and roasted malt combination.  Further inspection reveals some nice coffee and caramel notes as well.  Medium-low carbonation with a rich mouthfeel.  A mineral taste is the first thing to strike my palate.  Coffee and caramel come along as well.  A bit of dryness on the palate too.  There is a lingering bitterness and a long finish. The body is lighter than I was expecting, helping make the beer very drinkable.  A very respectable stout from a great brewery.

Bottle. Pours a very dark brown with a medium creamy light tan head that lasts awhile that leaves behind good sticky lacing along the glass. The aroma is a roasted malt with molasses and caramel. The taste is a rich roasted malt with chocolate, caramel, and brown sugar. Easy to drink, a very good stout from Bells.

Bells variety case from Neffsville Beer Mart, Lancaster, PA...bottle pours black with a tan head...aroma comes off rather sweet...dry roasty taste with chocolate and a touch of alcohol...good stout...I like Bells.
Bottle thanks to tjthresh.  Pours a black/dark brown pour.  Iced coffee, caramel, roasted malt, and hints of cocoa.  Nice mouth feel with some sweetness and a balanced roasty flavor.  Quite good.
draft at ecentric cafe.  smooth, creamy, nice balance of bitterness and sweetness.  would drink again.

Appearance: As is typical with stouts, Bells Kalamazoo stout pours the color of black coffee. It doesnt have much of a head from the initial pour, but the lacing is rather impressive.  A good swift swirl of the glass will help pull out about a finger of stunning light brown frothy head that (again) disappears quickly.  (4)

Smell: This beer smells very good.  Ive poured this one a bit cold, but right out of the glass I get an explosion of roasted espresso.  This is followed quickly by caramel and bittersweet chocolate aromas.  There is also a nice bit of rich tobacco and floral components that gives this beer quite a bit of depth.    

Taste: Kalamazoo tastes identical to the way it smells, which is a very good thing.  There is lots of soft bitterness right away that helps carry the strong espresso and chocolate components down your throat.  The tobacco from the nose comes across on the tongue, too, which is a very nice touch.  For a 6% ABV beer, this thing is packed to the teeth with deep, dark roasty flavors.  

Mouthfeel: Although there is a ton of roasted flavors in the mouth, the beer feels a lot lighter than youd expect.  The bitterness is only faintly detected by the palate, and there is not a lot of heaviness that coats the mouth.  I would even say this is one of the lighter stouts Ive had; which is good considering how drinkable this is.

Overall: Bells Brewery continues to amaze me.  Ive yet to drink one of their beers that isnt extremely inspired and worthy of my hard earned cash.  The Kalamazoo stout, along with the heavier Expedition stout, is a very solid stout.  Where the Expedition stout is meant to be more of a sipper, the Kalamazoo is something that can be enjoyed at a bit quicker pace.  With such a low ABV, this is one that can be ready to go with only about 30 minutes in the fridge.

12 oz bottle courtesy of the Binnys Singles Rack (Orland Park, IL). A beer Ive been meaning to get at for awhile now. Pours a largely pitch black opaque pour with fairly big brown head that cakes, laces, and moves down to a decent or moderate amount. Aromas are a nice combination of roasted malts, vanilla, creamy chocolate, caramel, light coffee. Initial is a good follow through, medium bodied, nothing overbearing, bringing on some good roasted flavors, bitter chocolate and coffee. Finish brings in some more of that creamy vanilla and caramel, but largely the sweet stays away. Instead depending on roast and bitterness. The beer is smooth and creamy in body, yes.. but stays true to roast. Nothing overbearing or burnt though. Great stout, through and through.

Sampled in Lexington, Ky. A really good stout. Drank out of the bottle. Not too much head, but a really nice smokey taste with a bit of licorice. A really good brew. Drank at room temperature. Quality.

Thanks DrHomolka!  Thick black, sandy 2 finger head had some dull grey in it, maybe I had licorice on the brain.  All I get is black malt on the nose though.  Lighter in body than it looks, lots of roast, balanced and sustained, tastes much deeper than only 6%

Bottle.  Poured solid black with no head.  Aroma is malty with some rasin and chocolate.  Flavor is sweet malt, coffee, dark fruit and a hint of smoke.  Medium bodied, creamy mouthfeel.  Somewhat dry finish.  Good stout.

Finally back in LaSalle County (IL). Welcome back old friend. Dark black pour. Cant see light through it when held up next to a light. Brown head that leaves a nice lace as the beer goes down. Roasted malt aroma with a little sweetness. Little sweetness in the taste, little bitterness, and a slight dry finish.
this is a nice stout.  it was less roasty than i expected but very complex with a pleasant smokiness and light fruity flavor.

Tap at Eccentric Cafe - Pours jet black with a quickly dissapating tan, frothy head. Smells nutty, with roasted barley and malt. Tastes roasty, smoky, nutty, and a bit of sausage in the background. Not the heavy mouthfeel I like in a stout, but pretty good overall.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2009 Must re-rate. I dont know if I had a bad bottle last time, was too drunk, or just pissed off! Who knows? This time I must say the beer looks great. Nice chocolate head, but not that viscous pour I was hoping for. Nice coffe and chocolate aroma, and it becomes even more pungent as the beer warms. Not extremely pungent, but good enough. Nice sweet coffe and chocolate taste with a slight bittering finish. Nice roast touch that is awesome as well. Creamy texture, but on the verge of only giving this a 3 but it wouldnt have made a huge impact on the score. Overall, nice offering from Bells, that I frigged up on rating the first time.

Bottle at home ... thanks iowaherkeye for this one ... deep black ... BIG bubbly lived tan head ... roast malts light coffee    ... big coffee chocolate milky roast ... flavour onslaught ... oh huge milky chocolate ... smooth rich tiny hint of charcoal in the background... good stout.

Aroma was full of chocolate, coffee and molasses. Appearance was black as night with a nice creamy head. Flavor was malty for an American brew, with chocolate, caramel and molasses, as hinted in the aroma. Palate was creamy, a nice medium bodied brew. A very good stout.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2010 BOTTLE: nice black pour, brownish head. Aroma of dark chocolate, roast/coffee. Pretty big complex flavor in this one - coffee, dark chocolate, malt, roast, and maybe a little sweetness.
UPDATED: MAR 26, 2009 Poured deep black with a brown medium head.  Big chocolate and malt aroma.  Rich flavor of chocolate and caramel, turning to roast and hop.  Goes down smooth.

Bottle.  Pours almost black with a small medium brown head.  Aroma is subtle dark chocolate and coffee.  Flavor is very robust, consisting of chocolate, coffee, roast malt, and a slight sweetness.  Excellent beer.

Batch 7051 found it hiding in my cellar. Poured black with a one finger brown head. Aroma is lots of chocolate and sweet malt. Flavor starts as bittersweet chocolate and a little caramel, then finishes with some roasty malt/ hop bitterness.

12 oz bottle. Pours a stout-like motor oil black, with a half finger high tan head. Smells of chocolate, caramel, malt, quite pleasant actually. Tastes of roasted chocolate, what I guess is molasses, and a hint of caramel. Goes down smooth, but not as full-bodied as I would hope for in a stout. Good, but nowhere near as good as Bells Expedition Stout is.

pours a deep black with a thick mocha head.  aroma is of malted chocolate...like whoppers...with a hint of coffee to it.  flavor is roasty with a touch of smoke, some chocolate, and molasses.  also a hint of a metallic taste.  nice creamy moutfeel with a roasty finish that has that metallic quality to it...

Poured from the bottle into a standard pint glass.  Pour produced an opaque, black-brown body topped by a thick, frothy head of dark tan foam.  Thick smell of coffee with hints of anise, along with a thick creamy texture and rich roasted coffee flavor make this stout a beer that eats like a meal.  I think that the only thing that prevents this from being a perfect stout is that the bitter, roasted coffee flavor lasts a little too long on the palate.

Another bottle courtesy of my beer director. Pours black in color with a nice tan colored head. Surprised at how much head developed. Aromas of caramel, coffee, molasses, and chocolate swarm from this glass. Upon tasting, it wasnt as heavy as I expected. Huge flavors of chocolate and espresso, dark malt, molasses and a light nuttiness. Just a great, easy drinking stout!!
Black in color with a decent sized tan head. Aroma is very roasty with coffee and dark malt aromas. Taste is of coffee, roasted malts, and dark chocolate.

12 oz bottle pours dark with small head. The flavors are so well balanced and it seems you get a taste of the molasses and chocolate with almost no taste of ABV. This is the first Bells I have had a gift from my son Chicago Bear. cant help but give this beauty top grades.

Thanks to HogTownHarry!!! Appearance: Deep dark black, small but consistent off white head. Aroma: Malt, smoke, peat and cream, some slight dark fruit lingering in the background. Flavour: Light body, smoke, peat, chocolate, lots of carbonation, a dry peaty finish, very enjoyable. Thanks Harry!
A nice Stout that didnt try to do too much at once. A roasted aroma is present from start to finish and tastes of the same. Very drinkable.

Bottle thanks to daknole.  No batch number, dark brown basically black with two fingers of very fine tan head, big roasted aroma, lots of licorice.  Taste is more sweet but bitter licorice bark, roasty slightly vegetal underbody, some coffee and chocolate.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2009 12 oz.  Pours midnight black, little tan head.  Smells hugely of coffee and chocolate.  Light licorice taste, complex body.  Great developing taste and lasting finish.  Prefect example of an american stout.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2009 12oz bottle, batch 8874.   Appearance: Black with a mid-tan head (4)   Aroma:   wet roasted grain, light coffee, maybe a little roasted vegetable (6)   Flavor:   medium dry, roasty, chocolate, light licorice, medium bitter finish with a hint of smoke/burnt flavor. (7)   Palate: medium, pretty smooth carbonation, but still has some life (4)
Overall:   Solid stout.   Nothing exciting, but not much to complain about except the quirky nose  (13).   Dont really get the crazy-high ratings for this one though.
Rerate: Didnt get that funky quality in the aroma, which helped overall.   Manages to pack in a good amount of flavor while being relatively light and drinkable.   Still just a solid stout, but Im a fan.

Deep black color very little head that disappears quickly and no bubbles coming to the top. Not nearly as good looking as a Guinness. Chocolaty aroma but also a sweet light spice akin to the licorice thats advertised on the bottle. A mostly bitter flavor for this stout. Malt as well but no sight of the licorice I think the strong flavors and evident hops overcome any exotic light spice. Overall a boring and bitter tasting stout.

Bottle. Pours thick and black with dense brown head and decent lacing. Aroma is of coffee, chocolate, and malts. Flavor is roasted malts, coffee, chocolate, and a slight hint of licorice. Finish is smooth and slightly bitter with a little alcoholic kick.

Poured a black coal like color with a thick brown head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, malts. Flavor is a great magnificant of roasted malts and coffee, a hint of bakers chocolate as well. Smooth as hell with a nice kick to it in the end.

Poured near black with a thick, creamy tan head. Aromas of roasted malts. Flavor is a nice combination of roasted malts, caramel, and a hint of chocolate. Full-bodied and incredibly smooth.  Thanks for the trade JB.

Not a hint of light escapes this brew.  Pitch black with a tan head that leaves nice lacing.  Chocolate, caramel, coffee, and licorice make up the fine aroma.  Medium-full bodies with decent carbonation.  The beer starts sweet with chocolate and caramel notes.  Finishes with dark coffee/espresso bitterness.  Absolutely delicious.

(11/15/08) Bottle at friends house in Philadelphia. Thanks a lot for this bottle archmik! Black-colored with a big bubbly beige to light brown head that falls slowly. Aroma of roasted malt, some coffee, some smokiness and licorice. Sweet roasty flavor with coffee, some fruit hints, licorice notes and a bit of espresso. Finishes bitter. Medium to full-bodied. Very nice.

12oz. bottle at Lunar Brewing. Poured into a Czech pils glass, black/brown and visually thick. It exhibited a frothy, dark tan head, with some dense, clingy lace. The nose was dry, with roasted notes, coffee, and a touch of sweetness as dark fruit and molasses. I found chocolate in the flavor with some coffee and caramel. I liked the mellow existence of the hop bitterness as it balanced nicely with the other flavors. Flavorful and very quaffable stout!

From a 12oz bottle this brew poured black with a nice brown head.  Aroma of dark malts, chocolate, coffee and licorice.  Nice silky chocolate and coffee taste with a little licorice in the aftertaste.  Solid mouthfeel - nice and creamy.  A very drinkable stout.

I did not find nearly as much aroma or flavor as the rest of the folks that reviewed this beer. Faint roasted aromas, decent chocolate flavor. Didnt find the licorice or anything complex. Loved the mouthfeel, very silky.
Pours dark brown/black, roasted malts, dark chocolate, molasses, caramel, little coffee, little licorice.

12oz bottle from Willow Bend Liquors (Tampa, FL). Pours a hazy dark brown to black color with massive two finger tan head that settles slowly and heavily laces the glass. Aroma is sweet and malty with strong notes of roasted malt, dark ripe fruit, some anise, molasses and dark chocolate. Flavor is roasted and malty with notes of dark chocolate, coffee, toffee, caramel, honey, anise, and molasses. Generally medium to full body with a pleasing chocolate and coffee finish.

Pours a dark black with an average sized tan head.  Excellent lacing.
Aroma of roasted coffee and licorice.
Nice blend of flavors in this one.  Intiallly you taste roasted coffee, malts, chocolate and thats balanced off with some hops and the the liicorice coming through on the end.  Another nice one from bells.

Interesting and licoricey beer. Pours motor oil black with a thick dark head.  Aroma is coffee, vanilla, licorice, and some spice. Immense licorice presence. Flavor is coffee, licorice, and a twinge of hops around the swallow. Lots of dark malt. Finish lingers licorice and some milkiness. Thick mouthfeel and decent carbonation. Complex beer.

This is a good stout.  Pours black.  Aroma is nice...coffee/licorice.  Not too much carbonation, which is good in my book.  Overall not at the top of the list of favorite stouts, but Ive had many, many that dont come close to this.
Wonderful. PItch black with a rocky tan head. Rich aroma of coffee and tons of roasted and coffee flavors, creamy body with a dry finish.

Do the folks at Bells make a bad beer?  This is awesome and is the closest thing to Murphys Irish Stout that I have ever tasted.  A wonderful beer that is both full-bodied, but not too thick or overdone.  My favorite style of beer and this is the reason why.  Pour me another please.  Cheers.
Pours black with small deep tannish head. Nose of sweet chocolate malt and coffee. Flavor of the same with hop bitterness through the finish. A very good stout.
Dark, heady, full body with creamy, tannish head that leaves the glass coated in a fine lace when tipped.  Chocolate and caramel flavors, mixed with espresso, that is sweet roasted flavor.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2009 A heavenly aroma of unadulterated stout bliss. Simply perfect. Chocolate, molasses and espresso-strength coffee. What else could you want? Full-bodied and chewy; creamy like a bowl of porridge. A hint of sweetness upfront, a trace of bitterness in back. A beer such as this truly could be a meal in itself, did it not have such a kick as well! It should be savored, yet I cant help but suck it down... I love stouts, and this is the best.

12oz bottle. Pretty, deep pour with nice sheen and quickly dissipating off-white head. Nose is brilliant sweet malt, very reminisicent of the big Imps. Taste is much lighter and roasty, sweet touch and rather slick tasting. Very well done stout, probably the best pure non imp ive had. Worthy brother of the Expedition.

Pours jet black with a nice tan head and leaves very nice lacing... Not hugely aromatic, smells slightly of roasted malts, a bit sweet... Roasty for days with slight hints of bitter chocolate and a very subtle hint of coffee... The initial flavor blast subsides into an airy almost light finish with a bit of lingering roastiness... Medium to full bodied...

Bottle: Dark, dark brown with a long lasting tan head.  Malty and mild chocolate aroma.  Sweet and malty flavors with a hint of dark chocolate bitterness and cardboard.  Smooth feel and easy to drink.  It’s hard not to judge it against the fine Imperial Stout - Expedition.  But, if I pretend I have never tasted Expedition, I would think this is a solid stout.

Very good nose of coffee and chocolate..pours black with a brown head. good flavors of chocolate , roasted malt, molasses, brown sugar and hints of vanilla.
finishes somewhat sweet. Good stout

12 oz bottle.  pours thick with a creamy yet firm head.  The aromas are complex:  heavy roasted malts combined with dark espresso roast;  also, thicker oatmeal like aromas hidden underneath the cacao bean.  thick, also rich in flavor.  brown sugar and molasses as well as baking chocolate and a smooth yet bitter coffee finish.  this is a tasty ale.  as it warms, the alcohol still is well hidden, but the heavier than expected carbonation is revealed.  all in all, it’s a damn good stout...one i would gladly imbibe on draft.
Pours black with light brown head. Burnt malt aroma. Burnt malt flavor with a hint of coffee. Full body with mild carbonation and a moderately bitter finish. Very nice.

Bottle courtesy of masonjer poured into a Bells snifter.

Pours dark, dark brown, almost black with very little light showing through even the edges.  The head is two fingers and tan and lingers as a cap for a while leaving some sporadic lacing.

Wow, does this smell great - big roasted malt backbone with hints of coffee and dark, sweet chocolate.  It all melds together so well as a single wonderful aroma.

The taste didn’t quite live up to the aroma, with the sweet chocolate and dark roasted malts still dominating.  The main reason it falls slightly short is the bitterness of the coffee which is a little overpowering in the finish.

The mouthfeel is as good as I have ever experienced for a stout of this style.  It’s so decadent and smooth with a perfect amount of carbonation that accentuates the taste.  Beautiful feel on the palate.

Bells knows how to knock their stouts out of the park and this is no exception.  This is a fantastic stout and one of the best of its style.  Highly recommended.

Bottle.  Roasty coffee/chocolate aroma.  Black body, small light brown head.  Flavor has roastiness, sweetness, coffee, bitter chocolate, and all cooperates together in a tasty blend.  Very rich.  Wonderful.

Pours an opaque dark chocolate color from the bottle with a beautiful thick chocolate milk head. It has a slight chocolate milk smell, combined with the roasted malts. Neither smell is overpowering. A little sweet, a little roast.
The taste has just a little sweetness. The roasted malts come through, but they arent overpowering. Like many Bells beers, it has great balance. Not too much of a single flavor.
It is a great balanced stout with just enough of everything. Very drinkable for a stout.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2009 Pours black with reddish accents only at the very edges when held to the light, topped by a 3 finger toasty tan head that has great retention. Aroma is toffee, lots of caramel and chocolate, and sweet roast. Flavor is very roasty, plenty of toffee, caramel coffee and chocolate, a hint of smoke and char as well. Finish is roast and light bitter hops. Body is medium slightly sticky and perfectly carbonated, slightly chalky on the finish. Great stout
bottle, pours silky dark brown, aroma of chocolate , coffee and plum, finish is light and slight bitter
UPDATED: DEC 27, 2008 Pours black; smells of coffee, chocolate, and caramel; very creamy with a roasted, and slightly licorice, flavor. Very smooth and drinkable - for a stout.
UPDATED: OCT 17, 2012 Pours blacker than Dick Cheneys heart - taste of coffee, chocolate, and a hint of licorice. Smooth drinking, and complex in flavor. Yum.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2009 blackish brown, with moderate lacing.  not much aroma.  moderately carbonated with a moderately full body.  Flavor is of mostly roasted malts, some creaminess and a medium amount of hoppiness.  notes of caramel, molasses, dark coffee and dust. finishes with burnt coffee and a high vanilla note.  I like this fine, however it is not my favorite stout. - I want to try the double cream stout from bells, I might like that better.
Ink black with a thick tan head.  Aroma of roasted decaf.  Taste of semi sweet chocolate and coffee grounds, but in a good way.  Definitely a keeper.
Bottle. Pours a black with a long lasting tan head. Smell of cholocate and carmel. Taste is creamy. Very rich and creamy
Pitch black with a flat beigt head.  Smells of dark chocolate and coffee.  Complex flavor with sweetness and smokey bitterness.

Jet black pour from the bottle with a medium-thick off-white head that lingers thru mid-glass and leaves good lacing. Aroma is a pleasant mixture of caramel and chocolate malt, with a whiff of coffee. Mouthfeel is full and tingly sweet, and the taste is a carbon copy of the nose, all rounding to a nice long, somewhat warming finish.

I had read a lot of good things about this beer, and was not the least bit disappointed. Good job Bells!!!

A very good stout.  Not as think as its imperial brother (the expedition).  Still, roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and perhaps some vanilla.  Velvety milk-chocolate aftertaste.  Definitely some creaminess on the palate.

poured from a 12oz bottle inot a wide mouthed glass.  aroma is very rich and chocolate-like.  slight notes of roasted barley - but not overwhelming - which I prefer.  minimal tan head that fades quickly and leaves lacing.  Flavor is sweet and malty - very nice.  chocolate is first as it fades, a sweetness takes over.  no harsh finish, and very pleasant.  palate is smooth and very digestable.  overall, a beer that I would love to have year round - too bad is too darn hot in florida to drink this any time but Nov through Jan.

Bottle.  Pours black with a creamy tan head.  Smells very raosty, with hints of chocolate and coffee.  Tastes thick and like roasted coffee beans, smooth and chocolatey, hints of vanilla and mabe some dark fruits.  Sweet and creamy smotth, with a nice dessert aftertaste.  Very good.

Bottle thanks to daknole. No batch number on the bottle. Pours with a dark brown head and a black body. Aroma of licorice, walnut brownies, florals, and milk chocolate fudge. Taste is chocolate, nuts, licorice, dust, followed by more nuts, fudge and strong anise and a light cheese taste with a bit of blueberry (or berry) chutney. Creamy mouthfeel with light bubbles.

Very nice stout.  Always pours an opaque black with nice frothy head.  The beer has a very creamy, velvey mouthfeel, which ushers in a dark & milk chocolate flavor, with roasted nuts and caramel.  So easy to drink.  Nice long finish.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Black as night, fading to darkest brown at the edge.  Some bubbles, but no real head.  Some chocolate and smoke on the nose, but, whoa, each sip explodes on the roasted malts, cola, dark fruits, toasted barley, really nice roast complexity.  Some nice ripe melon on the finish.  Licorice and smoke.  Medium bodied, long lasting finish.
(11.20.08) Black pour with a rocky beige head that doesn’t last. Sweet aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Roasty, bitter flavor with dark chocolate and caramel. Lasting finish.

Bottle. Pours opaque black, with a thin brown head that settles quickly. Nose is quite roasty - bit of acidity, sharp, slightly smokey. Flavor is quite roasty, lightly acidic, but in now way harsh. Hints of bitter cocoa peek through, but not very prominently. Some sharp deeply roasted coffee, leading to a dry, but very smooth, roasty finish. This beer has a superbly polished quality about it - whatever you think of the flavors, not a hair is out of place. Mouthfeel is smooth, medium-full body, with a higher than expected level of carbonation.

Pitch black pour with smokey coffee and bitter chocolate aroma. Incredibly drinkable for a big stout. Flavors of sweet chocolate and hops dominate this beer with a bitter coffee finish. So smooth and creamy on the palate if you drink this beer warm.  I love you Bells Brewery.

330 mL bottle. Pours jet black with a modest, very dark tan head. Great lacing on this one! Nose is- I’m not kidding- green olives, salt, pimento. Taste is still a little salty with the addition of typical stout/porter tastes: espresso, dark chocolate, burnt sugar, roasted and caramel malts. Creamy on the palate albeit a bit watery. Aftertaste is long with lots of dark chocolate. This would be killer with oysters or shrimp. Overall excellent and much more drinkable than the Expedition Stout.

A Mes rate: bottle at the Harry vs Wolfman fist fight.Solid black with a good tan head. Big rich malt, some cereal and a tonne of U.S. chocolate in the aroma. Similar flavour just a little better. Not sure about the grainy feel. Kinda like a Expedition light if you will. A good stout, not amazing.
Pours dark with a thick brown head and a coffee aroma. Has a rich and creamy mouth feel with a smooth malty taste and a slight hint of chocolate. Nothing to complain about, a delicious stout.

Pours an intimidating oily black.  Aroma is tons of burnt sugar and coffee, dark chocolates, light milk, and dark fruits.  Flavor is rich chocolate and espresso, nice and malty, with a comfortable bitterness that makes this more of a drinkable stout than its wicked counterpart -- Expedition.  Solid in every way.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text: Bottle from batch 8555. Pours solid black with hints of umber around the edges with a finger and a half of mocha head and beautiful lacing. Bouquet of licorice, molasses, brown sugar, caramel, toffee, black cherry, and a strong aroma of sweet roasted malts. Flavor is sweet licorice, caramel malts, bittersweet chocolate, and roast coffee. The palate is soft and smooth, the carbonation isn’t cloying or obtrusive, and the finish is a mellow bitterness that pleasantly lingers on the back of your tongue.
roasted smokey flavor up front with a strong coffee finish. You can taste a good bit of alcohol. really tasty.

A minimal dark chocolate scent, with hints of smoke, reddish dark brown opaque, a minimal brown head, flavor was smokey, with a full bodied creamy finish that lasted an adequate amount.  Overall a good beer that doesn’t live up to the hype.
Getting notebook online. Bottle. Pours a coffee black. Great roasted malt aromas. Real good malt flavors from the black and caramel malts. A surprisingly alcoholic mouthfeel. Real good stout.

Angry fist of Santa tasting at Chris_o’s. Black, very dark brown, with thin tan head.  Good stout.  Lovely choc intense malt aroma.  It’s a pretty good stout.  Bitter finish.  It’s good.  Nothing exceptional, but smooth and bitter.

Bottle from Bello Vino Mkt.  A beautiful, drinkable stout!  Aroma and flavor are of a licorice plant growing from deep black soil.  Faint notes of creme and whiskey round out a surprisingly drinkable ale.  Brilliant.

Very good.  Nice aroma chocolate, caramel, roast.  Nice lacing on the glass.  Pretty sweet but wont fall into the category because of the hoppy background.  Well rounded stout.  Usually one of the main picks during winter time or when im in a stout mood.

Nice dark color, easy going head smells a bit sweet, and musty.

What a great chocolate / bettersweet chocolate and a lite to lite mild roasted coffee lingering finish.

I like this stout because its poundable.

Very clean and great lingering flavor that makes you want more.

Bottle from my Bell’s variety pack... mmm...  it had been a while since I first tried this one... deep and dark, brown foam... coffee & chocolate subtle aroma...  taste of coffee, chocolate and a little sweet, maybe the molasses...  I hate licorice, but this was perfect..  Don’t let the licorice description deter you from trying...

Bottle Chris O’s. Pours a thick dark ebony with a small off whitish head. Aroma: Rich and roasted ground coffee beans, bitter dark chocolate, slight charred carbon and alcohol. Flavour: good mothfeel that sticks to the back of your throat lingeing dark bitter choclate and coffee with some toffee and liquoirce to finish. Would prefer a little more body and creaminess but would drink again.

Bottle at chris_o’s pre beerexposed tasting. Alround rating: Roasty, thin, not really much going on, pritty boring stuff and not really my style. I cannot see for the life of me how this could get such a high rating.

Delicious stout, big chocolate flavor up front, roasty and smooth, with a dry bitter chocolate finish. Slight scent of licorice, lingering coffee notes in the finish. Pours black with a smooth brown head. Just really well built in every way.

Bottle @ Chris_os Pre-Beer Exposed Tasting, September 2008.
Pours impressively black with a small, creamy, staying, brown head. Sweet aroma, lots of chocolate and coffee. Low carbonation, wonderful, creamy mouthfeel. Flavour is impeccably elegant. Sweet, light dryness, coffee, cocoa. Stunningly balanced and only 6 %. Great.

Pours jet black with a tan head.  The aroma is big coffee.  The flavor is largely coffee, with some background chocolate notes.  It has a heavy body with low-medium carbonation.  This a delicious stout!  It is like espresso beer.

tap at dos segundos- pours black withf rothy foamy head. nose is light taste is roasty burnt toast, burnt coffee, so roasted. maybe a bit one sided. it is probably the roastedest beer i’ve ever had. it is bitter from the roast. it is a strong taste. dont know if paired well with the nachos either.

Pours black with a dark mocha colored head. Smells of Chocolate, cofee and alchohol. Tastes of rich chocolate, cofee, and alcohol. The flavors blend nicely. I went into this thinking it was an imperial stout, but when i started to smell it i realized it was just a stout. I definety could taste alcohol even though it dosn’t have a ahigh ABV.

Bottle.  Poured a dark brown/black with a three finger brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt.  Flavor is roasted malt, bitter coffee, slight caramel note and chocolate.  Medium/full bodied with soft carbonation and a slightly disappointing mouthfeel.  A little thin.

On tap at Magoos.  dark solid amber. modest head, very nice lacig, Nice mix of malt and hops.   Burnt malt fragrance, . flavors of Tobacco, Chocolate, and caramel, coke with bitterness.  Very much like StormKing but just a tad thinner.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2009 Poured near black with a thick, creamy tan head.  Aromas of roasted malts.  Flavor is a nice combination of roasted malts, caramel, and a hint of chocolate.  Full-bodied and incredibly smooth.
12 oz. bottle of six.  Pours a deep black color with a small darker tan head.  Smooth taste of malt, licorice and chocolate.  Extremely drinkable.

Bottle given to me by robert of stateline. Thanks roberto!  Aroma of black licorice, alcohol chocolate and malts. Dark black in color, no head. Taste is burnt oak, vanilla, roasted malt, a hint of chocolate. Very smooth. I like the way it goes down. No trace of alcohol in the taste.Texture is perfect, not to thick or to light. Low carbonation. Overall good sout!

After having been denied 2 years ago in my attempt to sucker on the dark chocolate teet of Bell’s Kalamazoo Stout due to late entry to a club that offered it up on tap in ol Dirtroit, I was shocked to see this suculant treasure had finally landed here in Jacksonville. Now with regular and easy access to the Two Hearted Ales, which remains on regular rotation, I, in Japanese anime style, jumped for joy at the new treat.  It pours dark; there is no light.  Those crazy physicists at CERN might want to take another look at to what happens to light once it is sucked thoroughly through a black hole.  Taste is mocha, superbly balanced on the taste buds, with roasted malts dancing about heavily, offering a creamy comedown to a well rehearsed chocolate factory.  Coffee notes play well and hypnotized the treated taste particles on my tongue, less anything acidic, no thanks starbucks. Oh and Arsenal is playing loverly football:) GO GUNNERS!;
Pours a dark brown with a light brown head. Great aroma of roasted malts, caramel, coffee, and chocolate. Very roasty tasting stout with great balance. Definitely worth trying.
This is my favorite comercially available stout.  It has everything a stout should have.  Nice full body, tan head, and roastiness that fills the palate.  This is a stout to be enjoyed year round.
12oz bottle: Dark brown pour with a foamy, light brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt, coffee and some faint cocoa.  Heavy roasted coffee taste.  Slight dry finish.  A very nicely balanced stout.

12 oz bottle.  Very pleasing scent to this beer, roasted ground coffee beans and cream, and some almost amaretto nuttiness to it as well.  Enjoyed the pour, very dark brown cream head and decent size, mostly goes away though, dark brown coffee color , about 2/3 opaque.  Good amount of roasted coffee and nuts in the flavor (go figure), also some good strong caramel malt and an unimposing balancing hop, smooth, though a nice bite right in the middle, medium full body and a good linger.  Just a very good, drinkable, balanced stout, hard to beat for the style.

Bottle.  Pours with a small head, clear body, and black color.  Hints of molasses, roasted toffee, flowers, and port.  Full body with a sticky texture and lively palate.  Long flavor leading to an absolutely fantastic beer.

Great find- dark black pour - head that wouldn’t settle - nice lacing- taste is smooth stout.  flavor comes out more as it warms... this is a very drinkable brew that fits well into my taste.  Nice balance of coffee/roast - I think I prefer the Imperials but this is very good.
Cheers
UPDATED: SEP 9, 2008 This was very good and creamy. Love that its only 6%. Just goes to show ya not everything has to be Imperial to be very good.
pour is dark black with one finger an head.  aroma is that of strong gas station coffee.  taste is a lot of coffee and chocolate, some toffee and caramel.  very good drinkable stout.

A dark dark stout with a thin moka head, and big chunks at the bottom. A nice bitter chocolate malt, cream, light hops, figs, and dried fruits. In mouth, a good moka chocolate, cold coffee, roasted bitterness, a bit of burned notes. A good pleasing stout.

Bottle; batch 7648. Pours black with a creamy tan head that settles to a light layer & ring and left behind good lacing. Aromas of milk chocolate, coffee, and a slight roast. The flavor is much the same but with the roast standing out much more. Full body, smooth, and a coffee and roast aftertaste. Very nice Stout!!

Pours a dark brown with a half finger beige head.  Smells are roasted malt, dark chocolate, toffee, caramel.  Flavor is sweet roasted malt and hops up front with a burnt coffee and bitter dark chocolate finish.  Seemed a little thin for a stout, almost the consistency of a porter.  Great beer nonetheless.

Bottle aquired in trade from StFun. Pours a dark brown with a tan head. Roasted malt flavor with a hint of coffee. Smooth and even on the palate. Just a tad thin or I would have thought it was an imperial stout. An overall great brew.

From STFun trade.  This stout was excellent.  For a straight stout, it exhibited more maltiness, balance, and consistent flavor than most (if not all) I’ve had.  Nice sized head and lacing.  The carmel and coffee flavors and smells were apparent.

dchmela..........you’re the MAN!!!  I really liked this.  BLACK in the body.  Pretty malty, and caramel and coffee smells are present.  Very smooth and creamy.  Not too bubbly.  Not sure if I like it as much as Java Stout, but I really like it.

Bottle 12 fl.oz @ home[ Courtesy of kmweaver ]. Clear dark black color with a large, frothy - creamy, good lacing, fully lasting, beige head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, roasted, caramel, chocolate, coffee, coffee dusty. Flavor is moderate to heavy sweet and bitter with a long duration. Body is medium to full, texture is oily - creamy - smooth, carbonation is soft - flat. (180608)

Thanks to msante79 for this one. One of the nicest stouts I have had. Has the deep roasted malt tastes, but not overpowering like some stouts that taste like an ash tray. Smooth and creamy feel. Roasted malt blended with deep chocolate and coffee. All well blended.

Pours pitch black with a large tan head, that fades thin with some bubbly lacing. Aroma is very roasted - coffee, some ash, and a bit of coffee and chocolate.  Taste is very smooth and creamy - some hoppiness up front, burnt toast and roasts, and leaves you with some smokiness and bits of chocolate.  One of my favorite stouts.

As black a beer as I’ve ever seen.  Pretty much opaque.  No head.  Big stout aroma (coffee, chocolate, roast, molasses) with some astringency underneath.  Hoppier than most stouts, not too sweet, and not a lot of bitterness from the roasted malt.  Body is a tad thin.  Very good, not great.

pours black with several fingers of tan, slowly dissipating head.  Really nice, softly sweet hazelnut odor.  The taste is different then what you’d expect from the odor, though that’s not necessarily a bad thing.  Taste of burnt toast starts off as it melds in with chocolate and ends with a nice, smokey aftertaste.  Really solid stout

Black in color with a nice looking tan head.  Looks inviting.  Good lacing.  Smell is roasty, a nutty coffee aroma, dark chocolate, some licorice.  Taste is a nice roastiness, coffee, licorice, and chocolate.  Almost too roasty in taste.

opaque black with sediment under a small brown head.  milk chocolate and sugared coffee aroma.  flavor is similar to aroma with dark black unsweetened coffee.  touches of maple syrup.  smooth and creamy texture.  medium bodied.  roasty aftertaste.  is there oats in here?  i’m not getting the licorice the bottle claims but thats perfectly o.k.

Bottle.Pours BLACK like oil with a medium tan head. Aroma of roast malt,coco,and coffee. This brew has a very smooth creamy falvor with notes of licorice, raisin, smoke, vanilla, coffee,and so on,and so on. I could find no fault with this stout, other than I believe it made me slightly flatulent,good stuff buddy.
Thank you to the hard working crew at Bells

The lacing is attractive and lasting. Aroma is one dimensional: only smoked malts, not even sweet and no evidence of hops. Yet mouthfeel is smooth and even; very heavily roasted malt and some burnt bitter chocolate combine for a warming and relaxing flavour. Finish is full and bitter. An appreciable beer.

Bottle. Moderate malt aromas of cereal, dark chocolate, and strong coffee, light herbsfor the hops, with date, brown sugar, vanilla and milk in the background. Head is creamy with some large bubbles, light brown, with good lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is black with a red tint. Flavor is moderately sweet and lightly acidic to start and moderately sweet and bitter in the long finish. Palate  is medium to full, creamy, and has a soft carbonation. It finishes moderately astringent. A good Stout with some deep flavors and aromas
Nice mocha aromas and a decent head at pour.  Smoky fruits with a hint of raisin and plum, not too bad, but a bit overrated.

A dark, ferociously roasty stout.  Jet black body, with a frothy tan, root beer float like head.  Smells like a mocha latte: rich bittersweet baking cocoa, plum, damson, and roasted, smoked malt.  Like a bonfire.  Further notes of lavendar, overripe grapes, raisins, boysenberries and a soil-like earthiness.  And that’s just the aroma!  The taste is remniscent of a smoked porter, with gunpowder tea, intense roastedness, chestnuts, kalamata olives, licorice, blackcurrants, and once again, a rich, damp earthy character.  This beer is intensely complex, the finish is full of thick smoke and grilled meats. Chewy, bitter and bracing, yet oily, soft, and not overly harsh on the palate.  Very long lasting, dry finish.

12 oz. bottle.  Not served in a glass.  Aroma of dark malt.  Swirling the bottle, I see a creamy persistent head.  Taste of dark roasted malt, prunes/raisins, dark chocolate and licorice.  Medium full in body, carbonation pleasantly medium-low.  Good brew, but one a sitting is plenty.

12oz bottle served in an English pint glass. Very dark brown/nearly black body with an inch of tan head. Deeply roasted smell of dusty chocolate & coffee. Big bold burnt/roasted flavor, deep earthy undertone, some dark chocolate. Like a sessionable Imperial stout. Good stuff.

Pours a deep brown/black with a small thin coffee colored head.  Aromas of coffee roasted malts.  Taste is very much the same.  Palate is nice and creamy and silky.  Dont let the short review fool you, this is a fantastic beer!

Poured a dark brown/ black with a tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts and a bit of coffee.  Taste of roasted malts with mild coffee flavor and some hops bitterness in the finish.  More carbonated that I would have expected.  A very nice stout.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a black/dark brown color with a light to medium head.  Aromas of cherry, dark chocolate, coffee and licorice are apparent on the initial pour.  Consistiency is full-bodied with a bitter finish.  Overall, a very nice selection.

aroma is roasty with some licorice and coffee.  pours black with off white head.  flavor is roast, coffee, licorice, and some raisin.  full bodied.  a good stout in everyway, it just didn’t knock my socks off.

Pours black with a a lot of tan head. Aroma is a smoky mix of chocolate, coffee, and malts. Flavor tastes strongly of the roasted malts with hints of the coffee coming through. The warmer it gets, the more the coffee is evident. Extremely drinkable.

Pours an opache black with a small tannish head. Aroma is sweet chocolate and coffee. Maybe just a hint of dark fruit buried underneath all of the dark malt. Flavor is really more of the same although the fruit shines through a bit more. Finishes somewhat short and cocoa bitter. Medium bodied, very smooth texture.

Bells in Chicago, it was a happy weekend.  This is obviously a very well done stout, I think it just isnt made in the way I like it.  It carried a very smokey flavor that I have never liked in any beer.  Other than that it is great with the normal stout descriptions without getting so heavy it becomes are to drink.
From a bottle poured black with a fair amount of head.  Nice tiasted malt flavor with a lingering finish.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2009 [Batch 8606 - bottled July 8th 2008] Pours a lighter shade of dark brown with a large fluffy tan head.  Fantastic fresh aroma of bakers chocolate, vanilla, coffee beans, and roast.   Yummy flavor, like Expedition light.  Notes of coffee, roast, chocolate and oatmeal like sweetness.   Not too bitter, not too sweet, but just right.  Very easy drinking stout that isnt too light like sooo many regular stouts.   

[7.6.09 - batch 8606] still drinking fine 2 days from a year old... fantastic!

12 oz bottle. Finally got to try this tonight. This may be the perfect session stout. Pours dark brown with red tint around the edges and nice thick tan head.. Aroma is roasted malt, molasses, coffee, chocolate and a touch of caramel. Flavor is smooth and creamy with roasted malt, molasses, caramel and chocolate. Nice creamy mouthfeel.Expectations were high and this beer delivered.
Poured like black from the tap with a light tan head.  Strong coffee aroma and mild coffee flavor with a faint addition of cocoa and licorice.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2008 So, as I sit back in my lazy boy and partake of this fine stout while posting my second review to RateBeer, I cant help but look back in wonder at the amazing amount of change I have made in my life in 7 months. Wow.

The stout itself is excellent. Pours a dark brown, almost black, with a small bit of foam which settles out fairly quickly. It goes down smooth, not heavy at all, leaving a slight brussels lace trail on my Guinness glass (sorry Guinness) between sips. I can definitely taste hints of coffee and dark chocolate, along with licorice. Very faint, but it is there indeed. I am not a licorice fan, in fact, I rather dun like it, which is why I was hesitant for so long to try the Bells Kalamazoo Stout which is made with licorice. I should know better by now - all good beers deserve a fair try. The first sips right out of the fridge where cool, which slightly masked the spectrum of flavor, but as the stout warmed a bit, more of the licorice and dark chocolate come into play. I definitely recommend giving the Kalamazoo Stout a few minutes to warm before having a quaff.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2009 [rerate]Wow, this beer is awesome.  I really under-appreciated this beer the first time I had it in 2008.  So smooth and rich in flavor.  Unique chocolate and roasted malt combination.  Definitely one of my new stand-by stouts.  

[July 30, 2008]Bottle.  Dark black with a small brown head.  Great looking stout.  Aroma is rich roasted malt and coffee.  Flavor is bitter sweet with chocolate and roasted malt.  Strong in flavors with a nice smooth finish. [8.5.7.4.15]

Bottle. Black with a small tan head.  Average aroma, coffee, chocolate.  Flavor is a bland sweetness and mild bitterness.  Smooth, little carbonation.  For a stout this is very good but it tries to be an imperial as well so my judgment falls into that category.  By all means a very good stout but less than unimpressive when compared to imperial stouts.

From a 12 ounce bottle brought back from NC by Margaret--Poured a deep black-brown body with a beautiful gray-brown head.  Thick, roasty, nutty, complex and creamy as a stout should be.  Licorice and molasses finished across the back of the tongue as this beer happily made its way down to my belly.

Pours dark black with a tight tan head. Aroma is chocolate, molasses, light coffee and burnt bitterness.
Flavour is sweet in the front, big roast malt,  burnt bitterness through the end that mellows as you drink.

I get no hint of brewers licorice. 

Well brewed and well balanced but, I agree with a couple raters below. I am not as big on this stout as most people seems to be. Though its a very decent brew.

Bottle - Seems like this one was a little lost on me compared to other raters.  Pleasant stout aroma with coffee and coco malts.  The palate was an even keel and a blend that really didn’t jump out as really that outstanding.  Had this in a massive tasting so will need to try again soon to get a better perspective.

12oz bottle.  I have had this a few times - first chance to rate.  black pour with long lasting creamy head.  aroma of sweet roasted malt, coffee, molasses and caramel.    a bitter-sweet chocolate and coffee taste.  also light licorice.  creamy medium body.  dry roasty bitter finish.  relatively awesome.

(Sampled 7-6-08 from 12 oz. bottle poured into shaker)- poured blacker than midnight during a heavy thunderstorm, very attractive tan head over one finger high formed and last for quite awhile, light carbonation.  Aroma of bakers chocolate, heavily roasted malts, and hard coffee.  Hits the mouth with double semi trailer wide body, the malt hits the tongue hard and just sits there, moderately sticky in feel, finish has a very nice taste of molasses and toffee. As heavy as this brew is, it makes it all in balance- not very easy to accomplish!   I may be one of Bells harshest critics, but even I have to say this is one damn good beer!

Bottle thanks to Alobar.  Pours nearly black with a dark tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, licorice, cocoa, and dark fruits.  Taste is very similar with a great velvkety mouth feel.  Medium carbonation.  Very tasty.

Bottle. Pleasant roasted malt aroma with a hint of chocolate and coffee. Black body with a small brown head. Sweet pleasant roasted body with roasted or almost burned caramel and chocolate notes with a hint of coffee. Sweet chocolate palate. Very nice.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2008 12 oz bottle from Johns Grocery.
Aroma: Full of chocolate malts and roasty. VERY roasty.
Appearance: Very dark and black. Dark tan head, not very big, but pretty bubbly and dissipates quickly leaving a creamy and lacy swirl. Beautiful lace, actually.
Flavor: Chocolate, mocha, roasty aftertaste. Hint of black licorice, burnt malt and toffee.
Palate: Medium body, great roast flavor. Carbonation brings the bitter flavor out well towards the end. Dry finish and silky smooth.
Overall: Awesome stout! Love to have more. Smooth and not overpowering. Complex flavors and great dry, bitter finish. Very balanced and delicious.

I came in with high expectation, and found them slightly dashed.  Excellently thick viscosity, deep, dark color and a nice head that dissolves after a couple minutes.  I have no complaints about the taste, but I didn’t experience any of the complexity other tasters here have described.  All I got was a pleasantly bitter, creamy, beer flavor.  Quite good, but there are better options.
Brewers licorice anyone? This beer is as dark as used motor oil and drinks as thick. For fans of dark stouts (not that Guinness water shit) this is a beer that you should try. Awesome beer.

When I saw this poured out, I had to say ’wow’!  Very dark, thick reddish brown head, soapy notes in aroma along with chocolate.  Palate is neither sweet or dry, I guess that’s why they call it a stout, weird to me, used to sweet or dry.   It’s nutty, with some coffee notes and a bit of hops, but overall pretty mild.  Well the longer your drink it the less mild it seems.  Creamy feel.  Drank this fairly warm.  Just had it in the fridge about 1/2 hour.

Much like their Expedition stout, this is too is a top notch stout.  I’ve been able to have this beer several times over the past two years via generous traders and have never been disappointed.  The beer pours out a nice black hue with a creamy 1-finger thick tan head.  Aroma just screams for you to inhale.  Dark chocolate, espresso, roasted coffee beans, and scorched marshmallows pulls you in.  Dark fruits, coffee, dark chocolate, toffee, chewy malts, with a slight finish of molasses.  Could be an every day beer if Bells ever decided to distribute out this far.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2009 aroma of roasted malt and chocolate pours black with tan head which lingers around the edges.  very nice flavour of chocolate and faint tast of roasted coffee beans  Easy on the palate, a very smooth drink.  nothing off from start to finsh.  Solid brew In a blind tasting was my least favourite of sinha stout and la granja.  Surpriising considering I rated it higher than sinha

Pours out black with a nice tan head with very good retention. Smell is very complex, reminds me of Dark Lord, full of coffee, chocolate, and different dark fruits, very very good. Taste is awesome as well. Starts out deceiving, but then all of a sudden it hits you with an onslaught of taste. Beginning is green, then roasty, changing quickly into cherries, plums, other dark fruits, then adds some chocolate and coffee flavors to finish it off. If it didn’t start off a little weak with the green flavor it would be an easy 5 for taste. Medium carbonation, medium to full bodied, slick on the tongue. If the very beginning of the taste was eliminated this would just be beyond a great beer, the green flavor isn’t bad, but doesn’t seem to fit with the rest of this beer. Seriously get this if you see it. Highly recommended.

$9.49 for a six pack at Total Wine.   Happy Fourth of July!  And what better way to celebrate than with a sixer of some of Americas finest stout.  Im somewhat amazed at finding Bells Kalamazoo Stout in North Florida.  Bells must have really ramped up production, and I am grateful.   Black beer with a small tan head.  Aroma of stout! Great stout flavor!   Chocolate, coffee, dark malts, burnt toast, molasses.  Very roasty, bitter and dry on the end, but the full, silky smooth flavor takes you there.  Nothing off, no rough edges.   Perfect balance.  Yum!

12oz Bottle - Trade - Masonjer 
Aroma  Huge Stout aroma, chocolate, coffee and light licorice.  
Appearance  Dark Black in color, Nice light head and clear if you can see through black. 
Flavor  One of the best Stouts I have ever had.  Huge flavor and just crisp and filled with so many flavors.  Coffee, chocolate where huge in this beer.     
Palate  Nice Mouthfeel, Awesome texture with a good dry finish. 
Overall  Loved the flavors. Just a precise beer to drink the flavors where so perfect. Great Great Beer.

Pours very dark brown with very little light brown head. Amazing aroma of sweet chocolate, caramel, lightly roasted oats and malts, and espresso! Taste is equally impressive. lightly sweet chocolate balanced by slightly roasted, dry coffee. The earthy sweetness lingers for a long time very pleasingly. Flavor palate is as full as the body, and very very smooth.

Bottle.  Expeditions little brother, this one.  Very tasted.  Roasty barley, chocolate, marshmallow on the nose.  Smooth sweetness and not over the top.  Perhaps the best American session stout out there.  Sol-id.

Im glad Im finally getting to try the upper echelon beers.  Pours a dark, almost coffee like consistency with a deep caramel colored head.  The aroma is of molasses and caramel and cocoa.  The flavor is very full and has hints of coffee and caramel with a little bit of a smokey flavor.  Absolutely phenomenal beer.
I like this slightly better than Expedition Stout because it goes down a little smoother and flavor is easier on the palate.

Bottle, Bells brewery never lets me down.  Large rocky head with excellent lacing.  Extremely dark brown/black color.  Aroma of molasses mixed with toasted coffee.  Full bodied with a creamy texture.  Average carbonation with a moderately sweet flavor that in a lightly bitter finish.  The warmer it gets toward the end the better it tastes.  An excellent brew from an excellent brewery.

Well, leave it to Bells to make stout my 2nd favorite style. This is actually the third stout in a row that I have purchased. The first two were Expediton stout from Bells, and a few nights ago i tried the poet from New Holland, and Kalamazoo stout is right in the middle. I loved everything about this beer.

ABV: 6 %
RateBeer rating: 99
Calories: estimated at 160 C
Volume: 12 fl oz.
Glass: pint

Purchased at: Issac Newtons, Newtown, PA
Price: $4.50
Consumed at: home

First Impression: A very impressive presence - a nice aroma, good head and rich flavor. Aroma is bitter, coffee, and roasty. Visuals are an inky black body topped with a tan head that is persistent and lacy. Taste is thick with espresso notes, licorice, and pepper. Palate is perhaps its downfall - a bit weak, with a medium finish. Second Impression - not anything close to a Yeti or a Shakespeare, but not a bad stout - far surpasses a Guinness. But for $4.50 a 12 oz bottle, Id much rather have the Yeti.

Aroma: 8 out of 10

Visuals: 5 out of 5

Taste: 10 out of 10

Palate: 3 out of 5

Overall: 16 out of 20
this is what an american stout should be. black, thick, aromas of coffee, chocolate. sweet, yet enough espresso , bitterness and tobacco to bring it all together. my new "go to" stout
A good stout. Pours very nice,  with a nicely carbonated body.  Flavorful nose, and a great bitter chocolate finish.

Bottle pours a pitch black color with a dark tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, vanilla, tobacco, and molasses.  Similar flavors, but also noticed some sweetness that reminded me of apples.  Nice bitter finish.  Couldnt recognize the licorice mentioned on the label though.  Oh well, still a very tasty stout.

nose of coffee & dark bakers choc. looks nice in the glass. coffee , coffe ,coffee on palate with some bitter choc on finish, clean & dry. not  my favorite style but  good.  bells is one of my favorite brewers & happy as hell to hear he is coming back into the chicago market.

Highly drinkable for a full bodied stout. Light carbonation. Initially, the flavor is lightly sweet and roasty malts. The flavor ends in a bitter, dark chocolate finish that lingers until the next sip. Perfect level of alcohol. Surprisingly strong for a 6% beer - has the taste of imperial stouts.

batch 7648... dont remember where I got this, but thanks to whoever sent it to me.  Pitch black beer with a thick sticky tan head.  Aroma is frickin awesome.  Rich sweet cocoa and dark chocolate.  Herbal, slightly smokey with a kiss of black licorice.  Flavour matches the aroma in intensity and balance.  Soft dark chocolate, licorice and cocoa.  Soft sticky sweetness, but completely without any cloyingness.  So rich and decadent that its hard to imagine that I cant get another easily.  Soft roasty bitterness.  Fudgey and delicious.  Just an incredible beer.
What a beautiful stout.  Pours a nice deep brown with a short lived tan head.  Lots of coffee and malt.  So creamy with that perfect stout bitterness.  This is a great stout.
Nice dark roasted flavor. I have trouble tasting the licorice that is in there. Smooth and rich, without too much bite. I would happily drink this one again.
Holy crap what a beer.  Short tan head, almost crude oil appearance, oaky whiskey aroma with complimenting flavor of coffee, toffee and chocolate.  Delicious!!!

12oz from CaryTheDude. Pours dark licorice with tan fluffy head. Smells like dark malts, coffee, licorice. Taste is roasty and dry, with coffee and chocolate notes, and licorice in the finish. Mouthfeel is full-bodied with low carbonation. Outstanding stout.

This beer is black with a pretty light brown head. Really roasted aroma. Taste is a wicked amount of bitterness and espressso. Hops are there. I didnt really get that much chocolate out of this beer. Bunch of things in the taste which I couldnt quite get, but I knew that they were there.

Smells like Hershey syrup. Big chocolate and coffee notes with some malted milk. A dark black body sits beneath a rich beige head that dies down to a thin collar. The taste is roasty and bitter, with chocolate, molasses, espresso, and sweet, milky notes. A really good and drinkable stout for sure.
Lovely, fantastic, wonderful.  Not saying its the best stout Ive ever had, but there are no complaints.  Full, not a bitter finish, and an awesome mouthfeel.

Dark brown with very slowly dissipating tan frothy head that leaves a trail of lace on the glass. Aroma of roasted malts, licorice, coffee and smoke.  Smooth and creamy medium bodied beer tastes of both sweet and roasted malts with some licorice and coffee notes to it.  Another solid Bells offering.

Wicked tastey brew, creamy, chocolatey with vanilla notes, nice touch of oak. Pours deep black with a large vanilla coloured head. Wonderfully smooth, i love the roasted nutty aroma that lingers throughout the whole beer.
Aroma is coffee, malts and smoke. Pours black with minmal tan head. Very well hopped for a stout - which I like. Very smooth, very creamy, goes EXCELLENT with chocolate.
Poured black from the bottle with a moderate beige head. Heavy chocolate taste, slightly malty. Outstanding semi-sweet aftertaste.

Bottle. A pitch black beer with no head. The aroma is of coffee and bitter chocolate - lovely. The flavor is sweet and yet bitter from coffee notes and bitter chocolate notes combined with hints of smoke.
I ve wanted to rate this beer for awhile, just never got around to it. Wonderfull coffee like roasted flavor, with a creamy back end. Thats all I could muster up.
Pours black with minimal tan head. Nice malty, chocolatey, and coffee nose. Great balance to this beer. A nice initial malty sweetness is matched by a roasted coffee finish. Very good.

12 oz. bottle.  Thanks to trades with SoLan and dchmela, I have two bottles of this great stout to enjoy.  Pours black with a moderate chocolate brown head that lasted through the first quarter of the glass and left light lace.  The aroma is chocolate and coffee as the dominant characteristics with some roasted malt detected as well.  The flavor is more influenced by the roasted malt with the coffee and chocolate more in the background.  Very creamy and smooth.  About four or five seconds after the swallow, a very subtle anise flavor emerges.  Excellent.

rating #100! Pours an excellent thick black with a finger of creamy tan head. Aroma is wonderfully roasty, with some chocolate. The flavor is outstanding, a nice sweet roasted mocha with a hint of molasses. Outstanding creamy body with a nice sticky mouthfeel. Glad this is #100, Bells rarely disappoints.

DELICIOUS! Wonderful beer that says brewers licorice on the bottle but has not flavors of licorice.  just an amazingly creamy and rich stout that pleases all the senses.  another homerun from Bells.  Kudos.

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2008 Draft at Coles in Buffalo. Poured black with a thin beige head. Roasty and smoky aroma with a pinch of coffee. Medium/full body. Flavor is again roasted with smoke and coffee, but also a hint of fruit sweetness and floral hops. Very good.

Bottle pours a dark black body with a thin tan head.  Aroma is coffee, sweet sugar, chocolate perfect.  Very creamy beer and very complex for a 6% stout, this is the answer to the question: which local beer would you drink all the time and a lot of!
A terrific stout.  Creamy with a rich roasted flavor.  This one really sticks to the mouth.  Very satisfying.

[Bottle] Poured deep black with a good sized tan head. Aroma was heavy in roasted barley, along with some bittersweet chocolate, and burnt caramel. Flavor is fantastically rich, and mimics the aroma quite nicely. The sweetness of licorice root really comes through subtly, building as you drink it. I dont know if Id really be able to identify it if I didnt already know it was in there. Soft bitter finish adds a great ending to this awesome beer.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2008 12 oz. bottle.  Pours opaque black with a medium tan head.  Aroma is roasted malts and a bit of the black licorice mentioned on the label.  Taste is simply solid roasted malts and coffee, and is very nice.  I can see why its rated among the top few "regular" stouts.  Excellent.

12 oz bottle, pours jet black with brown head, that mostly dissipated.  Aroma of smoke and roasted coffee beans.  Taste slightly bitter and coffee.  Mouthfeel slightly creamy, but a bit more watery than I would expect, has some nice carbonation.  A solid stout, though Ive had better.

ok, first off I havent had a stout in years.....I used to be all about them but then lost intrest about 4 years ago.... ..Ive stuck to IPAs, APAs and belgin strongs for the most part. But the other day I though lets get a good stout. A huge WOW.....Wonderful aroma, chocolate, coffee and slight alcohol. Jet black. And a wonderful flavor coffee, chocolate, cream and roased malt! Sooooooo good. I know theres better out there and I have had better stouts. But after such a long break from this kind of beer....it was breath of fresh air.

Bottle. Aroma very roasted malt (coffee-ish), maybe mild hops. Flavor more of the same. Good stuff, but wasnt terribly interesting for me, and the body seemed a touch weak with all the roastiness circulating. Not as impressed as others have been with this brew, but still solid if you take away the weight of expectations.

UPDATED: FEB 2, 2017 Rerate 2/2/2017. Aroma is rich with chocolate, coffee, roast, vanilla. Flavor of sweet chocolate malt, roast, booze, vanilla. Sweet, decadent, strong palate for a stout. 
7/4/8/4/14 (3.7/5) 
5/18/2008. Bottle.  Pours black with a beautiful dark brown head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma and flavor strongly of coffee, some roast, and chocolate.  The palate was a little thin despite the big flavors in the beer.  Some sweet richness in the finish, but not enough.  The palate gets weaker as you continue to drink.  This is just a weaker version of Expedition.  It is good, but I am shocked that it is the #3 stout, as I would rate many other stouts over it.

Thanks emacgee.  Pours black with a nice tan head.  Aroma is dominated by coffee with hints of vanilla.  Taste is roasted coffee, with hints of licorice.  Very smooth and creamy on the palate, with a very long sticky finish.  Would drink again.

Bottle thanks to Hellbilly.  Black with good sized dark tan head.  Roasted aroma of powdered chocolate and mollases with a slight amount of hops .  Taste is similar with a little licorice and then bitter hops at the end.  The hops keep it interesting an uncloying.  Medium body.

12 oz. bottle into a shaker.  Oil pour with dirty tan head.  Aroma of coffee, currants, and vanilla.  Flavors are the same an include hints of molasses and malts 9 little to no hop action) - full flavored for non-imperial.  Smooth on the palate with a medium to heavy body (not too thick, but, again, impressively full bodied for non-imperial).  Overall: great beer worth trying, but wasnt super unique; still, a very sturdy stout.

More than a thousand reviewers grant this ultra thick stout a 99% style rating. And again, I believe the experts are a bit off.
Color, lacing, finish are all top notch but the overly bitter aftertaste takes away from its complete perfection.
Still, Bells has another extraordinairy beer to offer.
UPDATED: JUN 6, 2008 excellent stout with a moderately thick body, smooth in taste with a smoked, slight roasty after taste.

Shared with Pyrozoid.  Pitch black poor with a foamy light brown head.  Aromas of licorice, milk chocolate, prunes and molasses. Strong alcohol mouthfeel.  Sweet start ending in a long lasting crisp dry finish. Medium body.  Flavors of coffee, chocolate, and prune juice on a licorice finish.  My expectations were maybe a little to high before drinking.

(Dégusté avec french tickler) Une biere noir avec un collet moyennement collant. Senteur de licorisse, chocolat, melasse, miel et dattes. Saveur de chocolat, sucré, le gout de miel qui revient. Une biere qui je croit est surévalué.

Not a beer to hide its strengths. Roast overload in the nose, with hints chocolate and fruit. Black body and rich tan head follow. Strong roast flavors, definitely for coffee lovers. A little bit of chocolate in taste as well, finishing salty, and a little too sticky for me.

Dark, little to no head. Fresh smell, not dank, a nice change. Chocolate,mmmm... nice taste...malt meets you then hops greets you. Even, not too watery on the palate. No bad aftertaste. No infighting, nothing cloys...very dynamic as a whole with no overpowering ingredients. Well played. A little salt..maybe from the licorice.

First off, I have to complain about the label... WTF is that hideous graphic, a portrait of a charred corpse?!? Im not sqeamish, but Its shockingly offensive enough to demote the beers appearance by a point. Exiting the bottle in an oily brown stream, the stout settles in my glass with absolute opaque, brown-fringed inkyness. Gazillions of tiny, tiny bubbles muster merely a ring of dark tan foam and scattered speckles of lace. A surprisingly plain nose exhibits gentle nutty, coppery, and leafy vegetal scents. A bit raisiny as well?? The flavor evokes half-burnt fireplace logs and the daintiest hints of granola and honey... like the aroma, it is dark, rough, and dimensionless. Thick, creamy, mousselike mouthfeel is shattered by chalky, scouring velcro tannins, and ends up feeling like a  mouthful of fiberglas insulation. The finish flashes with brief, tinny tartness before settling into a permanent charcoal and salty parmesan rind aftertaste. To summarize: harsh and jagged... a beer as linear, acrid and muddy as chewing dry ground coffee beans... or the ashes from a cheap "sweet" cigar. In a year or two it might mellow to palatability, but will never be remotely enjoyable or complex. Im completely pissed at this f*cking waste of my money !

Help this one up to a spot light.  Dark carmel color to one quarter inch, giving way to inky darkness.  Actual frown head.  Smell of my grandmas dark brown molasses bread and black licorice.  Very smooth and creamy with a flavor that is lighter than expected, without licorice but with the coffee, molasses and chocolate one would expect.  A slightly watery finish, does not really detract, if anything gets you ready for another slip.  Very drinkable.  Maybe a good one to serve to those who dont "like dark beer."

Nice brown head. Onyx color. Roasted aroma. Really a great brew. Definitely getting the licorice.  Some coffee as well. Kind of wish I was drinking an Expedition though, but I guess the 6% is a little more reasonable.

Wow i thought this was an imp. stout.
Tons of flavor.. no licorice though. Chocolate mostly with coffee and molases. Slightly bitter and a long finish. 
A bit of a band aid aftertaste.

One of the smoothest stouts that I have had.  Pours a brown head and dark body.  Chocolate and coffee in the nose, with some doughy notes.  Palate is lighter than most stouts, with a slight but lasting finish.  Very pleasant to drink.
Dark black appearance, subtle flavors of chocolate and coffee Easy and smooth to drink

Dark brownish black appearance. Smallish tan head that settles quickly to a thin layer, leaving some lacing. Aroma is almost all roasted coffee malt with a bit of bitterness. Flavor is roasted malt, with coffee, a little chocolate, and some licorice. Finish is nicely dry, with bitterness but not much of the floral hoppiness you get in Bells Expedition. Has a pleasant lingering coffee aftertaste. Relatively straightforward but solid stout.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2008 Bottle, color is black with a tan head.  Sweet charcoal, chocolate and coffee aroma.  Very smooth, flavorful and drinkable beer.  It is not overwhelmed with flavors of chocolate and coffee but they are there.  Nice simple taste with slight bitter undertones.

great nose of roasted malts and hints of coffee
taste is very similar...though it gets a little less dynamic as it you drink it
good stuff though

Pours black with brown head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, roasted malts, some nuttiness, and dark fruit.  Tons of roasted malts and burnt coffee with slight licorice, chocolate and caramel notes.  Full creamy palate with dry finish.
Straight up roasty, flavorful yummy stout.  Like most of Bells "base" products, this is a benchmark for the style.

Pours deep black with small brown frothy head. Aromas of roasted malt, chocolate, and dark fruits. Flavor is roasted malt, coffee, and some chocolate in the finish. Very good brew, but nothing to jump up and down about.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: Bottle. Pours pitch black with small cocoa head. Sweet aroma of chocolate, caramel and unknown spice, perhaps clove. Tastes of medium-sweet chocolate, roasted coffee, clove, with delicious slightly sour-bitter ending on back of tongue that lasts. Everything in perfect balance. Creamy, rich mouthfeel. An after dinner cordial. to linger over and relish.

Dark and a bit oily looking.  Fluffy off white head.  I dont get much licorice, but I do like the aroma.  The flavor is dry and roasty.  The finish is smooth and wonderful.  Another good Bells experience.  They really need to distribute to GA.
I loved this stout.  Great roasted malt.  Tastes of nutty coffee and liquorice.

Enjoyable full-bodied stout with a licorice undertone, solid roasted, caramel and chocolate malts.   Not sure who the guy on the label is supposed to be, but he should take pride in knowing his mug graces a great beer.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2008 pours nearly jet black, not as thick as the expedition, with a thin brown head andvery little carbonation. aroma is all stout with roasted nuts, coffee, and honestly, some black olive notes (actually licorice) along with chocolate malt. flavor is wonderful. starts off with roasted malt and quickly turns to a full on coffee flavor with a great lingering bitterness. i agree with the last rater about the "burnt dark chocolate". almost perfectly describes the atertaste. amazed at how bells makes two different, yet two great stouts with this and the expedition.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2010 Pours a black color topped with only a thin brown head. I was a little disappointed by the lack of a decent sized head. The aroma is roasted chocolaty malt although the scent is mild. There is however quite a bit of flavor to this one. It starts off with a nice rich toasty dark chocolate flavor blended in with roasted malt, and a a little coffee.Roasty bitterness in the finish.  The mouthfeel is nice and full. Lots of lingering roasted, almost burned, dark bittersweet chocolate flavors. This one is good.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2008 [06Apr08] Bottle, batch 8306.  Pours a black body with creamy brown head.  Aroma of earthy coffee, burnt malt, and dark bread.  Medium to heavy body; slightly oily mouthfeel.  Flavors of dark, bitter chocolate, coffee, ash, and black licorice.  Finishes dry and bitter with a lingering bitter aftertaste. {7/5/8/4/16}
[03Oct08] Bottle, batch 8652.  Pours an opaque, very dark brown body with creamy brown head.  Aroma of burnt sugar, roasted coffee, burnt malts, along with a hint of dark chocolate.  Dark chocolate flavor with earth, coffee, ash, and black licorice tones.  Finishes dry with a slight bitter cocoa bite; lingering coffee aftertaste.  Medium to heavy body. {8/5/8/4/16},

pour out of bottle black with a 1 finger beige head.  Beautiful, creamy froth that disapates way slow.  Thick lace.  Smells of sweet espresso and nuts.  Sweet caramel cream for an instant then a wide coffee and roasty hoppy flavor.  Dryer then I expected.  Very dark roasted mocha finish and more dryness and alcahol. (in a very good way)  Like most of their beers, this is truly crafted well.  You could drink this a few times and, i think, and pick up different nuances each time.  I have already edited this rating twice since i opened the bottle.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2009 12 oz bottle courtesy of Linus stick. Pours am opaque black color with a big fluffy tan head that lasted the whole glass and left some lacing. Big nose with roasted malts, dark fruits and sweetened espresso. The flavor features coffee, molasses and burnt toast. The mouthfeel was smooth and creamy, but just a bit lighter than I expected, it was still pretty darn satisfying. The finish was long with a sweetened coffee aftertaste. Overall: A killer stout and one that goes down real easy. I love it.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2009 pours black with small tight tan head.smells of roasted malts and coffee taste dark choclate ,burnt cofee and sweet carmal molasses very smooth and creamy. great porter stout or should i just say stout

Black, quickly fading brown head, slight lacing.  Nose is water-cured black olives, roasted nuts and dark roasted coffee.   Dark chocolate, molasses, coffee, anise, slightly sweet but not at all cloying taste. Very dry finish. Rasping, moderate bitter after from roasted characteristics.  Creamier as it warms and breathes, carbonation fades to subtle, near imperceptibility.  Overall a nice, subdued and balanced stout.

Extremely dark with a quickly diminishing head.  Outstanding flavor: ; coffee, chocolate, molasses, and more.  A bit of a hop bite in there.  Very creamy.  Feels just right in the mouth.  The sort of stout that I can sit and drink watching a ball game till I fall asleep.  One of my favorites.
