Pours sticky and thick with great creaminess to the head and lacing all over the glass. Smooth, with a roasted malt flavor. I couldnt really taste the brewers licorice advertised, but it made no difference. I have yet to try a better stout!
Pours black with small medium brown, bubbly head. Aroma of roasted malts. Flavor is dark chocolate, coffee, & anise. Nice thick/creamy mouth feel. Bells is a great brewer in my experience.
damn fine beer.  nice and roasty with notes molasses, chocolate, vanilla, and liquorice.  really great mouthfeel.  i love bells.
DARK BREW WITH AN NICE FINSH  TASTE OF COFFEE AND A DRY FINISH  THIS IS A VERY GOOD STOUT  SMOOTH MOUTH FEEL  TONS OF FLAVOR

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2008 Pours  dark with no head. This pops with a chocolate, roasted coffee, and black licorice flavor. Finishes moderately bitter.  One of the easiest drinking stouts ive had. Ill  look for this one again.

On tap in my kegerator.  Picked up 1/4 keg @ Total Wine & More in Springfield, VA.

They regularly have Bells 1/4 kegs.

Dark as night, but medium alcohol content.
Dark head which seemed unusual.  Good aroma.
Taste of anise, dark coffee, and burnt toast to give a bit of bitterness.
Great mouth feel and not too chewy.  I dont like watery dark beers.
Filling beer, not ideal for a hot summer day.  Great with a winter meal.
Not bad.  Gets easier to drink the more you drink it.  Very dark in color.  LOts of flavor and smells coming out of this beer.

12oz bottle.  Pours a deep black with a thin brownish head.  Aroma is rich and sweet, with aromas of anise, molasses, chocolate,  and roasted malt.  Taste is creamy and full, with a mellow and dry flavor of roasted malt, chocolate, coffee, and spice.  An amazingly balanced and drinkable stout.

12 oz. bottle from Vintage Cellar. Aromas of chocolate and molasses. Opaque brown/black color with a lively dark tan head. Near full bodied with creamy carbonation. Flavor is coffee, dark roasted malt, and a bit of chocolate. Not getting molasses. Finish is surprisingly dry and no more bitter than coffee. Smooth and good tasting, though a sour note seems to come forth after awhile. If theres anise, I am not getting it.

12oz. brown bottle with no date, poured into a pint glass. 
This beer is like squid ink, black without any light penetration. A thick, fluffy, chocolate milk head leaves a heavy lacing behind.
A very mild beer on the nose. Chocolate malt and currants are most distinguishable. As I drank, I began to pickup a smoky backdrop the deeper my nose got into the glass.
The currant sweetness fades quickly to leave a long roasted coffee bean aftertaste that just sticks to the back of the throat. A tad bit too long for me.
Its a heavy, creamy, medium carbonated stout. Great balance.
This is a definite sipper that grew on me. I decided to hold off on tasting notes until I had a second later in the week. The aftertaste is a bit much, but the subtle nose and delicate palate made up ground for me. This would probably pair well with sweet desserts to help cut that bitter closing.
Bottled.  Oil black, opaque colour.  Tan film on top.  Nice aroma of sweet honey combined with roasted malt and chocolate.  Flavour was more coffee plus licorice and gentle smoke.  Great stout.

UPDATED: APR 8, 2008 Nice black pour with a tan head.  Looks kinda like coke, but thicker, thought not quite as thick as the Expedition stout.  Really strong aroma of coffee and malt.  I can smell it from a few feet away,  Real nice stout flavor.  Bitter and slightly sour.  Hints of coffee and chocolate.  Slight alcohol aftertaste.  Quite good.

Bottle. Pours an opaque black with a 2 finger creamy thick tan head that dissipates quickly but leaves nice lacing. Nose is cocoa and coffee. Palate is dark chocolate, coffee and cocoa.  Creamy mouthfeel.   A nice easy drinker  quality stout.

12 oz bottle (Batch 8007)
For some reason it took me a long time to get around to cracking this open.  I regret doing so.  While it is not quite on par with Expedition this is still a world class stout that deserves all the accolades heaped upon it.  It might be interesting to take a bottle of each, age them equally and see how they change.  The results couldnt be that disappointing unless one does a poor job of cellaring.
Aroma / Appearance - The temporary head was the color of freshly fallen walnut shells.  The body could have been mistaken for Expedition, being equally dark in color.  The scent of coffee, smoke, licorice and nuttiness stand out most.  There are other active smells as well which combine to form a very dense and complex experience.
Flavor / Palate - Anise/licorice, black coffee and slightly dry plain cake form the basis of the first sip.  The experience is very consistant.  It wraps up with the same black licorice taste.  For a regular stout this is an excellent world class release.  I can definitely see myself returning to this one in the future.

Pours very dark brown almost black.  Not a whole lot going on in the nose.  Very dark malt, molasses and bitter chocolate in the taste.  A little thin, but smooth in taste.  Decent beer, but there is not much that can hang with the Expo.  Ill stick with it.

Bottle.  Dark beer, with the slightest hint of a ruby ede, tan head, some lacing.  Aroma is very malty, milk, coffee, caramel, chocolate.  Flavor is similar, creamy, but roasty, nutty, caramel, and chocolate, coffee; I can even taste some molasses.  Aftertaste is still roasty, with good bitterness from the roasted malts.  I dont taste the licorice, but thats probably a good thing.

Poured from a 12oz bottle (Batch 8237) and served in an English pint glass.  This stout poured an extremely dark brown with a one-finger thick head of dark tan foam that quickly settled down to a thin layer that lasted throughout the entire glass.  A fair amount of spotty lacing was left behind.  The aroma of the beer was made up of rich milk chocolate, freshly ground  coffee, roasted malts, and a hint of dark fruit.  The flavor consisted of cold coffee, bittersweet chocolate, a touch of burnt malt, and some mild molasses.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied and creamy smooth with light carbonation.  A really clean and flavorful stout.  Kalamazoo Stout makes regular appearances in my fridge.

Bells Kalamazoo Stout is a great light alternative to Bells Expediion Stout. Pitch black with a small tan head, the aroma is of coffee, licorice and some chocolate flavor. The flavor mimics the aroma and stays on your palate until you take the next sip.

If you have a free night, this is a great beer to relax with and share a six pack with a friend. It is harder to do the same with the Expedition Stout.
Pours out black with a small tan head. Aroma is of roasted malt and chocolate. Taste is complex with a nice full mouthfeel. Chocolate, roasted malt, licorice and slight bitterness on the finish.
deep black pour with a thin layer of khaki froth.  thick roasted malts and semi sweet chocolate on the nose.  the malts are definitely the star of this show.

Bottle courtesy of mgumby10 - thanks!

Sure wish I could get this stuff locally. This is a great stout. Pours deep black with brown highlights and a tan head. Lovely dry roasty flavor, just the right hints of sweetness to keep it from being chalky or ashy, mouthwatering bakers chocolate, cappuccino, maby a trace of that licorice they mention. Very nice mouthfeel, incredibly drinkable at 6%.
 Splendid, really splendid.

12 oz bottle from a trade with the cheeseman. pours dark brown with a small tan head. roasty aromas with lotsa sweetness but not overly abundant or complex. flavours of anise, chocolate, coffee, all good roasted stout flavours. very drinkable and completely satisfactory. im glad i have another (courtesy hogtownharry).

Bottle courtesy of gunhaver.

Poured into a pint glass, quite black with a tan one-finger head. The foam leaves a bunch of thick lacing as it dwindles to a cap.

Aromas of chocolate graham cracker, sweet cream, and a hint of roastiness. Heavenly.

Flavor tones down the sweetness a bit, while upping the roasted character. Fudge at the very front of the palate, then a big roasted finish with some astringency. I would have liked more sweetness to balance out the roasted bitterness because it seems a little too harsh for a sweet stout. 

The carbonation is a little high for a stout, but it remains pretty smooth, and the roastiness makes for a dry finish.

Overall this beer is a nice change of pace from all the RISs Ive been drinking.

Pours oil thick and black with a dark brown head that thins out quickly, but is present throughout the drink.  The aroma is thick and chewy with very roasty notes, coffee, and dark chocolate.  The flavor is very similar to the aroma, but the body helps contribute to the overall experience, making it quite pleasurable.  The oiliness of the appearance comes right through in the mouthfeel and makes it silky smooth.  very nice.  Wish I could get this locally.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2009 Very nice offering from Bells! A "lite" version of Expedition Stout, but still very much able to stand on its own. Aroma is nice; chocolate, coffee, and caramel. Very easy drinking! All of the aroma comes through in the flavor, with the addition of roasted malt and barley. Pretty much a simpler form of Expedition, with everything amped down a notch, and no alcohol presence. Somewhat sticky and bitter on the aftertaste. Give it a try.
33 cl bottle, Fargo. Ink black colour, dark tan creamy head. Intense roasted malt, coffee and chocolate aroma. Velvety in the mouth, very smooth, sweet and warming on the way down. Excellent.
Absolutly delicious! Nice dark oil color with tan head. Smells of roast and chocolate. Tastes of of caramel malts that go down nice. Loved it!

12oz bottle got through tade with StFun. pours black with minimal tan head, aroma isnt all that strong but filled with roasted malt, flavor of roasted malt and slighty sweet. not bad but i was looking for more in this one.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2008 Pours a black body and tan head.  The aroma is beautifully roasted malts with plenty of chocolate.  The flavor is a kind of bittersweet for a stout with a nice presence of hops.  Or at least more than I would normally expect.  The mouthfeel is thick enough with an easy finish.

Another Bells beer, another experience. This was like wow, very stong in its character and taste and surprisingly light finish. Very bitter but that doesnt stay in your mouth for long. would definetly buy again!

I am convinced these folks in Michigan have some sort of pact with Mephistopheles in brewing exceptional beers of all varieties.  Every beer tasted sets a new standard in their respective class- this stout is no exception.  The deep dark flavors of the roasted malts miraculously finish out to one hell of a refreshing stout.  Very drinkable and highly recommended.

This is like Expeditions little brother.  Not as much kick on the alcohol and not as thick.  However it is a very smooth beer and is highly drinkable.  I could put a few of these back in one sitting, but probably could only have one expedition.

Draft at Brixx. Dark, near-black color with a medium tan head. Smells nice and roasty and tastes much the same. A lot of roasted nuts and other burnt flavors. Not incredibly complex, but its not supposed to be and its perfectly balanced. Finishes completely cleanly and is even somewhat thirst-quenching...odd for a beer this heavy. I loved it.

Bottled. Inviting black pour with a light, fizzy beige head into a pint glass. Sweet caramel notes, faint licorice and roasted woods are in the aroma. Great flavor for a smaller stout, Some fruits mixed in with a hefty dark chocolate base and some coffee with vanilla cream. Long and roasty black malt finish with a good dose of bitterness. Sure as hell beats Guinness, I could drink this stuff all night.
Pours a very dark brown/black, with light tan head, Aroma of chocolate and caramel. Tastes of sweet chocolate and caramel with a hint of coffee. This is probably the perfect "session" stout.
Poured black with brown head.  Full of flavor of coffee and malts.  Lacks the sweetness the Expedition Stout has.

12 oz bottle thanks to gunhaver. Pours a nice brownish black with a tan head. Aroma is Malt and Coffee. Taste is toasted barley, licorice and coffee. Finishes very dry, and could use a little more sweeness to balance the flavor out but still a pretty good stout.

Bottle - batch #8237.  Color is black.  Creamy thick tan head.  Good lacing.  Aroma is coffee.  Tastes of malt, coffee and chocolate.  I really enjoyed this beer.  There is nothing crazy about this, no wild flavors like the Expedition stout.  Full bodied, smooth, and creamy.  I enjoy all the variety that Bells brings to the midwest, but sometimes you just want something straightforward.  This is simply a solid beer.

Another great beer from Bells.  Pours dark black with a finger thick tan head.  Roasted malt and chocolate aroma.  Smooth palate but could be smoother.  Kind of oily.  The flavor is much the same as the aroma.  There is a touch of smoked malt as well.

very dark black, with thin chocolate brown head.  would have liked the head to fill more of the glass, maybe a poor pour.  great lacing from the head tho!  burst of creamy chocolate aroma.  could have been smoother.  taste is chocolate and roasted malt, maybe smoked?  good tasting brew.  maybe some burnt coffee towards the end.  not bad, not as sweet as everyone made it out to be, but still very good.

Pours a thick oily black with a very thin but persistent tan head. The aroma is rich with molasses, slightly smokey burnt malts and a bit of chocolate. The flavor is awesome - sweet malty molasses, dark chocolate bitterness with the slightest hint of an alcoholic bite that leaves a little tingle on the tongue. All this coupled with a rich creamy mouthfeel makes for one of the best stouts Ive ever tasted.

Pours almost completely opaque with minimal tan head. Aroma is light with sweet liquorish and malt. Good smoky flavor, with sting malt. Smooth rich feel that tingles the mouth. Very good stout without the typical tremendous bitter bite.

This is truly a great stout.  I think I like this one better than its imperial cousin, Expedition.  This has a much more restrained  sweetness that isnt as cloying to me.  Pours black, with slight head, the fact that the head didnt stick around was one of the only drawbacks to this great beer.  Roasty malt flavors, the licorice really sticks around after the swallow.  I stocked up on some Bells this weekend, and I hope they are all as good as this one.

Pours beautifully. Takes a bit of a firm pour to get a nice tan head (that sticks around). Totally opaque color. Mild nose. Slight malt. Touch of dust. Flavor is nice and malty, but lacks any outstanding character or flavor. I hate to hold this one up to its brother (Expedition Stout), but there just isnt any unique character or depth that the Expedition Stout has. I know they are different styles, but the possibilities for both should be in the same ballpark I would imagine. There just isnt any punch. Its full, sure. But is it interesting? Sorry. No. Its decent and well made, but when held against the rest, it just doesnt keep its ground.

Pours very deep black with tan head. The head is very nice and fluffy and compliments the beer well; it also leaves an excellent lace. Smell is surprisingly fait put pleasant sweet ad malty. 
Taste is excellent, good sweet and dry balance. The licorice is pleasant and in no way overpowering. Very deeply roasty and malty, with a subdued but enjoyable hop presence.
Strangely smooth for all the roasty and complex flavors. No doubt this is a big beer, but there is very little alcohol flavor and very it doesnt have the typical biting harsh bitterness preset in many flavorful stouts, this is nice only to say that it is different, and hence refreshing. 
A different and welcome stout.
Pours a very thick black with a tan head.  Has a sweet aroma, flavor has a noticeable black licorice presence accompanied by a chocolate malt flavor.  Very good stout.
Nice chocolate flavor and a moderate smokey after.  Its very smooth for a stout but still has outstanding flavor.  Repeat buying and drinking will occur.

12 oz bottle.  Pours pitch black with a 2 cm foamy tan head that is lasting.  Aroma of chocolate dominates the maltiness.  Flavor is balanced between the bitter chocolate, mild malts, and a hint of sweet creaminess.  Tons of lacing, no noted carbonation, and light on alcohol.  Medium to full body.  Drinkable and great for when you want a big tasting beer without the imperial alcohol.
12 oz. bottle - pours thin black w/ practically no head; aromas are a little sweet w/ mix of malts, licorice and bitter chocolate; drinks creamy and nutty; slight bitter finish

malty and moderate of flavor and body. light charcoal taste that weaves in and out of this dark and hardly menacing looking brew. a dank sweetness this is a good stout with adequate carbonation that is somewhat biting. hardly any chocolate to my taste.

Not much to say about this one and I think they want it that way. Its not an imperial , dry, or sweet stout. Its just a stout. Well balanced with a good amount of flavor for a 6% brew. Drink all night with no regrets. Fine Bells product.

April 2006 - This was one fine beer...and I have 5 left (tempting me to hoard them all for myself). Beer poured dark, dark brown, with a very small head and almost no lacing. Highlights of red came through on the bottom and edges of my pint glass when held right up to the light. Initially, the flavor was all roasty with some coffee, but got immensely better as it warmed (dont go too fast!). Lactic tones came out making me think this should be touted as the best milk stout in the world. Perfect creaminess and hop balance. Freaking tasty!
UPDATED: FEB 9, 2008 Very dark with small brown head...very bitter stout and malty.  A pretty good stout but not quite my flavor

Thanks Jay23 for the great extra and the opportunity to try this one  
Batch number 8055 bottle poured into a large tulip glass. Jet black body with a tan head that goes into a nice layer of lace
 
Aromas of molasses and toasted grains fill your head 

Medium creamy mouth feel 

Taste is sweet malts with flavors of coffee and a slight hop bitter (where is the licorice?)

A very easy to drink stout a nice finish to the night if it was available I drink it again
My new favorite basic stout. I like the smooth, yet flavorful mouthful that is followed by a mild hoppy taste. I real nice combination.

Deep brown to black in color with a solid brown head.  There were scents of Valrhona chocolate, molasses, coffee and a touch of smoke.  This had medium strength with a balanced midpalte that lead to a hoppy finish.  Some creaminess in the middle leading to bitter coffee which makes its way through to the finish.  This one doesnt hit you over the head rather brings you in slowly.
bottle. nice dark pour.  lots of roasted malt.  nothing that jumps out and grabs you about this stout, but overall a delicious well balance stout

Pours a completely opaque dark brown with a thick foamy beige head.  A nutty roasted caramel-coffee nose.  A bit of smoke in the flavor.  Rich malt flavor that is balanced very nicely with a bitterness that hits in the finish.  Almost tastes a little burnt.  I dont get any of the licorice.  Decent mouthfeel with an oily texture.

poured thinner than some stouts, but had a head the color of Ovaltine which lasted for a fair amount of time.  Taste was rather middle of the road - definitely not an attempt at overpowering the genre - not as chewy as I would like in a stout, but definite burnt/toasted tastes that made me think Id drink it again...not bad.
Pours pitch black wiwth light brown head. The aroma has a smoke and coffee. Flavor is sweet with chocolate complimented by a slight bitterness. Very easy to drink and really enjoyable.

From dra19 via trade.  Thank you Dennis!  The pour was dark brown with ruby highlights trying to peek through.  A nice, one-finger tall brown head was produced and sustained for a bit.  The aroma was roasted malt, chocolate, lighter caramel and lots of spicy hops.  The flavor was mostly chocolate and roasted malt covered in floral and piney hops.  The mouthfeel was nice and the finish was what you would expect.

12oz bottle acquired in trade with Acknud.  Thanks for this!  Brew was almost pitch black with a medium sized diminishing tan head.....some lacing.  Aromas reminded me of smoked bacon....also hints of oak, spice and a light hop bite.  Full bodied and oily.  Thanks again for this great beer!
Very dry and roasted. Alot of coffee, some chocolate. Not too thick in the mouthfeel...but still very robust. Overall a decent stout, although a very dry one.

This one was also brought to me via trade from Mr. Atalla...THANKS AGAIN!!!  Dark brown/bordering black with a small cinnamon-colored head, the aroma and taste have bold coffee, chocolate, licorice, and toffee characteristics.  Very velvety on the tongue, I wouldnt mind a second.  This is probably a top 15-20 stout...but I guess Im a tough critic!!!

bottle, batch 7475.  pours pretty much opaque black, with a thinnish light brown head that fades to a film.  strong smell of coffee and roasted malts, backed up by notes of cocoa, molasses, and raisins.  more roasty coffee in the taste, a bit of bread, some black cherry, and more coffee.  the flavor lasts forever.  pleasant coffee bitter palate that lasts forever with a hint of light sweetness in the beginning.  creamy, silky mouthfeel, with a medium to full body.  this stuff is terrific.  i cant get enough.

Strong scent with chocolate and molasses as well as a slight burbon smell as well.  Appearance is as dark as the night itself.  One of the best stouts I have ever had.  Very smooth going down with a warming aftertaste.

Bottle from hopdog. More or less black. No head. Chocolate, licorice, and a minute amount of sweet roast in the aroma. Sweet licorice blends with light roast and a little chocolate. Also, some dark fruit. Dates, plums, black cherries. Rather fruity actually. As it warms, caramel malts and roast blend to create a nice smooth balance.  Full bodied with medium carbonation. Pretty nice.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2008 Bottle, batch 8205 on 1/15/08. Hoppier than I remember. Licorice and wood come through. Mouthfeel is quite thick, a bit too sticky though. 7/4/7/3/15-3.7

Bottle, batch 8205 on 3/25/08. Aroma is good but kinda of boring and tending towards sweet stout land. Flavor is full and roasted, with a licorice finish. Still a decent amount of hops mixing intriguingly w/ the bitterness from the dark malt. This doesnt blow me away, but I still love it. 7/4/8/4/16-3.9

Pours a dense, opaque molasses color. Brown head quickly dissipates, leaving a persistent ring. Aroma is of dark chocolate and coffee. The taste is a sweet expresso flavor, with chocolate. Some roasted bitterness. Mouthfeel is thick, slightly stick,  with some tingling carbonation. A very nice sweet stout.

Bottle courtesy of styles. I sure wish I had this one readily available as it just seems like a quintessential stout. Coffee and chocolate present in the aroma. Rich and creamy malt flavor with just enough carbonation. Just lovely.
12 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a fluffy tan head.  Nose of coffee, figs and licorice.  Medium body with a tang.  Taste is coffee, a touch of cocoa, smoke and licorice.  Finishes with dry burnt sugar.

A good black beer with a small brown head that dissapates really quickly in to a small film. The smell is mostly of roasted malt. I didnt notice any of the licorice that was noted. The taste also lacked any licorice which isnt a big deal to me. I like the smokiness of the brew and the roasted malts give it a fine dark earthy flavor. Another good one from Bells.

Pours is dark with a light brown head that vanishes pretty quickly, leaving decent lacing on the glass.  Aroma is of roasted malts and chocolate.  Taste is of licorice and bitter chocolate with some coffee.  Roasted malt sweetness and smoke are also present, more so in the finish.  The fact that licorice was included on the label almost scared me off, since I hate licorice, but the licorice here was very subtle and worked well.  Some metalic notes are also faintly present.  Mouthfeel is very creamy with some light carbonation.

Pours pretty dark with a mocha colored head. The aroma is of roasted malt with a hint of molasses and maybe some coffee.  The flavor is at first a little bitter with a strong coffee taste.  It then sweetens up a little bit with some roasted flavor in the background.  A very good flavor combination in this beer.  This is a pretty solid beer.  It has a lot of good flavor without being too heavy.

12 oz. bottle, batch # 6781. Black with a light brown head. A nice lacing is left behind on the shaker glass. Medium strong smell of malted chocolate and roasted grains. Medium heavy body with a smooth texture. Hearty flavor of blackened malts and sweetened coffee. Has a slight bitterness to finish from the blackened malts. 
A great everyday drinker. July 2005
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Dark brown medium head.  Just perfect.  Nutty with a medium body.  Very smooth.  Just tasty very stout like but still went well with a good tuna steak.

I have to have this beer as my after work treat.  Its heavenly.  Thick oily black with a coffee colored head.  The aroma is of coffee and heavy malt.  The taste is bittersweet bakers chocolate and espresso.  Loads of roasty flavors slightly creamy and full bodied.  This is a marvelous stout.

12oz bottle from ealdent. Pours a solid, opaque black with a very thick, brown, pillowy head that lasts forever and leaves lots of lace on the glass. The aroma is sweet and malty but with a thick layer of roasted grains and coffee. There are also hints of molasses and caramel in the nose. The flavor starts rich and bittersweet with lots of chocolate with suggestions of Espresso Cubano. The middle of the tongue picks up some milky sweetness in the malts, along with more coffee and chocolate. The finish is dry and extremely roasty and has a firm level of earthy hop bitterness. The aftertaste tastes like a mixture of earthy hops and espresso. The mouthfeel has a subtle tickle of carbon dioxide on the tip and middle of the tongue, and lends a very light and creamy texture to an otherwise full-bodied brew. Overall, a very good stout.

Pours a dark brown color with a thin, frothy brown head. Smells malty and toasty a little metallic though as well.
Tastes of lots of dark and toasty malts. A bit of chocolate. Surprisingly thin for a stout but its good. Nice carbonation. Coats the mouth a bit. Very drinkable for a stout.

Finally got a few down in FL so popped one open tonight.  Pours about as dark as beer can get with only faint chocolate brown highlights, the head a thin but rich espresso film with spotty lacing.  Nose is massive roastiness, rich chocolate with tart yeast characters, also faintly dusty and with a surprising amount of alcohol considering its only 6%.  Licorice hits you right up front and seems almost overwhelming on first sip, but as you keep going you realize how well integrated it is into the body of the beer.  The beer is quite lively on the palate, as the licorice brings initial bitterness that is quickly melded to notes of coffee, bark, drying out to a lingering smoky aftertaste where wintergreen hop character appears.  Not a simple beer by any means, made even better by the fact that its bottle conditioned.  Very nice.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2008 bottle.  Seriously, every time I have another Bells beer, I think - this is one of the best breweries in the country, if not the world.  They just do not disappoint.... This stout is another wonderful stout from Bells... they have the best stouts.  Nice dark black color with a thick tan head.  Aromas of chocolate, tons of roasted malts and a thin layer of coffee.  Nice and smooth over the tongue with a medium and low carbonated body.  Wonderfully malty on the finish and it leaves you wanting more.
Very very good beer. I wish it was more widely available. Impossible to find in Texas. Not too pricey for the quality either
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 15, 2008 Had it at the flying saucer.  Noticed it was bitter right away.  Decent lacing.  Notes of a lot of roast and chocolate.  Creamy and delecious, would drink again

Typical great beer coming from Kalamazoo Bells.  Poors our real dark and somewhat like syrup.  Fills your mouth with a chocolate and coffee and finishes slightly bitter; it leaves you with a warmth inside.  Highly recommended.
user_location: originally from Michigan, New York, USA

text: This is a very good beer even if its not as good as its bigger brother the expedition.  Nice and dark looking, like motor oil. I was expecting an imp stout but it was definitly only a stout.  As far as stouts go, this is pretty damn top notch.
Opague. Roast and licorice in the aroma. Full bodied, creamy mouthfeel. Creamy, malty flavor with roast, coffee and licorice, especially in the aftertaste. Well made.

Bottle. Pours jet black with a nice beige head- a real work of art. The aroma is an earthy dank dirt combined with coffee and chocolate. The taste is full of roasted notes, coffee, burnt malts, chocolate, and a nice hoppy addition. A great beer.

Pours an opaque black with a big light brown head that dies slow and laces. Smells roasty, chocolate, and expresso. All of the smells are in the taste along with a small hop bite. Balanced, delicious and subtle all around. Medium in the mouth and smoooth. Very drinkable on its own session or as a treat.

Id give this beer a 6 on appearance if I could.  Thick, opaque, black body with a foamy, lasting, creamy, tan head that laced the glass all the way down.  Aroma is all roasted malt, sugar, nuts, molasses, dark fruits, grapes and coffee.  Flavor is strong coffee and roasted malts, nuts, chocolate, brown sugar, molasses.  Medium body in the mouth, slightly watery towards the end, with a chocolate/coffee finish.  This is a really really good beer, complex, inviting but also tame enough to be consumed regularly.

Great stout as you would expect from Bells.  Surprisingly, theyre distributing to supermarkets as well.  This beer poured great with a very dark, almost black color and a frothy un-stout-like head.  The flavors were that of roasted malts and hints of coffee and even chocolate.  Very good stout!

typical looking stout-   Got a good thick two finger head in a Duvel glass.  Nose- some anise, bakers chocolate.  Taste- very rich, and good balance of dry and chocolate/molasses sweetness.  Great body and nice hoppiness on the finish. Drinks bigger than it really is. A lot of impy stouts probably wish they had the richness and flavour profile of this brew.  One of the best non impy stouts Ive had.  great work!

12 oz bottle thanks Pantanap.  A bit cold coming out of the fridge. Poured black, no head.  Nose of Dogfish Head Raison detre. Body is thick while cold.  Ill let this sit and come back to it.   A bit overcarbonated. Almost too sweet but bitter on the back end. A little chocolate, raisins, licorice. One is enough.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Says its brewed with licorice, thats no lie. It is the dominant flavor, especially noticeable in the dry roasty finish. A different kind of stout but pretty enjoyable nonetheless.

Pours a dark brown/black with a thin coffee colored head.  Aroma of roasted malts, chocolate and licorice.  Roasted malt flavor with taste of chocolate, coffee, licorice, and dark fruit.  Nice bitter dry finish with strong chocolate, roasted coffee and icorice aftertaste.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a viscous oily black with a nice choloate head, half find, thats cream and quickly disapating.  Nose of roast and chocolate, dark fruits, plum and raisin.  Good roasted taste with a carmel sweetness, chocolate notes leading into a good, solid hop bitterness, thats mellowed with some creamy fruit notes at the end.  A good bitter chocolate after with a touch of coffee.  Very good stout, highly drinkable and readily available.  This could turn into a winter staple "session" beer.

A: Just like a stout should look. Dark body with a thick mocha colored head.

S: Dark roasty chocolate with a pronounced sweetness. Some dark fruits are present but as usual, I cant figure out exactly which ones they are.

T: This isnt as sweet as a sweet stout usually is. There is a bit of roastiness and a great amount of chocolate. There is a bit of the licorice, but the balance is great.

M: On the heavier side of medium bodied; or the lighter side of heavy bodied.

D: Not a bad stout at all. Too bad Bells isnt available around here.

12oz Bottle. Tasty stout with roasted coffee, chocolate and licorice undertones.Tons of flavor. Excellent as a "dessert beer," and I find it much more drinkable than their Expedition Stout. My favorite from Bells, which is a fine brewery.
Dark black pour with thick tan head.  Creamy mouthfeel with roasted malt and chocolate.  Dry aftertaste.  Another good beer from a great brewery.

Have yet to have a bad brew from bells.  12 oz Bottle. smells like roasted cofee beans and malt. Pitch black with a creamy dark tan head. Has a thinner body than the Expedition but comes close to the same flavor explosion

Bottle. Pours a deep brown/black, no light visable through glass. Dense brown head. Aroma of slight chocolate, maybe some roast coffee. Flavor was more of the same, chocolate, coffee and licorice, slight bitterness.

12 oz bottle. Batch 7752, last bottle from a year old six pack. Jet black with a thick tan head. Big roasty aroma, lots of coffee and hints of caramel. Taste has a little more chocolate with the coffee. Great stout.
Pours black with a thick tan head.  Has a very smoky aroma with caramel and coffee.  Tastes of burnt coffee beans and hazelnut.  Very creamy mouthfeel with a nice dry finish.

Pours dark, with a very strong aroma of burnt coffee... taste is very strong chocolate and coffee with a very thick creamy feel in the mouth... taste lingers in the mouth for quite a while.. good stuff

Excellent. Pours dark black (redundant?), smells of roasted malts and hints of coffee. Liquorice and hops became more evident in the flavor, quite enjoyable. As it warmed, the flavors came more alive.
bottle. it has a very dark brown color with a medium head. the aroma is nice and roasty with the taste being also nice and roasty.
Excellent roasted character, nice hop balance, but drier than I expected to find.  Nonetheless, an excellent beer.

Remember back in college when you tried to switch from Bud Light to Guinness to show how sophisticated you were?  And you really didnt like the taste of Guinness because it was so different from your usual swill that you drank?  Well this tastes like you wanted that Guinness to taste...  its simply amazing.

Pours an insanely deep brown (almost black?) color - totally opaque - with an unbelievably creamy tan head.  Its stunning, really.  The aroma is of coffee notes and roasted malt.  Again - stunning.  The aroma is neither overdone nor overpowering - its balanced perfectly.  And it complements the beautiful flavor that this brew provides.  A stout that brings your palate to life with perfect roasted malt flavors on the front of the palate and finishes with an exceptional blend of chocolate and coffee bitterness.  Ill say it again - its stunning.

One of my favorites of all time, and Im not a die-hard stout drinker.  I have an Expedition Stout in my refrigerator and I cant wait to see what Bells has done with that one.
Bottle (Bager) at ØLklubben. Black brown head. Burned, coffee, nutty, chokolate, candy. Thin body - a bit disapointing !!!

UPDATED: NOV 16, 2007 12 oz Bottle.  Aroma smells like roasted malt and coffee.  Pitch black with a creamy dark tan head.  Coffee was the first thing that came to my head when drinking it and a little bit of chocolate.  Isnt very thick and is really smooth on the palate.

Bottle. Batch 8178. Aroma of roasted malt, rich molasses, charred wood and a hint of bitter espresso. Looks fantastic. Pitch black with a nice creamy khaki head. Excellent head retention with good lacing. Flavor is very dry. Roasted malt, liquorice and espresso. A nice hoppy backbone to balance out the malts. By far from thin on the palate, but I like my stouts a little thicker. A good offering nonetheless.
Bottle. Pours pitch black with a small brown head. Very well balanced with notes of chocolate, coffee, dried fruit and hops.
Dark, black, thick.  Consistent dark beige lacing head.  Smells of roasted coffee beans.  Tastes of chocolate and coffee, very smooth and very nice.  Great body and taste.
This stout is really steering me into more stouts.  There is a very rich malty carpet lays smoothly over the tongue.  I would take one of these anytime October-March

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2008 bottle.  black oil with thin brown head.  nice coffee/espresso aroma.  taste brings in a roasted bitter hop.  nice moderately thick body. sharp carbonation on the back end.  slight acidic quality on the finish.  hoppier than other stouts ive tried, the acidic element detracted a bit.  very nice aroma, and the bitter was well balanced but in general not my kind of stout.  worth sampling.

ive since had this one draft.  nicely rounded. hops didnt seem to dominate as much as it did in the bottle.  i bumped up the flavor and impression by a few.
Bottle Black pour with big quick dying head. Dark coffee and licorace flavor and aroma. Flavor is much thicker. Great brew.

Bottle. Nutty roasted dark chocolate aroma.  Black with perhaps the best head I have ever seen.  Nice flavor but a bit of a watery finish.  Not as bold as I hoped it would be.  It is slightly chalky but still quite drinkable.  Would really enjoy the flavor if it were kicked up a notch or two.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2008 I love the Bells dark offerings, they generally add more hop character than most.  I lived in Kalamazoo, so maybe Im partial.  Nice black pour with a dark tan head.  Standard stout flavors intense as with any Bells.  I will say, as Ive seen in reviews for this, that most Bells beers are not all that well balanced.  The special double cream stout is slightly better, Id rate this one 2nd in their stable.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: NOV 15, 2007 Dark dark dark with a creamy tan head that fades quickly and leaves sheets of lacing on the glass.  Aroma is coffee, chocolate and alcohol.  Overwhelming roasted bitterness in the flavor with a thin watery body.  Not as well balanced as reported, I would put this in the "average" category.

Very intense flavours here: Licorice and dark chocolate hit the entire range of tastebuds from start to finish. A little bit of alcohol, grassy hops and cola-float flavours in there as it warms. Very interesting with tickling carbonation in the otherwise super-smooth body.
12 ounce bottle purchased at Case & Keg Boca Raton, FL for about $2.25 Really enjoyable!

12 oz. bottle.  Pours black with medium sized tan head.  Aroma of roasted coffee.  Mouthfeel is nice and dry.  Chocolate notes really settle nicely around the tongue.  Finish is a bit bitter, but in a good way.
draft- nice tan head, on top of a dark black brew. roasty aroma which does not overpower leads to a great coffee/roast/ chocolate stout with just the right amount of sweetness. delicious.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2007 Black with good, creamy brown head / Toasty, malty nose / Big, full, chewy body with malt and hop balance with long, lingering finish / Dark roast flavors of coffee, bittersweet chocolate, and blackstrap molasses / Terrific.
pours black with tan frithy head,roast coffee chocolate nose.coffee chocolate notes.med carb,med mouth feel goo stout.
Tap. Black body, coffee nose, small tan head. Mostly coffee flavors, dry, slightly bitter, very drinkable.

Batch 7837.  Bottle.  Dark pour with a sliver of light filtering through the edges.  Thin tan head that vainishes into a slick of lace.  Smells of chocolate and roasted malt.  More chocolate on the initial taste.  Some bitterness from the hops help even the big malt presence.  Very nice mouthfeel, fullness that nicely entertains the palate.  Finish...well imagine a fine piece of dark chocolate melting in ones mouth.  Very nice.
Poured from a bottle that is roughly 10 months old.  Pours darks and thick, not much head.  Sweet aroma.  Not the strongest flavor but very smooth.  Good hints of coffee.  Very solid stout.
Dark chocolate scent and taste. Serious malt. This is a dryer more bitter Stout than usual. Not bad. Probably like this better than the Double Cream.
user_location: Heart of the Rockies, Colorado, USA

text: Pours black as mud with a sweet and candylike aroma.  The flavor is robust and very coffee like, yet mild.

Bottle: Opaque pour with a thick bubbly tan head. Nose is full of roasted barley, black licorice, dark chocolate  and a nice smoky hop suggestion. Flavor is robust dark malts, creamy dark chocolate malted ice cream richness, late licorice suggestions, and a strong, burnt salty bitter finish. This Stout has a great hop character to balance the massive body, making is extremely quaff-able. Perfect for sessions.

From bottle : Really nice aroma at first look, love at first smell you could say.  Pours a very dark brown, boarderling black color with a light brown head, not all that big, that diminishes fairly fast to a ring.   Great smell of roasted nuts, caramel, chocolate, coffee, malts.  Flavor is much the same as the aroma with some licorice and maybe a little bitty note of alcohol on the end.  Smooth as a babys bottom on the palate, creamy, full and very enjoyable.

Dark brown body with a small tan head. A really nice melange of chocolate, coffee, fruit, licorice. So nicely balanced for having this much "stuff" going on. Probably about as good as it gets for $8.99/six.

Bottle from ABC in St. Petersburg FL. Just about everything that needs to happen in a stout for me can be found here. aroma is dark roasted malt, little coffee. Taste is rich and sweet roasted malt, great cocoa beans,  little coffee and  finishes with licorice that is in no way overpowering but a wonderful finish that leaves me wanting more. allot of people are not licorice fans but this is so well intrgrated into this brew i think anyone would enjoy it. The body is full and in no way thin. Allot of other stouts out there pack plenty of flavor but lack in feeling on the palate. bells got it all good in this brew, glad i found it being as no one stocks it in tallahassee yet.

Bottle.  Poured black with a very dark head--this is thicker and darker than Samuel Smith Imperial.  Rich, wonderful aroma--cocoa beans, molasses, and espresso.  Flavor is mainly roasted malts.  A little dirt and stale coffee too.  Finish is powerful roast espresso taste.  An amazing stout, amazing.

12 oz bottle ..thanks to seaoflament.  This pours a dark brown, almost black, with a thin beige head that dissipates very quickly.  Aroma of Chocolate and roasted malts.  Taste is of roasty malt, bitter dark chocolate and some hints of coffee.  Medium body.  Has a strong aftertaste on back of tongue.

Ive received this from both Acknud and Mcbackus in differant trades. Thanks to both Bill and Matt. 12 oz. bottle. Pours a deep, almost black, brown with a small tan head. Aroma is of roasted malts, coffee, and licorice. Mouthfeel is creamy and a bit on the heavy side. At first the taste is of roasted malts, but as the beer warms a coffee flavor becomes more dominant. Also, undercurrents of licorice. The only negative thing I will say about this beer is it left a bitter aftertaste in my mouth. This was a great brew from Bells. I cant wait to get my hands on some Expedition, hint.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2009 Bottle thanks to drewbeerme.  Poured a deep brown (black) color with a slight tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, and smoke.  Smooth chocolate entry leads to a deep roasted coffee flavor with nice smokey notes.  One of the few beers I have had that actually feels creamy on the palate.  Really easy drinking.  Thanks Drew.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2008 Bottle. Pours nearly completely black with a brown, thin head, Smoky aroma, taste of anise and coffee. Fine product, but not quite 99th percentile. 7/4/7/3/15/3.6

Rerate April 12, 2008: Batch 8338 bottle from Whole Foods in Charlottesville., Pours a cola color with a small brown head. Weak mocha aroma. Taste of caramel, chocolate, bitter coffee and rye. Nice creamy chewy texture. 6/3/7/4/15/3.5

Thank you to DrBayern for this bottlePours basically opaque black with a sticky staying big tan head.  Smell is big and roasty at first, with some dryness about it.  As it opened up I didnt enjoy the smell quite as much.  Tastes of dry, unsweetened roastiness but with a tart soy flavor creeping up more and more as I drank it.  Creamy, nice body and mouthfeel with good a carbonation level, but I get the roast & "soy" flavor more than coffee and chocolate.  Still not bad, but just had a component Im not crazy about.

12oz.  Definitely opaque, frothy orange head that reveals some decent carbonation you cant see otherwise.  Non-descript roasted goodness on the nose, the first sip is definitely exciting which is what is required for a rating above 4 for me.  Great coffee and raisin in the body, with the smallest hint of liquorice reminds me ever so slightly of a sambuca shot with a coffee bean chaser.  Great, full, creamy mouthfeel that makes this very approachable and drinkable but still a better than average, very tasty brew.

Sampler from bottle at Clifton Beer Fest at Fries Cafe.  Yes, the color is "utterly opaque" with a rich malt aroma, good complex flavor with coffee, molasses, chocolate, something that reminds me of meats cooking on a charcoal grill, and God knows what else shifting around and flowing across the taste buds.  Not the heavist body youll ever find in a stout but it all hangs together very well.  Very fine brew.

(Bottle, thanks Ughsmash, olso2116 and Guerde) Pours opaque black with medium brown head. Heavy roasted to burned and light smoky aroma with dark roasted coffee beans and vanilla ice cream. Undertones of brown sugar/molasses, dark chocolate, cheese, gravel, oil, sulphur and black berries. Also some hints of hops. Rather complex nose.  Well roasted flavour with tones of spicy coffee, dark caramel, both milk and dark chocolate and hints of liquorice and dark berries. Good medium afterbitterness of both hops and roast. Smooth, round, velvety,  and full mouthfeel with a soft carbonation. A tiny bit oily. Medium to full bodied. A fantastic stout.
Has virtually no aroma.  Looks the way a stout should look.  Has a dark roasted toast and adds nothing special as far as other great stouts go.  Overall just an average stout.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2008 What a fantastic beer here. Uber roast complex of chocolate, oats, and cupcakes, but surprisingly zero coffee. Very black, very full of character, almost chalky with complexity. Another fantastic brew by the Bells masters.

12 oz. Opaque with a large creamy and lasting head that leaves behind a thick brown sugar frosting all over the glass. Aroma of cocoa, chicory coffee, and charred wood. Flavors of cocoa, coffee, char, prickly spices, and earthy metallic herbs. Palate is medium-heavy and creamy, with some hop-carbonation tingle.

bottle.....aroma: nothing terribly surprising here. full of roast and tons of chocolate....apperance: semi-thin dark brown almost black pour with one inch light brown head that dissipated quickly....taste: more of that roast, sweet malt, and chocolate thing going.  excellent mouthfeel.  good texture and somewhat creamy.  goes down easy and is very satisfying at that.

UPDATED: JUN 22, 2011 12oz bottle-pours a foamy brown head and black color.  Aroma is dark malt-licorice, dark fruit-cherry/sweet, roasty.  Looking forward to this as usually not my style.  Taste  is burnt coffee, some sweetness, licorice, acidic from hops, oak/wood, dark malt, chalky.  90 degrees from aroma.  2.2 *110325- on tap-pours a rich brown head and black color.  Aroma is licorice.  Taste is licorice.  3.8

Bottle/Trade Prize. The aroma of cocoa and coffee was out done by an amazing taste as if I had made moca-java coffee with less water than required. Possibly the heaviest beer I have tasted. I wonder what the tap version is like.
Pours black, brown head.  Very strong aroma and taste.  Tastes of coffee and chocolate with a long lasting aftertaste.  One of my favorites.

Good sweet nose with a mild chocolaty aroma.  The head is dark brown but fades very fast.  This beer has a big taste with a lot of bitter chocolate in it.  I also detect some piney hops at the end.
Theres alot going in this one, with some coffee aftertaste in there. This is indeed up there with the best.

Black beer with no head.  Aroma is full of coffee and bitter chocolate.  Flavor is a sweetish, bitter coffee and chocolate with a touch of smoke.  Excellent beer.  Not quite as thick and heavy as the Expedition.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black colour with a big rocky and creamy dark brown long lasting head leaving a very nice lacing. Soft aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and liquorice. Good creamish mouthfeel. The flavour has a soft roasty maltiness with good chocolate, liquorice, bitter hops and soft smokiness. Long roasty bitter chocolate finish. Great brew indeed!

Bottle: pours a dark black with a thin but lasting head, aroma of chocolate and malt, taste is very malty along with some toffee flavor, smooth somewhat creamy mouthfeel.  I havent had a plain old stout in a while.  Glad I tried this one.

On tap at the hops of fun festival in Mackinaw City, MI. A good way to start the festival. Ive always liked Bells line of stouts and this no exception. Cocoa and coffee with a good malty flavor. I will be looking for this in my local store.

Pours dark with a creamy and bitter taste, unfortunately I drank this beer after a few less dry beers so I will need to re-evaluate at a later time. I purchased this beer at top Shelf Liquor on Lithia Pinecrest Rd. and at Total wine on Dale Mabry in Tampa Florida.
Single bottle from World Market in Mooresville, NC.  Pours a dark dark brown with  a small head.  Aroma is all roasted malt and some cocoa.  Taste is strong coffee and malt.  Wonderful.

12 oz Bottle-Batch #7952-trade w/Acknud (who I forgot to credit in my 1st 2 bells reviews!) Jet black w/almost no head but good lacing which lasted thru the brew. Strong rosted malt aroma. Great flavor, more chocolate & licorice than coffee, also had some traces of vanilla & a strong roasted malt presence.  Very good, very smooth, & very easy drinking, Great mouthfeel; very rich & creamy. This one is a winner for sure, Thanks Bill!!!

This stout blew me away.  The aroma was mild, slightly chocolately and malty.  The taste was a blast of chocolate and roasted malt with a swirl of complexity that I couldnt completely pick apart.  It finished smooth with the flavors lingering only as long as they should.  There was nothing negative about the mouthfeel and finish, I was very pleased.  The flavor was slightly bitter, a little bit like coffee, which was very enjoyable.  Highly quaffable.

Date: 11/27/1999
Mode: Bottle
Source: Ale Atlanta

black, whispy tan head, roasted malt aroma, rich malt flavor, touch of roasted coffee character, bitterness in the finish
-------- />
Date: 10/14/2006
Mode: bottle

black, whispy brown head, touch of lace, body on the thin side, huge roasted and coffee aroma, roasted coffee flavor, very dry, roasted bitterness that starts light and grows, 

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 4/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 3.5/5.0Drinkability: 6/10
Score: **4

Poured an oil slick black color with a thin tan head that bubbled around the edge of the glass. The pour was so dark that almost no light came through. The aroma was big of roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and roasted malts. A big roasted flavor follows full of roasted coffee and malts, and sweet and dark chocolate. The roasted and sweet malts make itself known from the beginning. This is full bodied with a nice creamy mouthfeel that is smooth going down. The chocolate, malts, and roasted flavors blend togethe so nicely and makes this one really enjoyable. A really good stout from a great brewery.
A king stout. Rich flavors. Deep chocolates. Creamy. The perfect winter beer.

Poured opaue black.  Wow this beer is roasted.  Chocolate coffee dark malts are toasting my nose as I inhale and the smokey woodiness flavors melt into my mouth leaving nutty and bunt malt residue on my teeth.  For all its roasted character, it is bouyed by a quiet but studry creamy vanilla flavor.  Overall a nice stout for sure.
DARK! tastes like molasses and carmel. Too thick for my likings, I guess Im not a stout drinker. I think Ill stick to my belgium beers and ales.

Bottled
Opaque black color, thick expresso head. Licorice and milk chocolate in the nose. Full-bodied. Toasted malts, lactose and licorice in the flavor. Toasted malty aftertaste. Sweet stout -like, so more sweet than roasted. "Easy to drink" -big stout.

Bottled. Very opaque black colour with mediumsized brown head. Aroma is dark chocolate, licorace, coffee and some vanilla. Flavour is leather, coffee, chocolate and licorace. Not very much roasted notes when cold. When getting warmer there are some, especially in the aftertaste. Really wellbrewed thing.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2007 I very much enjoyed this stout from Bells.  Bottle: It looked so good in the pint glass I almost did not want to drink it, but I am sure glad I did.  Aroma and taste of malt, coffe and black licorice.  Very good.
Big black pour with a nice off white head. Very light roasted malt aroma with a hint of anise. Taste is basically the same, malt, anise and some coffee. Very smooth and great tasting stout.
I do not understand why this gets the high ratings it does. I found it way too unbalanced and bitter. Over-roasted. A lot of people seem to like it very much, but I guess its just not for me.

Bottle. 12 fl. oz. Black color with small, dark tan head. Sweet aroma of chocolate cake. Flavor is nicely balanced between a sweet, chocolate start and a wonderfully bitter, roasted end.  Lingering, bitter coffee finish. This beer did not let me down.  Fantastic.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2007 Pours a dark color with a medium to small head that disapates quickly.  Has the aroma of chocolate and harsh coffee flavor.  Has little carbonation and goes down very easily.  it felt like I was swallowing air.  I highly recommend this beer.

Nice dark pour with a tan/red head that starts huge but recedes to a respectable level.  Big roasty aroma with coffee and light chocolate.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Perfect carbonation.  This brew definitely has a lot going on.  Roasted malt and coffee is very bitter up front, milk chocolate and molasses in the middle.  Hops evident towards the finish.  Light citrus, bitter.  Great brew.

I like Guinness, but this stuff is a cut above ---at this point, I believe it to be the best Stout Ive tasted (not claiming to be an expert) .  I dont know when Bells started making their Stout, but the City of Kalamazoo should be honored to have its name on this brew.   I give it my highest recommendation!

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2015 This has to be just about the perfect stout.  Pours dark as night with a nice tan head.  Aroma of Roasted malt and coffee.  Creamy, full bodied and smooth.  Well balanced with a great roasted coffee, caramel malt.  Finish is nice.
UPDATED: AUG 23, 2007 nuts, chocolate and malts, VERY FLAVORFUL, some caramel and wood in there as well... its pretty much the best stout ive ever had

poured into tall tulip.  pours a thick Dark black with full frothy dark caramel head.  malty mocha milky coffee aroma.  smooth and milky on the palate.  smoky and malty with dry malty finish.  dry aftertaste of smoked malts.  this is a very good stout and a great grab.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2008 nice black pour. aromas of richly roasted malts, wood, dark cocoa powder and toasted fennel seeds.light to medium bodied but still creamy. flavors are heavily roasted with a little smokiness and some chocolate. nice acidic/bitter coffee like finish. nice change from the world of sweet and chocolate dominant stouts. thanks to ucusty for the bottle.

12oz bottle from Drewbeermes wedding reception.  Dark opaque black with small tan head.  Aroma of roasted malt, smoky.  Roasted dark sweet malt flavor, coffee, alc, some bourbon.  Med body, creamy.  Very good wedding brew, thank goodness for loop holes.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2007 im just starting to drink stouts, so i may have to revisit,  but it poured nice and dark.  almost felt a little lacking compared to the other stouts i have had.  not quite as thick but thats not always a bad thing.
Poured a dark brown with a tan head. Has hints of nuts, roasted malts and barley, some caramel and dark chocolate. Finished smooth and thick with a roasted taste.
Pours jet black with minimal tan head.  Very creamy feel to mouth with taste of dark chocolate, coffee and mild licorice.

Great dark coffee pour coupled with some sweet black licorice and dark chocolate flavors. There are some smoky and roasted tones in here too. Bottle from Chips in Outer Banks, NC. Great creamy texture with an elegant semi-dry palate to boot. My only complaint is that the initial sweetness seems a bit too up there but this one caught on with me quick.

Opaque, black as night body.  No head, just a bubbly thin film and a foamy rim around the edges.  The aroma is a very nice blend of sweetened dark chocolate, licorice, anise, and mocha.  Its quite a potent bouquet, and you can tell its pretty sweet before you even taste it.  The flavor supports that theory, as it is quite sugary up front.  The taste profile is a beautiful mix of various chocolates, both sweet and bitter, as well as licorice, raisons, anise, coffee, and some bitter hops.  The body is on the heavy side of medium, with a cloying sweetness that borders on outright sticky.  It sits a little heavy, no doubt due to the high sugar content.  Overall a very, very good beer.  Think a less extreme version of DFH Worldwide Stout.  I cant wait to try the Expedition.
Pours black cofee with a thin dark brown head. Smell of sweet licorice is present.  Smoky charcoal taste, very carbonated. Slightly sweet.

12 oz bottle...black and creamy...great chocolate and cofee aroma....roasted cofee bean and malts with a nice bitter/sweet chocolate background...very relaxing and enjoyable stout...one of my favorites

Pours almost black w/ a medium sized, semi creamy froth. Head retention is a little short and it reduces to a rather skimpy lace. Aroma is full w/ roasted chocolate malts. Full nectar w/ soft and creamy residual effers. A huge roast component balanced by thick, chewy malts and a mild fruitiness. Nuances of roasted coffee bean, bakers cocoa, leather, grilled meat, molasses, and black cherry. Robo Hop steps in and brings the roasted malts to a new level of awareness. The finish is bittered extensively and makes this brew totally drinkable. Good balance. Highly recommended.

Absolutely perfect opaque black pour, with a 3-finger head that has excellent retention and leaves webbed lace.  The bouquet is of freshly roasted coffee.  Superb integration of coffee, roasted grains, caramel, toast, bitter chocolate and almond /peanut skins.  Licorice shows up slightly in the finish, providing a hint of numbness to the front- and mid-palates, while the back-palate is satiated with lasting smoked bitters.  Smooth and ever-so-creamy mouthfeel with a solid body.  Very, very quaffable with excellent integration!

Now this is a beer worth waiting for.  From a bottle, after buying it at "home" in Michigan and driving home to Milwaukee, it was the perfect temp to sample.  Very smooth, pleasant finish, and the appearance is perfect for a stout -- just what youre looking for.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2007 12oz, 8007, pours black with big tan head. nose is roasty, coffee, and nuts. flavor is very rich and complex with caramel, coffee, roasty, nutty, milk chocolate, wet grains, and licorice. mouth feel is rich and full. this is a very good stout.

Pure black with a fine thin espresso head.  Strong coffee aroma with bittersweet chocolate, dark berry fruits, and a touch of hops.  Flavor is creamy on the attack with some light sweetness which graduates into intense dark roasted coffee and a touch of hops and anise before finishing dry with some roasted malt astringency and bitterness.  Body is substantial yet quite light on its feet delivering flavorful blows but always coaxing you back with a smooth body and refreshing mouthfeel.

[Bottle] Pours black with a tan head.  Good lacing on the glass. Aroma is strongly of roasted malt--I dont get molasses or chocolate from it.  A little sweet at first, now I get chocolate, but once again mainly roasted malt with a little bitterness.  Medium-thin body.  Long finish.  Pretty good beer.
350 mL bottle.  Black with a creamy tan head.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, and leather.  Good creamy mouth feel with tastes of chocolate, caramel, and a bitter roasty finish.  Yum.

12 ounce bottle in pint glass.  Pours black lasting brown head and lace.  Aromo a of roasted dark chocolate and fresh dark bread.  Flavors of roasted chocolate, coffee, and some raisinyness.  Medium body.  An excellent non-imperial stout.

12oz Bottle courtsey of WeeHeavySD. Pours a solid black with a small tan head. Roasty aroma. Flavor starts off a bit chocolaty with malty sweetness. hints of spices and cofee with a more bitter finish. Extremely well balanced and drinkable.

Bottle. Nose, even when slightly too cold, gives an impressively deep coffee and chocolate backbone to some sweet cherry notes. Hint of oatmeal, maybe. Something grainy. Pitch black with no head and some minor ruby hints at the right angle. Leads with chocolate, strong and malty, but balanced sweetness. Second layer is a quick touch of spice, mostly carbonation mimicking spice, and finally a full bodied coffee finish. Palate is complex, smooth at times but robust with carbonation. A superior beer.
Black with small dark brown head.  Roasted coffee aroma with strong hints of dried fruits  Bittersweet chocolate and coffee flavor. Great stout
This stout pretty much had it all.  I had been looking for this one for a while, having heard such great things, so I was thrilled when I came across it.  Pretty much lived up to the hype.

Robust aroma of malt, molasses and coffee.  Poured a nice black with a small, tan foamy, semi-creamy head. Head receded into a nice creamy cap. Left nice lacing.Flavor is sweet chocolate, roasted and burnt malt, black coffee, with a slight taste of molasses. Do I taste a touch of caramel as well? Well balanced. Medium body, with a creamy, slightly sticky texture.  Very, very soft carbonation.  Long bitter finish with a very slight touch of smoke. A very good Stout by Bells!  The strong bitter finish though might limit how many I would want to drink. Having said that, I really enjoyed this Stout! Nothing wrong with a beer that can make you happy with just one. :)  I will definitely buy again.

Bottle: Poured a dark black/brown with a thick tan color head. Its aroma was sweet caramel and hints of chocolate but not over shadowing. The taste was sweet coffee caramel malt, the molasses brought a nice twist to the finish as it was a bit more present. Overall one of my favorite stouts so far.
12 oz bottle.  Pours dark and opaque with a thick creamy tan head  Aroma of sweet malt, coffee and molasses.  Flavors much the same, however a little bittersweet.

Thanks for the botte from john_adam200.  Sweet milky smell with a little bit of roasted grains. No head.  Twirls with small bubbles that fade immediately.   Pitch black color.  Mellow, medium body, slight roasted grain flavor, chocolate.  A bit dry.  A barely noticable background acidity.  Maybe thats called a spicy or roasted-grain bitter finish.  My rating is a little low relative to others, primarily becauseI prefer sweeter beers.
Solid overall stout with everything youd expect, both in malt and body.  Nothing spectacular in comparison to others, but nonetheless right where it should be.  As good to style as any.
pitch black with whispy tan head.  flavor is very interesting with hints of licorice and peat and a nice burley complex finish.  very unique and quite good

12oz bottle poured in a tulip.  This black beer with a rocky tan head has a delicious pervasive odor.  It smells of cocoa, coffee and not-quite-burnt pancakes.  The head leaves a soapy lace on the glass.  It has a slightly bitter coffee taste accented with chocolate and mellowed out with dark honey or molasses.  It is smooth and easy drinking.  I think this beer is much better than the Expedition Stout

Outstanding! This is a great beer. Aroma of malt and chocolate. Pours almost balck with a nice tan head. Flavor is chocolate and coffee with roasted malt. It is amazingly drinkable for a stout. It is very dry and doesnt linger. One of the best.

Poured a dark hazy brown colour with a large frothy tan head. Aroma is roasty, molasses, coffee. Medium body. My first sip put me back in my seat, this stout is fabolous. I love the initial taste differences of finishing taste. The intial taste begins with a nice mouthfeel of a creamy rich dark chocolate moving into a caramel and expresso overlay then transitioning into a very roasty coffee. Finishing taste is a long lasting bitter. Perfect carbonation and great lacing of the glass. Head diminished but stayed true to the last sip.

From 33 cL bottle. Pours hazy brown with a very short living head. Aroma is raisin and malty sweet. Flavour is thick malty, sliht wineous and mild raisin flavoured. Minor liqourice note. Dry into a light spiced finish.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2007 Palate was a little dry, carbonated.  Not thick.  Flavor was robust, roasted malts and coffee.  Slight hint of chocolate.  A very roasty, robust stout.  Certainly closer to a dry stout than an imperial.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2009 Appearance: Pours a dark, opaque black body with a rich, creamy beige head.

Smell: A sweet, succoring aroma of milk chocolate, licorice, and an iced caramel macchiato.

Taste: Rich, roasty espresso and dark chocolate flavor smoothed out with a shot of cream. A noticeable, fruity twang and a hint of licorice keeps things interesting. The finish is strongly roasty, and slightly astringent.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Moderate carbonation.

Drinkability: Quite nice! It should be on anyones list of things to drink before they die.
Very thick and dark pour with minimal tan head.  Long and complex, with some sharp coffee and roasted notes.  Leaves a bitter roasted finish
UPDATED: JUL 15, 2007 Loads of chocalate come to my mind. I love chocalate therefore this beer works for me.
UPDATED: NOV 1, 2007 Pours Opaque with a small brown head. Roasted aroma with hints of smoke.  Coffee and some chocolate coat the mouth.

Charred oak, chocolate, and cherry aroma. Black color with a thin tan head. Taste is smoke from beginning to end and a bit yeasty. As the glass warms, the taste of molasses and dates appears. Finish is coffee, but hop notes become more pronounced at room temperature. When served cold, this is a fairly mediocre beer. When warm, it really comes alive.
Poured dark brown with a khaki head.  Had an aroma of vanilla, malt and chocolate.  Had a great flavor with a taste of sweet molasses when it first hits your palate.

(22oz bottle) Sampled at at a gathering at TiggMTLs place in Vancouver on June 30, 2007. I think BeerPrince brought this? Thanks whomever you are, Beer Santa, as Ive been chasing this beer for a couple of years now. Opaque and thin white head. Vanilla and roasted beans in the nose. Flavour is pretty chocolaty with some licorice and sweet malt. A good but but only in moderation as its pretty thick and sweet.

Bottle. Very dark, with a lasting tan-coloured head. Bags of chocolate in the aroma. The chocolate theme continues on the palate - dark cooking chocolate comes to mind. Some sweetish elements but fairly bitter with liquorice becoming apparent too. Full mouthfeel without being too rich or sticky. A very tasty and satisfying stout but not too much of a brainblaster (which is good).
i love this one. probably my favorite dark beer. you cant see through it. thats always a good sign. its got a weird mix of flavors that somehow managed to work well.

Black pour, medium brown head. Aroma of chocolate, caramel malts and smoke. Flavor is dark chocolate mainly, roasted malts and sugary mollasses. The aftertaste is where the licorice comes through. Good stout but damn 4.09 Im not sure if its that good. It leaves a pretty bitter smokey taste that lingers and kinda puts me off.

Bottle @ the Brickskeller, Washington, DC.  Aroma is faint but there is chocolate, and deeply roasted malt.  The flavor is rich, with powerful sour flavor from roasted malt, some caramel, a tiny bit of chocolate, and then the licorice comes through ever so softly in the finish.  The body is thick without being overpowering.  Truly a fine stout!
Pours a opaque black color with a brown head.  Aroma is malts, molasses, chocolate, and, roasted malts.  Flavor is malty, caramel chocolate, and roasted malts,

Bottle. Whats with the dude on the front? Pours a deep black with only the slightest edges of red and orange. A medium head with a light hazelnut color. Smell on the pour was rich roasted coffee, milk chocolate and some sweet cherries. Amazing combo. In the flavor department it is mostly sweet mollasses and roasted coffee. Mouthfeel is smooth and refreshing. Some other beers have much the same taste but miss on the aroma and refreshing feel.

Expeditions baby brother.  Everything seems identical except for the thickness/creaminess.  Very fine beer with all of the amazing chocolate, fruit, malt aspects of big brother but a little easier to put away a couple at a time.  Fine beer.

Black, black, and black....how does that saying go?  Black as a midnight sky on a moonless night....this poured with a beautiful tan head that accented the brew beneath.  The aroma was a roasted delight that reminded me the day after a good smoke on the smoker.  The roasted scent turns into a roasted bomb of a taste.  Delicious flavors.  Although I am well happy with this one the flavor does not last as long as I would wish, this is only a minor issue though.

Pours an ebony, totally opauqe.  Head is a gorgeous tan color and is seeminglyt lasting for an eternity.  The aroma, oh the aroma...Rich and roasted, some black strap molasses and a slight nuttiness.  Maybe a touch of winter spice shining through the darkness.  The flavor is warming and roasted and last forever.  WOW.  An almost creamy mouthfeel.
Smooth and creamy yet so think and heavy. A complex brew with hints of, well, damn near everything that makes a good stout!

Its a pitch black beer with a huge, light brown and creamy head. The aroma has notes of roasted malt, light sweetnes, toffee and slightly sweet coffee. The flavour has a light sweetness, nice roasted malt, sweetish coffee and licorice, toffee and a hint of chocolate. The flavour is roasted and yet very smooth. It has a light bitterness and a very, very nice balance and harmony - yummi, what a nice beer. Thank you Linus_Stick for this wonderful beer!! 2342
12oz - Happened upon it in Indy.  Like a nice smooth cup of coffee.  Nice, satisfying mouthfeel, full without being heavy.  Good.

From 12oz bottle, black hue with dark tan creamy lasting head = good lacing, roasted to burnt smell + hint of carmel odor, thick syrupy texture, flat carbonation, a bit of a chocolate taste + generous carmel malt that along with roast were the dominant flavor, a slightly sour aftertaste, preferred the imperial stout to this guy.

Much thanks to theisti for this one! Dark as night pour with nice burnt-colored head. I can already smell the roast and I havent even sniffed it yet. Good lacing. Beautiful smell of deep roasted malts...some chicory as well. Medium bodied, creamy mouth feel. Stong, powerful flavor of roasted malts...some molasses and coffee notes as well. Finish is wonderfully bitter. theisti...this is worth every beer I gave you! Thanks!
Nice full, thick stout.  What else can I say that hasnt already been said.  Great beer
Excellent stout pours dark brown with hints of malts chocalate and coffee.  ecellent beer!!!

12oz bottle courtesy of mreusch-A dark black body with a small ring for a head and an aroma of roasted malt. Taste of sweetness, chocolate, roasted malt and a small bitterness. Nice tasting stout. My 400th rating and then a little Iron Maiden(Invaders)is playing on RB. Kick Ass.

I was very excited to try the Kalamazoo Stout. I had just had my first Bells Pale Ale a week earlier. Was expecting a little more, but I was not dissapointed. Great dark, opauque pour, with chunks. Was a bit thinner than I had expected, but did have a wonderful taste. Not as bitter as sierra nevadas stout, and not as sweet as Stones Imperial. A great chocolaty, licorice taste. Would reccomend to anybody looking for a good stout.

Pours a deep brownish-black with large frothy brown head with lots of coffee and nuts in a malty nose. Rich malty taste with coffee, nuts molasses and hints of candy and chocolate on a bitter thick creamy body. Good stuff!

Rated 3/17/07:  This is marvelous, a great stout that hovers in between an imperial and a sweet stout. Full bodied with a strong aroma and flavor. Roasted malt hits the nose immediately, lots of coffee and nuts in the aroma. Its robust and inviting. Rich dark pour with a thick fluffy light brown head that eventually fades along with some mild lacing. This beer is a meal in a glass that provides a silky smooth mouthfeel both creamy and filling. Roasted malt is the first flavor that is noticed followed by black coffee, roasted nuts, and mild chocolate. Taste is phenominal. What a great stout it drinks like a mild dry or sweet stout but is packed full of aromas and flavors more likely found in the imperial style. I cant say enough good things about this brew.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2007 Seems like I have had this before, but I dont think so.  Thick black pour, 2-finger dark tan head.  Aroma didnt jump out that much, but picked up on coffee with sweetness like vanilla and chocolate.  Smooth feel with taste of burnt coffee, chocolate, licorice and malts.  Some bitterness at the end, but then still smooth too.  Really well-balanced.  I never appreciated stouts as much in my earlier days, but theyre growing on me and this one is a step in the right direction.  Yum.

Bottle.  Cant believe Ive never rated this before now.  This is simply a great stout.  Pour is about perfect for the style... dark motor oil body with a two-finger brown head.  Aroma on this particular bottle was a little less than most in recent memory, but chocolate is there as are some sweet vanilla wafer like undertones.  Flavor is about perfect... smooth chocolate maltiness, vanilla sweetness and a little bit of a fade into a coffee like bitter aftertaste.  Mouthfeel is really smooth.  I guess part of the draw for me on Kzoo Stout is that it isnt like so many of the overdone, alcohol heavy, shock and awe stouts out there.  It just does a tremendous job at offering something you wouldnt mind drinking all night long and enjoying every last second of it.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Got this via a trade with LeopoldStoch, who I must say was a pleasure to trade with. Thanks Brabdon! Pours a slick, syrupy black with a small caramel head that fades to a spotty film with some head still clinging to the edge of my snifter. The head oddly forms after the pour, which was fun to observe. The aroma is smokey with obvious licorice, chocolate and roasted malts. The mouthfeel was velvety smooth and full-bodied. The flavour did have a smokiness to it, which was surprising, but in no way inappropriate for the beer. The The caramel and black roasted malts were initially the most apperent, yet in the finish, the chocolate and licorice truly came through. There is some nice bitterness from the roasted malts and minimal hopping in the aftertaste, which lingers for quite some time.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Not a huge stout fan, but this one may have changed my mind. Complex aroma with lots of malts and licorice. The taste compliments it well. A bit sweeter than most stouts, and perhaps this is what Ive been seeking. Purchased from Kingdom Liquors in Brandon.

I was fairly pleased with this stout.  It is oddly smokey, which I was not expecting, but lacked the awesome amount of dry "burned pizza crust" roastiness Ive come to expect from truly top-drawer stouts.  I was a bit intrigued by the remark on the bottle about the inclusion of "brewers liquorice" I learned about from the label.  This beer reminded me a great deal of Alaskan Brewings smoked porter; it is good and recommended.

Appearance is an inky black with a decent head that seems to materialize once the beers been in your glass for 10 seconds already.  Aroma is very chocolately, but this didnt show up much in the flavor.  The flavor was distinctly smoky, which I was a bit intrigued by.  Mouthfeel was smooth and good.  Definitely recommended, but I cant say I whole-heartedly agree with its current position in the 99th percentile of beers on this site.

Pours a pitch black with a thin, creamy tan head with nice lace. Gorgeous aroma - molasses, roasted malt, smells like the malt bins at the local homebrew supply - light licorice, too. Tastes... wow. Roasty doesnt even begin to describe it. Again, molasses and licorice, wonderful roasted malt, transparent hopping (bitterness from roasted malt balances hops perfectly). Beautiful lingering licorice & hops aftertaste. Body is ideal - thick without lingering too long in the mouth, carbonation at perfect levels. This beer is perfection itself, and its a crying shame that I only have one bottle (and now, none!) Thank you Robin!!!
thick malt and alcohol smell. sharp bitter taste. dark coffee, smoke, nut, licorice. full-bodied. real dark and really nice

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2007 12oz 2007 bottle.  Aroma is big roasted malts.  Notes of roast coffee, dark chocolate, and smoke.  Pitch black with dark amber around the edges of glass.  Large creamy tan head left excellent lace and was mostly lasting.  Flavor is awesome.  Roasted malts with bitter tones on the finish.  Flavors of espresso, smoke, with some molasses.  Transitions well from lightly sweet to moderately bitter.  Palate is medium bodied, smooth, and watery flat.  For a regular stout this delivers big time.  I really wanted to rate it higher as Ive never had a regular stout that matched it.  Id prefer the nose and flavor to have a little more fruit/spice.  However, this is the best stout Ive had to date.  I am truly in awe of this beer, well done Bells!!

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of malts, licorice, coffee, and chocolate.  Poured dark black in color with a small brown head that mainly diminished.  No lacing.  Opaque.  Flavor is lightly bitter.  Tastes of malts, chocolate, coffee, smoke, and raisins.  Medium body.  Smooth texture.   Soft carbonation.  Medium-length chocolate malt finish.
