Overall, I am clearly not as impressed as others are with this one.
Enjoyable stout but a bit too much licorice for my taste.  Lots of mixed flavors but licorice stands out more to me, which is not one of my preferred strong flavors.
Smells of coffee and alcohol, strong alcohol. Flavors of coffee, chocolate, molasses, and alcohol. Surprisingly not as strong as it smelled. Well balanced between roasted malt hoppy bitterness.

Picked up single bottle at Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul, MN. Pours a dark opaque brown brew with a lasting tan head. Aroma of dark chocolate, cream, some hazelnuts, black licorice and some espresso. Taste is high citrus, highly carbonated, bitter on the tongue, and a metalic finish.
Nice dark color with fizzy brown head aorudn the edges.  Smells of a thick light cofee.  Hop bitterness intermingled with coffee followed by a dry finish.  A little to carbonated, but overall nice.

Bottle thanks to jb175: Pours very dark almost black with a big foamy brown and grayish head. Aroma is very nice cream and  bittersweet chocolate. Flavor is rich smooth with sweet chocolate and roasted bitterness. Medium creamy body. As it warms it starts tasting very coffee like and not as sweet. Very well balanced stout.
Bottled sample from my good friend Piscator.  I loved this stout.  Great roasted flavour  Extremely smooth.  Could have had a few of them.  Would seek this one out for sure.

Another fine stout from Bells.  Black in the glass.  No head.  Buttery caramel and hints of chocolate.  The chocolately bitterness finish long and strong.  I prefer the Double Cream by Bells but this is a fine fine beer.

Pitch black, minimal to no head - taste was a bit metallic and watery b/c it was prob served a bit too cold.  once it warmed the chocolate showed through - but it was still nothing amazing.  I dont agree this should be in the 99th percentile.

Pours a deep black, with a beautiful, creamy, tan head. Aroma is of roasted malts, molasses, toffee, caramel and chocolate with a hint of licorice in the background. A nice oily and smooth mouth feel with a lightly metallic finish. Dominated by the roasted malts, this one has a long solid finish. I can see why so many people enjoy this beer.
Pours dark with a great brownish head.  A bit too sweet for my liking in Imperials but its another great beer from Bells.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2007 mmmmmmmm tasty goodness here id say. a plethora of roasty-ness coupled with an utterly amazing creamy and smooth moutfeel, and then some caramely-choclate. lite this stuff up if you have the means!! another winner!
Ummm roasty good stuff here. Need to go get some more of this. Very very smooth going down, creamy/malty/coffe-ey good. Bells does it again
Nice. Roasted flavors, a hint of chocolate, and creaminess make this a tasty one. Its a very good stout, and Id drink it again!

A damn good beer.  One of the most flavorful, yet easy to drink stouts I have ever had.  Wonderful chocolate, roasted coffee and light licorice.  Very creamy, and a nice sweetness that really complements the beer.  I utterly loved it.

Beautiful beer.  Possibly the only truly perfect pour Ive ever seen.  Nice contrast of roasty chocolate and licorice flavors.  Definite plum, raisin, fig and every other dried fruit flavor in there.  A touch of cherry.  Sweet up front, transitioning into a mellow dryness in the back.  Nice earthy hop bite back there.  Perhaps the best part of the beer is the dense, smooth palate, which somehow doesnt reduce the perfect drinkability one bit.  I almost feel like I can taste a bit of alcohol, but that may be the licorice playing tricks on me.  It didnt give me that "wow" feeling when I first taste it that the truly great beers have, but it is so flawlessly crafted that I cant help but be in awe of it.  And I hate black licorice.
A beautiful looking beer.  Nice brown head.  And it tastes even better.  Lots of chocolate, coffee, and nutty flavors.
12 oz. bottle at Zenos, Penn State.  Poured black with tan head.  Roasty, chocolatey flavor.  Good malty body.  As good as advertised.

Black with a thin tan head that disappears quickly and leaves a slight ring around the edge. Smells malty and chocolatey with lots of coffee. Excellent creamy profile with tasty coffee and choclate flavours with little carbonation. Hints of chocolate and coffee perfectly blended with only a hint of bitterness at the very end.  A worthy example of a good stout.

I have to be fair, this beer, maybe most stouts, are harder on the palate for me. However, this is the first Stout that I thouroughly enjoyed. Pours darker than Guiness, little to no head. Flavori s like roasted caramel, chocolate and licorice.The aftertaste was a bombardment for me, too heavy.
Very impressive.
bottle from Kingdom Liquors - very black with virutally no head - roasted coffee, chocolate, malty, full flavor - not my favorite though

A very respectable stout, though a bit overrated. It does not stand out when paired up against Dieu du Ciels Aphrodisiaque or even Sammy Smiths Oatmeal Stout. I would have appreciated more complex notes of vanilla, belgian chocolate, toasted caramel which seem to be absent. A fine example of the style, nonetheless.
Aroma dark coffee and a hint of nuts, very appetizing. Lightly carbonated and and full bodied, slightly bitter.

On tap @ The World of Beer: Pours a very dark brown to black with a light tan head. Aroma is roasty with hints of chocolate and coffee beans. Flavor has hints of chocolate, caramel and strong coffee. Very creamy and delicious on the palate.

Strong aroma of roasted espresso beans and dark chocolate, and light soy sauce. Pretty black appearance, creamy mocha/tan head. Very full and rich body, smooth. Bitter chocolate and roasty coffee flavor complemented very well with licorice. Why cant there be a Columbus Stout like this? Very solid offering.
Black beer with tan-brown head.  Robust, notes of smoke. Bitter chocolate.   Very drinkable.  Medium bodied
Pours deep very dark brown color with a thin light brown head.  Smells and tastes chocolatey, roasty, some coffee.  Quite yummy... something I could drink often and continue to enjoy.

12 oz bottle thanks to Degarth. Pours a deep black with a tan frothy head that lasted a long time. Chocholate, licorice, and caramel came through in the taste. Very tasty stout, that at the right temperature was really good.
Aroma of spoiled milk.  Good stout flavor--perfect blend of malt and hops, with a slight bitter aftertaste.  Not my favorite stout, but a good one.
From bottle.  One of the better stouts Ive tried.  Im not huge in stouts-- but this one I could drink anytime.  Seemed fairly conservative in respect to style, but nicely brewed and balanced.

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2014 Bottle shared by Lubiere (merci!!) served in a goblet, cold. AP06/07
App.:  Very dark brown-black, large flecks/chunks of off-white yeast, smallish light mocha head.
  
Aroma:  Lots of dark dried fruits, wood, cacao and dark chocolate; hints of smoke, small amounts of licorice and molasses.
  
Palate:  Medium body, fairly aggressive carbonation, slight astringency.
  
Flav.:  Lots of dark coffee and cacao, tangy; a touch yeasty, strong lingering bitter/tangy finish, slightly smokey.

********************
12 fl oz bottle from Potsdam NY, served at cellar temperature in a tulip glass. 
App.:  Deep brown-black with a fair mocha head.
  
Aroma:  Deep, dark, roasted, black coffee and dark chocolate notes, hints of molasses, licorice and grape jam, deep, clean and as expected.
  
Palate:  Medium+ body, restrained effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Deep, dark, clean and delicious, dark chocolate, black coffee, roasted barley, slightly ashen; dry with decent bitterness and a long, dark-roasted barley/malt finish.
Straight-forward stouty goodness.

jet black nice brown head, nice lacing on the glass. Aroma is all roasted malt, and a hint of smoke. Flavour is again alot of roasted malt, chocolate, a hint of smoke and coffee. nice mouthfeel, overall excellent stout, but i still dont think it beats the St-Ambroise Oatmeal Stout.
This stout is nice. Pours a semi thick black with a scattered brown head. Chocolate and malt on the nose. Smooth rolling taste. Plenty of roasted malt on the finish that lingers.

Black with a monstrous, frothy, grayish tan head. Roasted malt nose with bittersweet chocolate and licorice. Same flavor with a small dose of bitter hops near the finish. Roasted licorice aftertaste. Body is full, but not heavy, carbonation is balanced. Very drinkable, perhaps too drinkable. Not very complex, but it doesnt need to be. Great stout.
Wonderful stout. Ive finally found a dark beer that can replace my beloved deceased Grants perfect porter (RIP). Bit of an odd mouth feel for a stout which kept the score from being higher.

12 oz bottle, Ive gotten several lately, Im guessing this one came from DrBayern.  Needed someting low octane that was cold to end my night early as I got at 5am today.  Batch 7694.  Pours Black with a large 3 finger tan head.  Aroma is sweet roasty and dry.  Tast is very very nice rich and complex with a lighter side of an impy taste.  great stout.

Pretty much like the commercial description. Personally I prefer less of the dark fruit characteristics. still, very roasty, some smoothness. solid stout. dictionary example of straightforward stout. Had this at Bodega Brew Pub downtown La Crosse, Wisconsin USA. Occasionally available on draft there.
My favorite stout hands down. It has a unique bitterness for a stout that smacks your tongue instead of shaking its hand.

Batch 7289, Aged 1 year; black in color and poured a giant frothy, medium brown head that slowly diminished. Aroma is sweet and chocolaty. Flavor was very sweet, almost sour in the mouth, with chocolate notes slowly appearing. Finished strong with rich roast and chocolate flavor. I liked it more than Expedition, as Kalamazoo seemed to have some direction and not over the top with everything.

Bottle:  Dark brown pour with a large tan head and thick, sheet lacing.  IMO, a perfect appearance.  Nose is roasted malt and coffee, hint of cocoa.  Taste is dominated by the roasted malt and coffee, some chocolate tones and a bit of hops bitters.  Creamy mouthful and rich taste is easy to enjoy.
Drank with stegosaurus at Issac Newtons. Bottled.  Blackish pour. Roasted aroma with a mild caramel/roast chocolate taste and a dry finish. Very Smooth. Incredible.
UPDATED: MAY 20, 2010 Black color. Medium body. Lots of roasted malt flavor. Hops were a bit on light side. Smoke was first aroma, and enjoyed it. Not as sweet as Bells Expedition Stout.

Bottle.  Pours black with a small light tan head.  The aroma is weaker than expected, but I do get some chocolate and roasted malts.  Solid flavor.  Roasted malts, chocolate, licorice, with a slight touch of coffee.  There is some noticeable bitterness.  Dry finish.  A good year round stout.

This is a very good example of a stout (leaning towards a dry stout). The aroma is rich with chocolate, molasses, burnt malt, and coffee. The appearance is super dark brown with a tan three finger head. The flavor is like the aroma with an assertive bitterness despite a lack of hops in the aroma. The palate is thick and the aftertaste is dry and very much like bitter coffee. If you are a lover of true stouts then you will enjoy this beer.
Bottle. Black beer with ruby highlights. Light fruity aroma (berry) with roasty malt. Fruity, licorice, roasty flavor. Lingering fruitiness and roast. Medium bodied. Good, but not great.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2007 Beers like this are the reason that Im proud to be from West Michigan. Poured black with a medium caramel head that thinned and then retained throughout the drink. Aroma is burnt coffee and dark chocolate, taste is similar with deeper character. Very thick, smooth texture, extremely drinkable.

Also, is pretty good when mixed half/half with a Newcastle brown ale... I was curious.

12oz bottle Black as the heart of my ex with a dinse thick head malts chocolate and lightly smokey.  It tastes Perfect.  This will fight punch for punch with the gonzo and the oak aged yeti as the perfect Stout.

12oz bottle, served in a pint glass. Batch #7820, packaged 02/07/2007. Pours pitch black with a 2 finger dark brown head. Bubbly. Aromas of coffee, malt, caramel, chocolate. Smells fantastic. Looks fantastic. Hope it tastes as good. Fore is chocolate and roasted coffee beans, back of the tongue is malt, some astringency, and coffee. Finish is all coffee and chocolate, with some nice malt in there. Wow, it does taste as good as it smells and looks! Chewy palate, very easy to drink. The coffee and chocolate notes hang around for quite a while. The kind of beer you cannot wait to take the next sip from. The best beer of the evening by a pretty good margin, and thats a compliment when another 99% overall beer was sampled tonight. I see several 6 packs of this in my very near future. Outstanding. 

Drank this with a package of chocolate fudge Pop Tarts. Hows that for a food and beer pairing?

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2007 Pours pitch black with a mocha head and keeps nice lacing.  It tastes of coffee with the addition of dark chocolate.  The taste gets slightly more bitter as warming starts to set in.  The carbonation is low and keeps a smooth feel on the toungue.  The finish is very powerful and stays with you in the back of your throut.  A very delicious stout.  Makes a great after-dinner drink.

Dense black, thick dark mocha colored head (great lacing).  Nose was deeply rich with notes of medium roasted coffee and toasted dark chocolate, with softer burnt notes and hints of caramel.  Flavor was in perfect balance between the coffee and dark cocoa notes.  Hints of molasses emerge on further warming with just the right amount of burnt roasty tones to round this out.  Medium to full bodied, soft and creamy carbonation, roasty, bittersweet finish.  This is the text book example of what a stout should be.  For the style, it doesnt get better then this...

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2007 12oz bottle.  Pours semi dark black with a small brown head.  Aroma of roasted malts and sweet chocolate.  Wonderful malt taste with some chocolate bitterness at the finish. As it gets warmer the chocolate becomes more pronounced and sweeter.  Nice mouthfeel.  A model stout.
Coffee aroma with a foamy chocolatly head. Tastes of chocolate with a bitter after taste and long lasting finish. I liked this beer but its lacking somewhat in the taste.

Black appearance with a dark tan head. Aroma is of roasted coffee. Taste is roasted coffee, fairly bitter up front with an almost creamy finish. Extremely drinkable, I wish I could find get this more often.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2011 It would seem perverse to call this a session stout. But if I did, it would only be because I want to drink it so bloody often. This beer exemplifies that rarest of balances between seriously deep complexity and quaffability. Its big, its roasty, its chocolatey, but somehow its also smooth and subtle. I dunno, this one just rocks and Im so glad I can get it regularly now.

12oz bottle. Pours jet black with a small tan head that settles to a thin ring with minimal lacing. Aroma is loaded with roasted malt, caramel, and licorice. Taste is full of roasted malt but not harsh with a licorice aftertaste. Good clean bitterness with no roasted malt harshness. Full mouthfeel at first but finishes dry. A great stout.

My fellow Americans dont understand stout.  They seem to think its alright for stouts to have the texture of Cool-Whip and the flavor of a newsprint.  Its enough to bring one to his knees in despair.  Ive come close to climbing atop a soapbox downtown and proselytizing about the need to understand a stouts yearnings.  Looked at from a distance, you would see how the skyscrapers parallel my body framing me in concrete loneliness.
And just when I thought I couldnt go on, just when I thought that I was the only one in the entire world that cared, I found this, Kalamazoo Stout.  It made me believe in America again.  This tastes remarkably like stout.  It has body, it has flavor, it has a purpose and a sense of being.  Thank you Bells.  Thank you.

Pours totally black with brown head and thick cobweb lacing clinging behind on the glass. The aroma is solid with highly roasted to outright burnt malts and behind that is a hint of sweeter malts. The mouth feel is full for a stout and refreshing in the beginning and thins out in the end. The taste starts with burnt and roasted malts and carries it through to the aftertaste. There are moments when the malts seem charred but not chalky or sooty at all. The flavor is helped a lot by drinking it at roughly 65F. Really nice brew.

bottle: pours near pitch black, no light coming thru, eith a small tan head. aroma is aroma is very sweet and roasted with a hint of smoke in it. definitley some aroma of licorice.  flavour is full and very well balanced with raosted coffee and chocolate and molasses finish smooth as can be a great mix of sweetness and bitterness in this one. i am being very impressed by bells and how they perfectly balance beers for your palate.

Pours a nearly opaque garnet with a tight, rocky mocha-colored head.  Aroma is roasty, smoky and sweet.  Flavor is bold and assertive, like a strong roasted coffee with copious amounts of chocolate and molasses.  The finish is sticky sweet and hoppy.  A nicely-made stout.
pours pitch black with a tan head. Aroma of anise, chocolate, roasted malts. Very roasted almost smokey palate with nice spicey flavors. Another great specimen from bells

The guy on my bottle looks different than one here in photo?

Anyway, a very solid stout. The head was explosive and mostly lasting. Lacing was very good. Color is very black. After pour, I held my glass to the light...and I saw nothing but black! The taste is of roasted malts, chocolate, and coffee. However, the tastes seem very mild compared to other stouts. The Beer is creamy and smooth, leaving a very mild sweet chocolate aftertaste. Bitterness is mild. I could not smell anything though. Maybe my nose is stopped up or something. I will have to buy another bottle and re-rate....should raise the score a little
This is what made a great stout. It s dark roasted was truly a sight to behold. the malts display the toasted, mild coffee very bitter stout. A real winner.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2007 Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a pint glass, dark with a chocolate malt head. The aroma is pronounced and of coffee and roasted malt. The taste is coffee and cream, sweet chocolate and roasted malts. There is a touch of bitterness as it warms. This one is similiar to the Expedition Stout, but a bit more chocolatley and a bit less bitter. A wonderful effort in both cases.

Pours a nice dark black with a decent dark tan head.  Nice burtn chocolate nose with hints of dark fruit and tofee.  Nice coffee flavor, with hints chocolate, and smoked meats.  Nothing needs to be said about this beer because everyone knows it rocks.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text:
This beer pours an iny black color letting no light shine through. It comes equipt with a thin brown head. The head fades a little too fast, leaving a decent lacing.

This beer has a roasted barley aroma. It smells malty sweet with hints of caramel. It has an ever so slight chocolate aroma. Some dark fruit is also present in the aroma. Mostly figs and raisins.

This beer tastes exactly like it smells. A nice robust roasted malt flavor. It has a nice sweet flavor also. Some caramel maltyness. A little bittersweet chocolate mix in also. Figs make a slight appearence in the flavor as well.

This beer goes down very smooth. It leaves a sweet and roasted malt aftertaste. Low carbonation. It is a little thinner than I would expect.

I think this beer would make a good session beer. It is mild enough to not become overbearing. Also, it is not too high in alcohol, so putting down a few is possible.

Overall: Thanks go out to HimerMan for this fine brew. You truely are great for hooking me up with a fine Bells stash. Great beer.
Very yummy stout.  Very good body, smooth .  Has a nice hint of chocolate in its aftertaste which follows i nice coffeeish flavor.
Almost black appearance.  Dark tan head just beautiful.  Chocolate, coffe and licorice flavors combine for a very drinkable stout.  Heres to ya!

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2008 bottle. poured almost jet black with a very nice caramel coloored head. wonderful roasted coffee aroma with a touch of malt and chocolate. the coffee flavor stood out the most at first but as it sat more ,roasted  malt and bitter sweet dark chocolate came out. as the glass grew more empty my only thought was on having another. absolute delight. one of the most consistent and enjoyable stouts.
Thick smokey smell with molasses and roasted coffee. Huge roasted coffee tastes, finishes with smoke, burnt grain. Great consitency.

Oh boy, this is nice. Pours super black, easily as dark as any good imperial stout, with a thick bubbly brown head atop. Aroma is a roasty masterwork, loads of chocolate come through, as well as a bit of molasses and coffee. The flavor is very sweet and coating, tons of powerful chocolate, espresso beans, and a touch of hops. Leaves a feeling like Ive just eaten chocolate covered espresso beans on my teeth.

One of the most drinkable stouts that you can get!!!   I had this beer not too long ago.  Tastes of strong roasted malt with chocolate and coffee undertones.  This is a beer that is just really hard to keep away from your mouth.   Beer pours really thick and smooth.  A must for any beer lover.

Plenty dark for a stout.  Tons of roasted maltiness in the aroma.  More aromas of chocolate and some coffe and caramel.  The flavor follows suit, very much fantastic.  A very soothing mouthfeel, a nice full body.  Take your time enjoying this one.. I mean really take your time.  Another great from Bells.
Looks good, tastes great, smells wonderful.  Thick and rich.  Toasty and malty and easy drinking, like an iced coffee.  A very nice stout.

WtF!!!!!   do i have to move to Michigan?Wow.Slow rising huge, chocolate,pillowy,head.Aromas of espresso beans,roasted grain.Creamy sweet,body has intensified flavors of the aromas.Could almost satisfy and Imperial craving.As it warms dark chocolate flavors arise with a fruitier finish. This is a super duper stout... please beer gods...get it back in Chicago!

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2007 This is one of the nicest looking stouts Ive seen.  The generous lacing, nice tan head and brown body scream out to me, "Drink me...drink me now."  Must...resist...just a bit longer! Smells of chocolate, spices and dark malt.  Okay...no more...must...drink.  The first sip reveals nice spicy/herbal hints.  As the beer warms, chocolate, some hops and a lot of complimentary spicy flavors emerge.  Palate is full and peppery with lots of flavor on the finish.

Bottle thanks to DrBayern! Pours a very dark thick black with a brown head on top. Aroma is full of chocolate, roasted malts, caramel, oatmeal, and coffee notes. The aroma is absolutely fantastic! Flavor is very much like the aroma with chocolate and roasted malts taking dominance in the flavor following with a nice coffee taste. The mouthfeel of the beer is great, making this a very drinkable stout. The flavor profile and palate make this an everyday stout. An excellent stout!

Pours an oily black, with little to no head.  Heavy roast and caramel aromas.  Chocolate is present also.  Get some mocha coffee in there too.  Taste is pretty good, but a little light and short I thought.  You still get that good coffee, roasty, flavor with that patented chocolate taste, but I thought the finish wasnt all that impressive.  Still a very quality stout and quite enjoyable.  The expedition is better in my opinion.

12 oz bottle acquired via trade.  Pours black in color with a medium brown head.  Aroma is roasty, chocolate, and a touch of chalkiness.  Taste is roasty and sweet, caramel, with notes of coffee and bitter chocolate.  Bitter hop and roast finish.  Full bodied with a creamy body.  Really good.

From notes 12Dec2006.

Pours a very dark black, with very little hints of light creeping through the edges. The head is about one finger at the peak, and fades slowly to a soapy cap and ring. Theres a nice webbing of lace.

Smell; lots of roasted malt aromas, with chocolate, coffee and molasses. The coffee gets a bit stronger as this warms, and a bit of currants make an appearance as well. At first I wasnt sure I likes the aroma, but as the beer warms, this one just gets better.

Taste; this actually starts out a bit sweet, despite all of the roasted malt aromas. But then the slightly bitter chocolate and coffee come to balance out then sweetness with a little bit of bitterness. Once again, very nice.

Mouthfeel/Drinkability; Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied, and a bit on the creamy side, with a very smooth and natural feeling carbonation. With the big roasted coffee flavors, this one id very drinkable for me, as I love coffee.

I purchased this bottle while in Michigan, but I can now get this in Council Bluffs, Iowa. As with most of the Bells beers Ive had so far, this is one damn fine brew.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text:
UPDATED: AUG 19, 2008 The aroma is a little grainy, molasses and something roasted. The head was frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing and good lacing. The body is black.  The initial flavor was bitter with a nice long duration. The finish is kinda watery, the body is light to medium and the carbonation is a slight fizzy.
Trying a beer from batch 7785, bottled Jan.2, 2007. The aroma is malty, roasted molasses, coffee. The head is creamy, light brown, good lacing. The body is black. The flavor is smooth, flavors of toffee, coffee and a roastedness. Was told this doesn’t age well, I think it aged very well.
UPDATED: MAY 5, 2007 Bottle.  Aroma of coffee and chocolate.  Flavor much of the same, with a creamy presence.  Nice dry finish.  A solid stout.

The first beer from Bells to let me down.  Bells has been nothing but quality, but this was very average.  Taste was what you would expect from a stout (malt, roast, coffe little chocalate).  But man was this a dry finish...I mean really dry and just not pleasant.  I really wanted to like this beer, but it just did not happen.  Sorry Bells.

Bottle.  Black opaque pour with minimal to no head.  Aromas of roasted malt and coffee. Flavor also has roasted malts and not as much coffee flavor as aroma.  Very smooth with slight bitter aftertaste.  I couldnt give this a higher score; maybe b/c I have been getting more used to imperial stouts?

Batch 2329. 

Poured that gorgeous dark color that when you look at the beer, makes you feel a bit like a Pavlovian dog, the taste that your mind brings up just thinking about how a dark beer like this should/would/will taste. 

Interestingly flavorful with that nice dry stout bitter finish. Really nice brew all around, worth bringing a sixer home.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2007 Rerate Much more flavorful this time around - similar description overall - thicker mouthfeel. Original 3.7 Minnetonka, Mn - MGM Liquors - 12 oz bottle. Dark brown, cola-like pour with a decently thick mocha colored head. Good coffee aroma, with some back end sweet fruity accents. Flavor has some chocolate notes, good roastiness and some sweet cherries in the back end - trailing bit of licorice and good bitterness throughout. Very dry finish. Solid stout.

Bottle.  An excellent brew.  Bells outdoes themselves in the stout dept. with Expedition and then this.  Been waiting on this beer for quite some time and wait was worth the anticipation.  A very full body for a "regular" stout - almost imperial thickness.  A sweeter stout than I was expecting with a minimal amount of coffee bitterness- which is uncharacteristic.  Very smooth in terms of mouthfeel and finish - very little alcohol presence.  Extremely malty.  Do yourself a favor on this one - my full rec.
this was great.  Very malty and very rich.  Tasted like a stout should.  I will make sure I drink this one again

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2007 A very nice stout with a ton of roasted malt and chocolate flavor.  The caramel malt is very present, resulting in a creamy finish.  Very good.------
I need to rerate this later
good thick beer.  very pleasent aroma.  chocolate sents with a slight coffee smell.

12 oz bottle.  Batch 7785.  Pours pitch black with a half-finger mahogany colored head.  The aroma is of sweet chocolate, roasted coffee and peanuts?  The roasted coffee dominates the taste and is followed by chocolate and malt.  Finish is dry and bitter.

Pours a deep dark black with a beautiful coffee colored head.  The nose is roasted and coffee backed by pleasant sweetness.  The flavor is all about chocolate and dark.  A little down home southern molasses adds to the allure.  Finishes well.  A beautiful beer.
Bottle.  Dark color.  Coffee and chocolate aroma, with a great chocolate flavor as well. Creamy stout, with a great body.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2009 Poured a 3 year old bottle of this into a pint glass. Very dark appearance with a small brown head that laces nicely. Smells of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate mainly. Palate is creamy and thick, and the taste is quite the same as the aroma, with caramel and licorice added. Taste lingers nicely and is very pleasant. Pretty complex tasting stout, yet very easy to drink.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2017 ReRate: Bottle poured into a globe glass. Black color with a thick tan head that leaves some nice lacing. Aroma is caramel, roasted coffee & espresso beans, and dark chocolate. Initial taste is roasted malt, coffee, licorice. Aftertaste is lightly bitter and just a little earthy. Palate is just a tiny bit light but carbonation is on point. Still great stuff!

Bottle from Hy-Vee poured into english pint - Pours straight up black with a 1 finger brown head; Lots of roast and coffee with notes of caramel, black licorice, and chocolate to the nose; A great coffee presence with some roasted barley and a small hint of caramel sweetness on the initial taste; A dry and pleasantly bitter roasted aftertaste; Fairly full and creamy body; Pleasant carbonation; Could do with a little licorice in the taste. Maybe just me? Thank GOD we?ve gotten some of the better Bell?s products around here finally. A great stout that I?ll be buying more of for sure.

The aroma was roasty and toasty with a strong espresso coffee presence, chocolate and caramel. As it warmed some grassy notes emerged. Black with a rocky brownish head which lasted for days. The flavor was rich and smooth with chocolate, espresso coffee, caramel and some licorice character. A bit of grassy hop flavor was notable and a decent level of bittering to keep the malty flavors in check. The finish was dry and the body was full with a creamy character on the palate. A great stout. 12 ounce bottle.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: From the bottle, courtesy of MrBendo, pours black like oil with a thick, foamy off-white head that leaves a nice lacing.  Smells quite chocolate-ey with some mocha coffee beans as well.  Tastes very much the same--chocolate and coffee dominate a very rich flavor.  Also, I swear I can chew the head.  Smooth but not quite silky on the palate, with the mildest of bitter aftertaste.  Great stout.  Thanks Todd.
Very dark pour, thick and clingy to the sides of the glass.  Roasty, slightly bitter taste at the end with the maltiness up front.  Pretty heavy drink, great for slowing down and enjoying.

Darkest of brown, nearly black with a low brown head that had large bubbles.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, molasses.  Flavor was similar but with added bitterness and a touch of licorice.  Palate was creamy and somewhat syrupy (not too much).  The finish is also smooth and creamy, ending with a tang of bitterness.
12oz bottle @ Coles Buffalo NY. Great stout pours black & delicious. Full bodied, chocolately, smooth malt flavor. Easy drinking. Very enjoyable. Bells, please come to Buffalo.
This stout pours dark and relatively thick.  Not too strong and not too weak.  Very flavorful with coffee and chocolate standing out.  Best served a bit on the cold side.  I like this stuff!

Aroma of dark coffee with a slight hint of chocolates.  Small brown foam head, dissapaited quickly.  Flavor is of dark burnt chocolate coffees.  Simply delicious.  My first Bells beer, very impressed.  Easy to enjoy and sessionable.  Would love to try a tap version.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours a thick black with no head really.  Smells of toffee and caramel at first then licorice follows strongly.  The flavor is of a roasted licorice then as it warms you can taste more coffee.  I dont like licorice, so leaving that in my mouth afterwards wasnt pleasant.

Great beer when you want something not too heavy, but something very good.  Nice roasty aroma, some licorice and caramel.  Flavor is complex, well balanced, some caramel, roastiness, no complaints.  Medium to full bodied.  Nice almost flawless beer.  Definitely worth buying.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2007 22 oz draught at the Winking Lizard Tavern (Crosswoods) in Columbus, Ohio on 1/23/2007...  Bells Kalamazoo Stout is pitch black and has an extremely dense and creamy mocha-colored head.  The head pretty much never disappears and leaves dense lacing on the glass from top to bottom.  The aroma is mocha with a hint of roastiness.  The flavor is roasted malt, cocoa, and some mocha latte.  The finish is roasty and dry with some black coffee-like bitterness.  This stout is full-bodied with a very creamy texture.  Overall this beer is rich, flavorful, well balanced, and an all around great stout.  In my opinion, the draught version is better than the bottled version (at least newer, non-vintage bottles)...  Rating:  8  5  8  4  18 = 4.3.

4/02/2007:  I had a pint of this on draught at Fries Cafe (Cincinnati, Ohio) during the Bells Oberon Release Party...  Bells Kalamazoo Stout (draught) is rich and nutty with hints of chocolate and coffee.  It is really good, but not nearly as good or complex as the bottle version.  It also seems to be a bit more thin on draught than in the bottle.  I enjoyed trying this on draught, but prefer the complexity and depth of aromas and flavors of the bottled version...

12 oz. bottle. Aroma of mocha, roasted almonds, brown sugar, and a touch of hops. Pours a dark brunette with an amber hue and a small to moderate amount of sable head. The dominant flavor is coffee, and it is overly strong. There is also a slight lemon tartness, apparently from the hops. I do taste the licorice but probably only because the bottle told me it was there. The flavors are not particularly complex. Not as much aftertaste as I expected. Medium-bodied and lively in the palate. The beer becomes bland as it warms. I recommend drinking it relatively cold. Considering how highly rated this beer is, it stands as a disappointment. Frankly, I probably was generous in the rating. I easily could have rated this as low as a 3.3. Its not bad, but Ive certainly tasted better traditional stouts.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2007 12 oz., batch 7289, courtesy of GrbDg (thanks!).  Poured pitch black with some thin tan head.  Aroma is of coffee and nuts, but not in that brown ale way.  The taste brings the same flavors plus some chocolate and I thought I may have caught some licorice in there.  I love the malty front followed by the coffee and bitter chocolate finish.  Just the right amount of lingering for me.  I really enjoyed the nuttiness this one had.  While some people think the mouthfeel was too watery, I think its just fine.  This isnt supposed to be an impy.  Too bad this was the only bottle I got.  My first Bells experience and boy was it lovely.

12 oz Bottle - Pours a beautiful deep black with a tiny bubble brown head... Aroma is lots of burnt grains and coffee.. almost like chocolate chip cookies... Wonderful flavor.. lots of black coffee with some sweet hints in there... this is an AWSOME stout.. im in love.. i want to move to Kalamazoo

Bottle:  Pours dark and lovely.  The aroma is almost overpowering earthy at first (almost of mold) but quickly dissipates to more balanced levels.  The beer remains a constant blend of hops character and dry malt finish. I didnt get overwhelmed with licorice but noticed just a slight bite from it. I enjoyed this all the way through.
12oz Bottle pours out a pitch black topped with a nice tan head. Great aroma and tast of black coffee and roast. I also pick up a little smoke. Thanks to Buckybeer for this one.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2007 I have high hopes for this beer, Kalamazoo. First it is a stout which makes me think it will be bitter and secondly it is from bells.  They really make some interesting beers.  Dude on the front of this brown 12 oz  bottle is watching me thru his biker shades and he dont look too happy!  I am always apprehensive about rating beers that come so highly recommended. Odd, musty, non fruity, tennis shoe dish-soap aroma when you pop the top. You know, like the smell of a paper fire that was put out prematurely with water?  You would never expect the color from the aroma, very dark, possibly opaque in my steeler stein.  Slight creamy darkish tan head.  Flavor impact is that of good black coffee, roasted wood and something else malty, chocolately or something.  Fairly smooth and viscous. A bitterness hits the back of your throat but I think the complexity of the mixed flavors washes it away, for the most part. Very interesting though it is tuff to stop thinking of the harshness.  The taste is now beer that has been poured over burnt wood.  This is almost as sweet as sam adams cream stout. These stouts do have a lingering bittersweet finish that hangs on for a few moments or two. Much better than the offensive bells expedition.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: First of all, I couldnt stop sniffinh this beer! Could easily become habit forming. I guess I just love their malting. Then, sweet jesus, came the taste. Perfect stout. Chocolate and coffee from here to the horizon. Wait, I have to calm down... and open my other bottle.

Pours black and thick with nice thin milky brown head.  Great chocolately mocha flavor with nice palate.  Finishes great with a nice lingering after taste.  My first Stout and I am hooked, too bad I cant get it in my area.

Great aroma (find out for yourself). Pours a beautiful and not-too-creamy head. Just right. This stout is deep black indeed, which is, initially, misleading (I usually think "thick, creamy, heaviness with dark dark stouts). This stout is beautiful in every way, but not overbearing and heavy. They go down surprisingly quick, not just because of the delicious combination of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate (in that order), but because the lack of a bitter/heavy finish. Instead you receive a crisp and surprisingly lingering and winning combination of dark chocolate, light spice and coffee. Just an all-around winner and one of the best stouts anyone can ever have the pleasure of tasting. Im hooked.
12 oz bottle. Pours dark brown almost black with dark brown head. Aroma of sweet malt and coffee. Taste of malt, coffee and chocolate.

Pours dark brown to black with a thin creamy head. Aroma is mild; roasted malt and anise. Thick in the mouth with mild carbonation. Flavor reflects the roasting of the grains, though not as bitter as Id expected. Persistant flavor lasts for a while after the beer is gone...this is a good thing.

Pours a dark blackish color, with better than two inches of rocky-textured brown foam. Decent lacing. Sweet dark and roasted malt in the aroma.

The flavor is very full - with deep roasted malt, strong coffee, and some oak tannin. Together, they combine in a thick oily mouthfeel, and finish with a bitter roast and slight whiskey flavor.

Full bodied, moderate carbonation

This might be the darkest beer I have ever seen.  It also has a small and unusually dark head that lasts a minute or two.  Aroma is malty and roast.  Flavor is delightful.  Everything you love about a stout is here.  Plenty of roasted malt, coffee, caramel, chocolate, dark fruit, etc.  This is truly a premium beer and it cant get much better!

12 oz bottle, courtesy of StompBrockmore - pours oily black, like crude in a glass, with a nice sized mocha head that soon settles to a thin surface layer.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, tar, some alcohol, and a very nice and unexpected yeastiness.  That bready quality is a perfect counterpart to robust flavours of caramel, dark roasted malt, and coffee.  Dry, roasty, chocolatey finish is superb.  A hugely complex and delicious stout.  Very, very nice.

Pitch black appearance with a small tan head.  Aroma of coffee and licorice melt together along with some chocolate.  The palate lingers in your mouth for a while an then immediately goes into your throat.  There is various fruits involved in the  flavor like plum and raisin along a roasted bubbly flavor of hickory?  A little thin for a stout, but has a unique character I love.

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2007 Appearance is dark chocolate with a light almond colored head.  Has an aroma of roasted coffee.  Taste has a tinge of yeast and a hint of chocolate, but roasted flavor dominates.  A very dry but steady finish and suprisingly light.  This is a great stout for the price, but a little dry for my tastes.
Good amount of chocolate in the aroma.Pours dark with a medium head.Lots of coffee and chocolate in the flavor.Full mouthfeel with a big chocolate finish.
A full-flavored, solid stout. Excellent head and appearance with, of course, a deep black coloring. A strong, roasted quality that stays long enough to savor and enjoy.

Looks like a stout, tastes like a stout but doesnt quite smell like a stout.  Taste is big on the roasted malt flavors.  Some bittersweet chocolate hiding in there too.  Very smooth drink.  Slightly sweet but not overpowering.  The roasted flavors last for a while after you are done with this one.  Good, well balanced, stout.

Pours a dark dark brown almost black with foamy tan head and alot of lacing, pretty good coverage around the glass. Aroma is very light, a sweet nutty aroma with hints of chocolate. Feels pretty thick in your mouth but not filling in your stomach. Dark chocolate flavor, creamy, coffee and molassas. Finishes with a nice solid bitter, not lasting.

Color was a deep black; a creamy light brown head.  Aroma of molasses, coffee, and roasted malt undertones.  Aroma is much of the same; medium bodied.  Fairly straight forward, would have liked more complexity.  Good beer to have on hand.

The color was a deep black.  The head was fizzy and medium brown.  The aroma was roasty, coffee, and malasses.  The flavor was roasted, bitter, and waxy.  The palate was little carbonation and the finish was warm and a little bitter.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2007 Trade with brewblackhole. The color is a very deep murky black. The head is thin, creamy, and tan. The flavor is sweet, has hints of light citrus, and has a slight burnt popcorn taste. Lacks the complexity I expected but delivers all the same. The palate is crisp and burnt with small carbonation. The finish is warming with aparent roast.

12 oz bottle courtesy of turdferguson (the brother-in-law). Pours a very dark brown-black with a slight reddish hue. Light brown head with nice lacing. Aroma is chocolate and coffee with a little fruitiness.  Lots of chocolate and coffee flavor with some hints of cherry.  Nice hop bitterness for balance.  Great brew!

Pours an opaque black color with a dark brown head that quickly dissipates.  Burnt/roast and cocoa aromas dominate.  The carbonation is not apparent on the palate, and the mouthfeel is medium-bodied.  Taste is smooth throughout - roasted flavors are assertive in the finish and there is a little sweet/spice turn in the finish that may be the brewers licorice.  For a straight-up stout, this is an excellent beer and if it comes to FL, itll be a constant presence in the fridge.

bottle. pours black with a thin tan head that disappears quickly, leaving only a slight ring around the edge. smells sweet, malty and chocolaty. excellent creamy taste with little carbonation. hints of chocolate and coffee perfectly blended with only a hint of bitterness at the very end. overall, an awesome beer.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2009 Bottle, Batch 8874, pours black into the glass and gave me a medium sized dark tan bubbled head, some sediment in the bottle, aromas of dark roasted malt, dry dark chocolate, dark brown sugar, burnt sugar and caramel, has hints of smoke and/or burnt malt, and nut fragrances in the background, this stout has lots of dark roasted malt flavor with a decent hop and malt roast bitterness on the palate, some dark bitter chocolate and licorice in the background, has a hint of dark caramel and chocolate sweetness, has a pronounced dry finish with some bitterness, nice mouth feel, this is a full roasted flavored stout that is pretty dry on the tongue and has little sweetness, I prefer stouts with a little more sweetness in the flavor, if you like big flavored dry stouts you will love this.
Pours pretty much black with a small tan head. Aroma of raw smokey malts and a hint of chocolate. Flavor is light smokey malts, some roasted nutty coffee effects also with a slight bitter finish.

Pours a five finger brown head that fades to a thin layer leaving a good lace.  Black color.  Light-medium carbonation and heavy bodied.   Chocolate nose.  Starts with a roasted/burnt chocolate flavor, some sweetness, nice stout. $1.89 for a 12oz bottle from Chalet Party Goshen, In.
Black. Tasted dirty, almost rusty. Only a slight chocolate tinge to it and bad chocolate at that. Christmas present.

Poures black with a thin, deep tan head.  Aroma is classic Bells.  Roasted malts, chocolate, dark fruit, coffee, molasses, yeast, and hops.  Mouth is thick and creamy with little carbonation.   Flavor is delicious.  Rich roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, molasses, with a lightly sweet background.  Finishes with a little bitterness. This is one great beer, definitly wish I had tried this one a long time ago, I can only imagine what some cellaring would do to it.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2007 Pour is total blackness with a thin deep tan head.  Nose is a lot of chocolate covered cherries and some coffee.  Mouthfeel is smooth.  Carbonation is a little more active than the slight head lets on.  Great coffee and chocolate flavor.  Slightly bitter finish, but in a good way.  This is a great beer.
Thick, chocolately aroma with molasses and malt.  Extremely dark brown body, quite opaque, with a tan head.  Roasty malty flavour, burnt toast with drizzles of caramel.
Dark black body with a medium light brown body.  Rich roasted aroma, some chocolate and light coffee. Sweet roasted malt, light coffee, and a light bitter edge.
Pours a deep black with a tan head.  Sweet aroma.  Taste is a bold bitter surface with sweet pure water center.  Not for beginners but heaven for stout lovers.  Highly recommended.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2007 12oz. bottle - pours absolutely black, unless held up to a light where tiny little red flecks become visible. Floaty yeast in the glass, settling to a thin layer on the bottom. Medium mocha head on top. Aroma is roasty malt, full of light coffee, chocolate, but most significantly it is very yeasty and bready. Smells almost like a baked dessert, reminiscent of some Belgians. Pretty damned awesome. The flavour is slightly hoppy, but mostly its full of chocolately, roasty malt, with much of the same doughy character found in the aroma. Lightly sweet with a mildly bitter finish. Extremely complex and extremely delicious. Probably the best stout Ive ever had. This brewery is killing me - Im moving to Kalamazoo, MI. See ya.

Batch 7571. Beer is very dark brown, almost opaque. Head is initially large, beige, frothy, mostly diminishing.

The aroma is soft, dessert-like alluring. Malty with mellow moderate roasted grain, sweet milk chocolate, light café au lait and toasted bread crust; Hoppy with a light note of resin/pine; Yeasty with a light-to-moderate note of dough; Miscellaneous moderate note of vanilla, trace of cola.

The flavor is moderately sweet, lightly bitter with a long, building, moderately-to-heavily bitter, lightly acidic finish.

The body is full, texture is velvety and the carbonation is lively.

Smooth, soft, plush and creamy.

Bottles. This was a delicious full bodied sweet stout!  Beautiful black pour with dark tan head emitted a sweet roast malt & chocolate aroma.  Mouthfeel was smooth and silky.  Splendid sweet carmel, malt and creamy bitter chocolate were the flavors savored. Nice quick dry bitter chocolate and malt aftertaste.  This would make a perfect dessert beer.  It wasnt really rich. It was just a really nice sweet bitter stout.  I really enjoed it and would drink it again.
Dark color with a rocky brown head.  Rich malty flavor that is strong but by no means overwhelming.  Excellent after taste and smooth.

Bottle out of six pack, pours amazing dark colour. Beautiful tan head. Smooth and tasty to the finish with a huge array of flavours almost too many to taste. Also a very pleasant aroma. Im happy my home town has such a wonderful beer named after it.

Small, irregular tan head over nearly black opaque-brown beer. Definite smell of blueberries (the European kind), also something like brined olives; as well as coffee, but that less than expected. Again short fruity-blueberries, but the sharp roasted flavours of black coffee & tobacco come on with a vengeance. I still do get something salty, further nourishing grains, dark malts, restrained bitterness and very good balance. Very well bodied, slickness, but without becoming viscous. Excellent stout, certainly considering its relatively low ABV.

Oily oily oily oily black color. Tan head. Good lacing. The aroma causes me to take notice. This will not be a typical stout. Wonderful rich coffee aroma. Flavor does indeed hint at molasses but is more dominated by the roasty malt flavors. Hint of chocolate at the finish. What makes this so wonderful is just how strong all these flavors are. A stout with the ability to dominate your palate for the rest of the night.

Pours a dark brown/black color, with a small dark creamy head. Smell is heavy malty, sweet, and very roasty. Sweet taste of molasses and heavy sugars. The flavor is dark, sweet, and warm chocolate. Coffee is evident. Very full palate and strong tasting beer all the while very smooth.

Bottle. Pour is jet black with a thick tan head with beautiful lacing--i am really enjoying just tilting my snifter up and down and looking at the beautiful lacing. This is just as pretty as a guiness but has so much more going on in the flavor department.  Roasty, toasty and licorice nose with flavors of molasses, chocolate, and light coffee.  Thick creamy palate. Oustanding full body and balance. A very drinkable and flavorful stout. Welcome to NC, Bells!
UPDATED: DEC 18, 2006 a great tasty stout.  chocolatey body with roasty aroma, its creamy, rich, and very drinkable.

One of the best stouts out there and for the value one of the best beers available in our area.  I enjoyed the silky, black pour with the brown head.  I also enjoyed the roasted malt flavor.  Pretty full bodied and I would put it just a notch below the outstanding imperial stouts such as Storm King, Siberian Night, and Old Rasputin.

This is a very nice stout. Rich, deep brown body, and an attractive, light brown head (too bad it didnt last longer). Very nice lacing, though. Dark chocolate and espresso aroma, with a flavor profile to match. Pleasant, bitter aftertaste. Better carbonation than others of this style. When youre in the mood for a stout, dont hesitate to ask for this one.

12 oz. bottle from a 6 pack bought at liquor barn.  Pours black and silky, with a very little to no head at all.  Aroma is all roasted malt with a slight hint of chocalte.  Taste is malty but smooth with a strong roasty aftertaste. Very good.

Bottle from Santa. Dark brown with no head. Good roasted flavors and aroma. Smooth on the palate.Some hops but not much, bitter finish. I think I should try this beer again as I had Bells Java stout right before I had this one.

Pours a very dark brown almost black with a nice pillowy brown head that dissapates mostly.  Aroma of chocolate, roastiness, and a little coffee and caramel with a touch of hops in there as well.  Taste is about the same.  Mouthfeel was a bit thin but not bad.
Another solid beer from bells.

Pours muddy black with an average sized brown rocky head. Aroma is malty: roasted malts, and dark chocolate, lightly hoppy of flowers.  Flavor is moderatly sewwt and lightly bitter, finishes lightly sweet and lightly bitter.  Medium to full bodied, creamy, softly carbonated.  Clean finish perfectly carbonated, excelent.

Bottle, pours medium thick, dark black with a deep tan head that thins out and lightens up; good lacing.  Aroma of sweeter roasted malts, licorice and molasses.  Flavor of roasted malt, espresso, molasses (for a touch of sweetness) and some chocolate.  Smooth taste with a bit of lingering malt/espresso flavor.  An excellent roasty stout; highly recommended.
I actually liked it better the Expedition Stout. Smoother and just as flavorful. Overall a fantastic beer.

Bottle.   Pours ultra dark with small tan head, with nice lacing.   Aroma is deep dark chocolate, roasted coffee, burnt caramel.   Taste is the same, dark chocolate, roasted coffee, burnt caramel, with some sweetness poking through.   Thick creamy palate.    Great all the way round!   This is my standard for the style.
Very dark and still beer with not much head.  Very smooth and full bodied flavor.  Creamy and delicious.

Pours a very dark brown with a nice smallish tan head, nice lacing. Strong chocolate and some coffee, strong roastiness. Thick palate, full mouth feel. A little sweetness, quite a bite at the end. Not quite my style.

12 oz bottle. Opaque black color with a tight light brown head that showed some lastinf power and laced the glass. Smells ofrich chocolate cake and vanilla cream. Slightly sweet on the tongue with a lasting roasty bitterness. Creamy, full bodied mouth feel with dark chocolate, molasses, vanilla, and coffee flavors. Yum.

One of the best stouts Ive ever tasted! This is a beer for the holiday season! I you like your beer dark, you are doing an injustice to not try this. Thick and rich like coffee with not enough water. Chocolate, roasted malt, cofee, you name it its there! Gimme more!
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours a dark black color with a brown head.  Aroma is of molasses, chocolate, roasted malt, and coffee.  Flavor starts off with the molasses, chocolate, roasted malts, and coffee.  Gives way to the hops and slight alcohol warming.  Flavor lingers awhile.  Another very delicious Bells brew.

bottle.  midnight black pour with tan head.  fresh aroma of chocolate and sour malts.  very refreshing.   chocolate, roasted malts, touch of coffee and sugar.  a bit floral.  quality stout from start to finish
On tap @ Mad Mex: Black with a medium dark tan head. Aroma of roasted coffee, and some chocolate. Flavor, coffee, a fruity sweetness, some chocolate, a bittersweet finish. Really nice of draft.

(Tap at Hop Devil) Black body, medium tan head with good retention and excellent lacing.  Aroma of toasts and roasted coffee beans.  Really nice body full of creamy malts, like I was drinking a cake.  Some liquorice/molasses/raisins add to the complexity.  An enchanting stout that sounds like a spell from a Harry Potter book.

Batch 7532, in a trade with Hellomynameis - thanks Zac. Massive brown frothy head, opaque black pour, decent lace. Roasted coffee aroma. Smooth, full body for a very nice mouthfeel. Rich dark roast coffee flavor with hints of dark chocolateunctuated by  peppery spice and some citrus zest. Nice dry finish. Very satisfying.

12 oz bottle.  Pours black, perhaps not the darkest black ive seen a stout, but definitely dark.  Very strong aroma of roast, coffee, bitterness, I could smell it from several feet away.  Dark malty flavor, chocolate is present.  Very good.

Strong complex aroma of coffee and roast, color is pitch opaque black with brown head.  Pours a huge head which leaves good lacing.  Bitter chocolate flavor, slightly sweet too.  Great aftertaste, wonderful for sipping.  Palate is somewhat less than the "creamy" descriptor.  A great beer, definitely need to load up on these!
Dark brown appearance. Stong falvors of coffee,  a little bitter, but in a good way,  roasted toasty notes as well.  chocolate and mollassas flavors in aftertaste.
Great color, great aroma, great taste.....a very good stout. Im going to be driving to Michigan for this one, now that Bells is no longer distributed here in Illinois.

12-ounce brown bottle. Opaque very dark brown color with a thick dark lasting tan head and lace. Incredibly rich chocolatey aroma. Medium-bodied with a very full mouthfeel. Creamy. Dark malt dominate the flavor, especially chocolate, and it finishes slightly dry, more toasted than roasted. Big on flavors but not on alcohol kick. Impressive!
Bottle.  Really, a very good straight forward stout.  Very roasty, with a thin tan head.  A classic stout that I would drink anytime.  Very good.

Now this was some good stuff, split this with ross, Thanks man. Aged almost a full year and awesome. Pours a dark brown almost black with a small dark brown head. Tastes roasted and chocolatey like any good stout should didnt taste the caramel as much but its still great. This brewrey has never dissapointed me.

I usually prefer my stouts either sweet or imperial, but this is incredible. Well balanced with the malt up front, loads of flavors here, and while the body is light to medium it has a smooth oily feel that reminds me of Siberian Night. Really, its pretty comparable to SN in terms of quality. Reasonably priced, too.

Bottle. Poured a good, thick brown with a hue of black. Good, dense, solid head that left a little lacing. Aromas of tar, pine, raisin, almond, molasses. Taste is very smooth with a hint of allspice that comes out on top. Very nice stout.

A session Stout if there ever was any.  Creamy head that produces a nice lacing.  Complex malt aroma focusing on a nice roasted flavour.  Nicely balanced hop character that dances on your tongue after the first sip has passed.  Very representative of the style for those new to the stout arena and are not quite ready for the immenseness that is the Expedition.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2007 Bottle. Good aroma of roasted malt and chocolate with a nice head to it sitting on a midnight black body. Very nice flavor. Slightly bitter with a touch of sweetness to it. Really smooth and well balanced. Very enjoyable. My go to stout.

Bells Kalamazoo Stout
12 oz bottle
Packaged 03/06, partaken 10/06
Medium pour in an English pint.

Poured black with a rocky mostly lasting light brown head with excellent lacing.

Smelt of moderate mild chocolate, dry nuttiness, mild coffee.

Flavor was upfront strong coffee bitterness with light sweet creamy chocolate tones, followed by a strong nutty coffee bitterness with light chocolate accents, on a long bittersweet molasses finish.  Mouthfeel was medium to full bodied, creamy and silky, with soft carbonation and slight astringency.

Overall, a very comfortable easy drinking, flowing, tasty stout, that could use some work on the aroma.
Pours dark with coffee aroma. Smooth cream and chocolate flavor with clean finish. Some molasses flavoring as well. A nice stout.

Bottle split with after4ever. Pours an opaque blackish brown with a light brown head. Aromas of coffee and chocolate. Creamy medium body with light carbonation. Taste brings the coffee and chocolate forward and adds a bit of malty molasses.Dry coffee and burnt toast finish with just a shade of pine.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2006 I would consider this more of a porter than a stout. It has a smoky aroma and a thik smoky nutty taste. It is a good beer, but is definitely on the lighter side of stouts, similar to an Obsidian. A good beer, but Ill take the Expedition over this anytime.

Pours deep and dark, with minimal tan head. Aroma is faint but sweet, with chocolate and roasty malt notes. The flavor has plenty of malty chocolate and coffee. Well-balanced with slight bitterness at the end. Nice smooth, creamy palate. Overall, a great example of a stout.
Pours black with slight tan head.  Very thick and dry.  Very malty and smooth.  Not as good as I thought it was going to be, but still okay.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2006 so far with all the beers i have drank but i have not rated them all this is one of the best beers i have ever drank. has a bout 2 finger head and very creamy i would drink this every day.

Bottle.  Wow, the aroma is sweet and inviting.  Chocolate, caramel and coffee...the color is almost black, with a thick tan head.  Medium body, with a woody flavor on top of the flavors in the aroma.  A bit long in the finish.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: 12-oz.; thanks to MTDSHN. Great stuff. Pours thick jet black with a copious and copiously moussy tan head. Nice clean roast nose with plenty of dark fruit and a bit of coffee and chocolate, but nothing excessive. Nicely creamy body, but nothing over the top or chewy. You really have to compare this beer in every way to an RIS, since the flavors are so rich and complex but the drinkability is ratcheted up to plain-ol-stout levels. This is a triumph for Bells without a doubt: big forward roast, raisin, coffee, and chocolate flavors permeate the palate. Its impossible not to like everything about this beer.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2006 Really well balanced beer.  Not too sweet, not too bitter, great flavor.  Could drink many of these in one sitting.  Good roasted malty flavor with slight bitter hoppiness.  Good taste duration, carbonation, mouthfeel.  Creamy but not too thick or syrupy.  Very good stout.
UPDATED: SEP 15, 2008 Bottle.  Pour is near black, with a great tan head.  Nice lacing in the glass.  Sweet and very roasted taste.  Very complex stout, terrific flavor all through the taste.

UPDATED: JUN 21, 2007 Nice dark motor-oil pour with light head.  Sweet, roasty aroma that is not overwhelming, but very inviting.  Taste is sweet, roasty, chocolate, complex, malty.  Wonderful feel - this one dances on the tastebuds.
Yup, its a good stout.  Dark, SMOOTH, slight sweetness, slight bitterness at the end, great aroma, thick...If you compare this to Guinness, ...its just much better.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2007 Wow...simply incredible.  Not sure why I stayed away from this one previously..its been staring at me at the local Kroger for quite some time.  Tried fromt he bottle.  Pours thick and almost black...opaque.  Very thick head that recedes in about 30 seconds to not much.  Chocolate-like smell and taste.  A little sweet and fruity, but not in a bad way.  Very smooth and will be a great winter drink.  Aces on this one...drink up.

12 oz bottle, batch 6485 (7/14/04).  Another old Bells.  My Dad just bought this in MI last month.  Pours a dark oily opaque black with some chunky yeasties.  It has a thick frothy dark brown head that quickly recedes to a thin film that leaves some lacing.

The aroma is sweet lactic chocolate, some roasted bitterness, and some dark fruits.

The flavor is lactic chocolate, roasted coffee bitterness, and some slightly sour dark fruits.  It has a decent bitter finish that balances well with the initial sweet creaminess.  The mouthfeel is medium to full and velvety.

Overall, an excellent stout!  Its up there with Yeti as my favorite.  Even at a year old, this is excellent.  I wish I could get this out in CO...it and Two-Hearted would be regulars in my fridge.

This is one of my favorite beers, so my opinion is biased. I usually drink at least a 6 pack of it a month. Aroma: Quite strong but not overpowering, very malty and hints of coffee as well. Taste: Very rich malt, coffee taste with slight hints of chocolate. Bitter after taste, also a bit heavy in your gut. Little white head that goes away fast. This is a wonderful beer and I recomend it highly.
A classic stout from a classic stout house.  Roastiness, coffee, nice and creamy.  A classic.
UPDATED: JAN 7, 2007 Coffee aroma.  Burnt caramel, very roasted taste.  Very, very  good.  Ive re-rated this because its grown on me over time -- my new favorite stout.

Aroma: exciting. Appearance: was good, but not as creamy as others, with a head that disappears soon.Flavor: definite let-down, not creamy, with too much, unbalanced malt. Palate: good. Overall, short of something great. I was excited about trying this native stout, figuring a smaller brewery tries harder. This higher-alcohol beer is in a different category than a classic Irish Stout. Its more of an Export variety. Definitely NOT a Sweet Stout, either. More complexity is needed.

Bottle.  Appearance: black with a small head.  It smells like a coffee, but less bitter.  The taste is a remarkably clean, roasted flavor at first, but finishes with a bitter burned taste and finished a bit unpleasant.  Maybe I got a bad batch, because I usually love stouts and am rating this much lower than the average.  In all fairness, it traveled a good ways before the tasting.  Nevertheless, I must rate as tasted.  Maybe I can rerate this one someday with better results.
!2 oz bottle....Big coffee, toffeee not too much warmth which is good slight liquorice. Greta roastiness too!

12 oz bottle courtesy of Leopoldstoch.  Finally!  A stout that doesnt try to be anything other than good.  Its not overdone, super thick or rediculously hopped.  Its pretty much perfect.  This is a stout I think I could drink everyday.  So nice and tasty, with lots of roasty chocolate and malt flavors going on.  Bells is an exceptional brewery.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2007 12 oz bottle via RegallacMC (thanks!). Been looking forward to this one. Pours a midnight black with an average size tan head. Aroma has notes of coffee, licorice and toffee. Flavors remind me of the Shastafarian Porter but less complex. Starts out with sweet molasses and chocolate, then some licorice and some roasted espresso. THin to Medium bodied. Silky mouthfeel. A bit too carbonated. Extremely easy to drink and a very good Stout.

This beer is a necessity for any beer lover. It was the first beer that opened my eyes to what beer was really about. Very dark brown head and has a coffee aroma to it with a hint or caramel. Very roasty and nutty after taste. Extremely smooth and rich in flavor. Deffinatly an upper class stout.

Pitch black pour, black as the Expedition some creamy, lacing and a dark brown head. Superb, potent dark chocolate Aroma is bold dark Malt with a wisp of choclate powder and the full Roast of coffee. Even some smoke notes as well.  Tartness in the palate is very nice and full-taste in the medium-heavy body through and through

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2007 Bottle.  Pitch black pour, black as night, completely opaque, with a creamy, lacing, very dark brown head - very pretty.  Superb, potent dark chocolate aroma really took me aback.  Roast, coffee, and even some smoke notes as well.  Wonderfully strong roasty taste, healthy bitterness and rather dark chocolate.  Thick, full, humongous feel - but not sludgy.  Manages to remain smooth and creamy.  Roasted chocolate / coffee beans in the coating finish.  Very dry and very roasty aftertaste.  Its rare to find a beer this explosively flavorful - a superlative brew.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2007 The original light bulb over my head.  Pours to opaque black with a creamy tan head, wafting burning cedar, hazelnut, espresso, dark chocolate.  Immense roasted malt flavor, sweet nuts, coffee, and a lightly bittersweet finish.  This is a wonderfully done example of a nearly easy-drinking stout, neither a sipper nor a session.

This beer pours out of the bottle in a stream the reminds me of used motor oil. Once in the glass, its a glowing black with a dark and murky tan and copper head.

Smells of a great blend of dark, smoky barley, coffee and a creamy nuttiness. The dryness of the burnt elements are delightfully offset by a slight malty sweetness.

The flavor starts with a mild barley, toasted marshmallow and nut foundation that picks up dry elements with the onset of the carbonation. This releases the expected smoky elements and a touch of honey. This beer then finishes off with a smooth coffee and smoke.

The mouth feel is surprisingly glassy and smooth with a micro-bubble carbonation. 

As far as the smokier stouts go, this ones top notch. Its charred, but still smooth and clean with a superb silky mouth feel.

This beer started off pouring a huge head, which eventually died down to a normal amount of lacing.  Aroma was gentle, but had some dark chocolate and....something vaguely whipped and dairy like.  Tough to describe that quality.  The texture of this beer was excellent.  It managed to feel creamy and thick, yet light enough for easy drinking (rather than gradual sipping) if you choose to do so.  Flavors had some additional caramel and toffee notes, along with dark chocolate and milkiness upfront, and the flavors becomes more and more roasty as you swallow.  The bitterness on the throat seems to come from the roasty malts rather than a hop presence (though I assume hops are there?).  Great beer though, perfectly balanced yet easy to drink compared to some of the real big beers out there.  Its tough think of a better regular stout out there.

Poured with a thick head of tight foam that sank around the edge of the glass leaving a pillow in the center.  Dark dark beer.  Looks fantastic.  Coffee and bittersweet chocolate aroma.  Very smooth drinking.  Tastes of chocolate, malt, and slightly burned marshmallows.  It finishes nice...very pleasing.
Pours very dark, with a thin tan head, which quickly decipated.  Chocolatey aroma.  Wow, great taste, very smooth, nice and full body.  Great job once again Bells

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2006 355 ml bottle.  Consumed on 9-1-06 packaged on 6-15 (info available from website actually).  No head, with thin lacing.  Faint aroma.  Very opaqe deep dark amber (no transmittance).  EXCELLENT taste!  No conditioning sting, this is bottle conditioned so ita a REAL ALE.  Bitter at start, malt and chocolate in middle, finish is sweet black licorice.  Medium mouth feel.  Suprising how high the alcohol content is actually.  Somewhat filling.  Excellently crafted beer!

A nice dark brown pour with a slightly foamy lace. An aroma of toasted malt and coffee. A little less coffee flavor than I expected. A nice smooth malty beer that could easily care more alcohol. A nice palate that was almost creamy. A good flavored coffee like bitter finish. A very good beer.

Perfect big black, creamy head.  I dont think it could be any more black.  Great roasted coffee and chocolate.  Nothing atypical with respect to sweet Stouts.  Flavor was perfect.  No bite or alcohol taste.  Very, very smooth.  This got even better as it warmed up. I wish more brewers would brew this type of stout.

12oz bottle (thanks to monger) poured jet black with a nice tan colored head. An aroma of roast, chocolate, hops and slightly toasted coffee. Taste was everything that was in the aroma, smooth with some chocolate, roast and hops. Overall one of the best stouts made.

Bottle.  Poured a dark brown with a ton of mik chocolate colourd head that would leave lacing.  Aroma was rich and chocolatey with a roasted touch.  Tastes incredibley roast with a subtle chocolate malt body before finishing coffee bitter.  Very creamy and smooth in the mouth.

Bottle.  Pours a blacker-than-Darth-Vaders-heart black (well, his heart in "A New Hope," anyway)  Smells like coffee with chocolate and coffee.  Also smells like coffee and hints of coffee, with more coffee.  Flavor is roasted malt with a chocolate finish; coffee throughout.  A coffee film texture rolls along the tongue.  An almost perfect stout.  I will DEFINITELY pick up a sixer (at least) next time Im in Kansas City.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: UPDATED: MAY 1, 2011 Yet another excellent stout from a fine brewer. Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured thick, black and oily with a small dark brown head.  The aroma is dry and roasty with elements of coffee and floral hops. The mouthfeel is thick , somewhat creamy at first and a bit gritty towards the finish. The flavor is strong and sweet with chocolate that fades into bitter coffee that finishes with a lingering floral hop note. The flavors really coat the tongue and linger long after the sip has been swallowed. Very nice.

Dark black in color, MilkChoclatey tan creamy head.  Aroma of robust coffee.  Chocolate, figs, and french roast flavor.  very light palate.  A desirable beer that feels like a porter but looks and tastes like a perfectly made stout.  Figs or dates in the finish.

Big thanks to SpringsLicker for sending this brew to me.  Pure black body with a light volumed tan head.  Aroma of dark chocolate, light anise and some roasted malts.  Nice roasted barley taste, coffee, malts with some light hops and some dark fruit accents.  Ending is sweet with light coffee tones.

Pours a black center with translucent brown edges; tiny head with minimal lacing.  Chocolate, vanilla, and roasted malt aroma.  Huge mouthfeel; tons of dark chocolate, tobacco, roasted quality, with a long bitter-chocolate finish.  An excellent stout.

Thatll hurt come winter.  Pulling out a bottle, found in one of those odd (for a longtime NY/PA/DC resident) Detroit-area liquor stores, the scent coming off the glass is, uh, roasty but in a soy-ish direction.

But golly, thats a tasty beer.  Some of the stouts Ive recently run into have been overly carbonated, but this bottle doesnt seem to be afflicted by it.  I dont know if I could drink this beer in session (and a six pack from which Ill have to dole out at least two bottles doesnt present the opportunity), but Im happy that I dropped $9.60 in an Ann Arbor liquor store (strange beast, that... but this comes from someone who goes to a state store often) for it.
Batch # 7329.  Good Caramel flavors.  Not reall hoppy.  Creamy like texture

This beer is much like the expediton stout but not as strong.  My girlfriend actually preferred this one to the expidition stout.  It has a strong taste of chocolate that only adds to the wondeful taste.  I would suggest this one for any stout fans!

via trade with OhioDad - Pours a dark brown color with a small tan head.  Light spotty lacing.  Sweet coffee, chocolate aroma and flavor.  Has a lingering roasted aftertaste.  Medium to full body.  Good beer.  Thanks Scott.

Dark black pour with a reddish hue to the foamy tan head.  Aroma is light on malt, there is a hint of some fruit, maybe cherries, although they arent listed in the description.   Very full bodied beer, roasted malts dominate the flavor, there are hints of coffee and molasses.  The finish is slow, but clean.  This is s a very good stout.
Poored thick and had a tan coolerd head that faded as i drank the beer. Had a roasted nut taste. A very good beer, but i prefer a smoother taste.

Pours black creamy tan head.  Aroma roasty sweetness.  Flavor creamy sweet roasty-ness with touches chocolate and molasses.  Roasted flavor lasts with touches of hops present.  Exellent stout but what do you expect from Bells.

Dark black appearance with brown head, creamy on top and fizzy on the sides. Diminishes but lasts throughout the beer. Strong roasted flavor with average to long aftertaste. Smooth from beginning to end. My choice over the expedition by Bells.

Pours thick and very dark with a moderate sized dark orange head - quite nice looking. Aroma has deep roasted malt with a molasses style thick sweetness.  There is some char in there as well.  Medium body with  a moderate amount of carbonation.  Malts are way in the front with a ton of roasted flavor.  There is an herbal hint in there that reminds me of sasaphras and anise.  There are some traces of coffee, dark chocolate and cream.  The finish adds some wooden hoppy aspects.  The taste of roast, wood and anise last in the mouth long after the beer is gone.  A solid stout.

Bottle. Pours very dark with a smallish head that is brown. Head disappears failry quickly. Aromas of roasted malts, caramel and dark chocolate. Fairly complex flavors that are dominated by roasted malts and chocolate. there is bit of sweetness but the finish is on the bitter side. This Stout has a medium too light body without being watery, so it is easy to drink. Nice.
Very little head. Toasty, chocolatey and very drinkable. It was gone so quick, I had to have another.

12oz bottle from blue max liquors minneapolis: Quite a stout indeed, full of flavor but not overly aggressive or harsh like stouts can sometimes get.  One of the few easily quaffable stouts I have had.. really great stuff.

Maravillosa cerveza!!!!!! ahhhhhh!!!! Luce perfecta  bella, de color oscuro y corona espumosa, se sienten los sabores de cafe, chocolate y un poquitin de amargos (comome gusta). Que delicia...con esta cerveza quien necesita un postre!!!!! quiero mas!!!!

bottle.  Aroma:  Big roasted malt, wood, caramel, hint of anise, and notes of coffee.  Appearance:  Dark, dark brown.  Very small brown highlights.  Head was medium tan and voluminous.  Some head lingered to the bottom of the glass.  Flavor:  Again the roasted malt flavor dominates.  Getting touches of coffee, molasses, vanilla, and woodiness.  Noticeable smokiness as well.  Not getting much hop flavor, and bitterness seems to be from the roasted malts.  Palate:  Medium bodied and creamy.  Carbonation was good.  Nice dry finish.  A little astringency detected, as well.  Overall:  A good stout.  Robust, rich in flavor, and drinkable.

On the Summer solstice, you get a second beer, a Stout!  Aroma is woody with a touch of aromatic sweetness.  Pours black, so black you cant see through the glass.  Head is a tan brown that suggest really nice lacing.  Choc-o-latey flavor with a slight bitter ending, and a syrupy mouth feel.  Taste becomes more bittery as the glass drains away, yet remains bold all the way down.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2007 Bells Kalamazoo stout is very nice. Pours a nice black color with a medium sized head. The aroma is nice, bittersweet chocolate and some caramel. The taste is smooth and full. It has a very thick mouthfeel, and the taste matches that. The flavors are of coffee and bittersweet chocolates.

pours black with aromas of roasted malts, coffee, and chocolate.  some lacing and a medium body.  flavors cover the tounge of malt, coffee, chocolate, carmel, and black licorice.  very nicely carbonated much more than a typical stout.  bells makes an impressive brew.
Picture perfect stout... pitch black with a nice tan head.  Very chocolatey aroma and taste.  Goes down smooth but a bit watery.

In Panama, brought down from Cleveland. I paid 1.69 for the bottle.  An amazing beer. Ive only had one stout that I thought was better. Poured incredibly dark with a huge creamy head, the flavors were a medley of chocolate coffee, a slight taste of bitter and a bunch of other flavors wonderfully mixed.
