A couple of times it seemed a slight bit watery, but the complexity certainly over compensated for that. I wish I had more...I checked my rating for the Jasper stout, this was in fact equally good, if not better...the difference was in the creamy head, but that was likely manipulated by tap vs. bottle. I am going to go ahead and give this one a 4.5!!!!!!! We have a winner!!!!

(Bottle via trade with BBB63, thanks Mike!) Pours very very dark brown, nearly black. Nearly opaque but for some light at very edges. About 1" of soft tan head that recedes to about 1/4". Great aroma of rich roasted molasses, coffee, caramel and chocolate. Mouthfeel smooth, full yet slight wateriness. Sloppy, webby lacing. Flavor is rich and roasty, molasses dominates upfront, then more of the coffee with a hint of chocolate in the finish. Nice hit of bitter in finish as well. High marks for aroma and flavor. Great stuff.
Tap @ bells.  Rich dark body.  nose is coffee with chocolate and lactose (no diacytal).  Taste matches the aroma. unimanginitive  but perfectly balanced.

Bottle. Pours dark chocolate brown with thin caramel head. Aroma is chocolate, vanilla, caramel, coffee, and a hint of alcohol. Flavor is very smooth coffee, vanilla, caramel, and chocolate. I can barely detect any alcohol-very smooth.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2007 Great balance. Everything is just right-- not too much carbonation. ... Very creamy, drinkable, and definitive. Amazingly good for that near $1 a bottle price range too! The one truly distintive element is its only flaw. In the middle of the finish there is a faint metalic/aluminum taste. Its the fermenting process not the containers Im sure, and I quickly desensitized to this minor flaw.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2006 Excellent beer. Beautiful black with orange/tan head that lasts throughout. Creamy and rich with sweet coffee and chocolate flavors that are just perfectly balanced by the hops in the finish. Would be the absolute best session beer if the alcohol could be cut by 1-1.5 percentage points.
Coffee and vanilla in the nose.  Poured a dark brown almost black.  Roasty, caramel, vanilla, sweet and a slightly sour finish.

Nose is roasty toasted coffee malts with some  chocolate notes; opaque ebony body with very little tan head; flavor is malty, with lots of coffee, a faint molasses note, and a nice hop bite, with a semisweet chocolate finish.

Bottle poured an opaque black with a lasting brown head. Aromas of roasted malt, coffee and a hint of chocolate. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of roasted malt, coffee and bitter chocolate with a lingering roasty bitter finish.

12 oz bottle, thanks to slob!  Pours used oil brown with a small tan head that leaves spotty lace.  Bold aroma is all dark roasty malts, bitter chocolate, barely ripe figs and floral notes.  Flavor is also bitter and roasty, with delicate sweet notes evident as well, more of the bitter dark chocolate, cream, hints of molasses, prune and dandelion, with a lingering bitter/astringent finish.  Full body and gently tickling carbonation.  Quite enjoyable.

Thanks to gputty for this. 
Pours a deep, murky blackness with a tan head.  Nose is of nuts, and malts.
Flavor is roasted, with burnt malts.  Bits of sourness, chocolate, and an overall smokey flavor.  Mouthfeel is a bit thin.  Not a bad stout.

Poured a dark brown almost black color with red highlights on the edges and in parts of the body in the right light. Head was one finger and creamy but subsided to a thin but steady covering. Lacing was ok, not fantastic. The aroma was of strong coffee and smoked ash. The flavor was first of coffee and the strong roasted ash flavor hit me in the first few sips. The hops come through strongly in the finish, nice resinous flavors. As this thing warmed, it got more complex and far exceeded my epectations. Light chocolate and lactic tones started to come through with nuts developing underneath. The flavor is persistent long after each sip, lingering on the tongue. The mouthfeel is moderate to full bodied, but not motor oil thick or anything like that. The more I tasted of this, it came off like a sweet milk stout more than any other type of stout. A nice offering. Re-rate, May 06: A consistent experience, a very nice stout.

Bottled, Batch 7061.  Pours a dark mahogany, practically black with a medium cocoa head.  Aroma of chocolate, coffee, nuts, roasted and caramel malts.  Taste is much the same, fairly sweet throughout with a bitter coffee finish.  Very creamy mouthfeel.  I actually thought this was a milk stout.  Dont know why it took me so long to rate this--would be a great dessert beer.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Batch 7210.  Pours a dark black with just a slight hint of ruby red coming through if held to light.  Head was tan and foamy and left some lacing and sustained.  Aroma of milk chocolate, some roast, cherry, vanilla and coffee.     Flavor of chocolate, light coffee, toffee, nuts and I was getting a light hint of metallic at the end.  This is the best "basic" stout I have had in a while.  Typically the Imperial Stouts tend to get my attention, but this one is right up there with the Imperials. What a great beer.

Thanks to NewCastel1. Black body with a moderate tan head and pretty good lacing. Aroma is like any other stout, chocolate, coffee, roast and caramel. Smooth creamy mouthfeel with some bittersweet chocolate at the end. Tasty but it doesnt have the ooomph of Expedition.

This was an excellent beer.  Very smooth and rich, full bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and gorgeous appeaance.  Lots of chocolate and coffee on the nose and the flavor.  Some hints of smoke and almond extract with a touch of toffee.  Lots of carmel malt in this it seems as well.  Excellent beer.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2006 This was tasty.  Poured from a bottle and it came out black with a subtle brown head.  Felt like a soft and easy expedition stout.  It was not too strong, not at least til the last few sips.

Poured pitch black with barely any head. Very sweet chocolate and light coffee flavor. Had a hint of bitterness and very slight alcohol flavor. This was so very smooth and delightful. This is like expeditions little brother.
Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours dark with a dark tan head. Aroma of roast, coffee, chocolate. Flavor is smooth, coffee, roast, chocolate, and slight bitterness. Good stout.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2006 bottle from the eccentric cafe.  shared this with cmubeerman as zeswaft drove us to detroit.  all i could detect was an enormous aluminum/change taste.  thats just about the worst thing i can find in a beer, and it was all over this one.  i ended up giving cmubeerman the last half of the beer.  drain pour?  ill rerate it if its any good.  RERATE: draft.  pretty smoky, a little empty.  extremely sweet malts.  quite chewy, nice full body.  nice cold.

Guess Ive been spoiled in the last couple of days by Siberian Night and Edmund Fitzgerald -- this was pretty good, but not world class when compared back-to-back.   No way its a 99/100 percentile brew.  Vinegar, black olive and crosotic aroma that wasnt the best.  Damn near opaque Jacobean brown-black, pilin head.  Bad label.  Tangy, a bit unfinished, nutty, sweet and roasty.  Ragged acidic coffee finish.

Appears a midnight, pitch black with a foamy, 1 finger tan head that slowly fades out into a collar. Scattered lacing is left around the tulip glass.
Smell is of deep, dark roasted malt, sweet cream, roasted chestnut, vanilla, and a hint of bitter coffee beans touched with bakers chocolate.
Taste is of the same aromas with a dark roasted malt that stands out above everything else and sticks to the tongue.
Mouthfeel is full bodied with a sugar sweetness and dark roastiness battling it out for supremecy with the fizzy roastiness lasting long after the swallow.
This one is pretty good. The roasted malt and slightly overcarbonated body makes it a bit uneasy to swallow easily but it doesnt take away from the great characteristics found in this brew.

This stout pours a deep black color from a 12oz bottle. Medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is chocolate and coffee, some smoke. A medium to full bodied stout. Malts are chocolate and coffee, touch of vanilla and roasted malt. Hops are grapefruity, Very nice balanced, very smooth taste. Nice soft carbonation. Excellent stout. Not big, not over the top, just solid and delicious. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

From 12oz Bottle.  Dark, rich pour the color of succulent prunes with a moderate sized layer of lightly toasted tan head.  Smells like a campfire roasted smore complete with graham cracker, toasted marshmellow, and light milky chocolate.  Breakfast aromas of toasted whole grain bread waft to my nostrils as well, spread with a light layer of seedless blackberry jam.  That definitely brings back fond memories of living in Michigan.  Rich, full-bodied mouthfeel brings Saturday morning construction site cofee to the palate, straight from the thermos on a cold fall morning.  Some slightly bitter dark chocolate notes follow along eagerly.  Long lasting, dry finish with a hint of anise and salted oats in the final smack.  Very nostalgic tasting for me, as the flavors instantly bring back familiar memories of enjoying this beer during college.  Thanks, Tom!
Pours dark and opaque with a nice tan head.  Aroma of coffee roast.  Velvet smooth and slightly thin mouth feel.  Tastes of rich malt and coffee, chocolate roastiness.  Very nice stout!

bottle - Pours black with a big, tan, lasting head.  The aroma is of roasted malt and coffee.  The flavor has coffee and chocolate notes with a very well balanced roasted malt dominating.  The finish is moderately dry.  This is a great stout that should not be missed.
Nice dark color.  A lot of roasted coffee smell in this one.  Tastes very creamy with some hops, rye, coffee, chocolate and toffee.  Goes down smooth with a nice sweet/bitter after taste.

Dark brown.  A little liight and carbonated.  Nice coffee and roasted malt in the nose which continues into the mouth, along with the characteristic chocolat.  Palate too light for style.  Odd - it is better cold than warm - unusual for a stout.

12 oz bottle pours extremely dark opaque brown, almost black.  Huge tan head hangs around a while, but not too long.  Lots of lacing down the glass.  Roast malt and coffee aroma.  Lots of coffee and some bitter chocolate in the taste.  Complex, some flavours going on I cant exactly describe (maybe black liquorice??).  Not too sweet but not exactly dry either.  Nice creamy mouthfeel.  Long roasted finish, not too bitter.  Really good stout.

In the bottle. Dark brown head, but a thin head. Has a phenomenal aroma of roasted coffee. The flavor is a strong thick rich dry roasted malt. Tasty with a medium coffee and lightly chocolated flavor. I think I need to try this fresh on tap someday to fully appreciate it.
Pours very dark. Aroma is coffee with chocolate subtleties. Thought it was a tad to spritzy, but an all around good drink none the less.

really dark. excellent mixture of coffee,chocolate aroma.  great roasted malt flavor with loads of coffee and chocolate.  very creamy and thought it would be heavier on the tongue.  Stout lovers must give this a try

Pretty much pours as dark as dark gets.  Moderate creamy tan head.  Aroma is full bodied malty good ness, with some chocolate and coffee!!  Roasted malts, coffee and chocolate abound in the flavor.  Very creamy and very smooth.  A must try.

Rich dark pour with a thin brownish head. Aroma is stout and inviting. Chocolate and roasted coffee in the nose. Flavors of bitter chocolate, strong coffee, dark caramel, and finishes heavy and thick. A full bodied brew and very delicious.

Bottle - Pours deep dark brown with thin tan head.  Aroma is roasted malty chocolate and coffee.  Mouthfeel is a little thinner than I expected.  Bitter coffee flavor with a hint of sweetness on the finish.  I was expecting a bit more from the flavor after savoring the aroma for a while, but still a very nice stout.
This is a tasty stout.  Lots of dark roasted malts on the nose and almost a hint of meatiness.  Flavor is mocha-like with a long, long finish.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2006 Black color.Very good dark appearance.
This stout has a nice rich body, and a pleasant roasted coffee taste. Very good!
Black color. Very good Imperial Stout, very well blended, strong malt and caramel, delicate roasted malt, correct bitterness.A big thank to René!

On tap at the brewpub. This is a delicious stout. Very dark pour, with mocha head. Extreemly inticing roasted and nutty aromas. The flavour is nice and carmelized, with some nutty and coffee tastes in there. Nice after taste as well.
Very good dark appearance. Perhaps the standard for the head. I was a little dissapointed in the flavor.
another fine bells beer, this stout has a nice rich body, great color, and a pleasant, lasting taste

Bottle.  Fairly strong toasted nutty aroma, with some chocolate and fruity notes as well.  Small tan head.  Pure thick black and chunky texture.  Tasty!  A very good representation of the style.  Hard to find too many flaws with this beer.  Bells really excels at making the strouts with this and expedition.

The aroma is very coffee like with hints of chocolate.  The color is a deep, dark, black with a thick creamy tan head.  There is a nice roasted coffee flavor with a background of chocolate and some hop.  The finish is creamy and smooth.

Bottle. Tasting session with omhper and ante. Thanks MI2CA for the bottle!Small head. Burned aroma. Lovely roasted taste without the common offtastes of bacon and rubber. Dark caramel, salmiak, cookies. Sweet fullbodied and clean taste. Beautiful.
Bottled.  Opaque black, brownish head. Smokey coffee aroma. Dryish and very roasty with medium body. Strong sooty tar flavour, some dark chocolate in the finish. Interesting and rather complex.

Black with a low beige head. Roasted aroma, notes of vanilla, cocoa, cracker and walnut. Flavour of coffee and dark chocolate with sweet undertones of cookies, blueberr jam, almond and nuts. Long aftertaste of dark chocolate, breadcrusts, roasted coffee and cocoa. Nice stout.

Very thick, looks like syrup when pouring into a glass.  I was a little surprised for a 6.5% to have such strong flavor, a little to strong.  It wasnt as smooth as I was hoping.  Definately a sipping beer.  However, I still enjoyed it and would buy it again.

Pours black with a small brown head.  Nice hop aroma with touches of coffee and roasted malts and caramel.  Moutfeel is gritty, oily and much more carbonated that I expected.  Tastes of chocolate, coffee beans, rye bread, and a long lingering roasted hops finish.
Bells has routinely impressed me. This one is not only not an exception, it was a pleasant experience on all fronts.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2007 Pours balck with a 2 finger thick tan head. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, and some slight chocolate notes. Flavor is coffee-like, sweet, roast, chocolate and a bitter finish. Good body, good brew.

Another gem courtesy of Styles- Opaque oily black pour leaving lots of nice belgian style lace. Head is mocha, initially large, and fades to a thin ring. Aroma is mostly coffee and malts, with vanilla and molasses. Semi sweet coffee  and coffee beans bitterness are well integrated with molasses and vanilla extract. Bitter sweet coffee finish. Lingering coffe flavours are nice. I almost prefer the other stouts from Bells that I have had, but this one, while not being the monster that the others are, is very well balanced and drinkable, and thats where it scores its points. Thanks Chris!

Pours black with a medium creamy brown head that dissipates quickly, some lacing. Aroma is roasted malts, coffe, soy sause. Flavor is not as intense as I expected, coffee, chocolate, roasted goodness with a touch of sour in the finish. Mouthfeel is a bit watery, carbonation is just right.
great thick rich stout i loved it easy to drink with great chocolate aftertaste.if you like a smooth stout with a good aftertaste this is it .

black with a great brown head. heavy bitter chocolate and coffee aroma. very balanced bittersweet flavor. bitter chocolate coffee smoke. nice. full body. great mild carbonation. long bitter smoked mocha finish. not very complex but an absolutely fantastic stout. one of my favorites.

No. 32.  Bells Kalamazoo.  Honestly I was hoping for Bells Expedition but Jason is probably hiding that in a closet somewhere.  Hell, Bells is Bells and Bells is delicious.  Dark and chocolicious like a stout of this stature should be.  Heavy stuff.

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2016 From the bottle: This is the way a stout should look right from the bottle, motor oil-black with a cascading tan head.  Little aroma, but theres a nice roasty flavor ... a hint of coffee, a hint of dark chocolate.  Nice.

Pours a very oily black with a large brown head.  Aroma is very chocolatey, dough, black olives, and slight citrus.  Flavor is BIG and very yeasty, black olives, coffee, chocolate, and a slight, basil-like note.  Mouthfeel is incerdibly full, almost sticky.  Quite a lot more rounded and full of details than the expedition.  Almost an imperial, nontheless.  I would definitely recommend.
Deep dark black color with a creamy brown head.  The flavor is everything the aroma promises and more, with its thick roasted malt/chocolate flavors.  Excellent Stout!!

Bottled.  Via trade with CaptainCougar.  Pours black with a big tan head.  Heavy Lacing.  Chocolate and roasted malts in the nose as well as a nutty note.  Smooth mouth feel with coffee and bitter chocolate notes.  Roasted with a slight smokiness.  Bitter finish

Pours a thin black with reddish tan head. Nose is subtle and roasty with some smooth chocolate notes. Flavor is crisp and roasty with mild bitterness. A little thin on the tongue. An easy yet satisfying drink.

Vintage 2003 bottle.Pours dark brown almost black with a fine tan head. Dominating milk chocolate and cream aroma, full with a heavy sweetness that makes it sticky and cloying - I miss some roast and hop in there. Flavor is roasted malt, coffee and chocolate with a dusty dry mouthfeel. Some sourness from the roast. Biding finish. A good stout, but being a top 50 I had hoped for more!

Poured pitch black with small frothy brown head with nice lacing on the edges. Thick as a brick.Aroma malty with chocolate and toffee in the nose. Big chocolate flavor hits initially, than settles into malty notes with a roasted barley flavor. Slighty bitter through the middle to end of the beer. Thick coffee like mouthfeel. Very nice stout. Bells makes some excellent beers.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2006 Completely black, dense stout.  Silky, molasses feel.  Strong roasted coffee flavor.
Sharp bitter chocolate bite.  Also has a unique smokiness to the nose. This is definetly a nice stocker for the Winter.

12 oz bottle thanks to Illinismitty.  Poured a deep black with a thick, fluffy tan head which faded slowly with nice lacing. Aroma of roasted malt with coffee and chocolate. Nice smooth malty flavor with notes of caramel, and coffee. Very rich lingering mouth feel!  Im not much of a common stout drinker, but this was outstanding. Probably the best stout I have had.
Black color, deep brown head. Strong coffee and chocolate aroma. Strong coffee finish. Very smooth and velvety. Fantastic beer.
Definitly one of the better stouts. Very complex taste, theres some molasses and chocolate that really comes out in both the flavor and smell.
Batch6666 Poured Black with tan/brown head. Nice chocolate malt aroma up front Flavor was balanced with chocolate malt and molasses. Very good !
Pours a nice pitch black with aromas of coffee and chocolate.  Very nicely balanced with a slight bitter aftertaste.  A very well done stout.

Bottle.  Thanks to richlikebeer.  Pours a dark black color with minimal tan head.  Aroma of coffee, malts, chocolate, caramel and molasses.  Taste is complex with caramel, malts and molasses dominating.  Coffee and chocolate could be found in the aftertaste.  This is a phenomenal stout!
12oz bottle. Nice oily mouthfeel with chocolate and molasses. A hint of espresso in the nose. As times goes on I  get  more of an alcohol flavor. Another solid beer from Bells.

12 oz bottle thanks to Duane.  Pours super black with a chocolate brown head.  Aromas of chocolate, and molassas.  Flavors were classic stout.  Some chocolate, but room for roasted malts and a decent hop bittering.  Good Good Good.
Bottle.  I made the mistake of drinking Bells Expedition Stout before I tried this one, and compared to Expedition, this was seemed a little watered-down.  A good, drinkable stout nonetheless.
Bottle. A beautiful beer, wonderful coffee and chocolate taste with a smooth finish. Medium to full body. Great looking. I m a fan.

Bottle.  Aroma of deep, rich arabica bean coffee - fresh ground.  Nice black stout with coffee ice cream colored head.  Really delicious, rich and smooth, hits good dark chocolate and cofee notes, a hint of booze.  Good stuff.
12 oz bottle. Aroma is of roasted malts and slightly sweet. Flavor is more malt and a little coffee with a dry finish. My favorite stout at this time - it would be tough to improve on.

Bottle. Black body, big frothy creamy dark khaki head. Nice brewers lace. Dry aroma of cocoa and dark malt, touch of alcohol. Flavour is quite dry with a mild roast that is not strong but pervasive. Dark chocolate is more obvious as it warms. Medium to full bodied palate would feel creamier if it were not so dry. Bit disappointing. It is a nice stout, but the Expedition is substantially more to my liking.
batch # 7185.   Pours a dark brown to black.  Aroma is sweet with a little coffee.  Taste has a little coffee (almost burnt), and a touch of bitter at the end.  A pretty good brew.
Bottle. Black colour with a beige head. Roasted malty flavor, hints of chocolate and coffee. Roasted malty flavor with hints of coffee, chocolate and dried fruits. Sweet finish.

Black colour with a light brown head. Roasted malty aroma with a light chocolate sweetness and some coffee bitterness. Soft coffee bitter flavor with some dark fruit sweetness and a chocolate note. Dry light sweet finish.
Bottle. Black colour with a beige head. Light sweet, roasted, coffee aroma and a roasted, coffee, raisin fruity taste. MEdium to full body with a light sweet finish.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2007 Bottle. Pours black with brown head. Aroma is sweet and roasty. Flavor is nutty, sweet, with subtle hints of coffee. Smooth but subtle bitter finish, but with some very slight notes of molasses. Very easy to drink, but still bold. Simply put, a great stout. No wonder this is a top 50.

Bottle.
Rating #2000.
Black coloured with a beige head.
Sweet and roasted aroma of malts, caramel and hops with notes of dried fruits.
Roasted flavour of coffee with notes of dried fruits and chocolate.

Looks inviting, Smells rough but like a fruity chocolate.  Taste is great, like a chocolate milkshake.  Creamy on the palate like whipped mashed potatoes.  Overall this beer is a real treat, just like a hot fudge sundae in a blender.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2007 impenetrable, this beer is like a black hole with a dense creamy head.  The aroma doesnt do the appearance of this beer justice, though only because it is fairly weak in scent... though what aroma there is smells creamy.  The flavor is really outstanding, the standard rich/creamy/coffee/chocolate flavor of a stout, with excellent mouth feel.  The flavors become more intense as this beer sits at room temperature for longer.  Ive drank very few superior beers.May 16, 2007:
Well, I have to mark off flavor by 2, palate by 1, and overall by 2.  This is a damnded fine beer, dont get me wrong, but this was a very early rating.  The nose was still great, I was tempted to up that.  The appearance is still phenomenal, though from the bottle I had less head.  The palate is a little bit fizzier.  The flavors are a bit more astringent and cola like that I remember.  Dont get me wrong, Id still drink this every day if my local had this on tap, but its just not the ethereal nectar of the Gods I once thought it was.  Perhaps my favorite straight stout.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2006 Pours black with a brown head and brown lacings. Sweet and very malty. Aromas of dried fruits and some coffee and chocolate. TIny minty hint towards the end. Quite port like. Dry finish.
(Bottle 35,5 cl) Pours a very pretty opaque black with a beige head. Very vinous and malty with some raisiny accents. Also chocolatey, coffeish and toasted.  A discreet bitterness. Very tasty. 270106

Many beer geeks believe substyle of stout called "American" stout, should be added to the stout and porter category. So examples like Kalamazoo Stout will fit in, and can be judged against other stouts that would also fit into this new style. 

So what is American Stout? It is basically a big, robust, flavorful stout, with big malt character, but also really big hop character. And what makes it American, is most brewers are using lavish doses of PNW hop varieties such as Cascades, Chinooks, Centennials, and Columbus. Kalamazoo stout pours to an opaque, ink black color with a big, creamy tan head, and a moderate carbonation. The nose on this beer is packed with aromas of malt and hops. Big whiffs of chocolate malt, and coffee pair with piney, citric aromatics. The palate is a firm malt back bone of dark malts. Flavors of dark chocolate, coffee, and a hint of vanilla coat the tongue. This beer has a very hefty body, it is quite viscous and oily, it really does resemble "motor oil in a glass". This beer finishes with big chocolate malt flavors up front, then dries out with a slightly roasty/coffee character, and a lingering hop bite. This beer is a bit stronger than dry or cream stouts, weighing in at about 6.5% abv, but isnt quite as potent as Imperial stout. 

What ever you want to call this beer, call it delicious, because it is. This is one of my all time favorite beers, from one of Americas best breweries. This beer is a perfect desert beer. Match this with German chocolate cake, or chocolate pudding with fresh whipped cream.
Thanks again to kms399 for this one. Pours almost black, small brown head. Nose is nutty, with coffee and roasted malts. Flavor follows the nose to a T. Slightly bitter, dry finish.
From bottle.  Pours black with a coffee colored head.  Roasted malts in the nose.  Flavor is nutty with more roasted malts.  Bitter, dry finish leaves something missing.

Pours, looks, and smells like a stout. Though the flavor is an exceptional blend of choclate malts, coffee, and caramel all balanced well for one smoooth brew. Malty, not overly bitter nor too sweet, though not as thick as I would expect with the flavor its presenting.

"Poured a jet black color with a brown heard on top. Left some cool looking lacings on the glass. Aroma was stong malty and roasted coffee and mabye some toffee. Taste was good, malty, bitter with some coffee. Full bodied and dry"

Bottle from Coles in Buffalo, NY: Nearly black in color with a small tan head. Roasted barley, chocolate and coffee dominate the nose. As expected, plenty of roast in the flavor as well as notes of licorice and prunes. Full bodied with a mild hop finish. Solid stout.

Nice dark black body with a good-sized dark brown head.  Not much of an aroma, but hints of roasted malts.  Wonderful flavor - chocolate, coffee, with a bit of bitter hops at the beginning, followed by a nuttiness, with just a hint of dark fruit sweetness.  Very nice, complex flavor.  Mouthfeel is delightful, just the right hint of carbonation.  Very nice beer.

Pour is a dark black with a large tan head.  Aroma is a nice mix of toasty malts and dark chocolate.  Flavor is caramel with dark chocolate with some coffee thrown in there.  Everything you would want a stout to be and then some.

12 oz bottle, via illinismity.  Pitch black pour with a nice half inch chocolate brown head that left great lacing.  Rich roasted malt and chocolate aroma.  Burnt malt and bitter chocolate flavor, very deep and full.  Bitter and dry finish with good length.  Full bodied chewy mouthfeel with perfect carbonation.  Ideal palate for a Stout.  Easy to see why this is so highly regarded.  Its nice to have a regular Stout so packed with flavor.  This beer has much more going on than many brewerys attempts at Imperial Stout.

Wow, this is some BLACK beer!  Opaque and with an opulent brown head that sticks to the sides of the glass, this beer screams "drink me!"  Smells like any other stout, chocolatey, coffeish, roasty.  Oh man, this is tasty, very bitter (the way I like stouts to be), roasted chocolate with a slight coffee tinge dominates, with a bitter finish.  Just the right amount of carbonation.  I would definitely buy this again.  And again.  And again!  I cant wait to try Bells other legend, Expedition.

Bottle. Very dark and totally black pour. Nice bitter roasted chocolate, coffee, malt aroma. Alot smoother and lighter then I expected from a stout. Has a definite coffee, chocolate, roasted malt flavor ti it. Bitter is one thing that I found this beer to be. A little to bitter for me while drinking and in the finish. But a good beer nontheless. One I can wait a while to try again though.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a very dark brown-black with a nice size foamy light-brown head. You cant see through this puppy. The aroma, well its just as good as a Stout can get isnt it? Roasted malt with chocolate, hops, smoke, coffee and caramel -- just awesome. The flavour is no slouch either: a big roasty caramel malt flavour with chocolate and a nice bitter aftertaste. Thick and creamy just as a great Stout should be. Spectacular, well done Bells!

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2006 Bottle (12oz).  Shared with blankboy, obtained via trade with MullMan.  Poured impenetrable brown-black with a thick, foamy, creamy dark brown head - oh yeah.  A roasty/smoke malt medley I cannot begin to do justice to, coffee beans, dark chocolate, cream, woodiness, juniper berries, hops - mmmmmm.  Taste follows the nose, quite bitter, even more juniper and tart blackberry notes, starts with some chocolate but the coffee and tartness join up with the hop bitterness to make this a decidedly long, smooth but bitter finish.  Mouthfeel is extremely creamy, thick in body, slightly lively mouthfeel, and incredibly complex.  Where have you been all my life?  The best regular stout Ive ever had.

Aroma of chocolate, roast coffee.  Appears black as pitch, with a small creamy brown head that dissipates.  Flavor is warm, roasty, with some suprisingly smoky notes, and with bitterness that comes more from the grains than from anything else.  Palate is medium thick and very smooth.  Overall, this is a fantastic brew and one that benefits from a restrained sense of balance.  It is even a bit more than the sum of its parts.

12-oz. bottle, Batch #6864, bottled May 12, 2005.  Pours near opaque only letting a slight amount of light to pass through this black strap molasses-like medium, with a small and bubbly frothy tan head, mostly diminishing to a floating film.  Fragrant fruit (grape, apple) jumps out of the glass first and leads the way for some extremely aromatic dark coffee, espresso chocolate malt, faint smokiness of dark roasted malt, caramel notes with yeast (leather) on the nose.  Dark bitter coffee and chocolate, biting like your wake-me-up espresso, oh this would make a great morning brew, modetately bitter lasting flavor with some sour leathery yeast notes.  Dark and full bodied, lightly fizzy and velvety palate.

12 oz bottle  Pours a heavy black with a lasting creamy light brown head which produces great lacing.  Has a lovely roasted chocolate and coffee aroma with nutty hints.  I also got a touch of dough.  A thick full bodied stout with a good amount of carbonation and a nice finish.  Good aftertaste.  This is a great stout with good flavors and a robust taste that lasts nicely.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2008 4/6/08 (Bought 12/2005)
I figured it was about time to drink my last bottle of the 6 pack I bought in December 2005. Wonderful aroma very similar to what I reported in 05. Amazingly thick, oily, and soft mouthfeel. Easily a 5 on the palate. I dont notice much of a bitter finish as I reported in 05. It seems to have mellowed quite a bit. Nothing over-powers anything else. Its just an amazingly thick, soft, and roasted mouthful. One of the best beers Ive had for sure.

12/31/05 
Pitch black with a small brown head that disappeared fairly quickly.  Nice aroma of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, nuts(?).  Wonderful flavor.  Mirrors the aroma.  Some coffee bitterness in the finish but its not overdone.  Very nice.  Thick and oily mouthfeel. Wonderfully balanced. I had to drive a long way to go on the beer run when I got this.  I wish Id have picked up more of this while I was there. (8/5/9/4/17)

Bottle.  Black Pour, big chocolaty tan head.  Some chocolate, roast, and alcohol in mild aroma.  Taste is very nice - tons of chocolate, very rich roast, with hops in the background.  The mouthfeel is thick, rich, and creamy.  A truly outstanding tasting stout.  Lovely lingering roast at the end.  One of the best stouts I have ever tried, thanks to Captain Cougar for the trade.

Pours a dark black with rich brown head that fades quickly.  Chocolately aroma with roasted accents; both of which dominate the taste.  

Full bodied - borders on creamy with a simple light carbonation.

Very good, and yet quite simple.

12 oz bottle.  Pours black with a creamy chocolaty head.  Smoky chocolate aroma.  A little of that smoke comes through in the flavor.  Nice combination with the chocolate.  Certainly worth the effort!

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2006 My last rating of this was bad...as styles pointed out.  Things this beer is...tasty.  Its not huge, but it is perfect for anytime of the year.  Ill rerate it more adequately when I have a bottle in hand.

Barbecue and chocolate cake aroma, some smoke and plenty of roasted grain.  The beer looks great, too, an impervious deep chocolate brown with lacing that practically climbs the glass.  Palate is smooth and creamy, with a deconstruction of smoke and hops on the finish that liven the beer up.  Chocolate, woodsmoke, and coffee all come through on the tongue, and stay there lingering awhile.  A complicated beer thats easy to love.

Pours black with a small tan head.  Smells very complex, notes of cream and caramel and bittersweet chocolate.  Taste is crazy with cream, oatmeal, bittersweet chocolate, caramel and java.  AFtertaste is complex and long lasting.  Nice beer.

Bottle: Nearly black body with small charcoal head. Nose was of buttery molases and hints of candied syrup. At first the moutfeel was thinner than I expected, although right on for a stout. Nut, chocolae, java, and butter flavor with no alch retention, very smooth and balanced.
The perfect session stout! Id killed off half this thing within 5 minutes... rich, creamy, chocolately... this thing really goes down well. Well balanced, well made.
Bottle.  Sweet chocolate malt aroma.  Dark brown with small head.  Molasses and chocolate malt flavor.  Nice full body.  A great beer.

This is a tasty stout with hintsof coffee, molasses, and yes lots odf coco/chocolate.  has a nice roasted malty/hoppy taste sweet then fades to bitter.  A great brew. Almost as good as the Special Double Cream Stout but not quite as smooth or chocolaty.   This one goes by itself NO food needed here... it is a meal in itself !!

Poured black with good head and some lacing.  There was a heavy chocolate aroma.  The taste was mostly chocolate with some hints of caramel.  The chocolate was good and not that stale taste you get with some.
I was a little disappointed in this one.  The feel in the mouth was thinner than I was expecting, and the flavors not as robust.  I enjoyed it; its just not one of my favorites.

This beer boasts an aroma resembling a creamy mocha java.  This beer looks and sounds like motor oil when poured into the glass with the exception of the small almond colored head.  A creamy rich taste of chocolate, coffee, toffee, malt, and mildly nutty that overwhelms the taste buds.  That infusion of flavors fades leaving a sweet and mildly bitter taste lingering on the palate for minutes.  This beer would defiantly satisfy the thirst of the Bolshevik philosopher on the label.  This is a good beer to fill-in after the supply of Dark Lord has vanished.
Pours dark black with a good sized brown head. Low aroma. Deep chocolate and heavy coffee, sweet to bitter. Complex taste which improves throughout the brew. Finishes well.
This was a very dark black beer.  I would have to say I was impressed with the taste as well as the appearance.
UPDATED: DEC 21, 2005 Had during a beer tasting party.  Poured black and had aroma and taste of malasses.  Decent but would have liked to see more out of it.

Pours a pitch black with a brown frothy head.  Very caramelly aroma with notes of chocolate, coffee,  and roasted malts very prevalent as well.  Exquisitely complex and wonderfully warming first sip.  Great Great stuff.  Get some its an awesome experience!!!

bottle pours black with a tan head. roasted chocolate, hops, almost seems like an oatmeal stout  taste is chocolate, coffee and that oatmeal thing again. very smooth with light toasted feel to it. great beer
Dark tan head. Roasty chocolate with a touch of coffee in the nose, and flavor.  Very smooth balance.  Had this at a tasting in Orlando 11/27/05.
UPDATED: DEC 2, 2005 Nice creamy mouthfeel,chocolate is the most noticable flavor. Not bitter or COFFEE in yer face. Very smooth.
thick malty goodness.   aroma may be stronger than flavor.  very tasty. palate is nice syrupy coating good good.  i drink this shit a lot cause its all over paw paw. me likey.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2007 I was starting to wonder if I even liked Stouts anymore. Either bored to death by Guinness or tortured by Imperial Stouts that try too hard but end up offering out-of-balanced, overly hopped, sticky goo (i.e. Bells 7000). I know that many people rave about stouts that are completely over the top on this site, but, personally, they end up being more work then their worth.  K-stout is almost perfect (for a stout). Tan head. Delicious sniff of coffee and roasted malt. Creamy, just a touch of flower like hops balance out a great tasting maltyness. My faith in stouts have been restored.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2006 12oz bottle. Packaged on June 21st, 2005. An amazing stout. Its borderline imperial. Bells never seems to dissapoint. Aromas dark chocolates, slight coffee. Taste is the same. Very creamy smooth. Dark as night with a beautiful tan head lacing that glass. As far as the style goes, its one of the best. Two thumbs up, and one bottle down.
Roasted coffee and chocolate with hints of molasses and burnt brown sugar...very, very smooth and creamy mouthfeel.  Another great stout by Bells.

Deep black color with big dark brown head that dissipates to leave a hint of lacing. Aroma is subtle, with roasted malt backbone with hints of vanilla and cream, and a slight saltyness reminiscent of soy sauce. Flavor is roasty, smooth, creamy, slightly acidic, with a subtle interplay of sweetness and faint bitterness in the finish. A very nice stout, smooth, subtle, slightly sweet.

12 oz. bottle.  Wow.  How Id forgotten just what a great stout this is.  Gotten hung up on imperial this or oaked that.  This is a rich, dense, easy-drinking, inexpensive brew that will have a nice home this winter in ma belly.  Rich, roasted malt with a great balance of hops really make this one of the best examples of a style.   Deep flavors of mocha with a slight sweetness.  Body is there but not over the top.  Finish is near perfect and leave one wanting more.

12z bottle.  Opaque hue with great finger width of tan head.  Deep chocolate notes in the nose.  Also a nice coffee and toffee, slight sugary raisins aroma.  Full in the mouth and delicious!  Great roasted coffee flavor, with bitter chocolate and a creamy mouthfeel.  Mild hop nose and flavor.  This is an absolutely wonderful brew!  Rich and creamy, sweet and bitter, dark and full!  Quite possibly the best brewery in the country.

(draft) Oh, Bells Kalamzoo Stout, where have you been all my life? This is as close to the perfect stout as Ive ever had. All of the flavor of an imperial, but without the high ABV and without the alcohol burn. My new favorite stout in the entire world. Yummy.

UPDATED: DEC 9, 2005 Great mix of chocolate and sugars(molasses).  Nice and creamy.  Smooooooth.  Far and away the best tasting stout I have had.  Like Expedition, but without the alcohol burn.  Almost perfect in all areas.  If it were perfect, Id have to stop trying new beers....
Dare I say I like it better than the double cream?  Rich, full, black, toasty, coffee-chocolate-caramel-candy flavor, round and smooth, mouth-fillingly luscious.  Thank you sir may I have another?

This is one of my all time favorite stouts.  Much better than the double cream IMO.  Pours almost pitch black, thick, nice deep brown head, and low carbonation.  Aroma is tons of roasted barley, chocolate, some coffee, and some licorice.  Flavor is overloaded with roasted barley, chocolate malts, and light caramel malt for a balanced sweetness.  The black malt is noticed only in the appearance, as there is no harsh acrid astringency in the flavor or mouthfeel.   Finish is so damn smooth, and moderately bitter.

Bottle: Poured a pitch-black color stout with a medium brown color head with great retention. Aroma of roasted malt with faint chocolate in the back. Taste is very creamy-like with a nice dose of chocolate. Not a whole lot of hops but I think this is for the best. Very well balance beer.

This should be everyones go-to stout. When simply wishing for a well-crafted and inexpensive stout, this one is one of the finest. Notes of espresso on the nose and roasted malt lead into more coffee, chocolate, and oatmeal. I didnt realize they used oatmeal in this one, but after having it again last night, Im almost certain they do. I like the fact that Bells doesnt go over the top with the roast here and opts for balance instead. Better on cask (several times at Bling Pig in Champaign, IL), but certainly fine out of the bottle as well. REVISED: Mr. Larry Bell reports no oatmeal. The creaminess, the brown-head retention; I assumed oatmeal. Thanks to Larry for correcting my error!

Been looking forward to trying this one and after 6 hours of class, a meeting, and a physics exam, I think I deserve it!  Pours very dark with a small and fading brown head.  Coffee and caramel aromas are strongest,  with some slight fruit notes as well.  Flavor is very well balanced.  Im new to the style, but I know a well made beer when I drink one.  This was a nice beer to unwind with after a long day.

My favorite beer to date. Its got a bit of a complex flavor with chocolate, coffee,  and a slight bitterness.  Dark pour, as with most stouts.  Not much carbonation to it either.  Ill agree with others on this one, probably the smoothest stout you can have.

Pours black with a one finger creamy brown head.  The aroma is roasted coffee beans, caramel, and molasses, along with some vinous notes.  The flavor is very roasty, with espresso and bittersweet chocolate.  Finish dries out nicely, but is very mildly bitter.  Moderately thick and slippery mouth feel.  About the smoothest beer youll ever have.

Pours a really dark brown with only a thin layer of foam. Nose is like going around the corner from where I live and they are roasting coffee beans.Roasty and a little smokey.Thick and rich. The roasted flavor is very well defined.Dee-lish
Bottle at the Hop Leaf.  Opaque with a thin tan head.  Coffee and chocolate notes.   Very smooth with a slightly bitter end.  A very good stout.

12 oz bottle at the Electric Earth Cafe, surprised to find this one here.  Nose coffee, a metallic coffee with some roasted barley and chocolate.  Dark black appearance with a light brown head that thins.  Total roasty, dark barley flavor with a bitter coffee and chocolate thing going on.  Granola finish with some nutty almond flavors and some grassy hops in there also.  Medium body.
pours very dark with a nice creamy head. Very smooth and drinkable with a great roasted flavor and hints of coffee and bitter chocolate. Overall a great, strong stout.
UPDATED: FEB 14, 2008 This is a great stout. It bours beautyfully, creamy long lasting head. aroma is choclaty and coffee. Flavor is awesome and very big. A perfect Stout.

Pours a deep reddish chestnut color, almost black, with a thin tan head. The aroma is very strong with sweet fruits, like cherry and pear. Scents of the finest chocolate in the world tease the nostrils. A bit of hop spiciness mixed in as well. Truly delicious aroma. The taste is strong on dark, bittersweet chocolate. A nice sweetness follows, as well as defined roasted notes. The finish presents more fruity chocolate, with a wisp of smoke. A bit of vanilla is present as well, mixed in with the solid malt flavor in the background. As you can tell, this is one very complex beer. I also sense a bit of nuttiness in there as well. The mouthfeel is very smooth, and shows a moderate body. Not as thick as some sweet stouts, but flavor is what this beer is all about.
Classic: deep & dark and roasted & toasted. Aromas of coffee, dark chocolate and BBQ briquettes. Rich flavors throughout. Healthy bitterness to balance things out. Solid stout with tons to offer.

Poured a nice dark brown/coffee color with a medium light brown frothy head that diminished to almost nothing.  Aroma reminded me of molasses with a touch of licorice and roasted malts.  First taste, wow, complex; creamy, rich, roasted coffee with some caramel and a slight alcohol taste, had some sweetness yet nicely balanced with the hop bitterness.  Continued to improve as I drank and the beer warmed.  Excellent brew full bodied and VERY tasty!
Very tasty!  I could taste all kinds of good stuff on my first sip.  The aroma is nice but you can definatley smell the alcohol even though its not a very strong beer.  Still very good stuff!
Great stout.  Had a thick tan head and poured coffee black but left good after taste.
Very good stout. Nice and strong, but not overpowering. Doesnt overdo it on the roasted barley.

Cask conditioned version at Firkin.  Nice light brown creamy head with excellent lacing. Brown-black color with heady  aroma of bitter chocolate and roasted malt, with touch of resiny hop. Creamy full body that started with a sweetish smooth chocolate with a burnt malt taste and finished with moderate bitterness.  Very enjoyable beer to savor alone after a meal.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2005 Poured dark coffee brown-black with a densy foamy dark tan head which faded slowly with nice lacing.    Aromas of malt, smoke, coffee, toffee, chocolate, peat, alcohon, yeast and hops.  Flavors included roast malt, alcohol, bread, herbs, grapefruit, chocolate, coffee, grapefruit,  caramel and molasses, with a good bitter finish.  very nice chewy mouthfeel.

Poured black with a thick tan head.  Very good head retention.  This looked like a Cafe Mocha.  Smell was fruity along with vanilla, chocolate and bitter coffee.  The main fruit was cherry.  There was a bit of a burnt flavor in the taste at times but it didnt bother me.  Terrific mouthfeel.  So smooth.  The best single Stout Ive ever had.

Truly great stout. Thick, firm head, very roasty, malty, slightly hoppy aroma. Highly roasted flavor, malty, yet has definite hop flavor.  Awesome balance of roasted, malty/caramel, hop flavors with hints of coffee, molasses and alcohol. Doesnt fit easily into category - ie., isnt Irish, imperial, sweet, cream, milk, etc.,etc. Only one of the best stouts around.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2005 Poured Black with very little head. Sweet smell of Vanilla, Chocolate, and coffee. Taste of roasty coffee and nut. Very smooth going down. This is a very nice stout and I will be getting more

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2007 Batch 6833, bottled April 14, 2005 enjoyed on October 24, 2005. Pours jet black with a thick, creamy, lucious brown head that fades to a tan hue that covers the body. Excellent lacing. Aroma is a wonderful blend of coffee, molases and chocolate.  Flavor is immediately of burnt molasses and coffee. Lots of great roastedness. This is closely followed by more bitterness from the citrusy hops. This flows into a burst of molases, toffee, caramel, raisins and plums, sweet and malty. Every drop is delightful. Taste fills the mouth. The finish is long with lingering bitterness and I savor every moment of it. Texture of this beer is incredibly smooth, creamy and chewy, coats the mouth.  Carbonation is soft and lightens the weight of this full-bodied brew. The full flavor and complexity of this masterpiece can be match by only a few imperial stouts, and yet it still quite sessionable. There is no better stout on the planet. There is not a single thing I would change in this beer, I have to give it a perfect score.

Very nice deep black pour with almost no head.  Wouldve picked up that last point with some head retention.  Sweet aroma with chocolate, vanilla, molasses, and other very nice roastiness.  Powerfully creamy and smooth across the palate, with a light chocolate bitterness on the finish.  Flavors were nicely roasted chocolate and coffee, caramel, and some light hops.    Another excellent stout from K-Zoo!
Black in color with a thick tan head. Aroma is rich with sweet,toffee,caramel,chocolate and cofee. Flavor is of caramel,toffee,coffee,burnt malt,chocolate and vanilla with a dry astringent finish.

Thanks to my friend Pennie in Ohio for this one. Little roasted aroma, but ample chocolate and malt. Deep black with a firm mocha head. If I hadnt JUST had the Java Stout by Bells Id probably be more wowd by this a lot more. Lots of bitter coffee and roasted flavors in the foretaste followed by a chocolate sweet creaminess. Expertly done stout. The people of Michigan are very lucky to have the Kalamazoo Brewing Company.

Wanted something rich to sip at with a nibble of chocolate as I settled in to watch a flick. Excellent choice - the thick tan head didnt last but the black body was all I needed. Obvious stout aromas of roasted coffee and chocolate malts, tinged with some slight sweetness. Full-bodid and rich this had a touch of mocha astringincy that I liked. Damn fine.

Thick dense head of malted milk ball color.  Great duration.  Rich and creamy aroma with milk chocolate, roasted grains and a hint of butter toffee.  Awesome.  Color is essenally black.  Medium bodied with plenty of roasted grains.  Smooth and creamy with a little hops bite.  Some light coffee in there also.  Slight lingering bitterness.  No real alcohol presence.  Goes down very easy.  Pretty good stuff!

12 oz. bottle. Pours dark, opaque cherrywood color with a persistent creamy, brown head. Aromas of chocolate and cold coffee with some fruity notes. Flavors of espresso and Milk Duds and a warm, hoppy finish. This is good stuff.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2005 12 oz bottle.  Espresso, dark chocolate, and some hop aroma.  Pitch black with a brown head.  Some lace.  Looks pretty think.  Very sweet.  Kind of like chewing on a coffee bean.  Bitter enough to balance sweetness.  Quite full bodied an silky smooth.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2010 bottle. Pours solid black with a dark brown head. The aroma is very roasty and ashy with assertive espresso notes. The mouthfeel is moderately dense for a regular old stout. This really brings the expedition stout to mind, just a little milder. Solid smoky, burnt, espresso notes are way up front on the palate with light creamier notes in the finish. Its pretty much expeditions little brother. Great stout.

[June 14, 2010]

Pint from a cask at Nicholsons Pub. This is one stout that translates well in a cask. The palate is very creamy and slick and the serving temperature really lets the strong roasty qualities shine. The finish is everlasting and savory like espresso and meat. Hops start to be noticed after a few sips. This is one tasty brew.

Black black black. Tan head. Mighty aroma here, only matched by its taste. Lots of molasses and brown sugar, combined with tons of roasted malts. This IS a stout. Taste is much of the same, with the addtion of a solid coffee character and a hint of vanilla. Some hops noted which rounds out a nice complex stout. Great mouthfeel. Big, thick, and chewy. Perfect for any time of the year. Yum Yum.
Pours black with mostly retained tan head.  Aroma of dark bread, brown sugar, chocolate, and molasses. Taste is very roasty but also somewhat sweet. Body is thick and carbonation is high for a stout.

Black pour through and through with a good size tan head. Strong aroma of malts - molasses, hint of chocolate. Wonderful taste of roasted malts, chocolate, molasses, caramel. Smooth with a suprise bit of bitter that lasts.

Black in colour with a fair amount of carbonation and a very dark head. The aromas are generally sweet and malty, with notes of milk chocolate and a bit of plum. The flavors are quite roasty, and suggest coffee, molasses, caramel, and a bit more chocolate. I could also detect a bit of hop flavor as well, but most of the bitterness comes from the roasted malts. Massive body to this one too!

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2005 Pours black as night.  Head looks like whipped chocolate mousse...thick and foamy.  Obvious aromas of dark chocolate, rich and malty.  Strong roasty, chocolate and coffee combo of flavors, sweetens near the finish...molasses like.  A taste which is a little stronger than a mocha  finish.  Body is big, thick, and chewy.  Very smooth and well balanced.  Flavor is distinctive and mellower than most stouts.

Bottle, thick looking black opaque pour.  Huge aroma of roasted malts and some chocolate, maybe a little toffee.  Very good palate - light smooth carbonation, with big roasted malts and chocolate.  Finishes with some small lingering bitterness.  Very nice - finding such huge stout flavors n a 6.5% stout is very nice.
Poured a dark black color with an averaged sized brown head. Aromas and tastes of chocolate, coffee and roasted malts. I loved the chocolate presence in this one. Coffee bitterness in the finish.

Bottle.  Pours a luxurious pitch black covered with a thick whipped brown head.  Great lacing. Aroma is clean (no sourness), sweet milk/coffee, mocha, perfect roasty chocolate background without being too burnt.  Earthy and woody without being overly oaky, wonderful balance.  Great coating mouth feel, creamy and rich, mild/low alcohol.  Mild roasty flavor, medium finish, but still very satisfying.  Low hop profile.  The body and the clean taste of this beer make it one of the best. Oh, the balance, the balance.

Black in color with a fluffy light brown head. Aroma is sweet coffee and a little chocolate. Flavor starts sweet with coffee and cream and some dark chocolate followed by a dry bitter sweet finish. Palate is rich and smooth.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2007 Pours thick black with a fluffy light brown head.  Soft chocolate notes on the aroma.  Flavor is very reminiscent to Expedition stout but everything is divided by 2.  That same sweet chocolate and mocha flavor.  Not nearly as much hops.  And of course half the alcohol.  Relatively thin mouthfeel for such a dark stout.  Makes for a very tasty stout.  Tons of what looks like powdered chocolate leftover in the bottle.

rerate, damn, this is awesome.  by the far the best non-imperial-stout-stouts ive ever had. best when its a bit warm

Exceptional for a regular sweet stout.  Opaque black with a thin tan head.  Aroma of coffee, caramel, roaste dmalt, some vanilla.  Palate is very thick and silky.  Flavor is sweet, but not cloying.  Lots of roast and bitter chocolate.  Some caramel malt, coffee, slight hops, and lots of residual (I think lactose) sugars.  Finishes nice and clean with a bit of lingering sweetness.

I really enjoyed this sweet stout.  I didnt quite get the molasses flavor, but did pick up on a rather apparent caramel flavor and aroma.  Dark chocolate also very apparent.  Poured a beautifully deep dark, almost black with surprisingly caramel brown head.  An excellent beer.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2006 So, I had this on tap.  It poured to a thick rocky brown head atop a dark black body.  The aroma is chocolate, vanilla, cream, rich roasted malts.  The palate is creamy, thick, and dry.  The flavor is hugely chocolate and roasted coffee malts.

Resampled on 1/7/06 from a bottle.  Still as good as ever.  Awesome.

color is black with thin layer of dense foamy head, umber in color.  aroma is roasted toasted chocolate malt, a little vanilla and tobacco too.  mouthfeel is very creamy, carbonation is lively.  flavor starts silky with smooth roasted malt, a little chocolatey, but goes to a more smokey and hoppy finish in the back of the palate.  dryish finish.  this is a great stout, someone trade me an expedition now!

Black, opaque with a dark, tan head.  Maple, molasses, rich, sweet, and tar-like intensity in the aromatics (some ash as well).  Flavor matches the aroma but a solid bitterness and hop flavor encourages drinkability.  Alcoholic heat and a plummy, earthiness make for a long finish.

Thanks CaptainCougar! This one pours pitch black with a solid tan head and nice lacing. The aroma can only beer compared with sniffing a carton of chocolate milk. This defines smooth. A velvety chocolate and mocha flavor. This is awesome! Bells makes the best stouts hands down!

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2008 Bottle.  Pours out like motor oil.  Very dark with brownish head that diminishes to about 1/4".  Taste is of dark chocolate and roasted malt.  Finish is creamy and slightly dry.  Lightly carbonated.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2009 Pitch tar black pour, with limited tan head. Sweet and salty aroma of almonds, burnt chocolate, and figs with sea salt. Super strong roasted coffee and chocolate, backed with earthy and fruity notes of pears and apricots. A little touch of grass in the background. Oats and caramel show on the back end. Palate is salty and a little oily, smoothing out on the way down, but leaving a dry and somewhat unsatisfying smack.

had this one right after sam adams cream stout and I must apoligize to sam for pitting him against such strong opponent,  nice and smooth with a nice strong chocolate mocha flavor.  slight bitterness to the finish, but mostly a strong nice roasted flavor with a fantastic full body

This pours out black with a brown head. Smells nice. Rich malty flavor, coffee aroma with coco in the back, hoppy start with a nice smooth finish. I had the expedition stout first so this is good but cant touch the expedition.

Pours out a pitch black with a slow forming head that works its way up to about an inch and a half of brown foam. As the head recedes down to a smaller on that lasts throughout rings of lace are left decorating the glass. Picture perfect looking brew here nice head good lace, what more could you want. Strong aroma with roasted coffee and dark chocolate coming out the most. I was able to smell this as I was pouring it. Taste is similar with a bitter coffee flavor up front and a slight earthy hoppiness as well. Slight bit of cream to the flavor before it ends in a lingering bitter coffee aftertaste. Mouthfeel is slick with a medium to full body. Great drinkability as this went down very easy and I would have had another if I had it.
Dark with tall light brown head.  Rich dark coffee.  Very creamy with excelent mouth feel.  Toasted with roasted chocolate flavor.  An excelent beer.

Pours black as any good stout would a very thick nice brown head laces the glass as you drink it.  Fantastic aroma of toasted malt and coffee.  Flavor is just like it smelled.  Very toasty coffee goodness abound in the flavor.  Some dark chocolate comes through and sweetens it up a touch.  The palate is very smooth and creamy for a stout and just bitter enough at the end to let you know it is a stout.  Better than a great cup of coffee very smokey and enjoyable.  Fantastic and drinkable stout.  Bells never disappoints!  This is not quite the expedition stout, but still a very good drink!
A flavorful toast and nice chocolate greets your nose at first, pouring reveals a  black stout easing into tan foam. A generous full body, lively drinking brew.

Bottle courtesy of csbosox: Black body that appears dark brown when held up to light, small, tight light brown head that fades to a small creamy ring.  Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, and coffee.  Full bodied, creamy, somewhat oily and sticky, medium lively carbonation.  Taste has a lot of roasted dark malt, some bitter bakers chocolate, light coffee, and caramelized sugar.  Finishes with some roasted bitter malt notes and just a hint of sweetness.  A great bottled stout.

Balck body medium brown head.   Roasty smell.  Bitter coffee coupled with creamy chocolate flavor.  Nice body with almost no waterness.  Slightly smoky and delcious.  NIce coffee finish.  This beer is good throughout.

This is almost like an Imperial Stout....in fact, I can hardly tell the difference.  Pours black as night with a tan head with lots of lacing.  

Taste is medium bodied with a roasty front end and chocolatey finish.  Very nice....but I swear its almost identical to the Expedition Stout.

bottle. maybe if i would have tried this before the Expedition Stout, i would be more impressed. Nice dark pour, tan head. well balanced of chocolate and coffee. above average stout, but not in my top 10
Honostly...not a real big fan of the stout beer.  However...i can certainly see how a stout drinker would enjoy this beer.  Very dark, creamy, strong tasting beer.
Bottle. Deep dark brown in color with a nice tan head.  Very roasty aroma. Coffee like.  Malty. Chocolate and caramel notes. Very creamy. Well balanced. Smooth tasting. Nice beer.

Black with a tan head and some lacing. Nice chocolate and roast nose with some coffee notes. Smooth and silky texture. Nice chocolate flavor that is very well balanced. Nice stout. Thanks for the bottle Josh!

Thanks to Springslicker for the bottle. Pours opaque black, small light brown head.  Caramely roasted malt aroma.  Syrupy sweet nose which dampens to a set of caramel flavors combined notes of coffee and unsweetened chocolate.  Slighty bitter finish interplayed with residual sweetness.  Mouthfeel is full and sticky, which has the effect of retaining the sweet character in the flavor profile even in the parts where it isnt overly emphasized.

Pours a pitch black color with a medium light brown head. Good, sweet aroma of roasted malt. Good flavor of chocolate and roasted malt with a bitter finish. Light to medium body, dry texture, soft carbonation. This is a very good stout although its not exceptional or special, its just plain good and enjoyable. Thanks to csbosox for sending this.
burnt aroma. pours pretty thick black.  flavor is robust, creamy but not too thick.,good.

Poured very very dark brown with a large tan head and nice lacing.  A good amount of floaties as well.  Roasted aroma of coffee and dark and milk chocolates.    Flavor also consisted of coffee and bittersweet chocolate with some caramel.  Light bitter finish.  Medium body.

UPDATED: APR 18, 2005 Almost black with a thin brown head. Aroma of chocolate, dark caramel, some leather, coffee. Big bodied and smooth with a slightly chalky and bitter finish.  Burnt flavors with coffee,  toffee and a bit of mint. Some smokeyness comes out as it warms. A  sweet stout though? Nice

12oz. bottle. Near black in color with a small tan head. Very faint roasted malt aroma. Flavor was much more intense than the aroma would lead you to believe. Lots of dark roasted malts, coffee and hops. Finish is nicely dry and bitter. Excellent.
Pours dark with dark brown head. Smells of dark, rich chocolate, hints of coffee. Taste is superb. Great mix of chocolate and coffee with morsels of caramel.

Very dark beer.  No light comes through this one when it gets held up.  It has a deep tan head which leaves fairly quickly.  Little aroma detected other than some light malt scent.  The taste however is incredibly roasted.  It is almost charred in character.  There is a subtle sweetness but mostly what I taste is a deep dark malt.  Friends noted that it reminded them of a dark coffee.  Very drinkable, heavy but smooth.  A great example of a good stout.

Pours an opaque black/brown with red hints.  The head was thin but chunky with an off brown color.  The aroma had plenty of toasted and burn malts, some ash and sharp hints, as well as some root aromas.  The body was very interesting in that it was creamy and fluffy as well as being lite and a bit watery, very odd combination.  The flavors were big on toasted malt, and smores came to mind a few times (gram cracker, charcoal, and coco hints).  Not a bad brew but nowhere near their expedition stout.

Great thick pour.  Smells are wafting at me from a foot away.  Aroma is heavy laden with molasses and oats.  Also smells of burnt rubber with some cinnamon.  This rating is somewhat of a tale of two temperatures.  The first 4 oz. or so, I had the beer at about 35 degrees.  It wasnt anything special at that temp, so I let it warm to about 50 degrees, and the difference was night and day Hence, I continue  Great, full body.  Caramel coffee edge, semi-sweet chocolate and toffee.  Hints at black licorice.  Theres a discernable dry bitterness left on the back 1/3 of the tongue.  Its slippery but dense, and prolongingly diffuses, making its presence known by peeling slowly off the palate.  Solid stout.  Not the second coming of Christ, but its good.

12 oz Bottle. Dark as night with a thick, creamy, tan head.  Roasty coffee/dark chocolate aroma with a hint of hops and maybe a hint of butterscotch. Flavor is big and roasty with plenty of hop bitterness. The bitterness from the roast and hops lingers in hte mouth. Very thick and chewy. Very smooth as well. One of the better stouts out there, although to me it is more of an export stout than a sweet stout.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: A good stout, but too strong for me.  Excellent aroma, smells like coffee and chocolate
a sweet smokey aroma.  dark black color with tan head.  complex flavor with roasty malts, coffee, dark chocolate.  nice sweet molasses hint as well.  a good stout.
Batch 6613: Burnt molasses really overpowers the aroma - as well as a liquid smoke aroma.  The body is roasty and smooth - with more smokey overtones and a dark chocolate base.  Good.
Wonderful.  Delicious.  Bells knows Stout.  This is highly recommended in conjunction with the Expedition stout.  One advantage is that its alcohol character is not at all overwhelming.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2005 Sweet aroma of chocolate/caramel and malt.  The tast agrees - VERY smooth.  My girlfriend even liked & she does not drink stouts.  Excellent mix of chocolate/cofee/caramel (with the caramel taking the lead) and nutty roasted malt.  I thought it was a little thin, but it drank just right.  Great finish with the best parts of the taste lingering. [$7.99/6pk]

aroma explodes with chocolate, malts and molasses also make an appearance.  the pour is jet black, with what i would consider alot of head for a stout beer...about a 1/4 inch of dark brown creamy topping.   alot of milk chocolate in the flavor, tailing off too som raosted malts and expresso flavors. nice thick rich creamy body, a totally full mouthfeel.  the first sip was a little bitter, but it smoothed out alot as the glass warmed a bit.  i dont know where i would stand on which bells offering is better (this or expedition) except in the line to get more of either one.

Powerful dark chocolate aroma. Slightly sweet, clean maltiness with abundant chocolate. Far more chocolate than most so called chocolate stouts. Much more milk chocolate than the dark aroma suggests. Glorious mouthfeel. Very well balanced, could use maybe at touch more hops.
Pours black, witha light brown head. Aromas of chocolate, coffee, and  smoked and/or roasted malt. Flavor is much like the aroma, and very nice. Another good one from Bells.

Draught at Mad Mex, North Hills. Nice chocolate and coffee bitter aroma. Light smokiness, and some milk sugar. Dark black clear with thin lacing tan head. Medium heavy watery body with medium carbonation. Starts with coffee bitter and chocolatey sweetness. Malt roastiness. Bitter burnt tangy malt throughout, with tangy medium bitter finish, chocolate. Nutty bitter finish, mild coffee. A nice stout.

Pours almost a jet black with a nice bit of foamy tan head.  Aroma is roasted chocolately coffee.  Flavor is nice and light, smooth, sweet and toffeish with a roasted nutty malty finish.  Overall, very very tasty beer.

In bottle.  Pours with a tan head, tight bubbles that last a while.  Black, totally opaque.  Nose is roasted malts, chocolate, coffee.  Very smooth palate.  Lots of stout character, chocolate, roasted malts, caramel, coffee.  Flavor dissipates suprisingly quickly.  Still a great stout.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2006 Bottle.  Pours a deep black body with a big light brown head.   Aroma is roasty and coffeeish.  Flavor is just like the aroma with a healthy dose of dark chocolate and choco-malts to boot.  Very rich flavor, smooth....almost velvety on the tongue.  Finish is lightly sweet with a nice bitter edge.  Much better than  I anticipated....another outstanding Bells ale.....no big surprise there.

Turbo kept on hound dogin me that I still had this in the frige. Well now I know why. Poured black with a chocolate head. The roasted flavor and roasted aroma just stands out and makes this a great beer. Havnt had mant stouts but if there all like this, i know now why everybody is rating these high.

12 oz bottle, compliments of hopscotch. A very nice stout with a rich creamy mocha head.  Has a nice chocolate, caramel, roasted nut smell.  Wierd, but another rater mentioned strawberry yogurt.  I would have never thought of that till I read it, but it really does.  Very unique.  Perfect balance with just the right bitterness. Pleasent aftertaste.  Id definately do this one again and again
Great initial chocolate smell.  Nice thick light brown head.  Fantastic chocolate and coffee finish

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2005 This stout is AWESOME!!
Poured black with a thick chocolate head and lacing that hangs in sheets.
Aroma of roast and chocolate, sweet and smooth!
Flavor is just great! roaty toasty, chocolate malt.
I am at a loss for words, I love this stout and will be having a few cases sent to me from Michigan...thank you god!

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2005 Duane, thank you! Poured black, black as night. Poured smooth like velvet With a HUGE brown Foamy, frothy head. As it settled, the lacing was left like the mountains and I could not wait. Aroma had plenty of caramel and roasted malts, chocolate and something I cant place. Oh, smooth, with roasted chocolate malty roasted caramel goodness. THIS IS STOUT BABY! Damn! Wish I had more. Finished dry and the mouth feel was full, like whipped cream. Duane, You ROCK! Thanx again. Yum! Get your paws on this. This was perfect!

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2005 Black pour with nice thick brown speckled head.  Very strong flavor going down of dark chocolate sweet malts, slight bitterness, some coffee/toffee sweetness as well.  Solid aftertaset, lasting.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2006 Damn fine stout.  Pours black with a medium brown head.  Coffee, chocolate, roasty aroma.  Full bodied but easily drinkable finish is relatively short and dry leaving a lingering coffee and molasses aftertaste.  My only complaint is that he aftertaste wore on me.

Quite sweet, very nice feel to it. Smooth as hell, very easy drinking for me, being a stout. Nice balance to this brew, it all comes together well. Cant wait to have again. Thanks to Duane for this one!

bottle. pitch black, mocha head. coffee, chocolate. silky smooth body. very rich complexity. tons of coffee, chocolate. very bitter throughout. This is a phenomenal stout, I should have picked up a few more bottles at Merchants when I had the opportunity but it was kinda tricky since I already had $100 worth of beer in my cart.

Thanks to Beerhandy for this!!  Pours a dark black with no light coming through.  Has a small frothy chocolate milk head.  Sweet chocolate and coffee aroma with some fruitiness.  Medium to thick smooth mouthfeel.  Sweet chocolate, coffee and a bitter roasty finish.  Tastes similar to the expedition without the kick in the tail.  great stout!
I agree w/weissguy that it smells like strawberry, but Id say frozen yogurt.  Taste is sweet sweet malts, darkened. Rich body with hint of white chocolate.  This is one of my new favorites.
it smells like strawberry Ice cream. and its black as night.  It tastes like chocolate chip cookies, its so heady

Black color with a creamy tan head.  Very attractive.  The aroma was a great first impression; very impressive.  Sweet milk chocolate filled my nose and made me say "wow".  The mouthfeel was smooth and the aftertaste faded slowly into chocolatey goodness.  Smooth and utterly delicious. Its reputation is well-earned.

Pours dark brown nearly opaque color with beautiful high lacy brown head that keeps going and going. Faint aroma, but explodes on presentation with a burst of chocolate, roasted coffee and burnt caramel. Long hoppy palate with bitter finish. High in carbonation, full of flavor, a lovely beer. Slightly sweet and robust flavor with bitter finish.

Dark as night with mocha colored head. Very rich rosated malt and toasted bread nose with hints of lactose. Rich creamy mouthfeel with light sweetness in the front with a drying finish. Chocolate, toast, charcoal, coffee bean, and more on the palate. Well made rich stout!

I had this beer on draft at a beer bar called Firkin in suburban Chicago, and I really enjoyed it.  However, I was disappointed by the bottle that I drink at home.  I loved the opaqueness of pure black and the chunky brown head, but other than the appearance, it fell short of what a Bells stout should be.  It lacked boldness of body and complexity of flavors.  It had a slight malty roastiness, but that was about it.  Maybe it was old and stale.  Certainly not a 99.

12oz - The first sweet stout I ever had (10 years ago) and still my favorite.  Smells like coffee, chocolate, & roasted malts.  Black with a small head and decent lacing.  Flavor is like it smells, very smooth and long lasting.  One sip stays with you for a while making for an enjoyable drink I would recommend to any stout or coffee drinker.

Opaque black brew with a tall mocha colored head.
Chocolate, coffee, and loads of roast malt in the aroma.
This starts out with a bitterness that lasts right through to the end. The Chocolate, coffee and a bit of sweetness make an appearance, but this one is dominated by the roast malt bitterness. I prefer a Porter over a Stout for the reason of a bit less roast malt bitterness, but for those who like a good Stout with those characteristics, this is a real winner.
bottle.  pours a dark, dark brown with a smallish light brown head.  interesting and flavorful.  a little bit sweet, alittle bit dry and a little bit bitter.  Exceptional!

Bottle.  Dark brown in color with nice brown head.  very good lacing.  Nice aroma of grain and malt.  Nice flavor of some chocolate and coffee but also a definite earthy taste.  nice balance.  i recommend it.

A remarkable stout. This stuff pours out so amazingly dark, youd think it was ink. It looks like a light-body espresso shot, except in this case, the head is light brown. I hold my glass up to a light bulb and still cant see through it. I notice dark malt aromas with some roasted as well. Definite smells of dark dark chocolate. Taste is smooth, and body pretty cloying. Im not noticing the coffee flavors as much, but more of the dark chocolate and dark roasted malts. The thick malty body with chocolate characteristics make this beer nice and rich. The lovely aromas and the somewhat intimidating appearance provide for an attractive beer and one impressive stout. Bravo Kalamazoo.

A little unbalanced.  Too much malt for my tastes, I prefer the expedition stout, another Bells offering.

This is what an ideal mug of coffee would taste like- you see, no bitterness, slightly sweet and roasted dark flavor.
Pours black with a nice dark brown head. Tastes and smells like a good mocha.Full bodied and leaves a nice bitter afternote. Great for rich deserts!

Opaque black with an extremely thick carmel colored head...beautiful.  Rich chocolate aroma along with coffee and amaretto.  Incredibly rich and creamy chocolate flavors accompanied by the wonderful coffee and bitter chocolate.  Very thick and chewy, this could be a meal in itself...near perfect.

Dense opaque appearance, thick dark head formation. Rich fruity (berries and stone fruits) aroma strong coffee roast and chocolate. Sweet creamy dark chocolate flavor, espresso with cassis and cherry providing some balance. Dry strong roasty finish. Very similar to their Special Double Cream that I had last night, should have done a side by side.
Pours black with a small tan head. Aroma is sweet and resembles graham crackers. Big milky, coffee taste. Coffee aftertaste. Low hop character. Great creamy stout.
Pitch black body with a brown head with hints of red.  Lots of roasty and coffee flavors and aromas.  Full-bodied and easy-drinking.  Bittersweet chocolate finish.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2004 Thanks to Mr. Facto for this beer.

Pours onyx black with a brown head that left a film on the beer.  This may be the blackest stout Ive seen thus far.  Aroma is fainter than I expected, but is a quite agreeable roasted coffee.  Flavor is predominately bittersweet chocolate with some coffee, with a subtle sweetness and a bitter roasted character to the finish.  The palate is extremely silky and thick, like wrapping the entirety of the mouth in a down comforter.  My only complaints are that the aroma and taste, though complex and quite balanced, are not as pronounced as I would like.  The real treat to this beer is the mouthfeel.  I think I may have a soft spot for the Java Stout more, but I can certainly appreciate the artistry that goes into this beer.  Overall Im becoming more and more impressed by Bells stouts, and I never cease to be amazed at how heavy they sit in the stomach.

This is a full-bodied stout with plenty of roast flavor as well as hints of molasses and chocolate. Ridiculous amounts of black and caramel malts make this stout smooth, creamy, and utterly opaque. 
(I know i just copied and pasted it, but I am rating over 100 beers today and am running out of things to say about them all!!!!!)

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2007 A thick dark pour promising almost sinnful pleasures, mocha chocolate roasted malt aroma, rich creamy mocha chocolate taste, smooth mouthfeel, nicely sweet aftertaste. It is my favorite stout,

12 oz bottle.  Tasted at 53 degrees. The color is black, ink black. Nice light brown head that subsides after a minute or two, but leaves a nice lacing.  Aroma is bittersweet choclate/cofee with a bit of tart berry/fruit hiding uder the surface. The taste  is multilayered, with the roast/coffee/woodsy flavor going to a sweetish/citrus rind flavor then a long lasting sweetish/roast finish.  There seems to be alot going on.
