Its a good thing that I have to beg borrow and steal these beers, as my total would be much less as why sample the rest, when you can have the best. #10 of their beers sampled, not a loser in the bunch. Trust the olde spavined Gusler, when I tell you this line of beers is phenomenal. Ranks a well deserved #66 on my current 1000 beer master list.

This beer pours a wonderful Mississippi River brown head. Its big and full without being overbearing and sloppy. I guess thats translates into being well balanced. When it warms there is a sweet roasted Turkish coffee flavor. In the spirit of the World Series...its a solid hard line drive in the gap double. Ill take it anytime but its not a homerun.

This beer poured perfectly into my glass, producing and excellent head. The nose consists of roasted barley and cocoa powder. Nice full body. Within my first, few sips I get a lot of roasted malt bitterness coupled with strong coffee. As the beer warms, I get more finesse from the beer, which means it becomes a bit sweeter and shows more of its chocolate side. The hop profile is pleasantly bitter, but its not a distracter to the malt show that makes this stout. The stout is high enough in gravity to make it feel like you are drinking a bigger beer, but low enough to make it semi quaffable.

Excellent stout.  Attractive opaque pour with a burnt, roasty aroma.  Great smoky flavor throughout, with a smooth, malty consistency.  Some coffee tones, but the smoky/burnt character from beginning to end is what did it for me.
The stout itself is amazing, so roasty that I could drink it for breakfast and be fooled into a placebo effect of a coffee caffeine rush!

Beautiful pour. Deep black with dark tan head that looks almost sandy, but feels so creamy. Its a roll call of dark malt flavors and aromas: caramel and chocolate being dominate, but with an undercurrent and finish of burnt bitterness. Low to no coffee, though. Incredible stout.

perfectly opaque when held up to the light, aroma was that of a starbucks iced mocha cappucino..quite chocolate and a roasted nose. malty chocolaty coffee flavors with wonderful bitterness lingering forever.

tremendous stout.
nearly black but with a  coppery glow when held up to a light. small but thick head,
 aromas of chocolate, coffee and deep roasted malt, the taste is also rich with coffee and bitter chocolate prevaling over a toasted grain character.
velvety mouthfeel , gives the feel of a cask-conditioned beer.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2004 bottle-age unknown
poured with no head whatsoever-burnt aroma-coffee appearance.  Palate was robust with the signature bells tingle on the toungue.  pretty good

ReRate-2003 bottle-I boosted the ratings on this one.  I didn't take notes of the one bottle i had, but i remember the mouth feel that of roasted marshmellows with chocolate over them.  very nice and unique!
Very large, dark brown head.  Great roasted flavour with a nice mix of chocolate and malt.
This one is wonderful.  The aroma was not the best, but the taste, oh the taste.  Coffee and chocolate roasted to high heaven.  And its smooth and creamy.  Very nice, indeed.

first,the label deserves a rating (or berating rather) : the etch-a-sketch wretch depicted  is highly unsavory with his dishelveled hair and grimmacing countenance--looks like they packed him into a beer keg and rolled him down a rocky hillside. but be not distracted by inept graphics, the greatness dwells within: this stout pours like melted bittersweet chocolate, a tahini-brown head jealously guards the topside, apparently sealing in some of the aroma, because this one actually tastes more profoundly wonderful than a comparatively modest nose suggests (okay, i had a cigar i confess). but the flavor is like sex in an airliner: fucking close to heaven. great body of godiva, italian roast and merlot, gently sweet, loving tug of bitterness. next time ill save the cigar for the after glow.
A good stout indeed.  Intense roasted flavours.  If there is one thing that Larry knows how to make it is stouts.
Tastes much like a dark roasted coffee.  Dark, black color with a tan head.  Not as bold as the Expedition stout, but still very good.  Lots of flavor and easy to drink.
very good stout. huge chocolate and coffee flavors.
Very impressed with this brew as my first sampled from the Bells family of beverages.  Not as thick as I had initially expected, but maintained a nice heas throughout the pint.

A very good stout.  I prefer this one over the expedition stout (which is much harder to find and twice the price).  This stout is smooth, but still nice and rich.  Its a bit oily, pours with a huge head, and is certainly enjoyed by me.
Nice and full flavor with hints of sweetness and bitterness that fill out the edges of this drink.

Black pour with a thin tan head. Burnt coffee aroma with a very small touch of malt sweetness. Excellent palate, creamy and full. This is my first Bells stout and Im very impressed.Toasted malt flavors with chocolate/coffee at the front and a little bitterness bringing up the rear. Excellent beer.

Bottled.  Dark, opaque pour, medium creamy dark head.  Beautiful big nose of milk chocolate, vanilla and a touch of coffee.  Flavor, wow, close to Mackeson overall (my favorite sweet stout) but more balanced and bitter.  Still mostly sweet and creamy, with a dynamight mouthfeel and strong finish, and in between velvet and wine and bittersweet chocolate.  Absolutely phenomenal; hard to imagine the Expedition being any better.
Black.  Roast and faint fruity notes in the nose.  Roasty and finishes nicely bitter and smooth.  Great stout.

Wow.Slow rising huge, chocolate,pillowy,head.Aromas of espresso beans,roasted grain.Creamy sweet,body has intensified flavors of the aromas.Could almost satisfy and Imperial craving.As it warms dark chocolate flavors arise with a fruitier finish.Dry,fruity finish.Good stout and buy.One of the best sweet stouts in america.
Big mocha head atop black body.  Aroma is roasty and coffee, with these qualities even more pronounced in the flavor.  Also notes of dark chocolate.  Very rich flavor, almost velvety on the tongue.

From September until March there is always a 6 pack of this beer in my fridge.  From the beginning, this beer doesnt try to hide itself ... it sports a dark brown foamy head.  The aroma is fantastic and rich and smells like bakers chocolate.  The flavor is complex but there are plenty of hints of coffee, chocolate and the tiniest almost imperceptible hint of anise.  To truly enjoy this beer, start cold and then drink over about an 1 hour period.  Notice the changing flavors as you work your way through the glass.  If I were to die a pharaoh, I would want a clay pot of this brew left for me as a daily offering.

Black in color; head was sticky all over the glass; burnt, burnt malt and coffee beans in the nose. The perfect everyday stout- screw guinness, what a joke. This beer sits with you and demands little. Creamy coffee with hints at mocha. Wonderful to just linger over and contemplate your next world changing ideaa.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2004 RERATE:  More acidic and burning than I remember. Flavors still there just more burning.  7/16/02 Thick very dark brown with a sparkling dark tan, small bubbled head. Aroma starts with roasted coffee and barley and as it warms caramel and alcohol.  Dark chocolate, sweet roasted malt and coffee dominate the flavors.  Carbonation is a bit biting on the tongue.  A very bitter finish, but the bitterness disipates quickly to a nice roasted/toasted lingering.  A Mackesons with a bit more kick.

This pours so thick and black that I almost went for the scissors.  You can not see light through this beer.  It has a rocky tan head and leaves great lace on the glass.  The nose is strong with burnt coffee.  The first sips coat the mouth with roast coffee and chocalate malt tastes.  As it warms up the burnt toast flavors balance against a caramel sweetness and buttery smoothness.  This has a real big beer feel to it and is very well balanced for its size.  A very nice stout.  I wish I had another.  Maybe in the back of the fridge...
Great taste -- strong taste of bitter chocolate, bitter coffee and dark malt -- a little thin, perhaps, but thats OK. The aroma puts me off, though, which keeps this from being a truly great stout.

Deep opaque mahogony or cherrywood color with a medium tan head that totally went away.  Aroma is roasted malt and bitter chocolate.  Initial taste is also bitter chocolate and roasted malt.  As it warms, it settles into a creamy milk chocolate flavor enveloping coffee and burnt flavors.  Just a hint of bitterness in the end.  Nice and full.  A great brew.  Thanks to proc.
Very good stuff!  Rich coffee/chocolate taste.  Bells does a great job!

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2003 Pours thick dark black color, nice lasting tan head, leaves a perfect lace, aroma of chocolate, coffee and nutmeg? Thick and creamy full mouthfeel, coffee and sweet chocolate taste, this may be my favorite stout, its hard to stop at just one, the best stout IMHO.

Pours with big, tightly carbonated dark brown head. Black in color - motor oil lie. Medium strength nose of roasted coffee, dark chocolate and slight dry hoppy notes. Crisp and chewy palate. Roasted flavors of coffee, bittersweet chocolate and just a touch of yeast acidity on the front end. Long and big finish of bitter coffee. Nice to see a big stout not over-hopped!! Very flavorful stout of solid quality.

Strong and rich.  not quite as smooth and sweet as their double cream stout.  this had  a much stronger coffee flavor.  medium to thin finish.  Bells darker brews are soo much better than their lighter ones. (my opinion)
A wonderful stout that smacks of coffee and chocolate.  This is truly the breakfast of champions.
another excellent stout from bells, dark almost black color, great roasted malt taste, with hints of chocolate. wonderful

This is an excellent stout, definitely a benchmark for stouts.  Aroma was a little off...sweet beef jerky almost?  I dont know what to say.  Typical stout characteristics but done very well. It had an excellent bittersweet finish.  yum!
Bottle. A fantastic stout.  A rich dark roasted flavor with strong bitter chocolate accents and a wonderfully velvet smooth feel and prolonged finish.
Larrys beers never come up short. This beer is bustin out! The only problem is getting a hold of it! Excellent.
Very black color, which was well appreciated.  Chocalate and oat nose, with strong roasted malt flavor, a hint of chocolate and coffee, and a nice bitter malt finish.  One of the better Bells beers.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2005 Nice slowly settling head on a jet black body.  Huge coffee/caramel aroma mixed with aromatic hops.  Burnt/chocolate taste that is slightly different with each sip.  Smooth mouthfeel.  A beer that needs much swirling and slow sipping for sure.

Struck me as more of a porter than a stout.  Strong coffee smell and flavor.  Handsome appearance and head.  The only problem was the acidity in the taste that I didnt much care for.  My first Bells beer and hopefully not my last.

This is a big beer, make no mistake.  It took me 3 bottles to figure the rating.  This brew pours a solid black with a creamy, mostly
lasting head the color of creamed coffee.  The lacing is good.   The complex nose changes
several times as the brew breathes (which I would highly recommend unless you prefer
your beer to smell like Band-Aids and medicine while you drink it).  When first poured
heavy malt dominates with notes of strong coffee.  Resin and flowers make up the hop
end, with soap, spice, anise, cola and alcohol bringing up the rear.  As the Band-Aid and
medicine smell dissipate, pleasant caramel remains.   The flavor improves GREATLY as the brew
warms.  If consumed cold the flavor walks a thin line between robust and harsh.  As it
softens, the rich complexity develops.  A sweet fruity/flowery spiciness is at the front with a long roasted bitter black coffee
finish.  The full body has soft carbonation and coats the tongue like cough syrup.  The
finish feels astringent and somewhat chalky.  Not for pussies.  The Expedition Stout must be INSANE.
tad strong.  Chocolate and coffee flavored malts do the trick here.
Another great beer from Bells.  Smells like coffee and chocolate.  A few of these will get you buzzed on a warm day.
This is definitely one of Bells best beers.  Outstanding chocolate, coffe flavors and good hop balance.  Sometimes the alcohol comes through a little strong, but somehow that doesnt seem to matter.
A top notch stout in anyones book. Re-rate:  Good roasted/chocolate flavor and nice hop bitterness but too damn carbonated for me.  Had to rate this one a little lower the 2nd time around.
A smooth well balanced stout.  Great smooth creamy feel.  Hops and malt all about.  Excellent.
A pleasure to be savored. Strong roasty taste- and a great, classic aroma.
Wonderfully thick and creamy stout with tasty roasted flavors of coffee and chocolate. One of Bells best.
Funny taste to this stout.  Cherry Stout was much better.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2006 Pours with traditional Bells creamy top. Estery aroma is fruity with abundant roast to match. Fluffy and airy on the palate. Opens with a metallic sweep of malt and beefy licorice notes. Hugely charred toward the end, with black cherries soon bringing balance to the overall intensity. Finishes with black coffee and deeply earthy roasted malts. Has become overly grainy and worty in the last year. Not nearly as good as I recall.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Excellent!  Robust flavor with a nice dry hopiness.  I dare say a 6.5 ABV may be an underestimate.

UPDATED: NOV 7, 2003 Shares with the Bell's double cream stout an intial tanginess, coupled with moderate carbonation despite the lack of head (hey, how do they do that?). Then after the initial flavor rush you get full blown roasted flavor. Creamy, nice, very nice.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: UPDATED: JUN 2, 2004 A rich, opaque stout with nice coffee aroma.  Indulgent flavors include hazelnuts, molasses, chocolate covered coffee beans and caramel malt.  The finish is dry and refreshing.  Very well balanced and always enjoyable.
A pretty tasty stout.  Roasted and coffee flavors are very apparent.  This is a full bodied brew with a very rich mouthfeel and smooth finish.  A very good stout.
Very dark. Very coffee-like aroma and a subtle chocolate flavor. Very good.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2004 Another whalloping beer from Kalamazoo. Lots of dark roast grain hull flavors, chocolate and small hints of acetic acid. Some light dough aromas. This is the most interesting Bells I;ve had. Amazing full velvet feel slips away fairly clean and light with a bit of acid on the tail. The burned roast adds to the bitter-side of the excellent balance. lots of hoppy bitter melding with the roast bitterness. very nicw.

The look on that guys face says it all about this stout. I really dislike alomost everything from bells and this is no exception. Overly strong with a bad taste. But I wont hold down the average just because I dont care for the bells taste

Bells makes better beers, but barely.  This one has really fascinating alternations of unsweetned chocolate and burnt molasses.  Be patient with it, as the more youre willing to relax and let the flavours open up, the more youll be rewarded with complexity.
Weird stuff. It was very thin for a stout, and had the oddest sesame oil flavor and consistency to it.
This is my favorite stout so far.  Great chocolate and coffee flavors.  This beer has a very complex taste that is very pleasurable.  Best on tap!
A great stout. Roasty after taste, quite bitter which i like. Bells does it again.

Full bodied, well roasted - a little bitter (which is fine). A good stout in a bottle.  Needs to breathe a little before drinking - always use a glass.  I found the second half of the glass to be better than the first.

Highly comparable to Rogues Shakespeare Stout.  Rich and smooth with chocolate and roasted overtones.  Amazingly integrated flavors, with a general sweet profile at first and a lingering bitterness.  Absolutely great stout.
Nice roasted chocolate flavor. Goes down a lot smoother than most stouts. Could have benefited from a little more head.
A nice roast/chocalate flavor. An easy drinking stout.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2003 Incredibly smooth mouthfeel and palate.  Low carbonation.  Deep, impenetrable black color and a good-sized creamy tan head.  Flavor is full of roasted malt, coffee, chocolate and generous quantities of hops.   Almost tastes and feels like a cask-conditioned ale.  Very nice.
UPDATED: MAR 31, 2005 The yardstick upon which all other stouts will be measured by.
Real good and real thick.  I think I recognize the guy on the label too.
Rich, full flavour.
So dark, so good.  I loved the roasted taste.  excellent
